abstract: The expedition of GARIBALDI excites throughout Europe an emotion which is becoming more intense every day. We have expressed our opinion upon this act of the celebrated partisan, and we still maintain all that we have said, It is an act contrary to the principle of the laws of nations, and to the real interests of Italy; and if there is in its audacity something which must strike and captivate the imagination, reason and conscience ought no less to reprove so great a violation of all international rights and duties.
lead_paragraph: The expedition of GARIBALDI excites throughout Europe an emotion which is becoming more intense every day. abstract: Mons. DE LAVE, who, following in the wake of BLONDIN at Niagara, achieved some notoriety by his feats at Rochester in crossing Genesee Falls on a tight rope, yesterday gave a similar exhibition at Paterson, N.J., which was witnessed by many thousand persons. The place selected for the "Grand Ascension" was below the Falls where the river passes through a gorge at least six hundred feet in width, and nearly two hundred feet deep. The rope, which was of manilia, and of the size of an ordinary hawser, was stretched across this chasm from near "The Cottage on the Cliff" to the top of "Morris' Mountain."

abstract: Application of Henry A. Mott. -- This was a motion to have the name of Stephen G. Marcan stricken from the roll of Attorneys, and was made before the General Term. abstract: J.A. Putnam vs. W.H. Morton et al., Trustees, &c. -- This is an action by the plaintiff as assignee of C.A. Hallenbeck, formerly one of the Trustees of School No. 2, in the town of Athens, Green County, to recover certain costs, charges and expenses against the district. Hallenbeck some time since brought an action in the Courts of that County against one Schoonmaker, a contractor for the building of a school-house in the District, for breach of contract.

abstract: REJECTION OF THE M'LANE TREATY.  The Senate to-day first rejected Mr. SIMMONS' amendment to the Mexican treaty, and then rejected the treaty, all the Republicans but Senator TRUMBULL voting against it. War is predicted with Mexico within six months.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Thursday, May 31.

abstract: On Tuesday last an Arctic Expedition, under the guidance of Mr. C.F. HALL, set sail from New-London, Conn. Intimations of this project have come to us from time to time, but the expedition of which Dr. HAYES is the head has so absorbed the attention of those interested in these matters that this announcement will doubtless take them by surprise, and excite curiosity know more of the adventurer who has so unexpectedly taken his departure for the mysterious regions of the North, and of the prospects which he has for achieving success.

abstract: The Senate of the United States once enjoyed the reputation of filling in the Government of this country the practical and conservative part which is theoretically performed by the House of Lords in the Parliament of England. It is a tradition still cherished in certain remote sections of the country that a Senator sits and speaks and acts for the permanent and national side of our politics, while a Representative, elected directly by the people, and for a brief term of two years, utters the current and changeful opinions of the moment. A good deal of new and strange, and not altogether pleasant light, has been thrown of late years upon the actual working of various departments of our model system; but we doubt whether, on the whole, any one branch of the Federal power has suffered so much in the general esteem of Americans, from its recent developments, as this particular body of the Senate. All our preconceived ideas of its dignity, its capacity, its value to the commonwealth, have of late been sadly shaken. The intellectual reputation of the Chamber has flagrantly fallen away. The nation no longer looks to it for those displays of sagacious patriotism and thoughtful statesmanship which made it a light in the land, when the permanent policy of the North, the South, the East and the West used to be uttered in clear and commanding accents from that floor by a CALHOUN and a WEBSTER, a MANGUM and a CLAY. Under the influences of the Administration, which at present controls a majority of the Senatorial voices, the Senate has gradually come to be regarded as a sort of Executive Council, the mouth-piece of the White House, recording the wishes and echoing the prejudices of the President. Here, for instance, within a few weeks, the whole country has been scandalized by the conversion of the Senate into a kind of passionate and vulgar caucus, in which one after another of the supposed leaders of the Democracy has aired his personal spite or his sectional indignation against one particular statesman of the Democratic Party. Of what possible importance is it to the people of the United States whether Mr. SLIDELL or Mr. GREEN, or Mr. BENJAMIN approves or disapproves of the political doctrines of Mr. DOUGLAS? These are matters to be settled by the parties interested in the proper assemblies of their own factions. To introduce them to the National Senate, to embody them in resolutions, to consume the time sacred to public business of no partisan character, in these contemptible squabbles, is such a dereliction from the lofty uses to which the Senatoria1 office was set apart by the founders of our institutions, as cannot fail to consign its abettors to general contempt.

abstract: Application of Elvina Boyd. -- This was the return to a writ of habeas corpus, obtained by the petitioner for the recovery of her infant son, Jacob Boyd, two and a half years old. The petitioner alleges that the child was taken from the residence of its parents by the father, Robert Boyd, and secreted somewhere in this City with one Maria Livingston, who the petitioner charges was the cause of the estrangement between herself and husband. The father refused to inform the mother where the child was. The parents are living together; but the petitioner charges that the father secreted the child for the purpose of causing the mother grief and anguish of mind; and that he was endeavoring to compel her to abandon him, and for that purpose had withheld from her suitable and proper food and attendance; but finding that such deprivation would not drive her away, he resorted to the taking of the child.

abstract: There was a large gathering of Republicans at Springfield, Conn., on Wednesday evening, to respond to the Chicago nominations, not less than 2,000 persons, including many from neighboring towns, being present. The principal speakers were Hon. GEORGE ASHMUN, President of the Chicago Convention, and ERASTUS HOPKINS.
lead_paragraph: There was a large gathering of Republicans at Springfield, Conn., on Wednesday evening, to respond to the Chicago nominations, not less than 2,000 persons, including many from neighboring towns, being present. The principal speakers were Hon. GEORGE ASHMUN, President of the Chicago Convention, and ERASTUS HOPKINS. On the former gentleman being introduced to the meeting, he was received with prolonged and continued bursts of applause. Silence being restored, he said that he had come to render an account of his stewardship. No one was more surprised than himself at his having been selected as their delegate to Chicago. So honored he had accepted the trust and went to consult for the good of their common country. However hopeful I might have been, he continued, I assure you I was not prepared for the scenes that awaited me; for although I have seen much of politics, and witnessed many public conventions, I am constrained to say that there never was a gathering like that at Chicago. It at least commands the respect of the people and the world. All were intelligent, educated, earnest, sincere men; all enlisted in one purpose, and that purpose to rescue our Government from the deep degradation into which it has fallen. And during all those days, I desire to give my testimony that in the Convention or out of it, before the assembling and after it, there was not one word of unbrotherly feeling. There was an earnest purpose to do a great work, and a determination to do it in the best manner; and in that spirit the Convention consulted and decided. And although some hearts were grieved, there was a burst of approbation and applause that gave an unmistaken verdict of the people in favor of our decision. Among the delegates, in the crowd, everywhere, whatever may have been the preferences or griefs, there was not a man left in Chicago who did not think we had nobly performed a great work.

abstract: REGIMENTAL PARADE -- PRESENTATION OF COLORS. -- Yesterday was the field day of the Hudson Brigade. At the hour appointed for forming, Col. D.S. GREGORY received an order from Brigadier Gen. HATFIELD countermanding the order for a regimental drill parade, in consequence of the threatening aspect of the weather. Notwithstanding, the Second Regiment proceeded to South Bergen and thence to the grounds selected for the parade, where they devoted the day to field movements. The Regiment consisted of six companies, as follows:

abstract: EXPERIMENTS WITH A LONDON FIRE ESCAPE. -- Last evening some initiatory and very successful experiments were made with a fire escape just brought here from London. The fire escape is the invention of a Mr. WEVILL, and has been for years in use in the English capital, where it forms, in fact, a part of the fire apparatus. The experiments took place in East Thirteenth-street, under the direction of Mr. A.J. GARVEY, foreman of Hook and Ladder Company No. 12. Mr. DECKER, Chief Engineer, several assistant engineers, two or three Presidents of Insurance Companies and foremen of various fire companies were present. In a state of repose the apparatus has much the appearance of a Hook and Ladder apparatus, excepting that the wheels are at one end instead of in the centre. On wheeling it into the street for use, the main body, or ladder part, is placed in a vertical position, the height of the present apparatus being thirty-five feet. If introduced in this City, however, an additional set of wheels will have to be added to prevent its coming in contact with the telegraph wires. The ladder part is got up on the extension table principle, being capable of elongation to any extent. Underneath the ladder is attached a canvas bag with a wire gauze covering, the latter serving to protect the canvas from taking fire. Through the canvas invalids and children are slid to the pavement. At the end are two small wheels to facilitate adjusting the ladder. By ropes and iron braces the machine is in a moment brought into play. The weight of the present machine is 950 pounds, and its cost about $1,000. The first experiment was made upon the Thirteenth-street Medical College. The apparatus was adjusted in its place in less than a minute. Men leaped out of the upper-story windows, and came down the ladder lengthened to 64 feet with perfect ease and safety. Sundry boys were slid down the canvas, and came securely and joyously bouncing upon the pavement. Similar experiments, with like satisfactory results, were made upon different dwellings in the neighborhood. Further experiments will be made in a few days in the City Hall Park.

abstract: Catharine N. Forrest Vs. Edwin Forrest. This was an application, on the part of defendant, for leave to file un undertaking on appeal, giving a number of sureties who shall justify in an aggregate amount equal to that required by law, instead of being obliged to find two sureties who will justify for the whole sum some $37,000. Defendant also asked to be relieved from filing security for future payments of alimony.
lead_paragraph: Catharine N. Forrest Vs. Edwin Forrest. -- This was an application, on the part of defendant, for leave to file un undertaking on appeal, giving a number of sureties who shall justify in an aggregate amount equal to that required by law, instead of being obliged to find two sureties who will justify for the whole sum -- some $37,000. Defendant also asked to be relieved from filing security for future payments of alimony.

abstract: -- It appears that the unsophisticated strangers from Niphon have allowed themselves to be swindled by the very institutions of whose existence we affectionately advised them. Little TOMMY, the wag of the Embassy, and the especial pet of Washington ladies, has been inveigled into a mock-auction shop, where some Peter Funk, not having the fear of the Mikado before his eyes, sold him a pinchbeck watch for $120, the intrinsic value of which might be expressed by a single numeral. It seems a little singular that of all our loose-trowsered guests, this TOMMY should have allowed himself to be victimized. He was the astute Pagan who first mistrusted that the amplitude of the dresses worn by our ladies was not based upon necessity, and demonstrated this fact by actual experiment, collapsing the hoops of a Washington belle with his irreverent Pagan hands, greatly to the discomfiture of the wearer. Had TOMMY displayed half of this wariness in his dealings with the Peter Funks, he would not have been made the victim of misplaced confidence. This occurrence at this particular moment is doubly to be regretted. It was rumored that TOMMY had formed an attachment for one of the chambermaids at Willard's, and a matrimonial alliance would certainly have been no unimportant strand in the friendly ligatures by which we are endeavoring to bind our country to Japan. Now, however, all hope of this happy consummation must vanish -- American watches and American women will be viewed with like distrust. And again, our Government had just concluded an arrangement with the Embassy for recoining their money. The unwieldy, shingle-shaped coins with which their trunks are lumbered, were to pass through the Philadelphia Mint, and emerge in the more symmetrical shape of eaglets and three-cent pieces. But now this arrangement is undoubtedly knocked in the head. It is not at all likely that the Niphonese will trust their money in the hands even of the "American Tycoon." When our officials call upon the Japanese for their "cash" they will receive nothing but polite bows. It is not at all improbable that TOMMY will be appointed spokesman of the Embassy, in which case he will put his thumb to his nose, and say "No you don't," for he has already picked up many slang phrases. And in refusing to intrust the native coin in the hands of a Democratic Administration, TOMMY will display sufficient shrewdness to atone for his late unfortunate fatuity.

abstract: Enoch Hidden vs. The Steamship Ocean Bird.  This was an action for supplies, the question being one simply as to the jurisdiction of the Court. The ship was a domestic vessel, her owner residing here. The supplies were proper and necessary for a foreign voyage, on which she was destined, but there was no necessity for a bottomry upon her at the time. The libel was filed Sept. 20, 1855.

lead_paragraph: ITEMS. -- A man was arrested yesterday for attempting to pass counterfeit half-dollars....Several parties were fined in the Police Courts, on complaint of the Sanitary Police, for keeping pigs in their dwellings....The Rocky Mountain and Ashland Clubs propose to unite and form an organization.... The Republican wigwam recently erected at Greenpoint (Seventeenth Ward) will be dedicated this evening with appropriate exercises.... During the last two months the receipts of the Hack Inspectors for licenses has reached the unprecedented sum of $2,760 25.... House No. 53 South Sixth-street, (E.D.,) was robbed on Wednesday of $17, and jewelry valued at $75 more.... The Directors of the Mercantile Library Association have made arrangements to provide row-boats for the use of members the present season.

abstract: The rapidity with which HICKS has been tried and convicted in the United States Court, furnishes an instructive contrast to the dilatoriness of criminal proceedings in those of the State. If this man had been brought before the Court of Sessions, he would have had at least three trials before being finally convicted, and the proceedings between his capture and final sentence would have lasted from a year and a half to two years, and have cost the State about twenty thousand dollars. The clearness of the proof against him, and the complete absence of any testimony for the defence, would not have hastened matters in the least. In the State Courts the usual course of the prisoner's counsel is to object to every question put to every witness, and to except to every one of the Judge's rulings against him. A ponderous bill of exceptions is thus made up, and, owing to the confused state of our criminal law, the number and intricacy and disorder of the statutes fixing the jurisdiction of the Courts -- actually leading, amongst other absurdities, to doubts as to where a prisoner, who has been capitally convicted, should receive sentence -- the contradictory nature of the reported decisions, due to the frequent changes in the Judiciary, both in the Supreme Court and Court of Appeals -- the chances are twenty to one that amongst them will be found one of sufficient moment to obtain a new trial. This process may be repeated almost ad libitum, and it has become so common that the public has got into the way of considering a criminal, who does not get more than two trials, hardly dealt with.
lead_paragraph: The rapidity with which HICKS has been tried and convicted in the United States Court, furnishes an instructive contrast to the dilatoriness of criminal proceedings in those of the State. abstract: The Weeping philosopher of the Tribune refuses to be comforted. He is obstinately and incurably unhappy. His mood is that of the Frenchman who declared that he "would drown  nobody should help him." GREELEY'S grief, however, is as fantastic as it is profound. It springs from a hallucination, which has already lasted six or seven years, and which bids fair to attend him to his grave.
lead_paragraph: The Weeping philosopher of the Tribune refuses to be comforted. He is obstinately and incurably unhappy. His mood is that of the Frenchman who declared that he "would drown -- nobody should help him." GREELEY'S grief, however, is as fantastic as it is profound. It springs from a hallucination, which has already lasted six or seven years, and which bids fair to attend him to his grave. He nurses it, as women nurse pet sorrows; -- and derives a sad but solid satisfaction from seeing it thrive and grow under his affectionate care. There are many men who go through life under the conviction that somebody is trying to poison them -- that there is a secret conspiracy dogging their footsteps -- that Providence himself is against them, and that they are doomed to eternal perdition. As a general thing, such people find their proper place inside the walls of an asylum; but now and then, their delusion proving wholly innocent, they are left at large to vent their woes upon their personal friends, or sometimes upon the public, through the columns of tolerant newspapers. Nothing offends them like an attempt to dispel the illusion which so pleasantly torments them; and any disavowal on the part of suspected parties, of the diabolical designs laid to their charge, is regarded as only an immense aggravation of the imputed offence.
headline: {'main': 'A Rooted Sorrow.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Rooted Sorrow.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Presidential campaign will not be fairly opened until the Democratic Party marshals its forces in fully the field. The canvass awaits the proceedings at Richmond and Baltimore. Until the Democratic candidates have been named, nothing can be done. The question of commanding interest in political circles, therefore, is what will the Democrats do?
lead_paragraph: The Presidential campaign will not be fairly opened until the Democratic Party marshals its forces in fully the field. The canvass awaits the proceedings at Richmond and Baltimore. Until the Democratic candidates have been named, nothing can be done. The question of commanding interest in political circles, therefore, is what will the Democrats do?

abstract: the City will be saved, and the thousands of employes be made happy in the receipt of their salaries. The Mayor consented to sign all the warrants necessary  to the payment of revenue bonds and and interests--all salaries of the Board of Education, Police and employes generally, erasing, however, from the warrants ...
lead_paragraph: An arrangement was yesterday perfected between the Mayor and Comptroller, by which the credit of the City will be saved, and the thousands of employes be made happy in the receipt of their salaries. The Mayor consented to sign all the warrants necessary to the payment of revenue bonds and and interests -- all salaries of the Board of Education, Police and employes generally, erasing, however, from the warrants which are headed "to the City Chamberlain, at the Shoe and Leather Bank," the name of the Bank. As Mr. Stout has the largest amount of funds on hand, he will probably receive the greatest number of calls, but Mr. Platt will also pay warrants similarly addressed, as a considerable amount has been deposited with him.

abstract: -We learn that a duel was fought yesterday, at Screven's Ferry, between Commodore E.W. MOORE, formerly of the Texan Navy, and Mr. CHARLES A. LAMAR, of this city. Com. MOORE is a witness on the part of the Government in the trial of J. EGBERT FARNHAM, for piracy, and it is understood that the difficulty arose from some strictures of Mr. LAMAR on his testimony given in a few days ago. The challenge was peremptory and the parties met on the ground with their respective friends, at 8 o'clock the forenoon. Shots were exchanged with pistols without effect, when JOHN OWERS. Esq., second of Mr. LAMAR, approached HAMILTON COUPER, Esq, the second of Com. MOORE, and stated that in behalf of his friend, he felt it his duty now to say that the offense was given under excitement and misapprehension, and that Mr. LAMAR regretted and withdrew the language that had given rise to the meeting. The retraction was accepted as satisfactory; whereupon the parties exchanged friendly salutations and returned to the city. -- Savannah Republican, 25th,
lead_paragraph: -We learn that a duel was fought yesterday, at Screven's Ferry, between Commodore E.W. MOORE, formerly of the Texan Navy, and Mr. CHARLES A. LAMAR, of this city. Com. abstract: Those who feel an interest in the subject of ministerial education will be glad to see, in paragraphic form, a statement of the action taken on this subject by the New School Presbyterian General Assembly. The question occupied a large share of the time of this body.
lead_paragraph: Those who feel an interest in the subject of ministerial education will be glad to see, in paragraphic form, a statement of the action taken on this subject by the New School Presbyterian General Assembly. The question occupied a large share of the time of this body. The annual report was made by the Secretary, Rev. J.A. MILLS, showing what had been done during the year, and urging the necessity of a readjustment of the existing plan, in order to give greater harmony and efficiency to its working. This report was committed to a special Committee, consisting of Profs. ALLEN and HUNTINGTON, and Revs. J.M. SHERWOOD and G. BUTLER, who subsequently reported a series of resolutions, recommending various changes, not essential to the plan, but deemed necessary to ad[???]pt it to the existing state of things and insure its success. This report was earnestly and thoroughly discussed for several days, Drs. Brainard, Allen, Walter Clarke, Mills and Huntington, and Rev. Messrs. Dowling, Sherwood and Seely being the leading speakers. It was finally resolved to recommit the whole subject to a special Committee to adjust, if possible, existing difficulties, and report to the next Assembly. Just before the adjournment of the Assembly this vote was reconsidered, and a part of the report of the special Committee adopted, together with a resolution urging the Churches in the meanwhile to contribute to sustain the Assembly's Committee's operations

abstract: For the possession of this letter we are indebted to a mistake which occurred at the Washington Postoffice. In making up the foreign mails, this letter, by an inadvertence of the distributor, was sent to Virginia instead of to Japan. As there was something very mysterious about the exterior of the document, it was forwarded by the Richmond Postmaster to Gov. WISE. Gov. WISE could not read tire letter
lead_paragraph: For the possession of this letter we are indebted to a mistake which occurred at the Washington Postoffice. In making up the foreign mails, this letter, by an inadvertence of the distributor, was sent to Virginia instead of to Japan. As there was something very mysterious about the exterior of the document, it was forwarded by the Richmond Postmaster to Gov. WISE. Gov. WISE could not read tire letter but with that astuteness for which he is so justly celebrated, he instantly divined that anything beyond his comprehension must be well worth knowing and of importance to the State. A special session of the Legislature was immediately ordered, and this document was laid before the body. The Speaker of the Assembly, who had lately been carrying on a correspondence with the Tribune as to the best and speediest way of dissolving the Union, after a careful examination of the handwriting, declared it to be that of HOBACE GREELEY. Gov. WISH at once surmised that there was an Ethiopian in the wood-pile, and that this letter had something to do with another invasion of that State which he has sworn to protect, and will die to defend. But as no one was able to decipher the cabalistic characters, the document was forwarded to the foreman of the TIMES establishment; it being well known throughout the country that this gentleman, from a long experience in the Tribune office, can read GREELEY's manuscript quite fluently. Our foreman, however, after a careful examination of the writing, decided that it was too bad even for GREELEY, or that, if emanating from him, it could only have been written during the excitement of the Chicago Convention. From a casual word here and there, he rather inferred that the latter was the case, and that the mysterious document contained a detail of the way in which he defeated SEWARD. But PERRY, who happened just then to come into the composing-rooms to sell a box of his Japan blacking, instantly set the matter at rest by declaring that it was simply a letter from Prince MOORAGARE to his cousin, the armor-bearer, and to ease the anxiety of Gov. WISH and the Virginia Legislature, he translated the contents, which translation we publish for the edification of our readers.

abstract: -Among the mail routes restored by the famous proviso adopted by the House of Representatives a few days since, says the Washington Constitution, was that from Kansas to Stockton, in California. For this service the Post-office Department paid at the rate of eighty thousand dollars per annum. For the nine months that it was in operation the returns showed that there were transported in this mail between Kansas and Stockton BUT THREE LETTERS AND TWENTY-SIX NEWSPAPERS! The service was useless, as it was extravagant, and was discontinued by the Postmaster General. The House has now ordered it to be restored, although there are four other routes, maintained at vast cost, connecting the valley of the Mississippi with the Pacific, and although over 825 miles of this route a mail is now carried under a preexisting contract. Thus the depressed revenues of the Department are to be made to pay $80,000 for the carriage of three letters and twenty-six newspapers during the ensuing year!

abstract: The Harper's Ferry investigation is said to have come to an ignoble close. There are no more witnesses ready, and it is said the Committee do not intend to issue any fresh summonses. It is even doubtful if they will make a report, as it is confessed on all hands that not one iota of proof has been adduced, ...
lead_paragraph: The Harper's Ferry investigation is said to have come to an ignoble close. There are no more witnesses ready, and it is said the Committee do not intend to issue any fresh summonses. It is even doubtful if they will make a report, as it is confessed on all hands that not one iota of proof has been adduced, or can be adduced, to show the complicity of any Northerners in the plot, beyond those already known. Considering the awful hints and surmises which were thrown out when the inquiry was commenced, and the dreadful nature of the revelations in which it was expected to result, it must be confessed that it would be hard to conceive of a lamer or more impotent conclusion than that to which the whole affair has come. Senator MASON, who has had special charge of the investigation from the commencement, has our sincerest sympathy. His zeal and industry deserved very much more startling discoveries than any that have so far come to light. The conflict between the Deputy Sergeant-at Arms and Mr. SANBORN and Miss SANBORN and the ladies at Concord, was sufficiently desperate to be the harbinger of awful disclosures, and that nothing more should have come of it is almost distressing.

abstract: The private life of THEODORE PARKER was a study, no less entertaining and instructive than his public career. A man of profound learning, unfailing geniality and warm affections, he added to the charms of a brilliant conversationist the stronger attraction of a large human sympathy. Troops of friends surrounded him. He never denied them access.
lead_paragraph: The private life of THEODORE PARKER was a study, no less entertaining and instructive than his public career. A man of profound learning, unfailing geniality and warm affections, he added to the charms of a brilliant conversationist the stronger attraction of a large human sympathy. Troops of friends surrounded him. He never denied them access. His house was public property; his ample stores of literary wealth were at the service of all comers; his table had always a vacant place for the transient guest. He loved the companionship of men, and luxuriated in the study of nature; found pleasure in a tiny leaf and the essence of poetry in the perfume of a flower. When he preached, a bouquet lay beside him in the Music Hall; when he retired to his study, the cackling of fowls beneath his window made music in his ear; when persons intruded upon his privacy, he subjected them to a chemical process of intellectual distillation, and drew from them the good that was in their natures.

lead_paragraph: SALE AT TARRYTOWN OF THE COUNTRY SKAT OF THE LATE JOHN G. BOKER. -- The country seat of the late JOHN G. BOKER -- prominently known to the public by his ownership of the Art Union Gallery, and disowning his daughter MARY ANN, who married JOHN DEAN' his coachman -- situated a short distance above Tarrytown, on the Hudson River, was yesterday sold at auction, From Commodore PERRY, who formerly resided there, Mr. BOKER purchased the place. It comprises 94 acres of land, well wooded and diversified with meadows, lawns, gardens and fishing ponds. The mansion is built of stone, in the gothic style, with tower, porticoes, and bay windows. The Hudson River Railroad cars were loaded with leading Metropolitan merchants and capitalists, who attended the sale, the former anxious to secure a splendid rural residence for their families, and the latter moved thither by the spirit of speculation. A good number of metropolitan Mrs. Toodles were likewise on the ground, the seductive fascinations of a possible good bargain drawing them as surely there as the needle is attracted to the magnet. The magnet in their case was the cataloguing for sale of the entire household furniture, from the carpets, statuettes and carved rosewood sofas of the parlor to the straw mattress in the "coachman's room." The house and land were sold first, Mr. HENRY H. LEEDS being the auctioneer. The bidding was spirited, jumping at first several thousand dollars a bid, and gradually lessening, till the two were knocked down for $91,000. For the furniture there prevailed strong competition, many articles selling for twice their value. Altogether the sale resulted much better than was anticipated, and, with the jokes of Mr. LEEDS and a collation given to purchasers, afforded a pleasant visit to the hosts who went there.

abstract: The contest for the champion flag of the Yale College Navy transpired on the 26th, and the Thulia, manned by members of the Junior Class, proved victorious. She accomplished the three miles in twenty minutes and fifteen seconds. There seems to doubt whether the regatta of the boat clubs belonging to the different Colleges will take place this season. Howard and Yale are at variance as regards the time for the struggle.

abstract: Miss MARTHA WORK, of East Granby, Conn., committed suicide on the 27th, by taking prussic acid. She had been engaged for some time to Mr. WALTER LOOMIS, of Windsor, and was to have been married on the 29th. Sunday morning she ate two pieces of custard pie, and remarked to her sister afterwards that she might go to church, as it was her intention to stay home. She retired to her room, and her sister following her soon after found that she was suffering intensely. Every means were used to revive her, but without success. A post mortem examination revealed the fact that prussic acid was the poison which she had taken. It is not known what could have induced her to commit suicide.

abstract: The Key of the Gulf, of the 19th instant, gives some interesting particulars of the Africans lately landed at Key West. It says it is really a gratifying sight to observe the happy countenances and changed appearances of the cargoes of the Wildfire and Williams, brought into our port by the Mohawk and Wyandotte. At every disadvantage they are comfortably ...
lead_paragraph: The Key of the Gulf, of the 19th instant, gives some interesting particulars of the Africans lately landed at Key West. It says it is really a gratifying sight to observe the happy countenances and changed appearances of the cargoes of the Wildfire and Williams, brought into our port by the Mohawk and Wyandotte. At every disadvantage they are comfortably housed, and fed and clothed -- and the unfortunate sick, if not rescued from death, have at least the dark abyss bridged over by comforts and care, to which they have been strangers. Every means of enjoyment is afforded them; and it is gratifying to see so many happy faces in the pursuit of pleasure. Among the Wildfire's cargo there is a young mother, with a babe about six weeks old. She soon became an object of interest among visitors, and in a very short time both mother and child were suitably and comfortably clad. The babe soon sickened and died -- and as we saw the mother bending and weeping, and kissing its inanimate form -- wailing in plaintive song, and responded to by numerous mourners around the corpse -- we felt that love was beyond all conditions of pride or place, and that many might rejoice and be flattered in their self love, if they would be missed as much as the dead babe was by its mother. It was laid in a handsome coffin, and a procession of seventeen went with it to its last abode. Low chauntings and loud wails of grief would break forth, and when at last the spot was reached, they became as silent as the narrow house which would contain all the heart prized so much. The little coffin was placed in the grave, each threw in its handful of earth, and amid the deepest sorrow they returned in silence back.

abstract: The new directors of the Great Eastern have made the Portland people the victims of "a sell," almost as gigantic as the great ship herself. The last Board positively announced that when the ship came to this country, she would come to Portland, and the Portlanders accordingly expended over $100,000 in building a pier and making other preparations for her advent.
lead_paragraph: The new directors of the Great Eastern have made the Portland people the victims of "a sell," almost as gigantic as the great ship herself. The last Board positively announced that when the ship came to this country, she would come to Portland, and the Portlanders accordingly expended over $100,000 in building a pier and making other preparations for her advent. A new dynasty having ascended the throne, her destination has wisely, perhaps, but unfairly, been changed to New-York, and Portland is left to pocket the loss and stomach the affront as best she can.

abstract: Some months since William H. Little, a young man employed in the banking-house of Winslow, Lamier & Co., was apprehended for stealing $3,000, which he had been instructed to deposit in one of the City Banks. In the trial of the case at the Court of General Sessions, Little was used as a witness for the State, and his testimony resulted in the conviction of another party who had been his confederate in the robbery, while he, upon a promise of reformation and with good advice from the Court, was restored to liberty. On Thursday, however, he was again arrested by Detective Young, at the instance of his uncle, Mr. Miller, of Goshen, Orange County, who charges him with having broken open a trunk and stolen therefrom $100, with which he fled to this City. He is now in prison awaiting an examination, and it is probable that in this case he will pay the penalty for his dishonesty.

abstract: --Even the London Times will sometimes blunder egregiously. It permitted its Paris correspondent, not long since, to announce that the Emperor NAPOLEON had interested himself in a hot-air invention for the propulsion of gun-boats; whereby it was calculated a yearly saving in the cost of fuel for the French navy would be effected ...
lead_paragraph: -- Even the London Times will sometimes blunder egregiously. It permitted its Paris correspondent, not long since, to announce that the Emperor NAPOLEON had interested himself in a hot-air invention for the propulsion of gun-boats; whereby it was calculated a yearly saving in the cost of fuel for the French navy would be effected to the extent of about 80,000,000 of francs. The calculator of this marvelous result would beat the mathematical gentleman at Barnum's. Now, let us sift the calculation. Two hundred war-steamers, each of 3,000 tons burden, running night and day without interruption for 300 days in the year. furnished with steam-engines consuming three tons of coal every hour, would consume in that time 4,320,000 tons of coal. We dare say that many fortunes might be made by supplying such a customer with coal at $5 a ton -- say 19 francs -- and at this rate his annual coal bill would be only about 80,000,000 francs. But the Emperor NAPOLEON and all the naval powers of the earth together do not perform one-half the amount of work above indicated. How shockingly, then, poor NAPOLEON must be cheated by his coalmen, if, by merely employing more economical engines in his twenty ships-of-war in commission, he can save yearly eighty millions of francs! We do not wonder that he has ordered such a marvel of an engine into the Reine Hortense; and, if what the Times correspondent says should turn out to be true, the new invention will probably pave the way for some device that will abolish the use of coal altogether, when the Bears can have it their own way with the Reading Railroad.

abstract: The Republicans in the House of Representatives, headed by Mr. SHERMAN of Ohio, yesterday did themselves infinite credit, and the whole country a serious service, by forcing the House to take the first step towards suppressing that brutal licentiousness of speech which has grown so fast upon our Parliamentary ...
lead_paragraph: The Republicans in the House of Representatives, headed by Mr. SHERMAN of Ohio, yesterday did themselves infinite credit, and the whole country a serious service, by forcing the House to take the first step towards suppressing that brutal licentiousness of speech which has grown so fast upon our Parliamentary debates, which has led to the most disgraceful of the many disgraceful scenes we have of late years been compelled to record as incidents of a Congressional session, which has degraded the Representative office in the eyes of all respectable Americans, and damaged the general reputation of our institutions throughout the world.

abstract: In the United States Senate yesterday, Mr HALE procured the adoption of a resolution instructing the Naval Committee to inquire into the disposition made of the land purchased for a Naval Depot at Brunswick, Georgia. The bill amending the act relative to private land claims in California was taken up and passed.
lead_paragraph: In the United States Senate yesterday, Mr HALE procured the adoption of a resolution instructing the Naval Committee to inquire into the disposition made of the land purchased for a Naval Depot at Brunswick, Georgia. The bill amending the act relative to private land claims in California was taken up and passed. The Post-office Deficiency bill being under discussion, Mr. COLLAMER moved an amendment, leaving the Postmaster-General discretion to judge of the propriety of restoring suspended routes. Mr. PEARCE, of Maryland, read a letter from Mr. HOLT urging the necessity of this policy. The amendment was, however, rejected. The amendment of the Finance Committee striking out the clause which restores suspended routes was agreed to. A lively conversation ensued in consequence of the South Carolina Senators urging that the Charleston and Havana mail contract should be given to the Isabel, instead of being submitted to competition. The latter course was adopted, and the bill passed. After an Executive session, the Senate adjourned. The bill, adjudging penalties to Marshals and their Deputies, for permitting prisoners to escape, was passed by the House. Mr. WINSLOW, from the Covode Investigating Committee; upon a question of privilege, made a statement in regard to certain witnesses, which the majority of the Committee refused to have called. He believed that with the aid of the Speaker's subpoena he could prove that large sums of money had been spent in securing the election of Col. SCRANTON, a member from Pennsylvania. Mr. COVODE, from the majority, explained that the House, in refusing to compel Mr. SCHELL to testify in regard to the disposition of a private electioneering fund, had established a precedent which the Committee could not disregard. Hence the refusal to act on the Pennsylvania case. Mr. TRAIN, of Massachusetts, rising to speak on the subject, was interrupted by Mr. HOUSTON, of Alabama, who persisted in speaking, notwithstanding a universal call to order: whereupon Mr. TRAIN remarked that he should consider himself guilty of gross impropriety, both as a member and as a gentleman, were he to continue speaking when he had no right to the floor." Mr. HOUSTON inquired whether the remark was intended to apply to him. Mr. TRAIN replied that it did, and then Mr. HOUSTON pronounced him a "disgraceful liar and scoundrel." A scene of great violence ensued, in the midst of which Mr. SHERMAN demanded that Mr. HOUSTON should be censured for this language. After a sharp contest, in which the Republicans sustained the demand of Mr. SHERMAN, Mr. HOUSTON made an apology, and the scene and session ended.

abstract: MEETING OF THE BAR OF HUDSON COUNTY. -- An adjourned meeting of the bar of Hudson County was held yesterday morning in the Court-house, previous to the opening of the Court of Common Pleas, for the purpose of paying a tribute to the late ASA WHITEHEAD, Esq. Hon. Judge OGDEN presided, and ROBERT GILCHRIST acted as Secretary. Mr. J.D. MILLER pronounced an eulogy on the life and character of the deceased, after which District-Attorney SCUDDER submitted the usual resolutions, which were unanimously adopted, and a copy forwarded to the family of the deceased.

abstract: A PASSPORT SYSTEM ESTABLISHED IN THE SOUTH -- We are pleased to be able to announce, on authority that the embarrassments which attend travelers from the South, accompanied by their colored servants, are to be removed. We have, heretofore, alluded to the vast annoyance to which Southerners are subject, in railroad cars, beginning at Richmond and rigidly inflicted at Baltimore. It is all right and proper, but the annoyance is not less grievous, and it could, at any time, be removed by a system of passports vised by the Superintendent of the road at the point of departure. We are happy to say that this system has been adopted. It is arranged, between the various railroad companies, that a conventional passport from railroad Superintendents, at points of departure -- Savannah and Charleston for instance -- shall pass the colored servant, and thus relieve the master from the necessity of identifying himself at every relay, which, in many instances, is quite impossible.

abstract: The suicide of the Hungarian patriot and hero, Count SZECHENYI, is the most important and striking among the many sad events which characterize the decay of the Austrian Empire. Count STEPHEN SZECHENYI was born Sept. 21, 1791, in Vienna, and was educated as a soldier.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH, Tuesday, April 17, 1860.

abstract: Eight days ago I left Naples, and since that time I have traversed Piedmont, Lombardy, Southeastern Switzerland and Bavaria. In this rapid progress it has been very interesting to remark how the tone of popular conversation varies, in the rail-cars, on the steamboats, in the country inns, and by the wayside.

abstract: We learn that the Massachusetts cattle disease, known as "Pleura Pneumonia," has made its appearance in this part of our State, exciting well-founded alarm among the farmers and owners of cattle, who are threatened with great loss in consequence. The New-Jersey Agricultural Society are taking prompt measures to investigate the subject, with a view to the adoption of some means of relief from the terrible scourge, and a report from their Committee may be looked for in a few days. We understand that several cattle have perished in the vicinity of Morristown, and four out of seven that are affected with it on the farm of Mr. ABRAHAM JOHNSON, just below the southern boundary of this city, have died. One of those affected was killed yesterday morning, and a post mortem examination made in the presence of Gov. OLDEN and a number of leading men, connected with the Agricultural Society. One lung was found to be perfect, but the other was very badly diseased with the same affection as that which appeared in Massachusetts -- from which State it has been brought by cattle raised there, and purchased in the New-York market by Jerseymen. It is only known among homed cattle, and is believed to be contagious, but not epidemic. The President of the State Agricultural Society has decided to call a meeting, to be held on the 6th of June, at Elizabeth, when it is expected that they will recommend preventive and remedial measures. -- Newark Mercury, June 1.

abstract: State of New-York, City and County of New-York. -- JOHN CONNELL, being duly sworn before me, a Commissioner of Deeds, did depose and say that he has read in several of the morning papers of this day, June 2, an account of the arrest of deponent and another person, on the charge of an attempt to leave the City of New-York to engage in a prize-fight in New-Jersey; and, in relation to said matter, deponent makes solemn oath that he has not, in any way or shape, been engaged or interested in such prize-fight, and had no knowledge of any such matter until arrested on this trumped-up charge. JOHN CONNELL.

abstract: A venerable New-England divine carried on a controversy on some metaphysical question with an unknown, but exceedingly clever, antagonist in the columns of a magazine. He was afterwards informed that his opponent was of the softer sex, when he exclaimed: ...
lead_paragraph: A venerable New-England divine carried on a controversy on some metaphysical question with an unknown, but exceedingly clever, antagonist in the columns of a magazine. He was afterwards informed that his opponent was of the softer sex, when he exclaimed:"How awkward it is to have a tussle for two years with a woman, and not know it was a woman!" It is even more awkward to conduct a debate in which the disputants are not certain that they understand each other's language or modes of thought, and where it is perfectly certain that not one of a thousand of the readers on either side can possibly decipher the strange syllables in which the thought of the other is expressed. The TIMES and the Staats Zeitung address two different nationalities, even when discussing the Constitution and laws which secure the rights of both; nevertheless, it is well to elicit and examine the views propagated among three or four millions of Americo-German citizens, for the information of our own population; and it is not amiss that German readers should learn as much, at least, of the views cherished in this country as are necessarily communicated in the attempt of the German papers to invalidate those views.
headline: {'main': 'German Logic and American Laws.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'German Logic and American Laws.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Metropolitan Police once more covered themselves with glory on Saturday morning by a second time frustrating a "mill" that has been long pending between two noted ruffians of the pugilistic persuasion, and which was to ...
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Police once more covered themselves with glory on Saturday morning by a second time frustrating a "mill" that has been long pending between two noted ruffians of the pugilistic persuasion, and which was to have come off on the Centreville Course, Long Island, on that day. This time it was the Brooklyn division, under Deputy Superintendent FOLK, who appeared in the field and reaped the laurels. They administered, we are glad to say, a tolerable number of broken heads to the amateurs present, -- they arrested both the principals, and they gave one of them a severe clubbing, and broke up the ring, and postponed the fight sins die, -- for all of which exploits they are entitled to the heartiest thanks, not only of the Metropolitan District, but of the entire country.
headline: {'main': 'Pugilism and the Police.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Pugilism and the Police.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The statements touching the case of HICKS, the pirate; which were published in the TIMES of Friday last, and the mysterious allusions by the criminal to his agency in the piracy and murders on board of the Saladin, contained in some doggerel rhyme which he ...
lead_paragraph: The statements touching the case of HICKS, the pirate; which were published in the TIMES of Friday last, and the mysterious allusions by the criminal to his agency in the piracy and murders on board of the Saladin, contained in some doggerel rhyme which he dictated to a gentleman in his cell, have led to a discovery of all the facts concerning those events, which have been volunteered by several persons who were cognizant of the circumstances of the case, and who have called at our office, or sent us communications on the subject.

abstract: The Times' City Article of the 22d says: "Rumors regarding modifications of the Ministry were, of course, freely circulated, together with statements as to the designs of France and Russia, but no real news of any importance transpired until near the close of ...
lead_paragraph: The Times' City Article of the 22d says: "Rumors regarding modifications of the Ministry were, of course, freely circulated, together with statements as to the designs of France and Russia, but no real news of any importance transpired until near the close of business, when a private mercantile telegram was received from China, dated April 14, to the effect that the Imperial Court have refused the ultimatum of the Allies, and that a blockade had been established of the northern ports, with the exception of Shanghai."

abstract: At 5 o'clock on Friday afternoon, it was agreed by the representatives of WOODS and KING, that the fight, made impossible by the arrest of the latter, should positively come off next morning, between the hours of 5 and 7, "no postponement on account of the weather."
lead_paragraph: At 5 o'clock on Friday afternoon, it was agreed by the representatives of WOODS and KING, that the fight, made impossible by the arrest of the latter, should positively come off next morning, between the hours of 5 and 7, "no postponement on account of the weather." To keen the matter as quiet as possible only half-a-dozen carriage loads of "friends" were to be informed of these suddenly arranged details. But, somehow or other, at least four hundred persons must have been let into the secret, and by ten o'clock in the evening the matter was canvassed in the detective's office, and the information had already been telegraphed to Inspector FOLK, of Brooklyn. In ignorance of this fact, however, the friends and backers of the principals, with a large crowd of amateur "sports," and one or two carriage-loads of reporters, made their way a little after midnight toward East New-York. Here the initiated were first informed that the rendezvous was at Centreville Course. The track was reached a little after dawn. Here it was rumored that the police were on the alert, as, indeed, they were -- for in the sequel it was ascertained that some forty were present in citizens' clothes, prepared for any emergency, each armed with mace and revolver. On account of rumors, it was judged best to go a few fields further on. This was done, a ring was made, and then the fact became very evident that the field was full of policemen. Inspector FOLK was present himself, and avowed his determination to put a stop to the fight. WOODS and KING were near at hand, but not on the ground. Many of the crowd thought that the police were either too few to interfere or were beyond the limits of their authority, and so arranged a little "test fight" between "feather weights" for the purpose of seeing what the police would do. Two young sports made themselves conspicuous in collecting a subscription for the best man. They collected about forty dollars from the crowd, and the feather weights, after some discussion, agreed to fight for that sum. They entered the ring -- their names, BILLY DONNELLY and TOMMY THOMPSON. They were about peeling, when the police exhibited their staves, made a rush, secured the ring rope and ended the "test fight" in a quiet and summary manner. The collector of the purse disappeared with marvellous rapidity when the Police made their appearance and has not since been heard from.

abstract: The United States Mail steamer Vanderbilt arrived at this port, yesterday morning, bringing three days' later intelligence from Europe, which is of considerable importance. The Neapolitan troops had been defeated by GARIBALDI, on the 16th ult.
lead_paragraph: The United States Mail steamer Vanderbilt arrived at this port, yesterday morning, bringing three days' later intelligence from Europe, which is of considerable importance. The Neapolitan troops had been defeated by GARIBALDI, on the 16th ult. The position of Monreale, which commands Palermo, had been invested by his troops, and a rumor was current that Palermo, or, at least, a portion of it, was in the hands of the populace. The royalists everywhere were much discouraged; the people were universally jubilant. A band of 500 volunteers had reentered Tuscany. On the 19th ult. sixty Pontifical gendarmes and said to have encountered three hundred and fifty Garibaldians in a grotto near Montefiascone. A contest ensued, in which the latter were defeated, the brother of ORSINI being killed, but owing to the darkness of the night the Papal troops fired upon each other in error, killing five of the soldiers and two officers. Papal troops, with a supply of artillery, were leaving Rome for the frontier. England had not yet given her consent to the assembling of a Conference for the settlement of the Eastern question, but she is understood to agree with Austria and Prussia as to the maintenance of the integrity of the Ottoman Empire. The House of Lords had rejected the bill for the repeal of the paper duty, by a majority of 89, Lord LYNDHURST asserting the constitutional right of the House to reject it. In the Commons Lord PALMERSTON moved for a Committee to examine precedents for such a course. In the race for the Derby, Umpire was badly beaten. ALBERT SMITH, the popular author and lecturer, died on the 23d ult.

abstract: COMPLETION OF THE STATEN ISLAND RAILOAD -- OPENING CELEBRATIONS. -- This road, which has been in process of construction over a year, was last week finally completed and thrown open to travel. The event was celebrated on Saturday by an excursion of the officers of the road, together with a large number of invited guests, who embarked at 11 o'clock A.M. on board a special train, at Vanderbilt's Landing, proceeding the entire distance of the route to its western terminus, at Tottenville, at which point it is designed to connect by ferries with South Amboy, thus affording a connecting line with the Camden and Amboy road to Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: COMPLETION OF THE STATEN ISLAND RAILOAD -- OPENING CELEBRATIONS. -- This road, which has been in process of construction over a year, was last week finally completed and thrown open to travel. The event was celebrated on Saturday by an excursion of the officers of the road, together with a large number of invited guests, who embarked at 11 o'clock A.M. on board a special train, at Vanderbilt's Landing, proceeding the entire distance of the route to its western terminus, at Tottenville, at which point it is designed to connect by ferries with South Amboy, thus affording a connecting line with the Camden and Amboy road to Philadelphia.

abstract: Parties who own real estate in this City, who have been so neglectful as to fail to call "at the captain's office" and settle for taxes during the year 1855, are reminded that the annual sale of property for unpaid taxes commences at the City Hall to-day, under the direction of the Comptroller, and will be continued ...
lead_paragraph: -- Parties who own real estate in this City, who have been so neglectful as to fail to call "at the captain's office" and settle for taxes during the year 1855, are reminded that the annual sale of property for unpaid taxes commences at the City Hall to-day, under the direction of the Comptroller, and will be continued from day to day until completed. The same warning applies to house-owners, whose water rents for 1854 remain unpaid, as both are included in the same sale. To the uninitiated it may not be amiss to state, that at such sales the fee of property is no sold, but it is bid off to the party who will take it for the shortest term of years, the owner having, however, the equity of redemption within twelve months, by paying the arrears and all expenses, with 14 per cent. added. Many fortunes have been made at these sales in old times, when books were kept in such a blundering manner that it was not uncommon for a party to have his house sold over his head, without his knowledge, as no notice of sale or of arrears is given, except such as is published in the papers selected for the job, and these are generally such as have the smallest circulation. Another feature, eminently deserving attention, is that a house or lot is not sold by its Street number, but by the number designated on the Ward Map, so that an owner who does not know the Ward number of his house or lot, is in danger of being incontinenlly sold out, his only relief, in case he has paid his taxes, &c., being the tedious process of appeal to the Supervisors.

abstract: FRANCIS LATZ, a middle-aged German, who for some time past has been unemployed, having become greatly dispirited at his ill-fortune, on Saturday evening procured a dose of strychnine, and with it terminated his existence. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body at the saloon No. 134 Canal-street, where deceased was temporarily stopping.
lead_paragraph: FRANCIS LATZ, a middle-aged German, who for some time past has been unemployed, having become greatly dispirited at his ill-fortune, on Saturday evening procured a dose of strychnine, and with it terminated his existence. abstract: Among the passengers by the steamer Adriatic for Southampton and Havre on Saturday, were no less than a dozen ministers of the Gospel of various denominations, who visit Europe on tours of business or pleasure, accompanied most of them by members of their families. Among these were Rev. Dr. Adams ...
lead_paragraph: Among the passengers by the steamer Adriatic for Southampton and Havre on Saturday, were no less than a dozen ministers of the Gospel of various denominations, who visit Europe on tours of business or pleasure, accompanied -- most of them -- by members of their families. Among these were Rev. Dr. Adams Rev. Dr. Patton, Rev. Dr. McGill, Rev. Dr. Thornwell, Rev. J. Douglas, Rev. R.B. Anderson, Rev. Mr. Thompson, Rev. H.D. Ganse, Rev. F.W. Williams, Rev. G.F. Morrison, Rev. R.R. Sertron Rev. Mr. Corbit. Besides these, there were among the passengers numbers of gentlemen distinguished in the army, navy, the law, the world of letters, and in commercial life, the congregation of whose friends occasioned a brilliant scene at the foot of Canal-street for hours previous to the sailing of the Adriatic. The numbers of private carriages, and the crush of crinoline, of silk, of broadcloth, of lace, of satin and of barege; the fluttering of ribbons, and the variety of female perfumes, might easily have led to the delusion that the occasion was the production of a new opera, or the appearance of a new prima donna. Seldom has the pier and its vicinity presented so brilliant a scene, even in the palmiest day s of the Collins line.

abstract: The Executive Session of the Senate in which the Mexican Treaty was rejected, having been a secret session, and the Senate not having seen fit to remove the injunction of secrecy, we must be content with what little has leaked out relative to proceedings in the aforesaid secret session.
lead_paragraph: The Executive Session of the Senate in which the Mexican Treaty was rejected, having been a secret session, and the Senate not having seen fit to remove the injunction of secrecy, we must be content with what little has leaked out relative to proceedings in the aforesaid secret session. If that little which we have is correct, the performances over the Mexican Treaty were nothing more than a stupid farce, and in rejecting the instrument, the United States Senate has committed a stupendous, egregious blunder. We cannot wonder that it holds to the ancient and absurd custom of enjoining the members not to report their own folly abroad. But in this case, we very much doubt whether those legisators have any very de finite idea of what they intended to do, what they have actually done, and how they stand in the matter. They undoubtedly think they have killed something, but whether it is a Mexican Liberal or Priest, an Abolitionist, a Negro, a Fillibuster, a Free-trade ghost, or a bloody war, that lies dead under the dead Mexican treaty, we do not believe even those who killed it can determine.
headline: {'main': 'The Rejected Mexican Treaty.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Rejected Mexican Treaty.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The report of Attorney-General BLACK upon the California land claims is one of the most astounding chapters in the history of fraud. After the acquisition of the territory by the United States, eight hundred and three claims, covering 19,148 square miles of territory, were ...
lead_paragraph: The report of Attorney-General BLACK upon the California land claims is one of the most astounding chapters in the history of fraud. After the acquisition of the territory by the United States, eight hundred and three claims, covering 19,148 square miles of territory, were made by private individuals, under Mexican grants. What first raised suspicions of their genuineness was that they included all the best mineral and agricultural regions of California, and all the places best suited for light houses, fortifications, ports, military stations, and, in fact, every spot in the State which was likely to prove indispensable either to the State or Federal Government. There was not a place to be found for a public building which was not held by some private individual, under a grant from the Mexican Government, or a conveyance from the original grantee, at an enormous price. When the parties were finally put to their proofs before the United States District Court, documents were produced bearing every appearance of authenticity; they were sworn to by hosts of witnesses; and even Mexicans in a high political and social position, members of the Government, and others, came on to San Francisco, to vouch for them under oath. The result was, that the larger portion of them passed muster before the District Court, and were duly confirmed.

abstract: While the Government of FRANCIS II. of Naples has been amusing itself and putting off the evil day in the capital of the Two Sicilies with pretended telegrams from Palermo and Messina, each more sweeping than the other ...
lead_paragraph: While the Government of FRANCIS II. of Naples has been amusing itself and putting off the evil day in the capital of the Two Sicilies with pretended telegrams from Palermo and Messina, each more sweeping than the other in announcing the annihilation of the Sicilian insurrection, the hero of Varese has been steadily pushing his victorious way from the provinces to the chief towns of the island which he has risked his life and his fair renown to deliver. It now appears that on the 15th and 16th of May the volunteers under command of GARIBALDI met and defeated the royal Neapolitan army in two successive combats, drove them back upon Palermo, followed them in their retreat, and succeeded in seizing upon and occupying the position of Morreale, a lofty semi-circle of heights which completely commands the City of Palermo itself. Terrified, as they well might be, by this rapid and decisive advance of their enemy, the royal commanders were making their preparations for abandoning an untenable attitude. Gen. LANZA had issued proclamations offering an "amnesty" to the people whose homes have been so infamously invaded, and whose rights have been so insolently trampled upon by the agents of his King; and establishing a vice-royalty in the island in favor of the Count DE TRANI, the son of a sovereign who never kept his word, and the brother of a sovereign whose brief reign has already taken its place in history with the most disgraceful despotisms of ancient or of modern times. Meanwhile, as if foreseeing the angry scorn with which the Sicilians must receive these concessions wrung from a falling tyranny, the Governor of Palermo was hastily throwing up intrenchments between the city and the seaport, in order that the troops might be able to retreat to their vessels, and escape from the island without being overtaken by the rising and indignant populace.

abstract: Mr. George Robinson, of Hudson, N.Y., has preferred complaints against Ruggles W. Clapp and Richard M. Robbins, of this City, charging them with having defrauded him of $9,976 62 by false representations. The complainant alleged that he had bargained with Clapp for the purchase of a number of bonds, and a farm of 1,280 acres in the State of Illinois, which he was informed belonged to Robbins and his wife, who conveyed to him a deed of the property in question, upon his delivery to Clapp of a note for $2,825, drawn on the 5th of February, 1859, by Cornelius Wendell, of Washington, D.C., and payable four months after date, with his individual notes for $7,151 in addition. The transaction is alleged to have occurred a year ago, but subsequently Robinson ascertained that neither Robbins or his wife owned the Illinois property, and that the deeds and bonds were of no value. The accused were yesterday arrested by Officers Smith and McCord, of the Lower Police Court, and Justice OSBORN required Clapp to give bail for his appearance to answer, but discharged Robbins on his own recognizances, as it was not shown that his part in the transaction was taken with a guilty knowledge.

abstract: In the United States Court on Friday last, Judge SMALLEY gave notice that the criminal calendar would be taken up this week and disposed of, without postponing any of the cases, except for most urgent reasons, in order that witnesses in detention might not be kept in confinement during the hot weather. We commented a day or two ago on the contrast between the promptness of criminal trials in this ...
lead_paragraph: In the United States Court on Friday last, Judge SMALLEY gave notice that the criminal calendar would be taken up this week and disposed of, without postponing any of the cases, except for most urgent reasons, in order that witnesses in detention might not be kept in confinement during the hot weather. We commented a day or two ago on the contrast between the promptness of criminal trials in this Court and the tardy and draggling gait of justice in our State tribunals, and we cannot but deem this new instance of regard for the interests of innocent witnesses, as well as of the public, an example of consideration for the rights of others, well worthy the imitation of those judges and prosecuting officers in our State Courts, who, finding ample time for political pilgrimages hundreds of miles away, plead the press of business in excuse for neglect of official duties.

abstract: There is, perhaps, little difference of opinion among intelligent men as to the necessity of a judicial tribunal for the determination of claims of citizens of the United States against their Government.
lead_paragraph: There is, perhaps, little difference of opinion among intelligent men as to the necessity of a judicial tribunal for the determination of claims of citizens of the United States against their Government. Serious objection exist to the adjudication of such claims by legislative committees; -- still greater to their determination by legislative bodies in Committee of the Whole. Much of the corruption that has pervaded our State Legislatures, and even the Federal Congress, may be traced to this fruitful source. With the best intention on the part of legislators, they cannot fairly and intelligently sit in judgment on private cases, and discharge their duty profitably and wisely upon public questions. It was never contemplated by the framers of the Constitution that Congress should be invested with judicial functions, and consequently it is no disparagement to Congress to say that it is a body in all respects ill-adapted and ill-contrived for their exercise.

abstract: William J. Schenck vs. Robert Campbell. -- The plaintiff is the owner of a valuable house and lot fronting on the easterly side of Fifth-avenue, between Thirty-second and Thirty-third streets, in this City. The lot was, in 1835, purchased of the defendant, who then owned half the front between Thirty-second and Thirty-third streets, and extending 150 feet in depth. In the negotiation for the purchase it was agreed that the whole front should be so divided as to be occupied by only three first-class dwelling-houses of extra width. The deed from defendant to the plaintiff contained a covenant that the plaintiff should not erect on the premises "any livery, stage, or omnibus stable, slaughter-house, &c.," or any structure "in which any kind of business noxious or disagreeable to the neighboring inhabitants should be carried on," and also a warrant by the defendant that "no more than two houses" should be erected on the residue of the front between the plaintiff's purchase and Thirty-second-street. The plaintiff thereupon erected his house at an expense of over $50 000. Shortly after, the defendant sold a part of the remaining land to Mrs. Underbill, who erected thereon a very expensive dwelling-house, leaving the corner lot, about 38 feet in width, unoccupied. In March last the defendant applied to the plaintiff to waive the restriction against erecting more than one house on the corner lot, who manifested a willingness to permit him to erect two houses to correspond in character with the architecture of the neighboring builings, if he would submit to him his architect's plans. The defendant declined to be controlled in this way, and at once commenced the erection of a livery-stable on the corner, informing plaintiff that if the neighborhood did not want a livery-stable there, they would negotiate with him for the property. This action was thereupon brought, and an injunction allowed, restraining the erection of the livery-stable.

abstract: In the Senate, Mr. WILSON procured the adoption of a resolution of inquiry into the circumstances of the arrest of Father LANZA, an Italian patriot, on board an American vessel at Palermo. The Houmas Claim bill was taken up, discussed briefly, slightly amended, and postponed. The Kansas bill being the order of the day, Mr. SUMNER delivered an oration on the "Barbarism of Slavery."
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Mr. WILSON procured the adoption of a resolution of inquiry into the circumstances of the arrest of Father LANZA, an Italian patriot, on board an American vessel at Palermo. The Houmas Claim bill was taken up, discussed briefly, slightly amended, and postponed. The Kansas bill being the order of the day, Mr. SUMNER delivered an oration on the "Barbarism of Slavery." As an exordium, he referred to the four years which had elapsed since the utterance of his latest speech on the subject; and disclaimed any sentiment of hostility or desire for vengeance, as the result of occurrences at that time. He had then spoken of the crime against Kansas. He had now to combat the doctrine recently asserted that Slavery is a form of civilization, by pointing out its essential barbarism and antagonism to all active forms of social development. He proceeded to prove the barbarity of slavery in itself, and the barbarism of the masters, citing freely from the speeches and writings of prominent Southern statesmen, and conspicuously from those of distinguished South Carolinians. The remarks of Mr. SUMNER were full of acerbity, abounding in unqualified invective, and well calculated to offend grossly the susceptibilities of Southern members. He was replied to by Mr. CHESNUT, of South Carolina, in a few bitter remarks, to which Mr. SUMNER rejoined by characterizing them as an apt illustration of the text of his discourse. In the House, a bill appropriating $150,000 for a post-office in Brooklyn was favorably reported from the Senate, and referred to the Committee of the Whole on the State of the Union. A bill authorizing a daily mail service inland, between San Francisco and Washington Territory, at a sum not exceeding $100,000 a year, was also reported and referred. Mr. HASKIN reported back the joint resolution reducing the prices of the public printing, and gave notice that he should call it up on Wednesday. A bill making various minor consulates salaried offices was passed.

abstract: No one who reads Mr. EVERETT'S letter of acceptance, which we published yesterday, will doubt the excellence of his intentions or the sincerity of his desire to promote the welfare of the country. But unfortunately good intentions are not all that is required in an active statesman, filling a position of high responsibility, at a critical period of a nation's history.
lead_paragraph: No one who reads Mr. EVERETT'S letter of acceptance, which we published yesterday, will doubt the excellence of his intentions or the sincerity of his desire to promote the welfare of the country. But unfortunately good intentions are not all that is required in an active statesman, filling a position of high responsibility, at a critical period of a nation's history. A clear perception of the evil to be encountered and of the remedy to be applied, a firm will in breasting opposition, and hopeful courage and confidence in the people upon whom in the end the result must rest, are quite as important as purity of personal character and fervent aspirations for the welfare of the Republic. We do not find in Mr. EVERETT's letter any evidence of the possession of such high and indispensable qualities. On the contrary, he deals with great questions in a small way; -- he meets bold and resolute enemies with a timid and deprecatory mien; -- and commits the fatal mistake of supposing that a great contest of opposing principles and contending interests can be most safely decided by pretending not to recognize its existence.

abstract: In the Court of General Sessions, yesterday morning, Recorder BARNARD presiding, nine test cases, selected from the seventy-five indictments, which the District-Attorney has procured from the Grand Jury, against parties charged with selling liquor on Sundays, in violation of the new law, were brought before the Court. The "representative" parties, were Michael Devine, Patrick Hughes, John Healy, Patrick Gleeson William Heller and Stephen Ryan, of the Fourth Ward; Samuel Gardner and ...
lead_paragraph: James Turpy of the Sixth Ward, with Patrick Degraw of the Fourteenth Ward. Ex-Recorder Smith appeared as their joint counsel, but owing to the pressure of his engagements, Recorder BARNARD consented to postpone the investigation of the cases till Friday. The Court-room was crowded with friends of the defendants and with the other culprits, who are declared as such under the recent statute. One case will probably be taken up as a test case, and the conduct of the remainder will hinge upon that decision.

abstract: Kansas is certainly entitled to universal sympathy. She is the child of misfortune, and it is sometimes hard to say whether she suffers most at the hands of her friends or her foes. She has been struggling for a recognized existence now for four or five years.
lead_paragraph: Her people have at last conquered a peace. They have defeated the worst designs of her enemies, -- have succeeded in throwing off the heavy yoke which the slave-holding interest, aided by the Federal Government, struggled long and laboriously to fasten upon them, and have applied, with a Constitution of their own making, for admission to the Federal Union. The House of Representatives, with commendable alacrity, has granted the application; and the appeal now, -- at the very heel of the session, -- awaits the action of the Senate. Every consideration of expediency, as well as of justice, favors the admission. The Democratic majority has much to lose, and nothing of substantial value to gain, by refusing it, -- and it was becoming a matter of some curiosity to know in what direction they could find motives for rejecting so just an application.
