abstract: If the Japanese are really coming to NewYork, we beg them to come at once. Not for our own sakes particularly, nor yet for theirs. The they have been bored to death at Washington is tolerably clear, and not at all surprising, and we think it very likely that they have repaid their persecutors in kind.
lead_paragraph: At least two fashionable matinees are already planned for their discomfiture in New-York -- one a fete champetre at a lovely country-seat less than a hundred miles from town; but as we are sure that those who entertain these orange-colored princes in petticoats will have their labor for their pains, it is not of them that we think in praying for the advent of the envoys of Niphon. For the fillip which their presence will, no doubt, administer to public amusements in general, and the Opera in particular, by swamping the City with strangers, who must, have something to see and hear besides the bare legs of "Tommy" and the embroidered trowsers of Tommy's masters, we imprecate their coining.

abstract: The annual meeting of "The Most Worshipful Grand Lodge of the Most Ancient and Honorable Fraternity of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New York" was opened yesterday afternoon, in their Grand Lodge-room, at the Apollo Rooms, No. 410 Broadway.

abstract: The Tribune rejoices that the Mexican Treaty is dead, which is reasonable enough, inasmuch as the Tribune has been laboring for months in the van of the small partisan phalanx which has been bent on doing the deed. But the reasons which our contemporary gives for the joy that is in him curiously illustrate the profound ignorance in which all tills zeal against Mexican Liberalism has been founded. The Tribune is glad that we are to give Mexico over to continued anarchy, because, among other things, "Mexico is a poor country." This proposition is at least refreshingly novel. To consider it for a moment, is to illustrate the importance of the commercial resources which we have sacrificed by throwing Mexico back into that gulf of anarchy, from which, with our helping hand, she might now have emerged. The valuation of the real estate of the United States after eighty years of prosperous national development, is only two and a half times greater in the average than that of similar property in Mexico, distracted by a lifetime of revolutions. The interior commerce of the Republic, in spite of no railways, poor highways, civil war and brigandage, amounts to $400,000,000 per year. The infant manufactures of Mexico produce nearly $100,000,000 per year. Her foreign commerce, so cavalierly contemned by our magnificent contemporary, amounts to nearly $60,000,000 per year; of which England has gradually monopolized nearly five-sevenths. With peace at home this commerce would be indefinitely increased, and under the provisions of the now rejected treaty, the greater part of that increase might be expected to be diverted to our own ports.

abstract: As we anticipated, and as our readers have been led to expect from the account of an interview which our Reporter recently had with ALBERT W. HICKS, he has made additional disclosures with reference to the murder of Capt. BURR and the brothers OLIVER and SMITH WATTS, on board the sloop E.A. Johnson, in March last. The admissions were made in course of a conversation with a gentleman who has been unremitting in his attentions to the prisoner since his incarceration, and to whom he professes to feel under many obligations for the kindness shown him.
lead_paragraph: As we anticipated, and as our readers have been led to expect from the account of an interview which our Reporter recently had with ALBERT W. abstract: Coroner GAMBLE, yesterday, investigated the circmstances attending the death of JOSEPH BABBUFF, a boy 10 years of age, residing at No. 420 West Sixteenth-street. Deceased was sitting on some floating logs, at the foot of Twelfth-street, North River, when one of his companions threw his cap into the water. In his attempt to regain it, he fell from the logs, and was drowned before assistance reached him.

abstract: -- A regular meeting of the Jersey City Common Council was held last evening at the Lyceum, the President, Alderman HARDENBERGH, in the Chair, and a quorum. The Committee on Public Grounds reported a programme for the celebration of the Fourth of July, which was adopted, viz.: A national salute at sunrise, 12 o'clock M., and at sundown; fire-works and music in the evening. The whole at a cost not to exceed $500, An ordinance amendatory to the Police Ordinance was adopted, providing for the appointment of an additional aid and four policemen. The Tax Ordinance was taken from the table, read, and again laid upon the table until the Salary Ordinance is adopted. The Salary Ordinance was taken up, and after being partially considered, the Board adjourned.

abstract: The will of the late Daniel Fanshaw came before the Surrogate, Hon. EDWARD C. WEST, yesterday, on an application for probate. By this will the testator gives to his wife, Harriet A., the use of his present residence on Third-avenue and Ninetieth-street, and nineteen lots and gores connected there with, and all household furniture, bedding, jewelry, &c.; also, an annuity of $1,500, to be accepted in lieu of dower. After her death this property is to be sold, and after paying her funeral expenses the balance is to be divided into eight equal parts. One of these shares is ??? among his grand-children. The grand-children, named Rebecca, Harriet, and Daniel, are to have a double portion, that they may purchase some remembrance of himself or his wife's, if they think proper to do so. Another portion he gives to the American and Foreign Christian Union, formed in the City of New-York in 1849; the interest to be expended yearly in donations of their publications among Sabbath-school Libraries. Another portion to the New-York Tract Society, formed in New-York City Feb. 19, 1827; the interest to be expended yearly in the purchase of their publications. These works to be distributed among the most depraved part of the population of the City of New-York. Another portion to the American Seamen's Friend Society, incorporated by the Legislature of New-York in 1833; the interest to be expended yearly for the publications of the American Tract Society, to be distributed in the boarding-house of the Society and the vessels in harbor. Two other portions to the Reformed Low Dutch Church, that may be built after 1856, between Fifth-avenue and East River, and Seventy-ninth and Ninety-fifth streets. One other portion to the New-York Juvenile Asylum; the interest to be yearly expended in the purchase of the American Tract Society's publications, to be distributed among its young beneficiaries. One other portion to Mr. Pease, for the benefit of the inhabitants of the Five Points.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from LEWIS TAPPAN and others, of this City, asking for the release of THADDEUS HYATT. The Kansas bill was taken up. Mr. GREEN, of Missouri, moved to change the boundary of that Territory, and then submit the Lecompton Constitution to a vote of the people.
lead_paragraph: The subject was postponed, and the consideration of the Army bill was resumed, when the amendment reimbursing the several States for advances made to the General Government in the war of 1812 was discussed at length. Without further action, the Senate adjourned. In the House, the Senate bill making provision for the return and support of the captured Africans was taken up. Alter much debate and opposition from Southern members it was carried by a vote of 121 against 56. A motion to amend the title of the bill, connecting it with, the Colonization Society in Liberia, was lost. The resolution from the Committee on Elections, relative to the contest between Messrs. BLAIR and BARRETT for the seat from the First Congressional District of Missouri was called up, but no action was taken thereon when the House adjourned.

abstract: If a stranger, in endeavoring to delineate the idiosyncrasies of the Anglo-Saxon race, asserted, among other singular facts, that, next to the pleasure of seeing a man hung, they delighted in hearing him sentenced to death, the statement would excite universal execration, and yet he would state nothing more than the truth.
lead_paragraph: The morbid desire to sup upon horrors, and indulge in that titillation of the nerves and curdling of the blood produced by contact with anything savoring of the gallows, appears to pervade all classes, high and low. From an aesthetical point of view there seems nothing especially attractive in the struggles of a man clutching at thin air for life, and yet men will go much further to see a criminal hung than to see a sinner baptised. One would imagine that there would be little music in the words which fall upon a man's life like the executioner's axe, and make him virtually dead while he yet moves and breathes; yet more crowd to hear the sentence of death drop from the Judge's lips than go to receive a benediction from BEECHER. Familiarity with the gallows and is paraphernalia is a bad thing, and very often begets a closer acquaintance. A man does better by eschewing these thrilling vicinities until he receives a summons from the Sheriff which he cannot very well disregard.

abstract: The Methodist General Conference, after a session of five weeks, adjourned finally to-day, for want of a quorum. There was very little more business to be transacted, but the conduct of those who left before all was completed, and compelled those who remained to separate without clearing the docket, is severely censured.
lead_paragraph: BUFFALO, Monday, June 4, 1860.

abstract: We publish to-day the most important papers relating to a grave case of domestic scandal Which has for months past been disturbing the surface of society in a leading Western city. Upon the merits of this case we, of course, do not now propose to pronounce any opinion.
lead_paragraph: The matter has been forced into the courts of law, and will there receive quite as thorough a ventilation as the interests of justice can demand, or as comports with the good of the community at large. But the story, as it now appears in the showing alike of the respondent and the complainant, must arrest the attention of the most thoughtless. It is not the common story of fashionable frivolity and reckless dissipation, which is so constantly invoked to point a moral and adorn a tale against the wicked people who wear Parisian silks, give balls, keep Lent, and build cottages at Newport or Saratoga. The parties in this affair have been living for years in the extremest decorums of one of the straitest of all religious communions. Theirs was like Mr. THACKERAY's Newcomes, a highly respectable family; not given to worldlinesses, pomps and vanities, but discreet and sober in all its ways. A model family, of that quiet and prosperous middle class in which we are so constantly bidden to look for all the graces of a Christian life, and all the certainties of a tranquil and impregnable propriety.

abstract: This match was commenced yesterday on the St. George's new ground, Elysian Fields, Hoboken. The weather was decidedly unfavorable, and in consequence but few persons were present to witness the contest. The play on both sides was very fine, particularly the fielding of the Philadelphians, eight of whom are Americans. On their side, the batting of Newhall was very good: his long-stopping was also excellent.
lead_paragraph: Johnson's twenty-one, Senior's ten, and Howe's twelve, were well got, each batting in fine style, but they were alike unfortunate in being run out. Barclay and Waterman played very nicely for their scores, and Kuhn brought out his bat after playing steadily for some time. The bowling of Gibbs, Brett and H. Wright was very good, but the extraordinary fine play, and sharp fielding of Sadler, who kept wicket in the absence of Long, did more execution in the service of St. George than has been done in a match for some time, he putting down no less than five wickets and running men out, assisted by fine fielding on the part of others, the Philadelphians' first innings making the fine total of one hundred and eleven.

abstract: At the regular meeting of the Board of Councilmen yesterday, the Street Commissioner was directed to clear all obstructions from Broadway prior to the 13th inst.
lead_paragraph: A resolution, offered by Councilman HALL, was adopted inquiring of the Commissioners of Police at whose instigation the recent foray upon signs and awning posts has been so vigorously carried on. Also, one of inquiry of the Comptroller as to the number of public lamps lighted by the Harlem Gas Company -- how they are located -- how many hours each lamp is lighted -- the size of the burners -- the cost per lamp, &c., &c. Permission was granted to Edward Philips, Jr., to exhibit his patent refrigerating apparatus in front of No. 37 Wall-street, the same not to occupy more than eighteen feet square, in compensation for which he proposes to give to each passer by a glass of iced water. The Board concurred with the other Board to pay $2,500 for making the floor of Essex Market water tight, "the same to be done without contracting." Also to pave Washington-street with Belgian pavement from Battery-place to Liberty-street. Also to open Sixty-fourth-street, from Eighth-avenue to Hudson River. Also One Hundreth and Twelfth-street, from Third to Fourth-avenue. Mr. SHAW sought to be excused from serving as Chairman of the Committee to investigate the charges against the Corporation Attorney, but the Board refused his request, and pending a reconsideration of the motion to excuse, an adjournment until Friday, at 5 P.M., was carried.

abstract: The Committee appointed to receive our Niphonese guests have been sweating their poor brains through all this sultry weather in regard to the ornamentation of the City Hall Park for the occasion. Although advising the Committee of Reception in anything which savors of aesthetics may seem as much a work of supererogation as though we attempted to teach them to chew to-...
lead_paragraph: -- The Committee appointed to receive our Niphonese guests have been sweating their poor brains through all this sultry weather in regard to the ornamentation of the City Hall Park for the occasion. Although advising the Committee of Reception in anything which savors of aesthetics may seem as much a work of supererogation as though we attempted to teach them to chew tobacco, we have a plan of ornamentation to offer which would astonish and please the natives as well as the foreigners. Let several of the Aldermen be suspended by the neck from each of the larger trees in the vicinity of the City Hall, with a large weight attached to their heels, and we venture to say that the exhibition would be pleasant to all, dissatisfactory to none. It is true that the Japanese might think that the trees of this country bore interior fruit to those of Niphon, but this fact could be accounted for by the sterility of the soil of the Park, and the little cultivation that is deemed necessary in raising Aldermen. If any one can devise a better plan for ornamenting the City Hall grounds, or a better use to which our Aldermen can be put, we should like to hear from him before the arrival of the strangers.

abstract: Edward Rowe vs. William C. Burdick. This was an action to recover for a quantity of brandy alleged to have been purchased of plaintiff by defendant, but not paid for. The plaintiff claims that in April, 1858, he sold to the defendant a large quantity of brandy, amounting in all to nearly $3,000 worth, which...
lead_paragraph: Edward Rowe vs. William C. Burdick. -- This was an action to recover for a quantity of brandy alleged to have been purchased of plaintiff by defendant, but not paid for. The plaintiff claims that in April, 1858, he sold to the defendant a large quantity of brandy, amounting in all to nearly $3,000 worth, which liquor was delivered, but has not been paid for, although the defendant still has it in his possession. The defence was that the plaintiff requested the defendant to purchase brandy, and showed him a sample, which defendant tasted, and thinks he tested. Supposing that the brandy which he was to take was all like the sample, he took a large quantity of it, but soon found that the bulk of the purchase was not the same as the sample. He refused to retain it, and has since kept it subject to the order of plaintiff, the latter having been notified that the defendant would not take it, and for what reason he refused.

abstract: Mrs. Traiter, a milliner at No. 9 Division-street, complainad at the Detective Police-office a few days since, that she had received a $5 counterfeit bill on the Centtal Bank of New-York, and a $1 on the ...
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Traiter, a milliner at No. 9 Division-street, complainad at the Detective Police-office a few days since, that she had received a $5 counterfeit bill on the Centtal Bank of New-York, and a $1 on the Central Bank of Tennessee, from a good-looking young woman who had purchased a bonnet, and said that she was Miss Emily Mestayer, an actress at Barnum's Museum, fortifying her assertion by presenting what purported to be passes of admission to that place of amusement. Subsequently additional complaints were made against the same young woman for attempting to pass other worthless bills, and Detective Roach apprehended her yesterday morning at her boarding-house, corner of Fortieth-street and Second-avenue. The accused is named Anna Keese; she was formerly a governess in this City, but it is said has recently adopted a disreputable life. She is held for examination.

abstract: The ship G.B. Lamar, Bradley, from London and the Downs April 30, reports: April 30, off Foulkstone, during a thick fog, came in collision with Br. bark Henrietta. The G.B.L. received very little damage. The bark lost foremast, bowsprit and cutwater May 9, lat. 47 23, lon. 22 55, picked up a bale of cotton, that had apparently been on fire. Has been 6 ds. abstract: OH, MOONSKI, SON OF FRUM! We want to  go home. It was in an evil hour that we stepped upon the ship which brought us to this accursed country; it was the breath of DZIZO that filled the  sails, and his was the hand that guided the helm.
lead_paragraph: OH, MOONSKI, SON OF FRUM! We want to go home. It was in an evil hour that we stepped upon the ship which brought us to this accursed country; it was the breath of DZIZO that filled the sails, and his was the hand that guided the helm. Our trowsers are rumpled, and our bodies are wearied. Our garments have been profaned by the touch of these barbarian women, and our ears are benumbed with their talk. Truly, as the great CONFUCIUS has written, of much trouble there is no end. Many times has MOORAGAKE bent his knees, intending to bow with humility and say to the Tycoon of this people: "Spare thy servants we know that we are Japanese, but we cannot help it." Yet remembrance of the duty which we owe to Niphon has prevented; it is glorious to suffer for the public good, and though we may never return to reap the rewarding smiles which the Mikado showers upon the faithful, our children shall be advanced to honor; it shall be said that their fathers fell victims for the good of Niphon and all tongues shall be loud in their praise. Namoo Amadi!

abstract: In the Senate yesterday the Houmas Land bill was read a third time and passed. The Army Appropriation bill was taken up, but no action was had thereon before adjournment. In the House the consideration of the Missouri Contested Election case was resumed, but no action was taken on the subject.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday the Houmas Land bill was read a third time and passed. The Army Appropriation bill was taken up, but no action was had thereon before adjournment. In the House the consideration of the Missouri Contested Election case was resumed, but no action was taken on the subject. A resolution was passed, giving the assent of Congress to such acts as the Legislatures of Louisiana, Texas and Arkansas may pass for the removal of the Red River raft, by levying tolls on boats navigating that river. Mr. MORRILL, of Vermont, commenced a speech on "Modern Democracy," but was kept for four hours waiting for a quorum, while a ridiculous scene was enacted in the House. At length he was allowed to proceed, with the understanding that his speech should be printed in the Globe.

abstract: If anything can convince the entire mass of the people of the North of the absolute necessity of displacing the oligarchy which bears sway at Washington, it will be the relentless tyranny with which it wields whatever remnant of power is suffered to remain in its hands. No consideration of justice or of public policy is ever allowed to turn it from its settled purpose, of fortifying its own power and promoting its own specific and selfish ends, at whatever expense to the general good.

abstract: In the northeast corner of the Park, overtopped by surrounding buildings, stands a modest edifice, the second story of which is reached by stairs on the outside in the manner of tenement bouses for one of which it might be mistaken, but for the close resemblance its exterior bears to the well-appointed stable of a  brown-stone house.
lead_paragraph: In the northeast corner of the Park, overtopped by surrounding buildings, stands a modest edifice, the second story of which is reached by stairs on the outside in the manner of tenement houses -- for one of which it might be mistaken, but for the close resemblance its exterior bears to the well-appointed stable of a brown-stone house. In spite of its appearance, however, it serves neither of these purposes, but does the twofold duty of a temple of justice and an engine-house. The first floor is occupied by "the masheen" and the "boys" that "run" therewith; while the rooms above are set apart "to the use and behoof" of the Superior Court of "the Capital of a Hemisphere." Firemen are not usually the most quiet race of men to be found. It is not surprising, therefore, that in this temple the yells of the athletes below sometimes rise and mingle with the notes of forensic conflict above, to the utter confusion of judge and jury, who for the time forget law, and become absorbed in the fact of the hubbub that rages below them.

abstract: Owens vs. The Mayor, &c. -- The particulars of this case were stated in the TIMES of the 5th inst. The trial was before Judge BRADY in the Common Pleas. It will be remembered that the plaintiff sued to recover damages for injuries received in being thrown from a cart on Second-avenue, near Twenty-first-street, in consequence of what is termed a "Corporation hole." The jury now gave the plaintiff a verdict for $1,500. An allowance of 5 per cent, was made.

abstract: The grand trotting match between Flora Temple and Geo. M. Patchen for $1,000, best three in five,  which was postponed from Tuesday on account of the rain, came off yesterday afternoon at the Union Course, and resulted in favor of Flora Temple, who is still entitled to be called the "Queen of the Turf" ...
lead_paragraph: The grand trotting match between Flora Temple and Geo. M. Patchen for $1,000, best three in five, which was postponed from Tuesday on account of the rain, came off yesterday afternoon at the Union Course, and resulted in favor of Flora Temple, who is still entitled to be called the "Queen of the Turf" -- having not only beaten her opponent, but even herself, and made the quickest time on record. In the long succession of triumphs achieved by this mare last season, which was the season of her glory, the fastest time made by her was 2:22 1/2, excepting one heat at Kalamazoo, Mich., where, upon a short track, she is claimed to have made 2:19 3/4 Yesterday she trotted the first heat in 2:21, the second in 2:24, and the third in 2:2 1/2 -- thus excelling everything in the way of fast trotting ever before seen in the world. Although the match was made only a few days ago, yet the announcement that Flora Temple was to make, her first appearance for the season drew together an immense crowd of spectators. There were from ten to twelve thousand persons inside the track, and not less, than five hundred carriages of all descriptions, from the St. Nicholas and Metropolitan Hotel coaches to a one-horse buggy. The fair sex were represented to the number of about two hundred. There were the, usual number of shoulder-hitters, fighting-men and gamblers present, but, on the whole, it was a very respectable assemblage. All of the ladies and ninetenths of the gentlemen were partisans of Flora Temple, and were not a little surprised to find her new rival almost the winner of the first heat.

abstract: Mrs. HARRIET HARITAGE, a lady 41 years of age, residing at No. 31 West Thirteenth-street, died on Tuesday night in consequence of dreadful burns received on Sunday last by the bursting of a fluid lamp....The body of a man, apparently 30 years of age, wearing the dress of a longshoreman, was found in the harbor between Governor's Island and the Battery. No marks of violence were visible, so a verdict of death by drowning was rendered.

abstract: Among the useful changes around the City Hall is the removal of the office of Clerk of the Councilmen from his late cramped and confined quarters to a large and airy room in the basement, directly beneath the late office. This apartment has been commodiously arranged under the direction of the Superintendent of Repairs and Supplies, and Mr. ROOME, the keeper of the City Hall. The old office will be arranged as a committee-room for the Board, the entrance being by a stairway through the present office. The opening of the proposed area around the City Hall, and the cutting down of the windows, will render the basement offices among the most desirable in the building.

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- An adjourned meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held last evening. A communication was received from the Superintendents of the Poor calling attention to the fact that they had received no money from fines imposed for intoxication in Police Courts, as required by the Metropolitan Police act. The matter was referred to a special Committee, with authority to examine the law and report what action, if any, is necessary in the premises. Considerable routine business was transacted, when the Board adjourned.

abstract: A meeting was held yesterday at the City Hotel, Elizabeth, N.J., which was principally attended by farmers of the vicinity interested in the Cattle epidemic, which, commencing in Massachusetts, has spread through several Eastern States, and has now reached our neighbors across the North River.
lead_paragraph: A meeting was held yesterday at the City Hotel, Elizabeth, N.J., which was principally attended by farmers of the vicinity interested in the Cattle epidemic, which, commencing in Massachusetts, has spread through several Eastern States, and has now reached our neighbors across the North River. A report on the subject was received from Mr. C.C. GUNN, of this City, and resolutions in relation thereto, and to the precautions necessary to prevent the spread of the disease, were read and adopted.

abstract: The ratification meeting advertised to come off at the Old Court House in White Plains yesterday, owing to some defect in the manner of giving the notice, was not large. Few persons, even in the village, had heard of the meeting.
lead_paragraph: The ratification meeting advertised to come off at the Old Court House in White Plains yesterday, owing to some defect in the manner of giving the notice, was not large. Few persons, even in the village, had heard of the meeting. The agents of the New-York publishers of the campaign life of LINCOLN and HAMLIN were on hand, however, and had placarded the whole town with their notices of The Jolly Flatboatman, which would be for sale at the meeting; thus, in part, supplying the lack of service on the part of the Committee. At 11 o'clock (the hour appointed for the meeting) only a small number had dropped in, and after consultation an adjournment took place to 2 o'clock P.M. At this hour a meeting, respectable in numbers and character, occupied the Hall, when JAMES A. HAMILTON, the only son of ALEXANDER HAMILTON, called the meeting to order, and introduced Hon. HORACE GREELEY. Mr. GREELEY was cordially greeted on coming forward, and addressed the meeting in a speech of about half an hour. The straggling character of the present meeting was the best proof of the necessity of meeting; he had seen a great many meetings in Westchester, but never a large one -- a general turn out; it was the worst place possible to get the people together; it was all circumference and no centre; they had always fought in a straggling, half-organized manner, and never had any notion of the character of the vote they were going to poll until after election. Four years ago they cast eight thousand votes in this County, and by proper effort that number could be considerably increased this Fall. Of that large number of Democratic voters at that election, not one in ten now approve of the manner in which the administration of this Government has been conducted, whether it were the attempt to force Slavery upon Kansas -- the wasteful, extravagant and dishonest squandering of the public money -- or any other of the many obnoxious measures which have distinguished it. On the contrary, many men who then voted for the Democratic Party are dissatisfied with the course affairs have taken, and are ready to cooperate with the Republicans to place the Government on a new track. Mr. HASKIN declared he went to Congress to do all he fairly and honestly could to bring in Kansas as a Free State. He had done worthily and well, because he had done what he promised to do. He could not say as much for Mr. BUCHANAN. He came into power by a large majority of the electoral votes of the Southern States, and little could be expected of him. The horse must know his master, and he knew him. JOHN A. DIX, an old resident, and well-known here, went around the country four years ago, saying this matter of Kansas was very bad, but Mr. BUCHANAN, when he came into power, would give us a very different state of things. Mr. PIERCE was charged with doing very badly, put we were now to see all these affairs set right. But what had been the sequel? Were we to have another JOHN A. DIX this time? He firmly believed that this County, if fairly organized, would give a handsome Republican majority this Fall. In this large, prosperous and wealthy County, there ought to be found no man to approve of the present profligate Administration. It might be said "all these things are settled now." But they were not settled, though, and there was no intention of having them settled. They do not mean to let Kansas come in as long as they can prevent it; she has three electoral votes to cast against them. This is the policy at the White House. There never was a Territory with the same number of population as Kansas, or anything like it, which has applied for admission and has been denied. He knew there were one hundred thousand people there: on a cold and wintry day last Fall, when the people were tired out by one election after another, they cast 15,000 votes. Even Oregon, with nothing like tee fitness which Kansas has, came into the Union, and she now turns round and votes to keep Kansas out. The Republicans were compelled to sustain themselves against unreasoning and unreasonable prejudices as to what they wish to do. If every man in the country could have the Republican platform placed fairly before him, or pick it up in the street without knowing whether one or another party had made it, he would say, "I do not see what is wrong here," and would be ready to indorse it heartily. Mr. GREELEY urged the importance of a thorough organization of the county, in which every Republican should have some work to do. One vote lost in a school district was twelve thousand votes lost in the State. In referring to the Chicago nomination, he said he believed they could not have selected two men who would have received so many votes outside of the Republican ranks; so that if they were defeated, it would be on account of their own apathy and coolness. After referring to the demands of the South for protection to slave property in the Territories; to the project of annex in Cuba in order to extend the slave power; to the probable acquiescence in these demands by the Baltimore Convention, and to the position of Mr. DOUGLAS, Mr. GREELEY closed his remarks.

abstract: On Wednesday morning play was resumed, with the St. George still at the bat. The weather was fine for Cricket, and everything was favorable for good play, the ground not being so dead as on the previous day.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning play was resumed, with the St. George still at the bat. The weather was fine for Cricket, and everything was favorable for good play, the ground not being so dead as on the previous day. The remaining three wickets added but 17 to the score, of which BURNETT obtained 8 by excellent play, the others not troubling the scorers. Considering the remarkably fine fielding of the Philadelphians, the total of the innings, 141, was highly creditable to the St. George. In the second innings of the Philadelphians, WALTER NEWHALL and BARCLAY were the only ones who made a stand, obtaining respectively 29 and 27, and not out. Both of these numbers were well deserved, and were made up of sixes, threes twos and singles. Some of the finest of the Philadelphia batsmen were got rid of for little or nothing, when large scores were expected, and needed to wipe off the large total of the St. George's first innings.

abstract: This will, which has been before the Surrogate for eight months past, was now admitted to probate. The testator left about $40,000 worth of property, most of which is in real estate. He leaves a widow, but no children. He gives one sister, a widow, the lot known as No.111 Sullivan-street, with the buildings thereon: to the New-York Catholic Orphan Asylum five hundred dollars; to an uncle two hundred dollars; and to his widow the two houses and lots Nos. 107 and 109 Sullivan-street. The will was contested by a sister who is not named in the will, on the ground of incompetency.

Insured for $6,500 in the Excelsior, United States, Importers and Traders, Exchange and Kings County Insurance Companies. The building, owned by Mr. WILCOX, was damaged to the amount of $50. abstract: Whether the rule holds good in Art, that "evil communications corrupt good manners," we shall be able, perhaps, next year to decide, when the few artists, who, having any manner of their own, have exposed that manner to the contagion of this year's Academy exhibition, shall once...
lead_paragraph: Whether the rule holds good in Art, that "evil communications corrupt good manners," we shall be able, perhaps, next year to decide, when the few artists, who, having any manner of their own, have exposed that manner to the contagion of this year's Academy exhibition, shall once more come before us with a twelve-month's work. Mr. CHURCH wisely evaded the trial; -- how wisely, his latest picture, yesterday privately exhibited to a discerning few at GOUPIL's rooms in Broadway, may satisfy the observer. This picture is as little like the "Heart of the Andes," as twilight is like morning and the North like the South. Yet, the veriest tyro in connoisseurship could not hesitate a moment as to the authorship, were he to stumble on it in the palace of some Hyperborean Prince. This is one of Mr. CHURCH's permanently great qualities, -- that his pencil is his own, and speaks his own language in his own way. You can no more mistake Mr. CHURCH's treatment of sunlight, in whatever phase, than Lord BYRON's allusions to the sea.
headline: {'main': "Mr. Church's Last Picture.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Mr. Church's Last Picture.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The sweet uses of adversity have found a fortunate illustration in the history of the Great Eastern. There is very little reason to doubt that had the great ship visited America last Autumn, the visitation would have resulted in a very serious popular disappointment. On no topic had sensation-writing so exhausted itself.
lead_paragraph: The sweet uses of adversity have found a fortunate illustration in the history of the Great Eastern. There is very little reason to doubt that had the great ship visited America last Autumn, the visitation would have resulted in a very serious popular disappointment. On no topic had sensation-writing so exhausted itself. The dimensions of the monster, its ponderous machinery, its stupenduous shafts and wheels and screws, its vast vistas of saloons, its steadiness, its speed, its manageability, had all been the subject of exaggerated statement, and of pictorial effort, which far exceeded all possibility of realization; and which actual experiment and inspection could only have put to shame. The mishaps which providentially postponed the trans-Atlantic voyage, added to the demonstration that no such results in speed as had been anticipated by the projectors were to be further counted upon, have had the salutary effect of reducing the popular expectation; so that the Great Eastern of 1860 will be likely to bring with it the raciness of a fresh sensation, and the pleasure of a satisfactory disappointment. Nor is the substitution of New-York for Portland, as its cis-Atlantic destination, the least of the advantages flowing from the protracted delay.

abstract: Since every dog will have his day, and the dog days are upon us, and the old dog pound has mysteriously disappeared, the City has been to the expense of purchasing and fitting up a floating dog-pound, which cost about $300, and is now lying at the foot of Twenty-sixth-street. The old dog-pound, after being laid up for the season last year, was much coveted for fire-wood, and, not having the fear of the Metropolitan Police before their eyes, the upper works, the deck, and finally the hulk itself, disappeared, no doubt to gladden the firesides of many who appreciated that economical method of obtaining firewood at the public expense.

abstract: The annual meeting for the election of officers of the Church of the Puritans was held in the Lecture-room of the Church last evening, the Pastor. Rev. Dr. CHEEVER, in the Chair. The meeting was opened, by a prayer from Mr. BERRY. The minutes of the last annual meeting were read, after which the reports of the Prudential Committee and of the Treasurer were called for, but as neither of them were ready, it was voted that they be presented at a meeting to be held on Tuesday evening, the 19th inst. The meeting then proceeded to the election of officers by ballot, members of the Church only voting. The following officers were elected, all of whom are supporters of Dr. CHEEVER, and received about two-thirds of the whole number of votes cast:

abstract: It is almost to be deplored as a misfortune for Congress to manifest, as it occasionally does, stray gleams of common sense and public spirit, so unhappy is its way of exhibiting them. Yesterday and the day before the House of Representatives afforded a striking example of this fact. Commencing its deliberations on Wednesday at 11 o'clock, it remained in continuous session until Thursday at 11 1/2 o'clock, -- vindicating the doctrine that the time of the House should not be wasted, by wasting two days of its time. It has grown, as the world too thoroughly knows, into a habit for members, who have no conceivable hope of influencing the action of others by what they say, and who have no thought of promoting the public good by sound or practicable suggestions, to speak for hours upon questions wholly irrelevant to the topic under consideration. These speeches, which seldom have a larger audience than a score of persevering representatives who lack other means of killing the hour, the reporters, and a few spectators straggling in or out of the gallery, appear next day in the Globe, and next week in a pamphlet, with which the country at large, and especially that portion of it represented by the drowsy orator, is presently deluged. Very frequently, we are assured, gentlemen are prompted by political committees outside to make and utter set speeches, that may serve for dissemination as partisan campaign documents, and that invaluable commodity, the time of the House, is drawn upon to initiate the circulation of these missives. So transparent, indeed, is the absurdity, that some of the more wise and modest refuse to visit the vacant House with their wisdom, contenting themselves with obtaining an imprimatur, authorizing the printing of the unuttered speech in the official record.

abstract: THE QUESTION OF ADJOURNMENT.  The House resolution for adjournment on the 18th was adopted in the Senate today by Democratic votes, only two Republicans voting for it. abstract: Edward Rowe vs. Wm. C. Burdick. -- This action was reported in the TIMES of yesterday, at which time it was on trial before Justice BOSWORTH, of the Superior Court, sitting at Tammany Hall. It is the suit brought to recover for brandy sold, and alleged to have been of bad quality. The trial now resulted in a verdict for the plaintiff for the amount claimed -- about $3,000 -- the jury finding, under the instructions of the Court, that if the defendant purchased by sample, it was his duty to examine the quality delivered at an early day, to see if it corresponded with the samples.

abstract: Russell Sturgis vs. The Steamboat Joseph Johnson. -- This was an action brought by the libelant, as the owner of the steam tug Achilles, to recover salvage for services rendered to the Joseph Johnson. On the 9th of March, 1855, the Joseph Johnson, a tug employed in towing vessels in and out of New York, and the schooner Henrico came in collision off the Jersey shore below Sandy Hook, by which collision the smoke pipe of the steamboat was carried away, as well as some of the wheel arms and buckets, and part of the wheel-house, and one end of her main shaft was thrown out of its bed. Her bowsprit was broken off and her upper joiner work injured. She Was disabled from using her steam power, and was left in an unavailable condition. Her master and one of her firemen remained on board the schooner when the vessels separated after the collision. Both vessels, thereupon, anchored for the night from half a mile to a mile from the shore. The wind was blowing fresh off shore all night, during which both vessels commenced drifting out to sea, and by nine or ten o'clock, on the morning of the 10th the Johnson had got nearly into deep water and out of the control of her anchor. The schooner's cable had parted, and she had drifted four or five miles further out to sea.

abstract: In response to a call to meet and ratify the nomination of LINCOLN and HAMLIN for the office of President and Vice-President of the United States, an exceedingly large number of Republicans congregated in and around Cooper Institute last evening. Nearly an hour before the time for organizing the meeting in the main hall, a cannon, placed in front of the Institute, and an excellent band of musicians on the balcony, kept the attention of those who had gathered outside until the doors were opened. At 7 3/4 o'clock the hall was two-thirds full, and at 8 o'clock, when the inside meeting was organized, the hall contained as many men as could be accommodated with sitting or standing room. The platform was filled by those who were named to address the meeting, by some of those who were named to act as officers, and by a number of gentlemen well known to the Republicans of the City. The rear of the platform was decorated with American flags, and a number of transparencies, on which were such inscriptions as the following:

abstract: Elizabeth N. Johnson vs. William S. Johnson. -- This is a suit by a wife against her husband, to procure a separation from bed and board, on the ground of alleged cruel and inhuman treatment. The parties are residents of this City, though married in Connecticut; and have three children. The complaint charges cruel and inhuman treatment of plaintiff in a great variety of instances. The answer denies these charges, and alleges improper conduct of the wife. The case is now on trial before Justice WOODRUFF, of the Superior Court.

abstract: ITEMS. -- A man named CAMEY was arrested on Wednesday night, while in the act of breaking into a carpenter's shop on Ross-street�. abstract: There was much enthusiasm during the evening in the square outside, where a large crowd had assembled to do honor to the Republican nominees. As two stands had been erected for the accommodation of speakers, quite a number, who would otherwise have occupied the hall, sensibly concluded to remain in the open air, and so escape the heat inside. During the evening the scene was exceedingly animated. An abundance of tar barrels had been provided, which, with Roman candles, skyrockets, double-readers, blue-lights, and other fireworks, fairly set the square in a blaze. As the "Rail-splitters" and the Republican Ward Clubs passed by in procession they were greeted with hearty cheers. A German Club, however, carried off the honors in this respect. About 9 o'clock in the evening, after the Clubs had all arrived, there must have been 3,000 on the square.

abstract: The Annual Statement of Mr. A.V. STOUT, City Chamberlain, to the Comptroller, after presenting in detail the manner in which the business of his office is transacted, and how the accounts are kept, refers to the fact that several of the Trust Funds are largely  overdrawn, and explains how the overdraft occurred. He says the accounts in the Comptroller's office were
lead_paragraph: The Annual Statement of Mr. A.V. STOUT, City Chamberlain, to the Comptroller, after presenting in detail the manner in which the business of his office is transacted, and how the accounts are kept, refers to the fact that several of the Trust Funds are largely overdrawn, and explains how the overdraft occurred. He says the accounts in the Comptroller's office were in such a confused state at the beginning of the year, that it was impossible to learn the condition of the various funds without much time and labor. Meanwhile, it being indispensable that payments should be made, there was no alternative but to go on and make them, while the investigations in the Comptroller's office were progressing, and as soon as the actual state of affairs should be ascertained, to make the proper adjustment. Accordingly a new set of books were opened. On completing the investigation of the old books in the Comptroller's Office, it was found that the "Assessment Fund" and "Street Improvement Fund" were each overdrawn for a large amount at the beginning of the year, and measures were immediately taken to replenish and supply the defic???encies. In relation to payments he says, it frequently happens that persons whose names are on the rolls are not found by the paying clerk, and do not call for their money, which prevents an early return of the rolls to the Comptroller's Office. As an improvement upon the present method, he recommends a return of the rolls with the names unpaid to the Comptroller's Office, and that the amounts due be deposited in the Treasury to the credit of "Unclaimed Warrants;" or, if preferred, the names unpaid to be transferred to new rolls for "back pay," and the amount left in the hands of the Paymasters, to be paid when called for. He complains that owing to the want of sufficient help and office-room, the present plan of making payments is very expensive to the Corporation. The laborers employed by the Croton Aqueduct Department are assembled every fortnight in the Park to receive their pay, an arrangement which results in the loss of from a quarter to a half a day's labor from each man to the City, as their pay goes on while they are waiting; and the same is true of the laborers employed in the City Inspector's Department. As there is a very large number of men employed, as named, the loss is considerable. He recommends that a suitable office be provided for the purpose, and authority given for the employment of a sufficient number of clerks, with proper sureties for the faithful performance of their duties. The cashier of the Shoe and Leather Bank certifies that there was on deposit in that Bank, Dec, 31, 1859, the sum of $4,030,504 15, belonging to the Corporation of the City of New-York; and that by order of the Chamberlain and County Treasurer, there was transferred from the account of the "County Treasury" to the credit of the "City Treasury," as on Dec. 31, 1859, the further sum of $273,863 72, making the total amount $4,304,367 87, which amount was standing to the credit of the following accounts, viz.:

abstract: AMERICAN AID FOR GARIBALDI. -- The Committee of Italians appointed by their countrymen in this City, to collect funds in aid of GARIBALDI and the revolutionary cause in Italy have already collected about $800, nearly all of which has been contributed within the last two days. From other sources, outside of the Committee, it is estimated that a larger sum has been collected, but the precise amount is not known. There are a number of wealthy persons in this City, Italians and others, who knew GARIBALBI when a candle-maker on Staten Island, and they stand ready to contribute liberally of their means should assistance be required. They are in hopes, however, of soon hearing that all Southern Italy, as well as Sicily, has been revolutionized without foreign aid, but should BOMBA, Jr., be able to protract the struggle for any length of time, not only money, but probably men and arms would be sent from this City. The Committee who have the matter in charge held a meeting on Tuesday evening last, and will hold an other shortly, to take measures to call a public meeting in aid of Italy, and to express American sympathy for the patriot cause. A Committee of prominent Americans will also be appointed to receive subscriptions. Mr. O. FABRICOTTA, a wealthy Italian merchant in this City, sailed in the Persia on Wednesday, for Europe. He is a member of the Committee in this City, and although he has private business in Northern Italy, it is understood that he conveys some substantial expressions of good-will from the Italians in this country to the patriots at home. The following are the gentlemen to whom has been intrusted the collection of funds for the Italian cause, viz.: E.P. FABBRI, No.66 Broadway; M. PASTACALDI, NO.87 Pearl-street; and J.VALARIO, NO. 40 Beaver-street.

abstract: There was a very large gathering of Republicans at Cooper Institute last evening, for the purpose of indorsing the action of the National Convention which met at Chicago. The main hall of the Institute was well filled, and there were several thousand persons anxious to listen to the
lead_paragraph: There was a very large gathering of Republicans at Cooper Institute last evening, for the purpose of indorsing the action of the National Convention which met at Chicago. The main hall of the Institute was well filled, and there were several thousand persons anxious to listen to the proceedings, who, as they could not get near the platform, organized a meeting outside. Mr. R.M. BLATCHFORD presided over the principal meeting, and speeches were made by Messrs. Wm. M. Evarts Rusch of Iowa, G.W. Curtis, H. Greeley, Wm. H. Fry, Judge Tracy, of California, Gen. B.F. Bruce and Gen. James W. Nye. The speeches were all spirited; nearly all acknowledged to having been greviously disappointed because Senator SEWARD had not received the nomination, but all of them expressed a determination to give to the nominations a hearty support. Resolutions indorsing LINCOLN and HAMLIN, were passed unanimously, and at 11 o'clock, after a glee from a Glee Club present, the meeting separated.

abstract: If the Committees of the Common Council of New-York City were invested with a jurisdiction to examine and decide all claims that should be made against its Treasury, on the showing and the testimony of the parties, produced in writing, not exposed to the sifting of a cross-examination nor the analysis of an opposing counsel, we apprehend that the City would be even more extensively robbed and plundered than it is at present.
lead_paragraph: If the Committees of the Common Council of New-York City were invested with a jurisdiction to examine and decide all claims that should be made against its Treasury, on the showing and the testimony of the parties, produced in writing, not exposed to the sifting of a cross-examination nor the analysis of an opposing counsel, we apprehend that the City would be even more extensively robbed and plundered than it is at present. That a jurisdiction of this nature can be more honestly and intelligently exercised by Committees of the House of Representatives and of the Senate of the United States, under the supervision of the House and the Senate, than by the Committees of our Common Council, we see no reason to suppose. In the case of the Federal Legislature there is only a more diluted responsibility -- as it is diffused among a larger number of individuals. We have no doubt that Congress should repudiate entirely all jurisdiction of private claims, and all appeals to its generosity or liberality. It has exhausted its constitutional functions when it has passed general laws for administering the relations between the Government and its citizens. Whether or not a given case comes within those laws, so as to entitle a citizen to their benefit, is purely a judicial question, with which Congress ought to have nothing to do.

abstract: We are suddenly plunged into another Indian war. The savages have risen in the Carson Valley; the whole region form Walker's Lake to Pyramid Lake is said to be alive with them. They have daubed on the full war-paint, and taken their women and children to Regtown, on the Carson River, a little west of where it sinks into Carson Lake.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Monday, April 16, 1860.

abstract: The various projects of private gain at national expense, disguised under the name of State tonnage duties, are beginning to manifest their true characteristics. The project of handing over the commerce of the Red River to the impositions of a private company, yesterday received the assent, in advance, of the House of Representatives, and will hardly meet any effectual resistance in the Senate. It will be closely followed up by Senator SLIDELL's proposition, now pending in that body, consenting to the virtual grant for twenty-five years to a private company of the Pass a lï¿½Outre, the most important outlet of the Missippi.

abstract: BODY FOUND. -- The body of an unknown man was taken out of the water at Fort Hamilton yesterday, and an inquest held by Coroner BENNET. AS there were no indications of violence about the body, the jury rendered the usual verdict of “found drowned.” The deceased had on brown pants, black black coat, coarse boots and white shirt. On the bosom of the shirt was marked “J.D. Butman.”

abstract: The intelligence which we published yesterday, of the failure of the mercantile house of JECKER & Co. in Mexico, has a good deal of importance in its bearing upon public affairs in that country. This house has played a very conspicuous part in sustaining the rotten fabric of priestcraft and tyranny which has so long oppressed the energies of the Mexican people. Its members are among the last of that long line of adventurers who have come from Europe for the purpose of preying upon the ignorance and necessities of the Mexicans; -- and their failure affords good reason to hope that the race of mercenary plunderers has at last come to an end. The fact that GABRIAC, the French Minister, who has made his diplomatic character the cloak for his mercenary and unprincipled projects, shares the misfortunes of his accomplices, will afford very general satisfaction in the community which has suffered so deeply from his schemes. And the lesson will not be lost upon those partisans of the Miramon misrule in this country, whose faith has been sustained by drafts upon the establishment which has now been ruined by its reliance upon this base and fraudulent Government.

abstract: The People ex rel. William Mitchell vs. Robert T. Haws. -- In this case, the realtor set forth that, by virtue of the act of 1852, the salaries of the Justices of Supreme Court were increased from, the former compensation allowed them. The plaintiff, in April, 1859, sent in a communication to the Board of Supervisors, which body, on the 16th day of August, 1859, passed a resolution directing the Comptroller to pay the plaintiff the sum of $8,350. This sum was inserted on the tax levy, and paid into the City treasury. Payment of the money was demanded of the defendant, who is the Comptroller of the City of New-York, which was refused. Thereupon the plaintiff obtained an alternative mandamus from Justice LEONARD, directing the defendant to pay the said sum, or to show cause for his refusal.

abstract: Netwithstanding the storm last evening, there was a very large gathering of citizens in response to a call upon all lovers of the Union, the Constitution and the laws, commerce, manufactures and agricultural who would rebuke sectionalism, fanaticism, &c., to meet and ratify the nomination of BELL and EVERETT. The room was filled long before the hour for the commencement of the proceedings, and while the audience was awaiting the organization, a band of musicians discoursed national airs, while cannon and fireworks outside reminded all in the vicinity that the nomination of BELL and EVERETT was about to be ratified. During the intervals between the performances of the band, the appearance of various well-known local politicians was greeted with applause. At 8 o’clock, on motion of J. Dr. PEYSTER CODEN, Esq., Gen. F.A. TALLMADGE was elected unanimously to preside over the meeting.

abstract: SHOCKING CASUALTY -- A MAN KILLED. -- Just before 6 o’clock last evening CORNELIUS BRESNEHAN, a young man, residing at the corner of Whitehall and Pearl streets, had his brains crushed out by the fall of the gable-end of the two-story brick building No. 23 Washington-street The premises were in process of demolition, and deceased, who was the driver of a dirt-cart, had stopped with quite a large number of men, women and children, living in the neighbor-hood, to gather fire-wood in the ruins. The only part of the building which remained at the time of the accident was the gable-end, and in endeavoring to pull a heavy beam from beneath a mass of bricks, the wall was shaken so violently that it suddenly fell -- the bricks apparently covering the whole of the wood-gatherers, and it seems wonderful that a dozen lives were not lost instead of one. Several persons, however, received severe bruises, and one man had his leg broken. Officer HEALEY and other Policemen were soon at the scene, rendering assistance to the wounded, and the body of BRESNEHAN, who must have been instantly killed, was removed to the Trinity-place Station-house, where an inquest will be held upon it to-day.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 24th, on the motion of Lord PALMERSTON, a Committee of Ten was appointed to inspect the journals of the House of Lords for any proceedings upon the rejection of the bill repealing the paper duty. The Committee subsequently reported, pro forma, that they found the Lords had rejected the bill in question, and Lord PALMERSTON then gave notice that he would move for the appointment of a Committee to search for precedents.

abstract: At about 2 1/2 o’clock, yesterday afternoon, an explosion took place in the packing and finishing department of Messrs. J.W. HADFIELD & SON’s pyrotechnic establishment, situated near the Williamsburgh and Jamaica Turnpike, at a place known as East Williamsburgh, in Newtown, Queens County, by which: two men -- CHARLES HADFIELD, one of the owners, and JACOB CREIG, an employe, were instantly killed. JOHN HULER was mortally injured and HENRY HADFIELD, a brother of deceased, ROBERT SRINDEE and about a dozen other persons were slightly injured.

abstract: An invitation to “All lovers of the Union, the Constitution, and the laws; and to all friends of commerce, manufactures and agriculture,” to meet at Cooper Institute last evening, for the purpose of ratifying the nomination of Mr. BELL and Mr. EVERETT, drew together several thousand persons, who ratified the nominations unanimously, and applauded the speakers without stint. Hon F.A. TALLMADGE presided, and the report of the doings of the Baltimore Convention was read by Hon. ERASTUS BROOKS. Speeches were made by Hon. JAMES M. QUARLES and Hon. GUSTAVUS A. HENRY, of Tennessee, and Hon. ZEBULON B. VANCE, of North Carolina. The principal speech of the evening was made by Mr. HENRY, who spoke for two hours and a half, reviewing the positions of the Democratic and Republican parties, and arguing that the union Party is the only party that can restore peace to the entire country. During the meeting an extract was read from Hon. MILLARD FILLMORE, to the effect that he would vote for BELL and EVΈRETΓ, even if his should be the only vote cast for them in this state.

HENRY, of Tennessee, and Hon. ZEBULON B. VANCE, of North Carolina. The principal speech of the evening was made by Mr. HENRY, who spoke for two hours and a half, reviewing the positions of the Democratic and Republican parties, and arguing that the union Party is the only party that can restore peace to the entire country. During the meeting an extract was read from Hon. MILLARD FILLMORE, to the effect that he would vote for BELL and EVΈRETΓ, even if his should be the only vote cast for them in this state.

abstract: -- The political devotees of the No-Platform Party in this City, with a seeming prescience of the fate that awaits them, -- a foresight all the more striking by contrast with their previous exhibitions of blindness concerning probable future events -- yesterday afternoon mounted a large bell on one of “HERRING’s Patent Safe” transporters, which was drawn through Broadway and other streets by a long train of horses decked with funeral plumes, while the bell (where Everitt went) tolled an anticipatory knell of the party’s death. The sides of the vehicle were draped in huge posters announcing the delivery of eulogies at Cooper Institute in the evening, and numerous mourners with saddened faces occupied places on the bier. Many were the jeers, among the unthinking crowd through which the pageant passed, at the “long tongue and empty head” that so well typified the party organization. And one unfeeling wretch ventured the prediction, that the Bell would be wrung in despair before Everett was raised to a position at Washington. An erroneous opinion very generally prevailed among the spectators, that the spectacle was only designed as an advertisement of the Bell and Everett meeting; we charitably pronounce this view erroneous, for we are unwilling to believe that that five so noble-looking horses, and a company of so fine-appearing men as those engaged in this display would consent to become mere migratory bulletin boards, like those men of humbler aspiration, whom merchants hire to promenade the streets, tattoed as extensively as a New-Zealander, with business advertisements. If, however, we are wrong, and the members of the party really did resort to the clap-trap of escorting a bell through the City, for the purpose of ringing changes on their candidate’s name, we shall next expect to see rival politicians of a different school indulging in the pleasing amusement of riding a rail through Broadway, and the disciples of DOUGLAS typifying the nomme de gloire of that statesman by contracting with BARNUM for his little giant, and bearing him through the City on their shoulders.

abstract: The Chamber of Commerce seems to have put itself out of temper very unnecessarily on Thursday, upon the subject of privateering. A majority of the Committee of the Chamber recommended the opening by the President of negotiations with European powers, for the purpose of securing the immunity of private property at sea in time of war. This the President has declared would be of no use, unless at the same time the practice of blockading commercial ports were also abolished. To this the Committee reply that even if ports were blockaded, any merchant vessels that happened to be outside would be safe, and be enabled to continue their business between neutral, and even enemy’s ports. The minority of the Committee, however, Messrs. ROYAL PHELPS and JOHN D. JONES, are so impressed with the importance of privateering to the United States that they refuse to consider any proposal for its abolition, and recommended that the whole subject be laid on the table. A good deal of wrangling between the two parties attended the reading of the reports, which seems to us to have been a very unnecessary expenditure of warmth, in view of the fact that there is not the slightest probability that the European Powers will agree, either at the approaching Congress, or any other Congress that will be held in our day, either to respect private property at sea in time of war, or to abandon the blockade of commercial ports.

abstract: George Beecher and Seven Others. -- A portion of the crew of the ship W.H. Starer were put on trial this morning, charged with revolt and mutiny on board that vessel, in this harbor, on the 23d May. The case is so recent that the testimony need not be given in full. The substance of it was, that when the ship was about to sail, and the crew were called to heave at the windlass, they refused duty, and on the officers understanding to enforce obedience a fight ensued, in which the crew used behaving-pins, land-spikes and pistols, overpowered the officers and crove them aft, and had control of the deck for half or three-quarters of an hour, until the Harbor Police were called by a signal, and coming on board took the defendants into custody. They were identified as having been actively engaged in the affair. The evidence for the defence did not tend to contradict the facts stated by the witnesses for the prosecution. Some witnesses gave Craig, one of the defendants, a good character as being peaceable.

abstract: This intelligence is furnished, in some good measure at least, by newspapers already established and ably conducted; but THE WORLD has originated in the widely-prevalent feeling that the time has come for living Christianity to assert itself in secular journalism more positively than it has yet done, and will adapt itself to that acknowledged want.
lead_paragraph: This intelligence is furnished, in some good measure at least, by newspapers already established and ably conducted; but THE WORLD has originated in the widely-prevalent feeling that the time has come for living Christianity to assert itself in secular journalism more positively than it has yet done, and will adapt itself to that acknowledged want. Neither as summing nor seeking to be a preacher of religious doctrine, it will yet recognize, in all its judgments upon the practical affairs of life, the authority and efficacy of Christian principles. Its capital has been supplied by members of various religious denominations, and it will do its work without bias, on the common ground of the great primal Christian truths.

abstract: Reports of Congressional proceedings for the last two or three days represent the House of Representatives as dealing with the question of the Missouri contested election, as if it  were a matter of quite as little moment as any private lobby scheme for plunder.
lead_paragraph: Reports of Congressional proceedings for the last two or three days represent the House of Representatives as dealing with the question of the Missouri contested election, as if it were a matter of quite as little moment as any private lobby scheme for plunder. After half the term for which Representatives are elected has passed, the question of a sitting member’s right to his place so nearly reaches a settlement as to have had the testimony all taken, and permission to sum up granted to the rival claimants, when the House wastes its time in a dispute concerning the order in which the speeches shall be made, until the day’s session nearly dies a natural death, and is at length adjourned over. Meantime the matter remains undecided, whether a great constituency shall be represented in the National Legislature by a man whom the majority of a District have elected, or by one whose claims to the post are supported only by the wishes of a minority. A question like this is one of too grave importance to be treated with careless neglect. The delay of judicial tribunals in awarding justice between private citizens in matters of merely personal interest, is often the subject of most just complaint. How much greater and more to be avoided is that delay of justice which affects the interests, not of one, but of thousands.

abstract: Presbyterians and Congregationalists, the two denominations whose contributions support the Home Missionary Society in its operations, are seriously at variance, and a withdrawal of the former of these bodies from the organization seems inevitable. The subject occupied much of the time of the New School General Assembly, at its late session in Pittsburg, and resulted in the adoption, of resolutions to the following effect. Regret was expressed at the embarrassed position regarding the Society which the denomination occupied, as well as at the determined opposition made by the leading Congregational associations of New-England to the course which, the Assembly has deemed it its duty to pursue. This policy is reaffirmed, although a desire is expressed to effect a good understanding with Congregationalists, and all disposition to take advantage of them in the cooperation, or to assent to any right which is not freely accorded to them, is deprecated. It is also made the duty of the Assembly’s Committee to endeavor to secure such an understanding as will lead to an equitable and final settlement of the whole question, and to recommend to the next General assembly such plans and measures pertaining to the Home Missionary work as they may deem necessary for its future prosperity. Finally, all intention of directing the contributions of the churches in any particular channel is disclaimed. The Evangelist for the present week reviews the present position of this question, at much length. It, of course, sustains the action of the Assembly, and declares its opinion that the separation of the two denominations in the Home Missionary work, so for as the main body of the churches is concerned, is near at hand, notwithstanding these attempts at reconciliation. This result, it thinks, will be advantageous in the end to both parties, as it will stimulate each to greater exertions. Under the heading of the “Self-excision of the New School Presbyterians,” the Independent discusses the same topic. It thinks that the present state of affairs has grown not from a decline of Christian charity, but from the growth of an ecclesiastical polity. The scheme of conference proposed by the Assembly it pronounces wholly impracticable, as the General Associations which are expected to appoint delegates for conference do not represent the churches at all. Nor, if they did represent the 1,200 Congregational Churches in New-England, would those out of that section consent to their adjudication in the matter. The Independent agrees with the Evangelist that an end of cooperation by the two Societies in the Home Mission work is inevitable.
lead_paragraph: Presbyterians and Congregationalists, the two denominations whose contributions support the Home Missionary Society in its operations, are seriously at variance, and a withdrawal of the former of these bodies from the organization seems inevitable. The subject occupied much of the time of the New School General Assembly, at its late session in Pittsburg, and resulted in the adoption, of resolutions to the following effect. Regret was expressed at the embarrassed position regarding the Society which the denomination occupied, as well as at the determined opposition made by the leading Congregational associations of New-England to the course which, the Assembly has deemed it its duty to pursue. This policy is reaffirmed, although a desire is expressed to effect a good understanding with Congregationalists, and all disposition to take advantage of them in the cooperation, or to assent to any right which is not freely accorded to them, is deprecated. It is also made the duty of the Assembly’s Committee to endeavor to secure such an understanding as will lead to an equitable and final settlement of the whole question, and to recommend to the next General assembly such plans and measures pertaining to the Home Missionary work as they may deem necessary for its future prosperity. Finally, all intention of directing the contributions of the churches in any particular channel is disclaimed. The Evangelist for the present week reviews the present position of this question, at much length. It, of course, sustains the action of the Assembly, and declares its opinion that the separation of the two denominations in the Home Missionary work, so for as the main body of the churches is concerned, is near at hand, notwithstanding these attempts at reconciliation. This result, it thinks, will be advantageous in the end to both parties, as it will stimulate each to greater exertions. Under the heading of the “Self-excision of the New School Presbyterians,” the Independent discusses the same topic. It thinks that the present state of affairs has grown not from a decline of Christian charity, but from the growth of an ecclesiastical polity. The scheme of conference proposed by the Assembly it pronounces wholly impracticable, as the General Associations which are expected to appoint delegates for conference do not represent the churches at all. Nor, if they did represent the 1,200 Congregational Churches in New-England, would those out of that section consent to their adjudication in the matter. The Independent agrees with the Evangelist that an end of cooperation by the two Societies in the Home Mission work is inevitable.

abstract: The moment a man becomes a candidate for the Presidency he is open to persecution in varied forms. Not only do his opponents feel justified in overwhelming him with abuse, but his friends err in the opposite extreme by fairly smothering him with ill-judged praise. The early incidents of his boy-life are dug from oblivion. Everything that he did after emerging from pinafores to trousers becomes known to the discriminating public, and nothing but the difficulty of gathering data prevents zealous inquirers from going back to his cradle-days, and learning from his nurse if he took kindly to Godfrey’s Cordial. In that chaotic period when boyhood ends, while it would be unfair to say that manhood begins, his doings are made the subject of vigilant scrutiny; and Heaven help him if he has ever been led astray by the warm passions of youth, and indulged in worse dissipation than sermons and soda-water. The journals of the day make mirrors of their columns, and in the reflection one is puzzled to know whether he should worship a saint, or give his vote in the coming election to defeat a devil.

abstract: The Berean Baptist Church in Bedford-street was last evening filled with a deeply interested audience to listen to a farewell discourse of the pastor, Rev. Dr. DOWLING, on the occasion of his taping leave for a temporary visit to Europe. The text was the...
lead_paragraph: The Berean Baptist Church in Bedford-street was last evening filled with a deeply interested audience to listen to a farewell discourse of the pastor, Rev. Dr. DOWLING, on the occasion of his taping leave for a temporary visit to Europe. The text was the 20th verse of the 33d chapter of Genesis: "And he erected there an altar, and called it Elelahe-Israel." This verse referred, said the preacher, to the history of Jacob in that celebrated passage of his life where he went forth to meet his irate brother Esau, and propitiated him with gifts, setting up an altar to tine Most High in token of gratitude for his providential deliverance. The present occasion was one calling for particular acknowledgements on his, the preach ear's part, to God for the manifold mercies which he had experienced during his labors as a pastor for over a quarter of a century, He arrived in this country over twenty eight years ago, during the cholera season, and shortly after landing, curing his temporary absence, both his wit and infant child were stricken down by that disease, and his wife was buried before be could. return. The recital these and other trials during the early part of his ministerial career, deeply after end the audience. Of the twenty-five years or his ministerial, function had been spent in this City eight in Rhode is land, and the remainder in Catskill and Philadelphia. From several of these places he saw old and familiar faces of friends before him. In Philadelphia, cats kill, Newport and Providence he had been blessed with revivals during his pastoral labors, and may had been added to the Church. During the ten years of his last pastorate of this church 324 had been added to toe Church. Which, wish 281 admitted during the paid of his first engagement, made a total of 605 -- of whom he had baptized ever 100. Of the whole number who were members when the church was first formed, only seven survived, and of the 400 members when he returned to the church in 1844 only 76 removed, -- all the rest had gone, and many of them had been removed by death. There were now 474 members, which was more than at any form period of the church five expressed his forwent there as for the many manifestations of kindness and friendship which he had received from the check, and invoked the blessing or god open his charge while he should be absent from them. He cloud by an appeal to the unconverted portion or the audience, using the language of Paul: "I take you to witness this day that I am clear from the blood of all men" The 438 b hymen was sung -- "Here we meet to part a gain," the audience joining, and the services were concluded by prayer and the benediction.
