abstract: George Law and Gustavus A. Conover vs. The  United States. This is a matter arising out of the defalcation of the late Postmaster Fowler. The oill alleges that Fowler was appointed Deputy Postmaster at the city of New-York by President Pierce during the recess of the Senate, on May 4, 1857, and...
lead_paragraph: George Law and Gustavus A. Conover vs. The United States. This is a matter arising out of the defalcation of the late Postmaster Fowler. The oill alleges that Fowler was appointed Deputy Postmaster at the city of New-York by President Pierce during the recess of the Senate, on May 4, 1857, and thereupon the complainants and Oliver Charlick executed an official bond for him in the penalty of $50,000; that afterwards, on the 17th of May, 1858, he was nominated to the Senate for the post, and his nomination being confirmed, it became necessary for him to file n new bond, That on or about Sept. 20, 1858, he applied to the complainants to become such sureties, exhibiting to them a bond for $75,000 signed by himself alone, having the names of the obligors in blank, but with four seals affixed to it, and stating to them that he was going to get Charlick to execute the bond with them; they at his request, and on that understanding, severally executed the bond and delivered it to Fowler in escrow merely. That Fowler was at that time a defaulter to the amount of $90,000, which they knew nothing of, and they would not have signed his bond at all if they had known of it; that Fowler being importuned by the officers of the Government to file his bond, and not being able to find Charlick, to have him execute the bond, filed the bond executed only by the complainants; that Charlick never executed the bond, but they were unaware of that fact.

abstract: The force of impudence has rarely, if ever, gone further than it went in the Court of General Sessions on Friday. A gambler and poli-...
lead_paragraph: The force of impudence has rarely, if ever, gone further than it went in the Court of General Sessions on Friday. A gambler and politician, named RILEY, combined about a month ago with a number of other rowdies in hooting and insulting a man named LUMAN, who was peaceably passing along Broadway at about 12 o’clock at night. LUMAN was naturally irritated, and threatened, if they were hooting at him, to “punch them.” RILEY thereupon struck at him, and immediately afterwards, without any further provocation, drew a revolver and fired at him twice. The first shot only grazed the side of his head, and, as if determined to murder him, the assailant thereupon fired another, which passed through his neck, luckily only inflicting a flesh wound. To this charge the fellow pleaded guilty, relying, doubtless, upon his standing as a Ward politician to come off harmless.

abstract: By the arrival of the Coatzacoalcos, from Havana, we are placed in possession of our City of Mexico correspondence, brought from Vera Cruz by the English steamer in the unprecedented time of eleven days. The particulars of the failure of...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Coatzacoalcos, from Havana, we are placed in possession of our City of Mexico correspondence, brought from Vera Cruz by the English steamer in the unprecedented time of eleven days. The particulars of the failure of the house of J.B. JRCKER & Co., the Government bankers, are thus received. The event, it appears, was not wholly unexpected, as it was understood that the Liberal Government would, upon its advent to power, repudiate all the transactions of JECKER with the Miramon usurpation. The recent advantages obtained by the Liberals had precipitated the result; the impression that the actual status must shortly terminate gaining ground, and on the 17th of May, the run upon the banker commenced. One million dollars were paid that day; but as six hundred thousand dollars were necessary to meet the requirements of the ensuing day, and were not on hand or procurable, the Bank failed to open on the 18th. A meeting of creditors was at once held, where it was learned that the foreign obligations of the house amounted to $1,300,000, while its home debt was $3,200,000, a total of $4,500,000. The assets were represented by mining property, $1,100,000; Government loans, $2,300,000; miscellaneous credits $3,600,000. JECKEP. desired four years’ extension in which to pay principal and interest, which his creditors are disposed to concede. The political news is of further disasters sustained by the Church Party in Durango, the leaders, RAMIREZ and CAJEN, having been utterly routed. URAGA continues to retain his superiority over the Reactionists. Should no reverse obstruct his advance, the reestablishment of the Liberal Government in the capital is looked for during the current month. By telegraph from New-Orleans we have advices to the 4th from Tampico, stating that URAGA had captured Guadalajara, but it had been regained by Gen. WOLL. The improbability of this story is sufficiently shown in the letter of our correspondent.

abstract: On the night of the 4th inst., a man named THOMAS Cox, residing at No. 90 Mulberry-street, and employed as a Eight watchman by a store-keeper in Chatham street, was found by the Sixth Ward Police insensible from injuries he had received in an encounter with some unknown persons at the corner of Mulberry and Chatham streets. He was removed to Bellevue Hospital, where his death resulted on Friday, from compression of the brain. Coroner SCHIRMER has commenced an investigation of the circumstances, and JOHN SULLIVAN, a lad 14 years of age, is in custody on suspicion of having given the fatal blow, another lad having sworn that he saw Cox fall, and SULLIVAN run from the spot, with a club in his hand, which he afterwards threw away. Information has been received by the Police that a man named HOGAN instigated the assault upon Cox, because he failed to obtain the situation of night watchman, which the deceased filled at the time he was beaten, but the evidence so far taken by the Coroner does not support the statement.
lead_paragraph: On the night of the 4th inst., a man named THOMAS Cox, residing at No. 90 Mulberry-street, and employed as a Eight watchman by a store-keeper in Chatham street, was found by the Sixth Ward Police insensible from injuries he had received in an encounter with some unknown persons at the corner of Mulberry and Chatham streets. He was removed to Bellevue Hospital, where his death resulted on Friday, from compression of the brain. Coroner SCHIRMER has commenced an investigation of the circumstances, and JOHN SULLIVAN, a lad 14 years of age, is in custody on suspicion of having given the fatal blow, another lad having sworn that he saw Cox fall, and SULLIVAN run from the spot, with a club in his hand, which he afterwards threw away. Information has been received by the Police that a man named HOGAN instigated the assault upon Cox, because he failed to obtain the situation of night watchman, which the deceased filled at the time he was beaten, but the evidence so far taken by the Coroner does not support the statement.

abstract: We sympathized to some extent with Mr. PRYOR of the House of Representatives in his attack upon the Congressional Globe, in view of its being a warfare waged in the spirit, and not with such fleshly weapons as bowie-knives and revolvers. But we are not sure that it...
lead_paragraph: We sympathized to some extent with Mr. PRYOR of the House of Representatives in his attack upon the Congressional Globe, in view of its being a warfare waged in the spirit, and not with such fleshly weapons as bowie-knives and revolvers. But we are not sure that it would please us to see the Globe extirpated. We find it so useful, occasionally, in tracing the progress of a bill, -- so valuable as a record of everything that is done and said in the two great Houses at Washington, -- that if it could be confined to what actually transpires there, we should wish that Mr. RIVES and his work might be immortal. It is a grievous abuse and nuisance, however, that this record should be made the medium of fraud as well as folly. Silly speeches will continue to be delivered as long as the Capitol stands, and we are willing that the people should pay for printing them; but why they should pay for printing silly speeches that are not delivered we have never been able to understand. Unless the official reporter there can be made to confine himself to the record of all the business of Congress, and to the speeches that are actually made in Congress, we shall be disposed to join Mr. PRYOR in his efforts to abate a nuisance.

abstract: The Japanese Envoys are at last on their way to New-York. They have seen the last of the American Tycoon, "His Majesty the President;" the last of Washington hotels...
lead_paragraph: The Japanese Envoys are at last on their way to New-York. They have seen the last of the American Tycoon, "His Majesty the President;" the last of Washington hotels and Washington hacks, of affectionate little negroes making advances of friendship to them through carriage windows, and of inquisitive young ladies inspecting them at the table and at the toilet, with, a thirst for knowledge and an innocence of evil perhaps unrivalled since the days before the fall. They are still undergoing a good deal of complimenting and parading, however, at Philadelphia, the Fathers of that friendly city having resolved, as the faithful telegraph assures us, to “outdo the metropolis with a third of the capital;” and they are probably destined to “pay with their persons,” as the French express it, for the determination with which BOOLE and VAN TINE will resent this insolent pretension of the rectangular Quakers, when their Excellencies and suite shall be fairly caged in the Metropolitan.

abstract: The Democratic cauldron is beginning to boil again. The time for another attempt at nominating a Presidential candidate is close at hand. The Southern veins of the party meets this week at Richmond. -- the Northern wing next week at Baltimore. The Richmond convocation will be merely preliminary. It will do nothing of any consequence, but will await the action of the Baltimoreans Possibly it may pass some resolutions, -- declare the unalterable determination of the Southern Democrats never to surrender the ground they took at Charleston, and make a tender of renewed harmony on these conditions. But they will make no nominations, and take no decisive action in advance of the other Convention.

lead_paragraph: Steamship Coatzacoaleos, Wilson, New Orleans June 2, at 8 A.M., via Havana 5th, 1 P.M. Arr. off Battery at 8:46 A.M., 9th, with mds and passengers to Walter Carloutt. In lat. 37.20, lon. 75, passed a propeiler strg, S.B.W. During the passage from Havana a passenger, named W.H. Mount, or New-York, who was brought on board in New-Orleans in the last stage of consumption died on the morning of the 6th at 6 A.M., and was buried same day at 10 A.M. with the usual ceremonies on such occasions. Capt Wilson reading the service usual to the Episcopal Church, in the presence of the officers, crew and passengers. His effects are in the hands of the purser. Mr. John A. Diamond.

abstract: THE FAIRBANKS SCALES. -- Two brothers, sons of a miller in the northern part of Vermont, having occasion for a more convenient method of weighing a bulky article than the old-fashioned hay scales, contrived a more simple plan for the mechanism, for which they took out a patent in 1830. The result was so satisfactory that they applied the principle, with progressive improvements, to other descriptions of scales, until they now furnish upwards of one hundred varieties of scales, the largest of which will weigh a loaded canal-boat of a hundred tons, and so down to the nicest bank or jewel scales.
lead_paragraph: THE FAIRBANKS SCALES. -- Two brothers, sons of a miller in the northern part of Vermont, having occasion for a more convenient method of weighing a bulky article than the old-fashioned hay scales, contrived a more simple plan for the mechanism, for which they took out a patent in 1830. abstract: Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, the distinguished Baltimore lawyer, Ex-Attorney-General of the United States, quondam Henry Clay Whig, but more recently Douglas Democrat, arrived in this City Saturday afternoon, and took rooms at the Fifth-avenue Hotel,
lead_paragraph: Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON, the distinguished Baltimore lawyer, Ex-Attorney-General of the United States, quondam Henry Clay Whig, but more recently Douglas Democrat, arrived in this City Saturday afternoon, and took rooms at the Fifth-avenue Hotel, where, at a late hour in the evening, he received the compliment of a serenade, given by the Douglas Committee of this City, representing, among other prominent citizens, the names of Wm. F. Havemeyer, Francis B. Cutting, A.V. Stout, Auguste Belmont, Moses Taylor, Edward C. West, John E Devlin and John Clancy. Dodworth's Band was engaged for the occasion, and at about 10 o'clock it appeared in front of the Hotel, and commenced playing some of its favorite airs. A crowd of five hundred or more persons soon collected about the Hotel, the balconies and windows of which were filled with ladies, and the band had scarcely finished the first air before calls began to be made for "JOHNSON." These constantly increased in frequency and force, until at length Mr. JOHNSON made his appearance on the balcony, and was introduced to the audience by Mr. ANDREW V. STOUT. He began by expressing his indebtedness to his visitors for the honor of their call -- an honor which he prized the more highly, as it conveyed an assurance to his mind that the views he entertained of the political condition of the country, and the policy best adapted to restore it to peace and harmony, met with the concurrence of his follow-citizens. There was no concealing the fact that sectional stride was last endangering the peace and security, it not the very existence, of the Republic, and??? this strife could be adjusted upon some fair and permanent basis, there was reason to apprehend the worse results. Was there no such basis? He believed there was. It was to leave the subject of that strife to be disposed of ay each politically organized community as it, might think best, Slavery in the States was universally admitted, except by a few fanatics, to be exclusively within the control of the people of??? state, and entirely beyond the jurisdiction of other States, or of the General Government. The results of this policy had been good; under it, no State had been agitated by its own management of the Slavery question. Why should not this right of managing their own concerns, and directing their own policy, be entrusted to every people having governmental power legally obtained? It was a matter that concerned themselves alone; their infancy as a Territory would soon ripen into manhood as a State, and then, it was conceded on all bands, this power would rest with them. Why deny the power while the people are preparing for manhood? Whatever disposition they might make of the question, they were the better and the sooner prepared for entire State sovereignty. At any late he??? was done. Unlike Congressional Interference which had always been??? to the South, and as they believed contrary to their Congressional rights, this principle of non-intervene??? made it an their??? own. Slavery was defended as a local Scale institution. It was the??? and properly claimed, to he a domestic concern, over which the people of other states had no control, and with which they bad no??? This was the ground which the South had always occupied, and it was the true ground. It was the ground held by Judge DOUGLAS, whose policy upon this whole subject was the true policy. He was in favor of the nomination of Mr. DOUGLAS for the Presidency, because he was confident of his satiny to??? it, and of his firmness and honesty to stand by it; because not only in this had he been just to the South, but he believed that in the future, as in the past, he would be faithful to all her rights.[Applause] Because he had at my national heart, and a mind to comprehend the interests of all sections of the Confederacy; because, not being instance with one idea, and imbued with mistaken??? fanaticism, he was true to the rights of all, he guaranteed by the Constitution. [Great cheering]

abstract: The festival in aid of the fund of the Steuben Monument Association, which occurred yesterday at Elm Park, drew together some fifteen hundred persons, a number which would have been considerably increased but for the fact that similar festivities were going on at the same time at Yorkville.
lead_paragraph: The festival in aid of the fund of the Steuben Monument Association, which occurred yesterday at Elm Park, drew together some fifteen hundred persons, a number which would have been considerably increased but for the fact that similar festivities were going on at the same time at Yorkville. The Steuben Guard, Capt. SHEPPER, of Brooklyn; Bayers', the Volk's Garten and Wannemacher's braes-bands, aided by some half a dozen Glee Club, furnished the music The company was on the ground at 2 o'clock P.M., and soon afterwards scattered in groups, or strolled in couples about the grounds enjoying themselves, singing and dancing, until 3 o'clock P.M. At that hour Dr. ZEUSCHNER, the President of the Association, called the meeting to order, and introduced Mr. OTTENDORFER, one of the editors of the Staats Zeitung, who addressed the a assemblage from the orchestra stand. The speaker proceeded to remark upon those characteristics of Baron STEUBEN which made him not only a fit representative of the great men who aided in the achievement of our independence, but which enabled him by his practical ideas, his indomitable energy, to take in hand the scattered and almost disorganized American forces, and bring them into the condition of well-trained soldiers. His practical genius was exhibited when, finding the Government struggling with embarrassment, and unable to complete the defences in the harbor of New York, he recommended all the German citizens to give one day's labor to finish the fortifications; which suggestion they promptly obeyed, and on the 5th of June, 1791, turned o??? masse, and aided to finish the works on Governor's Island. The same spirit manifested among the German population of to-day, would soon secure the required amount to erect the monument to his memory.

abstract: The Neapolitan Bour  bons, if men of their race could be supposed capable of instruction, might be pronounced to be in a fair way of learning the value of a character.
lead_paragraph: The Neapolitan Bourbons, if men of their race could be supposed capable of instruction, might be pronounced to be in a fair way of learning the value of a character. Ever since the outbreak of the revolution which brought down GARIBALDI and his volunteers like a thunderbolt upon Sicily the Government of FRANCIS II. has been dividing its energies between the manufacture of news at home, and petitions for help abroad. Thanks to the reputation which forty years of treachery and tyranny have built up, the “official” telegrams from Caserta are ranked by all the world with the proclamations of Chinese conquerors; and the nearest blood-relations of FERDINAND decline to lift a finger in defence of his throne. Spain, which gave Naples to the Bourbons, laughs at the notion of lending Spanish, soldiers to preserve it for them; and the only intelligence from Sicily via the Court which finds credence even in Vienna, is the statement that many of the royal soldiers who had retreated before the insurgents, “died of fatigue” on reaching their own lines. Everybody sees it to be the most natural thing in the world that the Chasseurs des Alpes should have put their Neapolitan antagonists to a rate of speed which their luxurious and lazy life in the guard-houses of King BOMBA had ill fitted them to endure.

abstract: There was a trotting match over the Centreville Course, yesterday, for $2,000, mile heats; the best 3 in 5, to wagons, between the b.g. Rattlesnake, entered by D. PFIFEB. and the b.g. Red Jacket, entered by F.J. NODINZ. The race was won by Rattle make in three straight beats. The time being 2:35; 2:35 1/4; 2:38. The attendance was large but there was no much betting. Rattlesnake was the favorite from the start at $100 to $60.

abstract: J.B. BROWN, a resident of Alexandria, was arrested yesterday at the Long Bridge, on a warrant, is sued by justice NOAH DEUMMOND on a charge of circulating the Helper book and other incendiary documents. He was taken to Alexandria by a police officer specially dispatched for the purpose, assisted by a citizen of the county, and carried before justice Price, who committed him to jail in default of $2,000 bail, BROWN was delegate to the wheeling and Chicago “Republican” Conventions, and voted for FREMONT in 1856. He has been suspected for some use of entertaining sentiments inimical to the south, and of circulation incendiary documents, and when arrested had about his person several copies of the Helper Look, and other publications of similar character. -- Washington States and Union, June 7.

abstract: The United States Mail steamer Arago, Capt. LINES, arrived at this port last evening, having left  Havre on the 29th, and Southampton on the 30th of May. Her intelligence is of the same date as that published in the TIMES of yesterday, received by telegraph from the North Briton, at Fathar Point. She brings us papers and correspondence two days later than had previously reached us.
lead_paragraph: The United States Mail steamer Arago, Capt. LINES, arrived at this port last evening, having left Havre on the 29th, and Southampton on the 30th of May. Her intelligence is of the same date as that published in the TIMES of yesterday, received by telegraph from the North Briton, at Fathar Point. She brings us papers and correspondence two days later than had previously reached us.

abstract: Mr. THADDEUS HYATT, finding that "the people" will not rescue him, and that there is imminent danger of his being liberated by the Senate, has, as a last resource, offered prizes for the best essays on its power to summon him as a witness, and commit him for contempt on refusing to answer.
lead_paragraph: Mr. THADDEUS HYATT, finding that "the people" will not rescue him, and that there is imminent danger of his being liberated by the Senate, has, as a last resource, offered prizes for the best essays on its power to summon him as a witness, and commit him for contempt on refusing to answer. It may be of use to persons who propose to expend their wits in adding to Mr. HYATT's notoriety, to suggest the propriety of their obtaining additional explanations as to what is to be the standard by which the merit of the various compositions is to be tested; whether, for instance, the prize would be awarded to a writer who happened to come to the conclusion that the Senate had served Mr. HYATT right, or if competition is only open to those who consider him a foully abused martyr and confessor. This is a most important question, and Mr. HYATT will, we trust, enlighten the public still further upon it before the essays are sent in. If he intends to reward only those who make a good statement of his view of the case, he should, in common honesty, prevent persons from competing who would only undertake to prove his folly.

abstract: We understand the wife of JOHN BROWN was recently in Boston, to receive the subscription made up in her behalf and her family, and sent by the people of Hayti as a testimonial of their respect and gratitude for one who perished on the scaffold to maintain their rights against those who hold them in bondage; that is, the rights of the colored people. This expression of gratitude amounted to about $30,000. -- New-Bedford Mercury, June 6.

abstract: The only unpleasant incident, thus far, which has attended the visit of the Japanese, was the robbery of one of them in Baltimore of his two swords. During the exhibition of fireworks on Friday night these weapons were placed upon the bed while the owner went to the parlor, situated on the fourth floor, for the purpose of witnessing the display in the square. -- When he returned to his room the swords were gone, and have not become visible yet. They were both encased, and the hilts were beautifully enameled and carved. A reward of fifty dollars has been offered by the authorities for the recovery of the swords. In addition to the disgrace reflected upon our own nation by this act of vandalism, the loser will be subject to severe censure at home if he should not regain his insignia of office.

abstract: GARIBALDI'S troops are six miles distant from Palermo, and occupy the heights surrounding it. An engagement has taken place, but without a definite result. The insurgents have maintained their positions, and the royal troops have reentered Palermo. Several Neapolitan vessels of war have arrived before Palermo, and a bombardment was feared, should a rising take place in the city.
lead_paragraph: NAPLES, Friday, May 25.

abstract: JERSEY CITY YACHT CLUB.--This fine Club have their yachting harbor on the bay which makes in at the southwesterly point of Jersey City. Two years ago the Club built a fine two-story Club-house, and sunk a number of canal boats to the south and west of it.
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY YACHT CLUB.-- This fine Club have their yachting harbor on the bay which makes in at the southwesterly point of Jersey City. Two years ago the Club built a fine two-story Club-house, and sunk a number of canal boats to the south and west of it. This forms a secure basin and breakwater against the southerly or westerly swell which used occasionally to roll in to the beach from the extensive bay at the back of the point. The Club-house is fitted up very nicely, the upper part for the accommodation of the ladies of the members and other lady friends, and the lower part for the members. There is at all times of tide a fine opportunity for the members to take out their families on little excursions -- which frequently occurs -- and the upper part is also surrounded by a verandah, from which a fine view is obtained of the little yachts. There are about sixty members of the Club, who are generally men of business, and who pursue yachting as a means of health whilst enjoying themselves.

abstract: Recorder BARNARD disposed of several cases yesterday. The first was that of Stephen Chase, alias Chapin, who pleaded guilty to a charge of perjury. On April 21, James Burns was arrested for arson, and held to bail i n the sum of $1,000 by Justice Quackenoush.
lead_paragraph: Recorder BARNARD disposed of several cases yesterday. The first was that of Stephen Chase, alias Chapin, who pleaded guilty to a charge of perjury. On April 21, James Burns was arrested for arson, and held to bail i n the sum of $1,000 by Justice Quackenoush. Chase testified under oath that he owned a house and for at No. 134 Second-street, which statement and oath were subsequently proved to be false. He was also charged on a second indictment for perjury, for giving false ball before the Recorder. The accused was remanded until Friday for sentence.

abstract: The very late advices direct from the City of Mexico, which appeared exclusively in the TIMES of yesterday morning, are highly interesting and suggestive, especially that portion relating to the failure of JECKER  Co. It will also be perceived that our correspondent, who dates from the City of Mexico the 29th ult., places no confidence in the reported defeat and capture of URAGA by WOLL, at Guadalajara.
lead_paragraph: The very late advices direct from the City of Mexico, which appeared exclusively in the TIMES of yesterday morning, are highly interesting and suggestive, especially that portion relating to the failure of JECKER & Co. It will also be perceived that our correspondent, who dates from the City of Mexico the 29th ult., places no confidence in the reported defeat and capture of URAGA by WOLL, at Guadalajara. This report, it is thought, was manufactured expressly for the British packet leaving Vera Cruz June 1. The reliance we place on our correspondent, certain discrepancies that appear in dates, and the improbabilities that attend the matter, lead us to believe that nothing serious has as yet occurred to retard the triumphant progress of the Liberals, or cause any change in their programme. On the other hand, the failure of JECKER & Co. is the severest blow that has fallen upon the Church faction and Government during the present revolution. The pocket nerve is at last touched, and the eyes of interested parties in Europe and the United States will be opened. This failure is but the beginning of an exhibit which will enlighten the public as to the enormity of the evils that have been inflicted upon Mexico by those European bankers, capitalists and diplomats who have held the destinies of the country in their hands since it became independent of Spain.
headline: {'main': 'The Mexican News.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mexican News.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The arrival of the Arago puts us in possession of our European mails two days later than had been previously received, although the news is of the same date as that published yesterday by telegraph from Father Point. There is nothing reliable concerning GARIBALDI’s progress, though the latest intelligence announced that he was actually in possession of Palermo. Everything indicates that he is certainly meeting with popular sympathy and success. A very spirited debate had taken place in the Sardinian Parliament concerning the cession of Savoy and Nice, but the vote had not been taken, though there was no doubt of the ratification of the treaty. The general European news is of no special interest.

abstract: The Tribune, with a promptness which does credit to its benevolence, solves our doubts on the subject of rail-splitting as a qualification for the Presidency. We beg to acknowledge its courteous attentions. It adds another to the many instances in which we have experienced the advantages of having neighbors willing and able to resolve all difficulties that may perplex the mind or encompass the path of mere ordinary mortals.

abstract: The People vs. Otto Hoym, et al. -- This was the return to an order to the defendants to show cause why they should not be permanently enjoined from further performance at their Theatre, at No. 37 Bowery. The action is brought by the Managers of the Association for the Reformation of Juvenile Delinquents under the new Sunday law, to revoke the license of the defendants. It is claimed that by the theatre licensed under it give performances on the Sabbath-day, their act will operate to revoke the license. The defendants have thus broken the law as alleged, and hence the action. The motion was not reaches, but will be heard at Chambers as soon as counsel can be heard.
lead_paragraph: The People vs. Otto Hoym, et al. -- This was the return to an order to the defendants to show cause why they should not be permanently enjoined from further performance at their Theatre, at No. 37 Bowery. It is claimed that by the theatre licensed under it give performances on the Sabbath-day, their act will operate to revoke the license. The defendants have thus broken the law as alleged, and hence the action. The motion was not reaches, but will be heard at Chambers as soon as counsel can be heard.

abstract: Between 3 and 4 o'clock this morning flames were discovered issuing from the fourth floor of the  building No. 11 Cedar-street, occupied by TIMOTHY O'LEARY, dealer in rag and paper stock. A damage of about $500 was done by fire and water, covered by an insurance of $1,000 in the New-York and Maline Insurance Company.
lead_paragraph: Between 3 and 4 o'clock this morning flames were discovered issuing from the fourth floor of the building No. 11 Cedar-street, occupied by TIMOTHY O'LEARY, dealer in rag and paper stock. A damage of about $500 was done by fire and water, covered by an insurance of $1,000 in the New-York and Maline Insurance Company. The stock of CHARLES S. KUH, on the second floor, consisting of bronze powders and soap, was slightly injured by water; uninsured. The loss upon the building is not material. The fire is supposed to have been, caused by spontaneous combustion of a bale of rags.

The jury were unable to determine from the evidence by whom the violence was inflicted, and they returned a verdict of “Death from compression of the brain, caused by a fracture of the??? at the hands of some unknown person.” JOHN SULLIVAS, a young man who was in custody on a charge of having much the assault, was discharge by the Coroner after the rendition of the???. Deceased was married and resided at No. 99 mulberry-street.

abstract: During the past week, according to the official returns, the City Inspector has employed 341 men, at an expense of $6,807 23, and in that time they have removed 3,651 loads of manure; 9,122 loads of ashes, and 6,986 loads of dirt and rubbish, making a total of 19,759 loads removed from the streets. If the work is continued at the present rate of weekly expenditure, the total will reach nearly $350,000 for the expenses of the year.

abstract: There was a large attendance last evening of the members of the Fifth Ward Republican Association, at their headquarters at the Fifth Ward Hotel, JOSEPH B. TAYLOR, Esq., presiding. The principal business transacted was the enrolment of new members, and appointing Committees of three each for the eight election districts, to supervise the distribution of campaign documents ...
lead_paragraph: There was a large attendance last evening of the members of the Fifth Ward Republican Association, at their headquarters at the Fifth Ward Hotel, JOSEPH B. TAYLOR, Esq., presiding. The principal business transacted was the enrolment of new members, and appointing Committees of three each for the eight election districts, to supervise the distribution of campaign documents, and do the general election work devolving on District Committee. The business part of the meeting ended, spirited speeches followed, by Hon. C.S. SPENCER, FRANK SHEPARD Esq., and others. Mr. SPENCER told how he lost $1,000 betting FREMONT would carry Illinois, and announced his readiness to bet treble the amount that LINCOLN would carry the State by a sweeping majority next November.

abstract: It appears that the news which comes to us from California, of the assassination of the Tycoon of Japan, is received with reserve by the Naval Commissioners in charge of the Japanese Embassy, now at Philadelphia. We alluded to it yesterday in the same spirit; for, ...
lead_paragraph: It appears that the news which comes to us from California, of the assassination of the Tycoon of Japan, is received with reserve by the Naval Commissioners in charge of the Japanese Embassy, now at Philadelphia. We alluded to it yesterday in the same spirit; for, although it is not in itself at all impossible that a prince, comparatively new to the throne, and representing a policy absolutely revolutionary in the history of his country, should have been violently put out of the way by the proud and powerful aristocracy of the only great existing oligarchy of the world, still such events as the murder of a sovereign are far more unusual in Japan than in any other Oriental country, or than they were but a century or two ago in Christendom itself.

abstract: PHOTO  GRAPHY AND THE ARCTIC EXPEDITION--A regular meeting of this Society was held in the Cooper Institute last evening, Prof. JOY, Vice President, in the Chair. In answer to an inquiry from the Chair as to the cause of the absence of Dr. HAYES, who was to address the Society upon the subject of this Artic Expedition, ...
lead_paragraph: PHOTOGRAPHY AND THE ARCTIC EXPEDITION. -- A regular meeting of this Society was held in the Cooper Institute last evening, Prof. JOY, Vice President, in the Chair. In answer to an inquiry from the Chair as to the cause of the absence of Dr. HAYES, who was to address the Society upon the subject of this Artic Expedition, Mr. CARBANATI stated that he had unexpectedly been called out of town, and would not be present. He would say, however, in his behalf, that Dr. HAYES was anxious to have a photographer accompany him on the expedition It was very desirable for many reasons, he said, that there should be a photographer connected with he expedition. But the expedition was short??? having hardly enough to defray its ordinary outfit, and if a photographer was to be sent, the necessary means must be supplied. He thought that this Society owed it to themselves and to the art which they were organized to promote, to see that the requisite means were furnished. He begged leave to offer the following resolution:

abstract: We understand that JOHN McREISSEY, the pugilist, is going into training at the “Abbey,” with a view of fighting HEENAN in August. He has left New-York, and expresses his determination to vanquish the champion of the world, notwithstanding the dire disease of consumption that is now upon him. We may now look forward to lively times among the sporting men, of which our city is so fruitful. -- Troy Budget, June 8.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL. -- A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, president KALBFLEISH in the Chair. A petition was received from C. PELL and others, asking permission to lay rail tracks and run horse cars through Fulton, Front, Gold and De Kalb avenues, returning through De???voise, Willoughby, Bridge and Water-streets. To Railroad Committee. By resolution the Commissioner of Repairs and Supplies was direction to furnish the newly elected Aldermen with the usual badge of office. A resolution was presented to open water, street in the Eastern District and St. Felix street in the Western District. Was referred to the Committee on Opening Streets. A special Committee of three was appointed to take charge of Washington Park, with power to employ suitable persons to keep the same in order. A resolution was adopted authorizing the Mayor to offer a reward of 25 cents for each dog delivered at the public pound. The Mayor and Dr. J.S. JONES, Health Officers, were appointed as delegates to the National Quarantine and Sanitary Convention, to be held in Boston on the 14th inst. The Board spent nearly two hours in voting for members of the Board of Education. The following gentlemen were selected and adopted; Messrs R.C. Bremond, John Bellingham, James Murphy, R. Trainer, E.W. Dunham, J.S. Thorne, C.P. Smith, Henry Mc???sky, Wm. McDermott, D.L. Nor???up, J. Johnson, James Howe, T.W. Field, J.S. Burr. As the last name was adopted on of the Aldermen discovered that be had voted wrong, and be moved a reconsideration of the vote taken on that name. Alderman STRONG moved as an amendment that the votes on all the names be reconsidered. Aldermen VAN BRUNT moved as a further amendment that the amendments be laid on the fable. This was carried by a vote of nine to eight. The President decided that this laid everything on the table, so that no members were appointed. The hour for adjournment being announced, the Board adjourned for one week under the rules.

abstract: -A stroll through BARNUM'S is good in warm weather. If a man is disposed to complain of his own superfluous flesh, and lament that he cannot scrape it off and enjoy the luxury of sitting in his bones, a sight of the "fat boy" does much to remove his discontent.
lead_paragraph: -- A stroll through BARNUM'S is good in warm weather. If a man is disposed to complain of his own superfluous flesh, and lament that he cannot scrape it off and enjoy the luxury of sitting in his bones, a sight of the "fat boy" does much to remove his discontent. This interesting individual is seven years of age, and weighs 250 pounds. He is about 2 feet 3 inches tall one way, and 3 feet 2 inches tall the other. In his more extreme youth he must have been what Solomon has laid to the charge of the foolish son, “the heaviness of his mother.” His face looks very much like the full moon rising from a flesh-colored mountain, while for purposes of locomotion his legs seem about as useful to him as they would be to a wagon-wheel. It is good to be fat, but not too fat! And then there is the Angel-fish. This is not, as one at first thought would imagine, a mere-maid, but a mere fish, -- yet most beautifully colored withal. Imagine to yourself a rainbow with fins, and you have already seen the Angel-fish. Of the boa-constrictors, with their interesting family, it is not necessary to speak; the? must be seen to be appreciated. In regard to the “What is it,” we have a shrewd suspicion that BAENUM has at length discovered the connecting link between humanity and Common Councilmen, although, as old nurses say, “it favors” the latter more than the former. Sometime BARNUM intends to tell his patrons What it is!

abstract: The city of Baltimore having got over her devotion to the Municipal system, has, like ourselves, begun to enjoy at least an approach to good order and good government. The letter of our correspondent, published on Monday, informs us that the r gime of the "Pluguglies" and "Owls" and "Blood-tubs" has passed away, and that Baltimore "may now ...
lead_paragraph: The city of Baltimore having got over her devotion to the Municipal system, has, like ourselves, begun to enjoy at least an approach to good order and good government. The letter of our correspondent, published on Monday, informs us that the r gime of the "Pluguglies" and "Owls" and "Blood-tubs" has passed away, and that Baltimore "may now be put down as amongst the most orderly cities in America." To those who remember what Baltimore was only a year ago, this statement will doubtless savor of exaggeration; but if no greater change has occurred than the acquisition by the Police of a share in the government of the city, the gain is indeed great. A tolerable chance of protection against robbery and murder at the hands of ruffians who not simply surpass in their vocation anything to be met with in Christendom, but in Heathendom, must no doubt cause a sensation in Baltimorean breasts, as novel as it is agreeable.

abstract: The Washington, correspondent of the Philadelphia Ledger says: “A dispatch, from Mr. COBB to Senator TOOMBS just received, settles some points concerning the Baltimore Convention. The Georgia Democratic State Convention has by a vote of 270 to 40, agreed to send a. delegation to Baltimore, with instructions to attempt a re-union with the Convention, upon a platform contestant with, and recognizing Southern rights. Failing in this, they are to join the Southern Convention at Richmond, and then take such independent action as may be deemed expedient -- that is, in adopt the “majority platform,” so called, and make a nomination for president and Vice-President, This course was a triumphant indorsement of the mode of procedure recommended by-Mr. TOOMBS and by Secretary COBB. Toe minority of the Convention seceded, and appointed a. Douglas delegation to Baltimore. This is called a bogus delegation in the dispatch. The Alabama State Convention have taken the same course, It is now quite certain, therefore, that the regular Southern delegates, thus instructed, will withdraw and go to Richmond, unless a platform, embracing the principles of the majority plat form and the Senate resolutions, be adopted by the Contention, When they shall have withdrawn, their places will be occupied by the bogus delegations, and DOUGLAS will be nominated, The Richmond Convention will also make a nomination of some candidates generally acceptable to the South -- perhaps HUNTER and DICKINSON, or DAVIS and LANE.

Failing in this, they are to join the Southern Convention at Richmond, and then take such independent action as may be deemed expedient -- that is, in adopt the “majority platform,” so called, and make a nomination for president and Vice-President, This course was a triumphant indorsement of the mode of procedure recommended by-Mr. TOOMBS and by Secretary COBB. Toe minority of the Convention seceded, and appointed a. Douglas delegation to Baltimore. This is called a bogus delegation in the dispatch. The Alabama State Convention have taken the same course, It is now quite certain, therefore, that the regular Southern delegates, thus instructed, will withdraw and go to Richmond, unless a platform, embracing the principles of the majority plat form and the Senate resolutions, be adopted by the Contention, When they shall have withdrawn, their places will be occupied by the bogus delegations, and DOUGLAS will be nominated, The Richmond Convention will also make a nomination of some candidates generally acceptable to the South -- perhaps HUNTER and DICKINSON, or DAVIS and LANE.

abstract: The greatest match of the season, and the most interesting to the breeders of fast horses, came off yesterday, at the Union Course, L.I. Since the last trot between Flora and Patchen, much speculation has been going on, in the minds of the betting men, whether Flora could compete with the big horse in a two-mile race, and repeat. But when it was recollected that she had previously performed the task in 4 minutes ...
lead_paragraph: The greatest match of the season, and the most interesting to the breeders of fast horses, came off yesterday, at the Union Course, L.I. Since the last trot between Flora and Patchen, much speculation has been going on, in the minds of the betting men, whether Flora could compete with the big horse in a two-mile race, and repeat. But when it was recollected that she had previously performed the task in 4 minutes 50 1/2 seconds, and that in her previous trot with Patchen she had done a mile in. 2:21 and 2.21 1/2, all doubt seemed to vanish, and she had the call up to the morning of the race at 2 to 1, while yesterday morning the betting had gone up to 100 to 40 on her, and just after she had passed in front of the stands it stood at 106 to 35, at which figure considerable business was done with the Patchen men. While the betters were laying out the money, and sporting men generally, hazarding their opinions, the Flora crowd were all alive for the event. The early trains of the Long Island Railroad dropped passengers at East New-York or Wood haven, and two mammoth trains were taken cat by Superintendent PALMER, at 2 o'clock, which carried 2,550 persons of all conditions to the Union Course. These were brought back in safety to New-York, notwithstanding the immense rush which generally occurs on these special trains. All the horse railroad cars which converge at East New-York did a big business and the track of the line of carriages and vehicles of all kinds which passed over the dusty roads was as distinctly marked by the cloud of dust as the line of fire on a prairie is traced by the smoke. The usual mixture of humanity and inhumanity met together, for an immense crowd of nearly 15,000 people were on the Course and stands, occupying-every available point of observation. The gamblers abounded on all the approaches to the Course, and many a poor simpleton, who was green enough to suppose that he could tell under which thimble the pea was placed, or which of the three cards was the one he had bet upon lost his money. But these are everyday occurrences, almost everywhere, and of course they are to be met in all their glory at the racecourse. Upon the arrival of the first train of cars some of the "soughs" made a dash for the back part of the inclosure, a few knowing ones having spotted a weak point in a twinkling. A couple of boards were wrenclied off, and about three hundred bilked the gate keeper out of a dollar a piece by getting through the fence. Those in authority, however, rushed to the breach, and stopped the inroad a great deal quicker than they usually do. A set to took place between a couple of the fancy men who occasionally "go in" on the Course as the best means of settling an account with some credit, both to themselves and the proprietors of the Course. Upon the arrival of the second train a party of half grown boys were seen at the outside opening of the Grand Stand, hauling up by means of a rope a number of others; the modus operandi pursued was as follows: the party of the first part in possession, lowered the bight of a rope in which, the parties outside seated themselves, and upon being drawn up to the sill of the opening were incontinently seized by the collar and seat of the breeches and shoved head-first into the opening, amidst the laughter of the outsiders. The refreshment stands outside were well patronized the lager at-sixpence a glass, bringing large returns to the owners of the kegs of that non-intoxicating beverage, and washing down the dust in the throats of the crowds who partook of it. Inside the course the arrangements were complete, various concoctions of chowder being the dish which was most called for, and sandwiches and oysters came and went with a rush.

abstract: An excursion train on the Dubuque Western Railroad came into collision with a regular train on the 1st inst., near Worthington Station. Mr. Hepner, Roadmaster, was seriously injured; Hon. O.B. Matteson, of Utica, received severe contusions on his face and limbs; Mr. Corse, of Alexandria, V., sustained bruises on his left arm, and Ex-Gov. Hempstead was badly cut in the ankle. Difference in the time of the watches carried by the two conductors was the cause of the accident.

abstract: The detailed account which has now reached us from California of the reported assassination of the Tycoon of Japan, spares the life of that Prince himself, and contents itself with slaughtering the head of his Government. The difference is material, not only to the Tycoon but to the rest of the world, for it is the Japanese Lord Palmerston, and not his nominal sovereign, who has been put of the way.
lead_paragraph: The detailed account which has now reached us from California of the reported assassination of the Tycoon of Japan, spares the life of that Prince himself, and contents itself with slaughtering the head of his Government. abstract: The frightful event which PRAED held up as the acme of social desolation has occurred in New-York. The “opera is demolished.” Signor SERVADIO has leaped after MAX MARETZEK into the insatiable gulf of public indifference, but without closing it. All the artistic brilliancies of CORTESI, MUSIANI, (including that vocal blue dahlia his ut de poitrine,) Miss PHILLIPS and AMODIO failed to conquer the apathy of the Academy. Even the Matinee with all its flirtations was in vain. The opera is demolished. But the opera resembles Mantalini -- it can stand a great deal of suicide; and we should not be surprised to see it suddenly come to life again one day nest week, again to die in spasms after a brief but exciting career. The really great merits of Madame CORTESI’s cohort ought to have prolonged its last lease of life, and ought to secure it a new one. But then, June is upon us, and the sirens of Saratoga and Newport already are heard in the distance. If the opera revives and lives, it is the Japanese, the Prince of WALES, the Great Eastern, and the Snooks family from the West who must maintain it. The New-Yorkers politely put on weeds and retire till next Fall.

abstract: THE PRESIDENT's DIPLOMATISTS. -- The organ of “His Majesty the President,” at Washington, takes great credit to that venerable public functionary for his recent diplomatic appointments, of Mr. APPLETON as Minister to Russia, and Mr. Ward as Secretary of the Paraguayan Commission. It is certainly a matter, of satisfaction to the country at large that two posts under the Administration should have been filled, not by cheap politicians who wanted them, but by accomplished men who are competent to discharge their duties.

abstract: The Democratic Convention at Richmond has adjourned, to await the action of their Northern brethren at Baltimore. They have done exactly nothing else. They took no action concerning a platform, said nothing about candidates, rigorously suppressed all freedom of debate, and severely snubbed the irrepressible Col. BALDWIN, of Syracuse, for pertinaciously protesting his devotion to the Union.

abstract: --We published yesterday morning an interesting letter from Hon. H.S. RANDALL concerning Lord MACAULAY's letter to him, published some weeks since, on the political institutions of the United States. It will be remembered that two or three English writers intimated that these were not the settled and matured opinions of the great historian. Mr. RANDALL disposes of this pretext very thoroughly. He publishes extracts of other ...
lead_paragraph: -- We published yesterday morning an interesting letter from Hon. H.S. RANDALL concerning Lord MACAULAY's letter to him, published some weeks since, on the political institutions of the United States. It will be remembered that two or three English writers intimated that these were not the settled and matured opinions of the great historian. Mr. RANDALL disposes of this pretext very thoroughly. He publishes extracts of other letters from MACAULAY to himself, in which the same unfavorable opinions of Democratic government are expressed in still stronger language, and in which they are declared to be the fixed and settled convictions of his mind. He does not believe that the prosperity of this country is due to the Democratic character of the Government, but rather that it has taken place in spite of it; and he refers to the cases of several of the British colonies for the purpose of showing that equal, and even more remarkable, material progress has been experienced under forms of government entirely different. Mr. RANDALL has very effectually vindicated himself from the injurious insinuations of his English critics.

abstract: The Republicans of Newark, New-Jersey, and vicinity, held a grand mass meeting in Military Park, Newark, last evening, to ratify the nominations of LINCOLN and HAMLIN. The meeting was called for 6 o’clock, but it was past 8 before the people began to assemble in large numbers upon the ground. Mean time, Rubsam’s band played a variety of airs, a national salute was fired from Market-street, near by, and by 8 o’clock a crowd of four or five thousand persons had collected together, which was subsequently increased by deputations from Jersey City, Paterson, &c., to the number of six or seven thousand. At 8 1/4 o’clock the meeting was called to order by Mr. T.B. HOWELL, who nominated for President, CORTLAND??? PARKER, Esq. Mr. PARKER was elected by acclamation, as were also the following list of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries:

abstract: ITEMS. -- Yesterday, the body of JOHN HOGAN, who was drowned ten days ago at the foot of North Sixth-street, was recovered and an inquest held by Coroner MURPHY, when a verdict of death by accidental drowning was rendered. A man named WM. SHORTEN attempted to strike a man standing on South Seventh-street, on Monday night, when the man lodged and SHORTEN fell heavily on the sidewalk, breaking both bones of one leg below the knee. He was taken to the City Hospital. A party of sailors landed at Barren Island on Monday, for sand ballast, and while there managed to get into a fight with the Brooklyn offal contractors’ men. Several were severely injures on both sides. The ringleaders were arrested and brought to this city for trial Sergeant HUNT, of the Filth Precinct Police, yesterday recorded good valued at $100, stolen from a Mrs. HAWLEY, in New-York, oh the 6th of April last- The thief has not been captured. Three men from New-York-named WILLIAM BROWN EUGESE SULLIVAN and FRANCIS MOORE, were attacked on Monday night on Hamilton Avenue, near the Jerry, by a party of rowdies, and severely beaten. MOORE had one of his arms dislocated. WILLIAM Down and FRANCIS DALY, two of the assaulting Party, were arrested yesterday by Officer Tourney, of the Third Precinct, and they were committed for trial Hose Company No. 1, of the Eastern district fire Department, proceeds to Newark to-day to join in the Fire Department celebration there. The regular monthly meeting of the Young Men’s Christian Association was held in the Washington-street Institute last evening. An essay was read which was followed by the usual discussion.

abstract: The Evening Post pronounces the institution of an Elective Judiciary to have been “one of the greatest experiments ever made upon human nature” -- a sentiment in which we entirely concur. It was a very bold experiment, and, so far as it has been carried out, the result has been anything but satisfactory. Twelve years trial of it have nearly satisfied political philosophers that human nature will not bear the tests, or, at all events, that judicial human nature bears fixity of tenure in office, better than periodical and frequently recurring elections.

abstract: Last evening a fire happened in the four-story brick building No. 31 Bridge-street, occupied by eleven families. It originated from a stove in an attic apartment, during the absence of the tenant, and the upper part of the building was destroyed. The occupants saved but little of their furniture, and that in a damaged condition. O’MEARA & HEENAN, coopers, having a shop in the basement, suffered damage by water of about $50; uninsured. The building can scarcely be repaired short of $1,500. It is a portion of an estate leased by Mr. GREGG REDMOND, of Brooklyn.

abstract: Amelia Morreil, alias Sarah Fall, wras tried yesterday before Recorder BAENARD, on a charge of grand larceny, it being her second offence. On the 11th of June,1856, she was convicted before Judge...
lead_paragraph: Amelia Morreil, alias Sarah Fall, wras tried yesterday before Recorder BAENARD, on a charge of grand larceny, it being her second offence. On the 11th of June,1856, she was convicted before Judge Capron in this Court, of a similar offence, and sent for two years to the Penitentiary. She is a woman of somewhat prepossessing appearance, and being well dressed, might readily pass in the street, and in stores, as a lady. In that guise, or rather disguise, she visited the dry goods store of E.J. Brown & Co., in Broadway, on the 22d of February last, accompanied by a man named Join B. Oppenheim, and while he was pricing some goods in the “make-believe” of an intention to purchase, the lady shoplifter was observed by one of the clerks to secrete under her cloak a piece of satin. The testimony against her yesterday was complete. She was speedily convicted, and will be sentenced to-morrow.

abstract: Augustus Irving vs. The Mayor, &c. -- The plaintiff is the owner of premises No. 255 Spring-street, which originally belonged to the City, The Corporation owned two lots adjoining, situated on Spring-street, one of which was sold to one Baldwin, and finally came into possession of the plaintiff. In 1836 an engine house was erected on the remaining lot, and in making excavations for this building the plaintiffs walls were, it is alleged, so undermined that the house settled several feet, doing much damage. The case has been once before tried, and is now on for the second time before Judge BRADY in. the Common Pleas.

abstract: The ostentation with which the Union Party are parading Mr. GUSTAVUS HENRY, of Tennessee, as "the grandson of PATRICK HENRY," at their meetings, reveals a lurking belief in hereditary legislation or statesmanship.
lead_paragraph: The ostentation with which the Union Party are parading Mr. GUSTAVUS HENRY, of Tennessee, as "the grandson of PATRICK HENRY," at their meetings, reveals a lurking belief in hereditary legislation or statesmanship. Mr. HENRY is, or has been up to the present, entirely unknown, both in the political and literary world; and the only ground on which attention is now claimed for his speeches and example is the fact that he is a grandson of PATRICK HENRY. This circumstance, whatever importance it may have for Mr. HENRY himself, in a social point of view, can possess none whatever in a political one, unless it indicates either that he inherits the eloquence of his ancestor, or that if the grandfather were now living, he would follow the same political course as the grandson is now pursuing. That PATRICK HENRY, however, did not bequeath his oratorical power along with his name, was made painfully apparent at the very first meeting at which Mr. GUSTAVUS HENRY appeared. He furnishes another illustration of the failure of the received laws’ of hereditary transmission, in the matter of intellectual power. Physical peculiarities, and even moral ones, are known to pass from father to son with a frequency and regularity which almost reach the rank of a rule; but as regards mind, naturalists are all at fault. In spite of a few brilliant exceptions, the history of great names is but a sorrowful record of their transmission in a single generation from great soldiers, statesmen and orators, to very common-place or very silly sons. Mr. GUSTAVUS HENRY may console himself for his present failure by looking over the list. He will find himself in the company of a vast number of highly respectable people.

abstract: EXPLOSION OF A FLUID LAMP SIX PERSONS INJURED ONE FATALLY. About 2  o'clock yesterday afterroon a peddler called at the house of Mrs. PEER, No. 182 Hudson-avenue, to sell patent fluid lamp...
lead_paragraph: EXPLOSION OF A FLUID LAMP -- SIX PERSONS INJURED -- ONE FATALLY. -- About 2 1/2 o'clock yesterday afterroon a peddler called at the house of Mrs. PEER, No. 182 Hudson-avenue, to sell patent fluid lamp safety tubes. He placed one of the tubes on a glass lamp, partially filled with burning fluid, and lighted it. To convince the family that a lamp with such a tube could not be made to explode, he gave it a violent shaking, when the lamp exploded, injuring one person, a child, fatally, and five others more or less severely. Every person in the room, except a child 13 years of age, who was alarmed by the motions made with the lamp and crawled under a table, was injured. Mrs. DURYEA, of No. 55 Dean-street, a daughter of Mrs. PEER, was badly burned about the face and hands. ELIZA DARNLY, 9 years of age, daughter of HAMILTON DARNLY, residing on Concord-street, near Hudson-avenue, was severely burned about the head, neck, face and hands. She is in a very critical condition. OTTO S. WIEBEL had his right hand badly burned, and was also injured by the flying glass. Mrs. PEER was severely wounded in the right breast by pieces of glass. The peddler, whose name is unknown, was also severely burned about his face and hands. The explosion set the room on fire, but the flames were speedily extinguished. Several physicians were promptly on the spot and rendered all the aid necessary.

abstract: A GIRL TIED TO A COW's TAIL AND DRAGGED TO DEATH. -- A terrible accident occurred in the town of Delhi. Delaware County, a week ago, which resulted in the death of a little girl seven years old. The parties to the sad occurrence were WM. SCOTT, a lad 17 years old, and his half-sister, ELIZABETH DOBY, the victim. The boy had been sent to take the cows to pasture, the little girl accompanying him. He had with him a piece of rope, with which he was to bring back some hay. On his way he playfully tied one end of the rope around the body of his sister, and the other end to the cow’s tail. When the cow had proceeded a short distance in this way, followed by the girl, the latter stumbled and fell, which so frightened the cow that she ran off at a furious rate, dragging the poor girl after her. After running some distance the girl’s head struck a solid rock, crushing in the skull, and at the same time the cow’s tail pulled out, so great was the force of the resistance. The girl was also badly cut around the face, neck and head. She was taken, up by the boy and carried home. Where she breached but two or three times before expiring. The boy is said to be rather deficient in intellect, and it is not supposed that he realized the imminent danger in which his sister was placed by his mischievous conduct. -- Rome (N.Y.) Daily Sentinel, June 11.

abstract: THE SPINGLER INSTITUTE COMMENCEMENT. -- The tenth Annual Commencement of the Spingler Institute took place yesterday, in the chapel of the Institute, on Union-square. The room was tastefully decorated with flowers and evergreens. The young ladies who were about to graduate were seated at the rear of the platform, and were dressed in white. The chapel was crowded with visitors, and the exercises were, as usual, highly interesting to all present. The following are the names of the members of the graduating class: Misses Josephine Allen Kate Benedict, Mary C. Bates, Mary A. Booth, Caroline S Bradbury, Mary Burkholder, Julia E. Cady, Anna E. Chapman, Nannie E. Cowan, Charlotte Coventry. Emma L. Driggs, Henrietta J. Edwards, Henrietta L. Farnsworth, Charlotte M. Field, Mary E. Gould Sophie B. Gilman. M. abstract: SUDDEN DEATH OF THE OLDEST RESIDENT OF POUGHKEEPSIE. -- Mr. ELIAS WHITNEY, the oldest resident of Poughkeepsie, Dutchess County, died very suddenly, at his residence in that city, a night or two since. He was in his ninety-first year; had been married seventy years, and had lived, in Poughkeepsie nearly fifty years. Mr. WHITNEY has had ten children, forty seven grandchildren, eighty-seven great-grandchildren and six great-great-grandchildren. He was one of the most respected citizens of Poughkeepsie. He had voted for every President, and never required a physician until he was in his eighty-ninth year.

abstract: HOW FREE NEGROES ARE TREATED IN KENTUCKY -- A few days ago JAMES WAGGONER, a free negro, was kidnapped and carried over from Ohio into Kentucky. He finally escaped from his cap ors, but was imprisoned in Newport. Finally, he managed, to have his case brought before the Court, but it was decided that he had no right to his liberty, although, it was proved that he was born in Ohio, of free parents. He was immediately put into a buggy and driven off to Alexandria, Ky. An injunction was immediately taken out and sent in pursuit of the fugitives, but before the party in change of the negro had been in Alexandria ten minutes they had sold him to one Dr. FOSTER, for $700. Dr. FOSTER has since published a card in the Cincinnati papers, stating that he believed the negro to be a fugitive from Slavery, and that he is willing to sell him for what he gave for him.
lead_paragraph: HOW FREE NEGROES ARE TREATED IN KENTUCKY -- A few days ago JAMES WAGGONER, a free negro, was kidnapped and carried over from Ohio into Kentucky. abstract: Since the failure of the Atlantic Telegraph, the confidence not only of tho public but even of scientific electricians has been considerably shaken in the ultimate practicability of a long direct line between England and America. Recent discoveries...
lead_paragraph: -- Since the failure of the Atlantic Telegraph, the confidence not only of tho public but even of scientific electricians has been considerably shaken in the ultimate practicability of a long direct line between England and America. Recent discoveries show that it is almost impracticable to work through an unbroken submarine circuit of nearly 3,000 miles, at any such speed as would insure a commercial profit on the capital invested in the line. A new solution of the problem, however, is now engaging the attention of scientific men in England, namely, the North Atlantic Telegraph. At a late meeting of the Royal Geographical Society, Col. SHAFFNER read a paper on the subject, from which we learn that the proposition is to submerge the cable from some point on the north of Scotland, in the first instance to the Faroe Islands, thence to Iceland, Greenland and Labrador. The length of the submarine lines would be 250, 350, 550 and 600 miles, making a length of submerged cable of 1,500 miles. Col. SHAFFNER, who has explored the east coast of Greenland, stated that the laying down of these cables would not be attended with much more difficulty than in other cases, for as far as he had examined the route he had found it unobstructed by ice, excepting on the coast of Labrador, where some special caution would be required in bringing the cable to land. The depths, so far as they had been sounded, did not exceed 2,500 fathoms, at which point there was a deep deposit of mud. The Colonel alluded to the great advantage which would attend having several short submarine circuits instead of an interrupted one. Through so comparatively short a circuit as 600 miles, which was the longest length of the submerged cables, as many as twenty words per minute might be transmitted, whilst the retardation of the electricity by the submerged wire of the former Atlantic Telegraph did not permit of more than three words per minute being transmitted. It is, however, intended, before bringing the enterprise definitely before the world, to undertake, under Government auspices, a careful surrey of the whole line.

abstract: The House of Representatives yesterday, by a very decided vote, adopted resolutions censuring the President of the United States for misuse of the patronage placed in his hands
lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives yesterday, by a very decided vote, adopted resolutions censuring the President of the United States for misuse of the patronage placed in his hands for public purposes, which he is alleged to have used for partisan and personal ends. This action is based on the disclosures of Committees of Investigation, and when they are fully published, we are inclined to believe that the country at large will ratify the judgment thus pronounced.

abstract: Gardner .A Furness, the young man who three years since was prominently before the public in con-_ nection with a case of scandal at the New-York Hotel, in which the wife of Mr. Woodman, a wealthy...
lead_paragraph: Gardner .A Furness, the young man who three years since was prominently before the public in con-_ nection with a case of scandal at the New-York Hotel, in which the wife of Mr. Woodman, a wealthy New-Orleans druggist, lost her reputation, was arrested yesterday by special Detective Lee, of the Harbor Police, on a charge of stealing a light wagon, valued at $100, from John Harmon, livery stable keeper, No. 45 Greenwich-street. It is said that on the 6th inst. he called at the stable in question, having a set of harness on his arm and leading a. horse which he had borrowed, and told John McKevin, the hostler, to hitch the animal to a light wagon. His right to take the vehicle was questioned, but he replied so speciously and plausibly that he was allowed to go away with it, promising to return it in the evening. From that time until yesterday, however, nothing was seen of turn or the property, although a diligent search had been made, the only clue to his identity being the description that the hostler gave of his appearance, his representations when he procured the wagon having been false, and Mr. Harmon knowing nothing about him. He was finally apprehended at No. -- Pearl-street, where he was engaged as Treasurer to the Columbian Wine Company, and after an examination before Justice WELSH, he was held in $1,000 bail to answer the complaint, Mr. Edward A. Hearne, counsellor-at-law, becoming his surety. It subsequently transpired that he had exchanged Mr. Harmon’s wagon for an inferior one at the stables of Carll & Duryea, near the Fulton ferry, Brooklyn, and his last acquisition had attended the races at the Union Course. Officer Lee in the afternoon went to Brooklyn and found the vehicle, whereupon another complaint for larceny was lodged against Furness, by the Brooklyn stable-keepers, and last night he was rearrested upon a warrant issued by Justice CORNWELL. The second wagon was recovered from a stable in State-street, this City, where it had been left by the prisoner.

abstract: THE YELLOW FEVER AT ACAPULCO -- DEATH OF THE AMERICAN CONSUL. -- We learn from Mr. JOHN P. CURRY, of the San Francisco press, who left that place on the steamer of the 20th May for New-York, that a virulent type of yellow fever was raging at Acapulco, from the effects of which upwards of 500 deaths had occurred within six weeks previous to his arrival there. Among those who had died was the American Consul, and some 30 Americans. Those who had the opportunity were fast leaving for the interior of Mexico.

abstract: Some of our Republican friends, in their earnest desire to excite the enthusiasm of the nation by detailing the exploits of "honest old ABE" with a maul and a wedge, certainly make a rather comical figure. The world has...
lead_paragraph: Some of our Republican friends, in their earnest desire to excite the enthusiasm of the nation by detailing the exploits of "honest old ABE" with a maul and a wedge, certainly make a rather comical figure. The world has moved a little since 1840; the United States have moved with it; and though log-cabins and hard cider passed tolerably well for arguments, -- or at least aided in arousing popular enthusiasm, -- in favor of a candidate twenty years ago, we fear that split-rails will hardly serve the same turn now. Intrinsically, in the first place, they are not half so well adapted to that special service, -- nor are the circumstances of the present canvass nearly so propitious to their introduction. A rail is not per se picturesque, nor does it suggest experiences upon which the average public mind loves to linger and expatiate.

abstract: The Joint Councilmanic Committee have, at length, decided upon the manner in which the Japanese shall be received. It is expected that they will arrive at Pier No. 1, North River at 3 o'clock, on
lead_paragraph: The Joint Councilmanic Committee have, at length, decided upon the manner in which the Japanese shall be received. It is expected that they will arrive at Pier No. 1, North River at 3 o'clock, on Saturday. The procession to receive them will be formed at the Battery, and will march from Battery-place to and through Broadway to Grand-street; through Grand-street to the Bowery; up the Bowery and Fourth-avenue to and around Union-square to Broadway, and thence to the Metropolitan Hotel, where the Embassy will remain during their visit here. The following are the military orders in connection with the reception. Maj.-Gen. SANDFORD has promulgated the following orders:

abstract: WORKINGMEN'S REPUBLICAN MEETING. The Workingmen's Association met last evening at No 229 Avenue A, for the purpose of taking action regarding their political course during the Presidential campaign. PHILIP FRANKENHEIMER occupied the Chair, and the attendance was quite good. After...
lead_paragraph: WORKINGMEN's REPUBLICAN MEETING. -- The Workingmen's Association met last evening at No 229 Avenue A, for the purpose of taking action regarding their political course during the Presidential campaign. PHILIP FRANKENHEIMER occupied the Chair, and the attendance was quite good. After organizing, resolutions were offered to the effect that as the Association had studied, with patience, the principles of the various political parties now in existence, and found the Republican Party to be the party of the people, chiefly for its advocacy of the measure designed to give land to the landless; therefore, they pledged their hearty support to ABRAHAM LINCOLN and HANNIBAL HAMLIN, for President and Vine-President of the United States. And further, they cheerfully indorsed the Chicago Platform, as continuing true Republican doctrine. The resolutions were adopted, speeches were then made by E.J. SHEPPERD and others, who congratulated the meeting on the stand they had taken in defence of freedom and justice, after which they adjourned.

abstract: Edmund, a slave belonging to Mr. Elgin, of Fayette County, Ky., conceived the idea of making a tour of inspection through the Southern States; so he contrived to seize a skiff and started for the lower counties of the State. Instead of pushing for the Ohio shore of the river he tied his boat each night to the Kentucky shore. When he reached the mouth of the Ohio he sold his skiff and took passage on a flat boat for New Orleans; but there he related his experiences so freely that the authorities clapped him in the calaboose and sent word to his master of his whereabouts.
lead_paragraph: Edmund, a slave belonging to Mr. Elgin, of Fayette County, Ky., conceived the idea of making a tour of inspection through the Southern States; so he contrived to seize a skiff and started for the lower counties of the State. abstract: Capt. HENRY, of Washington, thought it could not be possible that he had insulted Senator SUMNER, as he had  "in his veins three hundred years of the blood of a gentleman," and, therefore,...
lead_paragraph: -- Capt. HENRY, of Washington, thought it could not be possible that he had insulted Senator SUMNER, as he had "in his veins three hundred years of the blood of a gentleman," and, therefore, could not be guilty of an ungentlemanly act. We are not disposed to recognize the Captain’s logic. To assume that gentle descent renders a man incapable of ruffianly actions, is to make an assumption not warranted by precedent. In history there are, unfortunately, too many instances in which long family lines have terminated very suddenly in a noose; gentility has not unfrequently been brought to the gallows for exceedingly vulgar crimes. It is a very mistaken notion to think that blood improves with age. Wine gathers goodness with years; but the converse of this is generally true of blood and bone: -- both are apt to degenerate. When a man, in his own person, cannot display the fruits of manhood, it is very unwise for him to grub about the roots of his genealogical tree and deck himself with fossil respectability. In a live world, where men are judged not by what their fathers were, but by what themselves are, the logic of Capt. HENRY sounds very ridiculous. The blood of yesterday is recognized in this country as being quite as good as that which has been corked in veins for twice three hundred years; it is certainly nobler to found a family than to represent one. Capt. HENRY showed more manliness in apologizing for his rudeness than in boasting of his blood.
