abstract: The annual examination of the Cadets at West Point is one of the circumstances of which the country has a right to be proud. The United States Military Academy is one of the...
lead_paragraph: The annual examination of the Cadets at West Point is one of the circumstances of which the country has a right to be proud. The United States Military Academy is one of the institutions which may well be shown to intelligent strangers, whether Princes of Wales or Princes of Japan, or not princes at all. The best informed of our own countrymen, and the educated foreigners who have visited the spot, are alike of opinion that its entire management reflects credit upon all by whom that management is controlled. Not the finest military schools abroad, not the famous French Ecole Polytechnique, presents to the most careful and curious inspection fewer opportunities for unfavorable criticism, or more numerous subjects for sensible and discerning commendation. It is refreshing, in the mass of mismanagement and slovenliness and deception and chicanery, that characterizes so many of our institutions, both national and municipal, to find one place or one subject to which can be accorded almost unstinted praise; to discover a corner where spirited progress and rational conservatism go hand in hand, where whatever of the old is good is held fast, and whatever of the new is worth trying is at once appropriated.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from Dr.CHEEVER and others, for the release of THADDEUS HYATT. After considerable debate it was referred to the Select Committee.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented a petition from Dr.CHEEVER and others, for the release of THADDEUS HYATT. After considerable debate it was referred to the Select Committee. In the House the resolutions reported back from the Committee on Expenditures in the Navy Department, declaring that the Secretary of the Navy has, with the sanction of the President, abused his discretionary power, and that the President and Secretary were therefore deserving of the reprobation of the House, were taken up and adopted. Mr. Bocock, of Virginia, strongly opposed them. The president, he said, was independent of Congress, and Congress independent of the President. He was replied to by Mr. SHERMAN of Ohio, and after further debate, the several resolutions of censure were adopted by large majorities on vote.

abstract: With reference to the charge that the Hon. John Appleton,lately appointed Minister to Russia, had been a protege and beneficiary of Mr. Cornelius Wendell, that gentleman says in a recent card to the Philedelphia...
lead_paragraph: With reference to the charge that the Hon. John Appleton,lately appointed Minister to Russia, had been a protege and beneficiary of Mr. Cornelius Wendell, that gentleman says in a recent card to the Philedelphia Press: "Not one dime, directly or indirectly, has Mr. A. ever received, much less sought for, through me, either by any interest in the public printing or binding, or in any other way. As to the printing and binding, about which so much has been said, it is only proper in this connection to state tint Mr. Appleton has never received, or sought to receive, directly or indirectly, the smallest fraction of their proceeds, either through me or, so far as I know, from any one else."

abstract: The United States vs. Juan Molina, et al.  This action, tried before Judge BETTS, was brought upon a bond given by the defendants under the act of May 28, 1830 (4 Stats, at Large, 410,64,) which was executed on Jan, 18, 1859, in the sum of $1,400, conditioned that it the obligers should pay to the Colector of the Port of New-York whatever excess of duties or charges might be assessed on twelve hogs.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Juan Molina, et al. -- This action, tried before Judge BETTS, was brought upon a bond given by the defendants under the act of May 28, 1830 (4 Stats, at Large, 410,64,) which was executed on Jan, 18, 1859, in the sum of $1,400, conditioned that it the obligers should pay to the Colector of the Port of New-York whatever excess of duties or charges might be assessed on twelve hogs heads of sugar, over and above the amount estimated and paid prior to the delivery of the same, and also that the obligers should redeliver the said goods to the order of the Collector, provided he should require the same at any time within ten days after the examination thereof should have been made and reported to the Collector, and that in the meantime the said package, (sic,) all and every one of them, as delivered to the obligers, should not be opened without the consent of the Collector or Surveyor given in writing, and then in the presence of one of the Inspectors of the Customs.

abstract: The Massachusetts Legislature has resorted to the rather unusual proceeding of indorsing Senator SUMNER'S recent Anti-Slavery speech. Whether that body is in the habit of sitting in judgment upon each speech of its Federal Senators, or whether circumstances existed which rendered its indorsement in this specific case
lead_paragraph: The Massachusetts Legislature has resorted to the rather unusual proceeding of indorsing Senator SUMNER'S recent Anti-Slavery speech. Whether that body is in the habit of sitting in judgment upon each speech of its Federal Senators, or whether circumstances existed which rendered its indorsement in this specific case particularly desirable, we are unable to say. We do not remember any other instance, however, in which this course has been pursued. We infer, therefore, that the action of the Legislature in this case was prompted by motives which have no application to the ordinary speeches of the Representatives of the State in Federal Congress. The speech itself was exceptional, and that fact may have led the Legislature to think that exceptional action on their part was demanded. It was not an effort calculated to promote any of the practical national objects for which Mr. SUMNER was sent to Washington. It had no direct bearing upon any question awaiting the Senate's action, nor did it enlighten that body upon any subject over which it had control. It was an elaborate essay upon the character of Slavery; and if it had been delivered as a lecture, or an oration, before a popular audience, it would only been open to such criticism as its intrinsic character might invite. It would not have been out of place, at all events, as it clearly was when delivered in the Senate.

lead_paragraph: The Spring meeting of the Fashion Course races commenced yesterday with but a slim attendance, as is usual on the first day. Between 1,500 and 2,000 persons were on the course. The races which were run were not done in very fast time, although the track was in first-rate order.

abstract: The captured Africans at Key West occupied some of the attention of the Senate yesterday. The amendment of the House, increasing the appropriation for their maintainance and return to Africa, from $200,000 to $250,000, was rejected. On motion of Mr. WILSON tho Senate agreed to adjourn on the 25th, instead of the 18th, but as this was not concurred in by the House, it is
lead_paragraph: The captured Africans at Key West occupied some of the attention of the Senate yesterday. The amendment of the House, increasing the appropriation for their maintainance and return to Africa, from $200,000 to $250,000, was rejected. On motion of Mr. WILSON tho Senate agreed to adjourn on the 25th, instead of the 18th, but as this was not concurred in by the House, it is probable that the latter will be the day of adjournment. The consideration of the Legislative bill was resumed, the amendments for paying the claims of the Choctaw Nation the sum of $2,500,000 being rejected. The Post-office Appropriation bill was passed without amendment. In the House, in Committee of the Whole, the join resolution to reduce the price of public printing forty per cent. was passed. The further consideration of the proposed grant for the Select Pacific Railroad Committee was postponed till next session. Mr. COLFAX, from the Conference Committee on the House Homestead bill, reported that they were unable to agree with the provisions of the Senate Homestead bill, and the House resolved to adhere to their own bill without a division. Mr. ELY denounced the working of the Reciprocity Treaty with Great Britain, which had the effect of giving great advantages to the British North American Colonies, without any corresponding advantages to ourselves. The Senate's amendments to the Army bill were resumed, without action further than the limitation of the time of study for Cadets at the Military Academy to four years, in which the House concurred.

abstract: Dr. CHEEVER has actually "petitioned" the Senate to release THADDEUS HYATT. This is not only a sad falling off in the reverend gentleman's ardor, but a very discreditable abandonment of principle. It is only a fortnight since he declared from the pulpit that it was
lead_paragraph: Dr. CHEEVER has actually "petitioned" the Senate to release THADDEUS HYATT. This is not only a sad falling off in the reverend gentleman's ardor, but a very discreditable abandonment of principle. It is only a fortnight since he declared from the pulpit that it was "the people's" duty to go to Washington and take HYATT out of jail by force of arms; and still more recently he has insisted upon it that the whole question was one of principle -- that it was the power of the Senate which was in dispute -- that HYATT did not want to come out through an act of grace; but demanded his liberation as an act of justice. There were consequently in the eyes of all the Doctor's followers but three issues to this affair in the least degree probable: either that the Senate would discharge the prisoner unconditionally; or that the congregation of the church of the Puritans would break open the jail; or that HYATT would die in his cell.

abstract: The Committees of the Common Council having in charge the preparations for the reception of the Japanese Embassy, notwithstanding all the advice we have lavished upon them, are likely, we fear, to overdo the matter in their straining after unwanted effects. In a card published by them this morning they recommend the merchants to close their stores at 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, at the time of the expected arrival of the
lead_paragraph: -- The Committees of the Common Council having in charge the preparations for the reception of the Japanese Embassy, notwithstanding all the advice we have lavished upon them, are likely, we fear, to overdo the matter in their straining after unwanted effects. In a card published by them this morning they recommend the merchants to close their stores at 2 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, at the time of the expected arrival of the distinguished strangers. This is a suggestion of folly worthy of the Chairman of the Joint Committee. The only wonder is that the suggestion is not also made that the stores along the route of the procession be draped in mourning. Closing the stores of the City on such an occasion, and thus shutting from view one of its chiefest attractions, would be but a sorry way in which to indicate our gladness at the arrival among us of those whose presence, it is hoped, is to herald the opening of a trade with a distant country which will enure to the advantage of our merchants. It strikes us that it would be more sensible to recommend that the stores be arranged in the most attractive manner, that those whom we intend to honor may form an adequate conception, at first view, of the richness of the great commercial emporium of the country which has been the first to induce them to break through the reserve of centuries.

abstract: Spencer T. Parmlee vs. The New-York Steam-Heating Company. -- This case came up at the Chambers Special Term of the Supreme Court, before Justice BONNEY. The plaintiff sues to recover $42 000 damages of the defendants for refusing to transfer certain shares of stock on their books, which he purchased of one John Morris who indorsed to him the certificate of the stock in the usual manner, and which was transferable by the surrender of the certificate. The stock is alleged to have increased in value, being several hundred shares, and the Company refused to make the transfer on the ground that Morris had bought it of Lewis M. Hills, their President, and had not paid the notes he gave for it, and had agreed to return it, and that the plaintiff had no title to it.

lead_paragraph: The objection raised in the Senate by Mr. FITCH, of Indiana, and supported by Mr. MASON, of Virginia, to the reception of a petition presented by Mr. SUMNER, on the ground that the same gentleman had previously presented one from negroes, stying themselves persons of African descent, seems to indicate clearly that the Pro-Slavery Party in the Senate are clean "gone demented." The BOURBONS or STUARTS were sensible, clear-headed fellows in comparison with the personages who now form the majority of the Upper House of Congress.

abstract: ENCOUNTER WITH A BURGLAR. Yesterday morning, about 4 o'clock, a man named CONSTANT RUPP, residing at East Newark, was awakened by a noice in the house, and upon getting up to ascertain the cause, he detected a burglar ransacking the premises. Mr. RUPP at once closed with him, when the
lead_paragraph: ENCOUNTER WITH A BURGLAR. -- Yesterday morning, about 4 o'clock, a man named CONSTANT RUPP, residing at East Newark, was awakened by a noice in the house, and upon getting up to ascertain the cause, he detected a burglar ransacking the premises. Mr. RUPP at once closed with him, when the latter drew a dirk and stabbed him in the wrist, and with a slashing cut severed the cords of the other wrist. The burglar was secured, and on his person was found a valuable gold chain, the property of THOMAS CRAIG, of the Jarvis House, which had also been burglariously entered. The prisoner, WM. R. IRVING, alias Kelly, was taken to the Hudson County jail by Constable SHEPPARD to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: We publish in another column, from yesterday's Tribune, the letter from Mr. GREELEY to GOV. SEWARD, written in November, 1854, and formally dissolving the political partnership which was assumed to have existed between the parties up to that time. This letter is published upon the demand of Mr. GREELEY,
lead_paragraph: We publish in another column, from yesterday's Tribune, the letter from Mr. GREELEY to GOV. SEWARD, written in November, 1854, and formally dissolving the political partnership which was assumed to have existed between the parties up to that time. This letter is published upon the demand of Mr. GREELEY, for the purpose of refuting a statement made in the TIMES to the effect that his hostility to Gov. SEWARD, manifested so effectively at the Chicago Convention, had its origin in the refusal, or neglect, of Gov. SEWARD to secure for Mr. GREELEY certain political offices to which he believed he had valid claims. Upon this point the letter speaks for itself. It is explicit enough in its language to enable every reader to judge whether it refutes or confirms the original statement, that Mr. GREELEY had been disappointed in his expectations of office, and that he held Gov. SEWARD personally and politically responsible for his failures.

abstract: This regatta took place on Wednesday, in presence of the largest gathering of ladies and friends of the members that has yet occurred at the annual regattas of this club. There was not any wind at the time of starting, but between 2 and 3 o'clock a
lead_paragraph: This regatta took place on Wednesday, in presence of the largest gathering of ladies and friends of the members that has yet occurred at the annual regattas of this club. There was not any wind at the time of starting, but between 2 and 3 o'clock a breeze sprung up which lasted a couple of hours, and then gradually lulled again, preventing the Quick Step and Joseph Colgate from getting back in time. During the regatta the Club-house -- which was decorated with flags -- was enlivened by a fine band of music, to which the company arrayed themselves during the afternoon by dancing. The wharf and shore adjoining the Club-house was crowded.

abstract: REPUBLICAN MEETING IN THE FIRST WARD.  The ratification meeting of the First Ward Republican Association, which came off last evening, disappointed the most sanguine friends of the cause in that locality. About two thousand persons assembled,
lead_paragraph: REPUBLICAN MEETING IN THE FIRST WARD. -- The ratification meeting of the First Ward Republican Association, which came off last evening, disappointed the most sanguine friends of the cause in that locality. About two thousand persons assembled, who testified their approval of the proceedings by a respectful attention to the speeches, and by frequent applause of the sentiments uttered. The stand was erected on the south side of Bowling Green. Shortly after 8 o'clock the meeting was organized by the election of ROBERT S. GOULD, President; AMOR J. WILLIAMSON, and a large list of others for Vice-Presidents; and EVERARDO WARREN, and six others as secretaries of the meeting. Mr. WARREN then read a series of resolutions, cheerfully and heartily indorsing the nominations made at Chicago for President and Vice-President of the United States, and eulogizing the candidates as the best that could have been selected to rescue the country from its present corrupt and imbecile Government; approving of the platform of principles laid down in the platform, and pledging their unanimous and earnest support of the same. JOSEPH HOXIE, Esq., was introduced. He came forward amid a shower of fire-works, and proceeded to address the audience in his usual earnest and humorous manner, upon the prospects of the campaign. He was frequently interrupted by applause. CYRUS B. DUTCHER followed Mr. HOXIE, and Mr. ANGEL from the western part of the State, STEWART L. WOODFORD and others spoke. Refreshments were supplied in a room of the Washington Hotel, which were well patronized by the hungry and thirsty. The General Superintendent of Police was present with a strong force to prevent disturbance, but happily their services were not needed.

abstract: EXPLOSION Loss $4,000. At about 3 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, an explosion took place in the fireworks' storehouse of Messrs. BOCH  PUCHTA, on Green-street, near Union-avenue, Greenpoint, which destroyed the building and contents, valued at $4,000.
lead_paragraph: EXPLOSION -- Loss $4,000. -- At about 3 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, an explosion took place in the fireworks' storehouse of Messrs. BOCH PUCHTA, on Green-street, near Union-avenue, Greenpoint, which destroyed the building and contents, valued at $4,000. Two men, named URICH HOARE and HENRY WANDS, were arrested by Sergeant BRUCE and Officer DODD, of the Seventh Precinct Police, on suspicion of having set fire to the building. HOARE was discharged by Messrs. BOCH & PUCHTA, yesterday morning for intoxication, the owners not considering it safe to trust such a man about their establishment. A few minutes before the explosion occurred he was seen leaving the building, and it is supposed that he kindled a fire under it. The other man was arrested because he is an intimate associate of HOARE's. There was no person on the premises at the time, and, therefore, there was no one injured.

abstract: A farewell meeting of the friends of Rev. Dr. McCLINTOCK was held in St. Paul's M.E. Church in Fourth-avenue on Wednesday evening, to testify their respect to him on the eve of his departure for Europe to assume the charge of the American Chapel in Paris. A very large congregation was in attendance, including many clergymen of different denominations. After the singing of an anthem by the
lead_paragraph: A farewell meeting of the friends of Rev. Dr. McCLINTOCK was held in St. Paul's M.E. Church in Fourth-avenue on Wednesday evening, to testify their respect to him on the eve of his departure for Europe to assume the charge of the American Chapel in Paris. A very large congregation was in attendance, including many clergymen of different denominations. After the singing of an anthem by the choir, the services of the occasion were opened by the reading of passages of Scripture, followed by prayer from Rev. Dr. HAGUE Rev. Dr. DE WITT, President of the American and Foreign Christian Union, under whose auspices the American Chapel in Paris was erected, and by whose invitation Dr. MCCLINTOCK is to assume its pastorate, then addressed the audience in a few remarks explanatory of the objects and aims of the Paris Chapel, and the interest felt at the present time among Evangelical Christians of all denominations in its prosperity. He closed by introducing Rev. Dr. FAIRCHILD, the Secretary of the Union, who, he said, would read the instructions which had been drawn by the Society for the guidance of Dr. MCCLINTOCK in the discharge of his duties. These instructions were embodied in a very lengthy document, which was read to Dr. MCCLINTOCK, and which laid out for him an amount of labor in connection with his duties as pastor of the American Chapel in Paris, which must have convinced him, as it certainly did the audience, that the place was no sinecure. He was to do his part towards overcoming that great obstacle to the evangelization of the heathen world -- the Romish Church; he was to preach the gospel every Sunday without sectarian bias; he was to spend the week days in hunting up the American visitors in Paris, making their acquaintance, and reminding them of their Christian duties; he was to seek out particularly that portion of Young America which visits the gay French Capital for the purpose of spending their time in dissipation and riotous living, and to impress them with the error of their ways; and last, not least, he was to write a letter at least once a month to the American and Foreign Christian Union, giving a full account of his stewardship. The formula of doctrine to be observed in the services of the American Chapel was that adopted by the Evangelical Alliance at its session in Exeter Hall, in 1846.

abstract: Mayor Wood has achieved another substantial victory. By one of those bold strokes upon which desperate men sometimes venture, he has secured for himself a far greater degree of power than he ever hoped for. He came into office last January bewailing the fact, that State legislation had made all the Departments of the City Government independent of his authority, and protesting against
lead_paragraph: Mayor WOOD has achieved another substantial victory. By one of those bold strokes upon which desperate men sometimes venture, he has secured for himself a far greater degree of power than he ever hoped for. He came into office last January bewailing the fact, that State legislation had made all the Departments of the City Government independent of his authority, and protesting against being held responsible, under such circumstances, for the anticipated failure of his administration. The Supreme Court yesterday enlightened him, as well as the public in general, very essentially upon the extent of his powers. They decided that, wih the consent of the Board of Aldermen, he has full and complete authority to remove at discretion any of the heads of Departments, whose removal is expressly forbidden by the Charter except for cause. In other words, the Court decides that the Mayor and Aldermen are the sole judges of the "cause" for which any officer may be removed; and that it is for them alone to say whether any cause shall be required.

abstract: In the case of Adrian Mariotte, the billiard saloon keper, whose trial for puchasing -- technically termed, "receiving" -- a set of billiard balls, under the allegation that he knew them to have been stolen, was continued yesterday. The sole witnesses against him were the parties who committed the theft, while the witnesses called by his counsel, Mr. H.L. Clinton, gave him an excellent character, and proved that he had no reason to suppose the balls were stolen. Recorder BARNARD, in his charge to the jury, gave due weight to the testimony on both sides, and the jury, after a brief deliberation, brought in a verdict of not guilty.

abstract: John Wainwright, Trustee, &c., of the separate estate of Mary Nix vs. Arthur Nix. -- This was an action tried in the Superior Court before Justice MONCRIEF, and which arose out of the following circumstances: Previously to 1846, and on the 14th day of that year, Mary Nix was a milliner, whose place of business was in Philadelphia, she was possessed of considerable property in money, stock-in-trade, furniture, leasehold property, plate, &c., amounting to about $5,000, as claimed. On the date mentioned the plaintiff, Mary, married the defendant, Arthur Nix, who, as alleged, was comparatively without property. The parties cohabited together, and in January, 1847, the defendant, his wife, and Wainright, as Trustee, &c. executed a deed, tripartite, by which the defendant conveyed to the plaintiff, Wainright, all the estate, property and effects, of every name and character, of which he, as husband or otherwise, became possessed. This conveyance was for the separate benefit of Mary Nix. On the execution of the deed, Wainright executed a power of attorney to the wife, by which she was empowered to possess and manage the property so conveyed to him or his agent. Assuming such agency, in November, 1847, the plaintiff, Mary Nix, disposed of her property, including her millinery business, which she had continued to conduct in her own name, and came on this City, where, at Harlem, she began the wax-bleaching business, in partnership with one Samuel Childs -- (Arthur Nix acting as the clerk and agent of his wife.) In January, 1849, the partnership was dissolved, and the plaintiff, Mary, and her husband, continued the business until February, 1859, when the husband and wife separated, the property of the wife remaining with the husband, who possessed himself of it, as alleged, and converted it to his own use. The defendant, on the trial, admitted that he should pay $5,000 to his wife under the deed of trust.

abstract: ST. PAULDE LOANDO, West Coast of Africa. Twice have I, in my journeyings around the  borders of this darkened land, come upon LIVINGSTONE'S footprints. abstract: The real question at issue appears to be whether we shall continue our intercourse with China on our terms or on hers. Our terms are those on which we communicate with all the nations of the world -- simplicity, frankness, hospitality, high principle and equality, as between gentlemen. The Chinese, on the contrary, insist on keeping up the illusion of an unapproachable sovereign, an irresponsible Central Government, and the not less startling illusion of an infinitely superior morality and sense of decorum. So long as we permit this illusion, and endure its natural consequences, we must be liable to continual insult and degradation, to frequent interruption of intercourse, to the cost and trouble of reinstating ourselves, and the odium of waging war with a people who know the proprieties neither of peace nor of war, and over whom victory itself is a scandal. This is best understood by the analogies of private life. It may be necessary to have intercourse with inferior people, but it is for us to choose whether we will associate with them on their terms or our own. We may, if we please, condescend to their insulated ideas, listen to their petty quarrels, their invidious estimate of all classes above them, their perpetual tone of depreciation, their immensely exaggerated opinion of themselves, and the substitution of one or two distorted ideas and inflated sentiments for the recognized maxims and common sense of well-bred and well-educated people. If we do this we inevitably sink to their level, and wallow with them in the same Stygian pool of malignity and folly. The only escape is to dictate our own terms; to maintain truth, kindliness, and mutual respect; and to consider ourselves, not as conspiring against society for some paltry game of our own, but cooperating with it for our common good. Some such account may be given of the terms on which we may demand, and do demand, to communicate with China. The time has gone by when she could impose her conditions; they are condemned by the result; we have tried them and failed; we must now impose our conditions with such gentle force as may be found necessary. All policies are judged by the result, -- not our private advantage, but the final development. The result of ovr former weak and temporizing policy in China is that we are outcasts, and at war, at the very time that our trade is greater than ever, and some hundred thousand Chinese are settled in the British dominions. The result on China herself is that she is torn to pieces and her population decimated by a wide-spread rebellion, and she is driven to immense cost in the idle defenc of her barbarous system.

abstract: Bodenstedt, the great German Shakesperian scholar, who visited England on purpose to inspect the Perkins Follo, has brought out a section of an important work, Shakespeare's Contemporaries and their Works, to consist of sketches and translations. The present installment comprises the plays of John Ford, with specimens of Decker and Rowley.

abstract: The New-York City Charter has not done much for the welfare of the Metropolis, but it has at least enlarged the bounds of science. There was an English savant who thought he had created a living being, and called it an acarus. It was not a very noble creature, being only a sort of impotent and almost imperceptible flea; but it would have been a great thing, no doubt, to make it, had it been made. It was not made, however, and the clever country gentleman was forced to cry Ichabod over his achievement.

abstract: The differences between the rival champions, SAYERS and HEENAN, were brought to an amicable termination last evening, when a silver belt, of precisely the same make and value, was formally presented to each of the great pugilists. The interesting ceremony which so auspiciously closes this novel Anglo-American "difficulty," and sets an example which the diplomatists of the two nations would do well to imitate in the adjustment of their future controversies, took place in the Alhambra Palace, Leicester-square, in the presence of many patrons of the "noble art." The champions, who were loudly cheered on their entrance into the peaceful "ring" recently devoted to the feats of HOWE and CUSHING's troupe, were introduced to the spectators by Mr. CALDWELL as "the two bravest men who had honored the world since the days of WELLINGTON and NAPOLEON." High as might be this opening panegyric, it was fully indorsed by the plaudits of the audience. The belts, the coveted recompenoe of such matchless skill and endurance, lay upon a table in the centre of the arena, the winners and their friends being grouped around them. Before the addresses were delivered which were to precede the award the pugilists advanced half-way towards each other, and cordially shook hands, in token of their final reconciliation. The first belt of the two was presented to HEENAN, accompanied by an address written on parchment, which was formally read amid the vociferous cheering of the concourse by Mr. DOWLING. This address was as follows: ENGLAND TO JOHN C. HEENAN, "THE BENECIA BOY."

abstract: The citizens of the Border States are at last beginning to raise their voices against the wholesale robbery, of which the United States Post-office is now being made the instrument by the Pro-Slavery zealots of the South, with the active connivance of Mr. Postmaster-General HOLT. Twenty-one citizens of Kent County, Maryland, have determined not to leave the task of defending their rights any longer to the Northern Press alone, but to...
lead_paragraph: The citizens of the Border States are at last beginning to raise their voices against the wholesale robbery, of which the United States Post-office is now being made the instrument by the Pro-Slavery zealots of the South, with the active connivance of Mr. Postmaster-General HOLT. Twenty-one citizens of Kent County, Maryland, have determined not to leave the task of defending their rights any longer to the Northern Press alone, but to stand up for them themselves, and have accordingly protested solemnly and publicly against the action of the Grand Jury of the county in presenting newspapers and books as "incendiary" by wholesale, and thus preventing their delivery to the owners by the Post-office, under Mr. HOLT's rule.

abstract: On Wednesday morning a black canvas traveling bag was found on the Paterson dock, which had been cut open -- the articles it contained and the bag itself being stained with blood. The supposition then was that it had been stolen from the railroad cars, and that the blood was from a cut on the hand of the thief, made in the haste to get at the contents. From papers found in the bag, it was judged to belong to a Mr. W.S. BROWN, who, it would seem, was transacting business for or with Messrs. NORTHUP & MARTIN, Newark. Yesterday morning the bag was fully identified as Mr. BUNN's by Mr. MARTIN, one of the firm in Newark above mentioned. Mr. BUNN is a married man, about 35 years of age, with a family residing in Rathboneville, a small village in Steuben County, N.Y., where he had in operation a small flouring mill. He left his home on Monday morning last to go to Newark, since which time nothing has been heard of him. He had in his possession between $1,500 and $1,600 with to pay a note in Newark and one at the American Exchange Bank, New-York, which was due yesterday. It is supposed that he arrived in Jersey City, on Tuesday night, to take the 11 o'clock train for Newark, and it is now thought that he met with violence near the depot. He has always been regarded as a man of exemplary habits, and the worst apprehensions felt by his friends in respect to his appearance and the finding of his travelling bag under such alarming circumstances. The money which Mr. BURN had in his possession was on the Sussex County Bank, of Newton, New-Jersey, Mayor VAN VORST, yestorday morning, directed Coroner GAFFFEY to institute a careful search in the vicinity, where the bag was found. The missing man is five feet five inches high, somewhat stout, and is well known on the Erie Railroad, on which he has frequently travelled, for the purpose of selling flour.

abstract: The appointment of Capt. HALL, and his assumption of the command of the Great Eastern, has already produced a great improvement in her external appearance. The approaching visitor instantly feels that she no longer looks like a dark object of dread -- a long black coffin, surmounted with funnel-shaped plumes -- but a respectable packet ship, vast in proportions truly, but light and elegant in spite of her size. This result has been obtained by a streak of while paint along her sides, and the substitution of stone color for the black paint formerly on her funnels. The quantity of black paint about her masthead will also be reduced with still further advantage. Capt. HALL has determined to make her trysail gaffs movable, so as to admit of their being readily lowered on deck; and if these and the yards and topmasts are struck in a rolling sea, there is no doubt that any unpleasant motion of the vessel will be materially reduced. He has wisely decided that, as the upper decks are soft and porous, "holystoning," that humiliating and disagreeable task to the sailor-man, must be avoided, and the only way to make the decks water-tight and useful will be to apply repeated coats of bright varnish. Improvements in the machinery for steering are also in progress; these include an additional wheel, (to the same barrel,) which will allow the direct power of more men to be applied in lieu of steam. The next alteration must be a longer tiller, and, consequently, more leverage. Speaking-tubes between the forecastle, paddle-bridge and quarter-deck, and a steam whistle, are also being fitted; and among many of the commander's improvements not the least valuable will be a mode of safely lowering the boats down the lofty sides, by the use of a movable and running clip attached to the boat, which, taking temporary hold of a long sheer-batten, will bear the boat clear from the side during its descent, a matter of much importance when the ship is in motion; in some instances a similar result is to be obtained by the use of a fixed taut perpendicular rope and ring, instead of the sheer-batten and clip.

abstract: It is frequently remarked that our sectional differences would disappear if the people of each section could mingle more with those of the other A prominent New-York Democrat has been trying...
lead_paragraph: -- It is frequently remarked that our sectional differences would disappear if the people of each section could mingle more with those of the other A prominent New-York Democrat has been trying the experime[???] esiding at the South during the past Winter [???] perhaps, as staunch a supporter of [???]culiar institution as ever, but he objects [???]airpeculiarities of Southern society. While at P[???]atka, for instance, he was called upon by a Judge whose slumbers had been disturbed the night before by a serenade, and asked if he was one of the party. He said "No." The Judge replied that he was glad of it, for he meant to shoot on sight the first participant he could find. Our friend said he was glad he had not been present, as he did not like to travel 600 miles to be shot. A companion hinted that it was 1,200 miles, whereupon the Judge turned upon him, and said if he was disposed to take the matter up he would shoot him also. At another Southern town, while sitting upon the piazza of the hotel, our friend was amused by the sight of a dog running, yelping and howling, with a tin pail tied to his tail. Before he had done laughing the owner of the dog came along, declaring that he would shoot the man that tied the pail to his dog's tail, and being more than half disposed to shoot our Democratic friend for laughing at it! He has come back to New-York convinced that our Southern brethren, with all their virtues, might somewhat improve their style of redressing grievances.

abstract: Under the head of "Impressions of the Old School Assembly," the Evangel st replies to some remarks made by the Observer last week regarding the spirit of the New School Assembly. The article is in the form of a letter, dated at Rochester. It says, among other things, that "An impression has been made on some minds during the sessions of the Assembly, that New-School men in the vicinity were seized with a longing to return to the old hive. This is a grave error. The fact that they were hospitable and fraternal warranted no such interpretation as this. They do feel an interest in those whose great ecclesiastical principles are identical with their own. They have, during these sessions, experienced something of that fraternal sympathy, which in spite of all his wrongs, Joseph felt for [???] elder brethren when they were his guests in Egypt; but at the same time New-School men in this vicinity are, so far as we know, better satisfied with their position than ever before." The writer claims that the position of the New School Assembly on the subject of Slavery is much more satisfactory to Presbyterians in Western New-York than that of the Old School. While the differences between the two Presbyterian branches will become less, the great point of distinction in years to come will be that of virtually Pro-Slavery and conservatively Anti-Slavery influence. The resolution adopted by the Assembly on the subject of Slavery is not considered such ground for believing the Assembly safe from dissension as the conservative character of her strongest men, and the pacific disposition of the Southern members. Then, too, it is urged that the leaders have kept the Assembly in admirable discipline and that there are "no such bishops elsewhere in Protestant Christendom as may be found, to the number of a dozen or a score, in the Old School Church " These remarks are made in reply to some of like spirit recently contained in the Observer.

abstract: The Japanese Ambassadors are expected in this City to-day. They will be welcomed as becomes the representatives of that great and mysterious Empire on their first visit to this the Yeddo of the Western Hemisphere. The arrangements made by our authorities and citizens for their reception are on the most liberal scale, and the panorama of their escort from their landing at the Battery to their head-quarters at the Metropolitan Hotel, will probably form one of the most novel and imposing spectacles ever witnessed in this City.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese Ambassadors are expected in this City to-day. They will be welcomed as becomes the representatives of that great and mysterious Empire on their first visit to this the Yeddo of the Western Hemisphere. The arrangements made by our authorities and citizens for their reception are on the most liberal scale, and the panorama of their escort from their landing at the Battery to their head-quarters at the Metropolitan Hotel, will probably form one of the most novel and imposing spectacles ever witnessed in this City.

abstract: The steamor Niagara reached her wharf at Boston yesterday morning at 7 1/2 o'clock, and her mails were forwarded to this City by the morning train. We received our correspondence, exchanges, &c., at 5 1/2 o'clock P.M. The telegraphic dispatch from Hallfax, which we published yesterday morning, gave so complete a statement of the news by this arrival -- which is to the 2d of June, three days later than had been previously received -- that very little remains to be added. Our letters, however, and the extracts from our foreign files contain details of considerable interest, which will be found below.

abstract: From all that we can learn from the island, it is plain that the rule of King FRANCIS is doomed, and that no reconciliation can take place between him and his subjects. The cause of this state of things has been alluded to, but involves details so revolting and incredible that, though vouched for by Italians of the highest note, though the subject of indignant denunciation by Mr. GLADSTONE, though corroborated by the official dispatches of the English Minister at Naples, though made a reason, four years ago, for breaking off diplomatic relations with the Court of the Two Sicilies, yet we hardly know how to speak of them. Statements, have, however, been published in Paris which, if true, leave no doubt that the horrors enacted in Naples have been far surpassed by the crimes which have driven the Sicilians into rebellion. The capital and the adjoining territory are chastised with whips, but Sicily with scorpions. We may express our conviction that the facts we are about to narrate are essentially true. Certain details may be highly colored, and a melo dramatic air aiven to deeds which are only stupidly horrible; but the evidence from so many quarters is concurrent, and the names and dates are too fully particularized and the charges have been too long uncontradicted for us to doubt their accuracy. The Government of the King of Naples must be convicted of crimes compared with which the brutalities of Ferdinand VII, or the insanities of the Grand Duke Constantine are insignificant.

abstract: The Richmond Enquirer says that Hon. HANNIBAL HAMLIN has been franking Republican documents to residents of that city. It waxes eloquent under the provocation as follows:" If HANNIBAL HAMLIN fancies that the trash he is so eager to spead broadcast will help him down, here in his Helparisn, he may make up his mind to it that he will find himself just as helpless as his Carthagenian namesake did in his effort to take Rome. We saw one of these documents yesterday addressed to Dr. THEODORE MAYO, primed in Dutch too, (German we mean.) Now, is'nt this a good joke? Only trunk of HAMLIN'S sending a German document to a man who don't understand a word of it, but who was actually at Harper's Ferry as Orderly Sergeant of the Howi zers, for the express purpose or blowing HAMLIN sky-high, if he came in the way and sending him to fill the vice-chair to the black president of the place down below. HANNIEAL HAMLIN, there is no hope for thee[???] The nominee of the Democratic Convention will prove a Scipio to thee, and the Democratic dose thou will get at the next election will end thy career as surely as poison did the life of HANNEAL the Carthagenian. Let every one who gets one of the documents we allude to, pack it back again to the Helper hound. A large number of the documents have been sent here to people high and low."

abstract: For some days we have been obliged to look upon the result of the Sicilian insurrection as doubtful. The confident dispatches, claiming victory after victory, which were issued by the Neapolitan Government, together with the absence of any definite news from GARIBALDI himself, gave some ground for alarm. Happily these fears are dissipated by the intelligence which we are able to publish to-day. GARIBALDI entered Palermo on the 27th. The capital of Sicily is in his hands. In spite of every deficiency the levies commanded by the heroic Italian drove the troops from their positions. Henceforth GARIBALDI has all the moral and material strength derived from the possession of the chief place in the island. Timely supplies of men and materials will be the fruits of victory. Its moral effecte will be the discouragement of the army, and perhaps a large desertion to the ranks of the patriots. The whole interior of the country, together with its most important city, have now been wrested from the Royal authority. From one end to the other the island has been cleared of the Royal troops. It is now evident that the encounter at Calata Fimi was a victory for GARIBALDI. Instead of the troops attacking him, it is probable that he drove them from their positions, and then harried them on before him to Palermo. The troops have been driven out from their lines before the town, and probably only command the spot on which they are encamped. Far different is the position of the national party. From the beginning it seems that the Sicilians have had confidence in their leader, for they have joined him in crowds, quitting the towns held by the Neapolitan garrisons, and coming to swell the adventurous bands of GARIBALDI in the open country. We may therefore now consider that he has achieved almost certain success. He has the country at his back, and can obtain obtain supplies of all kinds from the interior; he can communicate with his adherents in any part of the island, while the royal garrisons are all divided from each other, and intelligence can only pass between them by sea. Now that Palermo is taken, the fate of those other garrisons is sealed. They must fall one by one, none being strong enough to resist such a force as GARIBALDI has at command without assistance from its neighbors.

abstract: "Italia fara de' sel" Italy is indeed deciding her own destiny. Every day which passed under the blue sky of Sicily and over the heroic march of GARIBALDI and his liberating army, bequeaths a new proof that the blow which prostrated Austria at Solferino sent down with the foreign tyrant every buttress of that hideous system miscalled a Government, under which the people of Italy have for forty years been writhing in a fierce but...
lead_paragraph: "Italia fara de' se!" Italy is indeed deciding her own destiny. Every day which passed under the blue sky of Sicily and over the heroic march of GARIBALDI and his liberating army, bequeaths a new proof that the blow which prostrated Austria at Solferino sent down with the foreign tyrant every buttress of that hideous system miscalled a Government, under which the people of Italy have for forty years been writhing in a fierce but never in an apathetic misery. Though called by a dozen different names, and vested in as many different rulers, this system has been virtually one and the same in Venice and in Sicily, in Modena and in the States of the Church. Force and fraud have been the very conditions of its existence; cruelty and rapine its familiar machinery of control. All the rest of the world had gradually grown away from the ideas of the Congress of Vienna; and it was hard, not for Americans only, but for Englishmen, for Frenchmen, even for Germans to conceive how fully and blindly and passionately Austria and the Austro-Italian sovereigns clung to these ideas still. The Pope and his Cardinals, the King of Naples arid his Councillors, the Northern Dukes and their favorites, believed in 1858, and lived up to the belief, as their predecessors had done in 1815, that the waves of the revolution of 1789 had been forever stayed on the shores of Italy and the Apostolic Empire. The mad and misguided Democracies of 1848 followed, and chastised by the reaction of 1840, had only confirmed this conviction. The King-craft of the Hapsburgs and their Italian dependents was of the simplest and most antique pattern. To cringe and lie in the moment of danger; to scourge and silence in the hour of victory, was the creed alike of FRANCIS JOSEPH and his crowned satellites beyond the Alps. For ten long years the Austrian Emperor had reigned in this creed of practice; for ten years, each one of which in its passage had, insensibly to him, been wearing away the very ground-walls of his throne, -- for each in its passage had been extending the relations of his people with the rest of the world, and making them more clearly recognize at once the depth of their own degradation, and the questionable reality of the power which towered above them.

abstract: Selection of a proper location for mooring the Great Eastern, after her arrival at this port, has been a subject of some difficulty, on account of her immense length, her heavy draft of water, and the necessity of having her lie afloat at all times of tide. The first suggestion to have her ancored and moored head and stern in the North River opposite the Battery, was open to grave objections on account of the large number of sailing-vessels and steamers which are constantly passing, and the liability of collisions and accidents. The difficulty and increased expense of boarding her while at anchor was another objection which the public, at least, would be likely to make the ground of serious complaint. It was finally determined to have her placed alongside of the dock, and near the Hammond-street pier, North River, was selected for that purpose. The wharf is nearly 1,200 feet long, so that she will have plety of room, lying with head or stern in the dock, and be clear of passing vessels. To give the required depth it has been found necessary to dredge out a portion of the slip which the monster ship will occupy. A gate across the head of the wharf will enable the managers to control the multitude which will flock on board by issuing tickets of admission. There are various conjectures as to the time she will occupy in coming across; the majority of nautical men being disposed to give her full ten days for the trip. Large numbers will go to Staten Island on Monday and Tuesday in anticipation of her arrival, and to obtain a full-length view of the great ship as she passes through the Narrows. As soon as she is announced in the offing steamers will also start to meet her, which no doubt will carry crowds of passengers to Sandy Hook or the Southwest Spit. Should she arrive off the bar at a low stage of the tide, she will be obliged to wait for high water, which will give sufficient time for parties to go down and escort her up. The public expectation is on tip-toe, and indicates that the excitement attending the arrival of the Great Erstern will, for a time, eclipse the Japanese Embassy.

abstract: Lord BROUGHAM was installed as Chancellor of the University of Edinburgh on the 18th ult., in presence of an immense audience, comprising a large number of distinguished persons. We copy the report of his Oration on that occasion from the Londen Times of the 21st, which states that the demand for tickets was very much greater than the accommodation afforded by the largest hall in the city, which would hold only 1,800 persons.
lead_paragraph: Lord BROUGHAM was installed as Chancellor of the University of Edinburgh on the 18th ult., in presence of an immense audience, comprising a large number of distinguished persons. We copy the report of his Oration on that occasion from the Londen Times of the 21st, which states that the demand for tickets was very much greater than the accommodation afforded by the largest hall in the city, which would hold only 1,800 persons. The Chancellor, Lord BROUGHAM, was, on entering the hall, received with the loudest cheering. He "wore a magnificent flowered satin robe, with rich gold embroidery, and a black square cap with golden tassel," and walked up the passage to the platform arm in arm with Sir DAVID BREWSTER, Principal and Vice-Chancellor of the University. The Solicitor-General, in a few sentences, introduced him to the audience.

abstract: On the report of Mr. MASON, Chairman of the Special Committee on the Harper's Ferry Insurrection, THADDEUS HYATT was yesterday released from the custody in which, for some time past, he has been held for refusing to testify before the Committee. In connection with this proceeding, Mr. SUMMER spoke at some length, vindicating liberty of conscience, and justifying Mr. HYATT'S course. The Majority and Minority Committees on the John Brown Insurrection made...
lead_paragraph: On the report of Mr. MASON, Chairman of the Special Committee on the Harper's Ferry Insurrection, THADDEUS HYATT was yesterday released from the custody in which, for some time past, he has been held for refusing to testify before the Committee. In connection with this proceeding, Mr. SUMMER spoke at some length, vindicating liberty of conscience, and justifying Mr. HYATT's course. The Majority and Minority Committees on the John Brown Insurrection made their report. A synopsis of each we publish elsewhere. The Tariff bill was then taken up, and was strongly opposed by Mr. HUNTER, who argued that no change in the present tariff was necessary, as it afforded sufficient revenue for the economical support of the Government, and the extinguishment of the public debt. Mr. SEWARD spoke at length on the subject, and strongly advocated the bill and its immediate consideration. To postpone it to the next session, he said, would be to postpone it indefinitely. The arguments for postponing it were so weak as to show a manifest disposition to avoid the whole subject. By a vote of 25 against 23, further consideration of the bill was postponed. The Army Appropriation bill was taken up, and some of the House amendments agreed to. The Overland Telegraph bill, already passed by the House, was concurred in by the Senate. In the House the proceedings were not of much importance. The request of the Senate for another Committee of Conference on the Homestead bill was acceded to.

abstract: If we may judge by the experiences of Saturday, the people of New-York are not likely to make themselves particularly ridiculous in connection with the Japanese. They have seen too many strangers of all sects and colors, and tasted too heavy excitements, to be thrown very far off their balance  even by the envoys of a prince whose very existence was a sort of myth to most of us a very few yeas ago.
lead_paragraph: If we may judge by the experiences of Saturday, the people of New-York are not likely to make themselves particularly ridiculous in connection with the Japanese. They have seen too many strangers of all sects and colors, and tasted too heavy excitements, to be thrown very far off their balance even by the envoys of a prince whose very existence was a sort of myth to most of us a very few yeas ago. Were the Brother of the Sun and Moon, or the Sun and Moon themselves, to send us an embassy, we fancy the good people of Gotbam would contemplate the strangers with a temperate curiosity not to be equalled out of Paris. Much as we have been abused and quizzed for our "wild enthusiasm," our people have a native good sense which discriminates between events which touch the passions and those which merely move the wonder of the crowd.

abstract: The grand exodus out of town has not yet commenced. Although the heats of early Summer are come, the world has not yet gone. Even those who have their country seats to retire to after the toils and dissipations of a New-York year, seem loath to leave the metropolis. The whirl of excitement, instead of...
lead_paragraph: The grand exodus out of town has not yet commenced. Although the heats of early Summer are come, the world has not yet gone. Even those who have their country seats to retire to after the toils and dissipations of a New-York year, seem loath to leave the metropolis. The whirl of excitement, instead of abating, gets faster as the sun gets higher; great processions, public balls, operatic matinees and other amusements, usually postponed until after the dog days, are still in contemplation; the Great Eastern and the Japanese Embassy will keep many here who at this season are ordinarily refreshing themselves on the sea shore or the mountain side. It is true the inducements to remain are greater than ever before; not only the two long-expected excitements -- one from the East, and the other from the West -- are now so near at hand, but the features of our own metropolitan life are themselves becoming more attractive. Out-door sports are becoming practicable to those who do not hurry to the country. Rides and drives to the Park, regattas, horse races, cricket clubs, furnish diversion and exercise to "all sorts and conditions" of men and women; and the crowds who engage in these amusements prove that their peculiarities are fully appreciated. One regatta is hardly over before another is announced; one race follows as fast on the heels of another as the beaten horse does after his victor; and even the languid fashionable world is stirred from the apathy that ordinarily overcomes it in June, and has of late been vigorously attending fetes champetres in the neighborhood of New-York, or, since it is determined to stay in town, turns out en masse at wedding matinees.

abstract: The Democrats renew their attempt to nominate a Presidential candidate to-day, at Baltimore. Everything at present indicates a stormy session. The Douglas men are apparently desperate, and inclined to resort to desperate measures for the accomplishment of their object. They proclaim their determination to nominate Mr. DOUGLAS by a two-thirds vote, if the new delegates from the South are admitted, and by a majority resolution, if not.

abstract: By the arrival yesterday evening of the Bohemian at Farther Point, from Liverpool on the 6th inst., and Londonderry on the 7th, we have three days later intelligence from Europe. It is of considerable importance.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival yesterday evening of the Bohemian at Farther Point, from Liverpool on the 6th inst., and Londonderry on the 7th, we have three days later intelligence from Europe. It is of considerable importance. The reports concerning GARIBALDI and the bombardment of Palermo are, as usual, conflicting. According to some advices, the bombardment still continued, while others describe GARIBALDI as having stormed the citadel, after the capture of a portion of the Neapolitan artillery. Subsequent accounts state that on a proposition of General LANZIA, commander of the royal trhops, an armistice had been conclude, GARIBALDI demanding that the Neapolitan army should evacuate Palermo. This would seem to be true, as still later advices from Naples, represent the King as refusing the conditions, the recommencement of hostilities being close at hand.

abstract: The Managers of the Great Eastern seem determined to play with the public impatience to the last. Either they have no settled and matured plan of operations, or they are determined that the world at large shall not know what it is.
lead_paragraph: The Managers of the Great Eastern seem determined to play with the public impatience to the last. Either they have no settled and matured plan of operations, or they are determined that the world at large shall not know what it is. The London journal received by the Niagara all announced that the great steamer would positively sail on the 9th, the day advertised. The Times, on the morning of the 2d, the day of the Niagara's departure, said: "The Great Eastern will proceed to sea on the day appointed, whatever may be her internal condition as regards general accommodation." These assurances, in which all the other papers concur, must evidently have emanated from the management: -- yet we now receive from Messrs. GRINNELL, MINTURN & Co., her New-York consignees, the following official announcement that her day of sailing has been again postponed:

abstract: The second day of the Spring meeting takes place to-morrow. Nicholas and Throgsneck ran in the Fashion races last year. The sweepstakes for 3-year olds for $1,300 mile heats, have four entries of good horses; and the Proprietor's of $500, two heats, will close the day's performance.

abstract: Jacob Sharp vs. The Mayor, &c., of New-York. -- The decision in this case was reported in the TIMES of Monday, June 11. The opinion of the Court has now been filed. The case, it will be remembered, came before the General Term of the Supreme Court, on an appeal from an order made by Justice Clerke at the Special Term, opening the judgment and allowing the City to defend the case anew. The judgment was one rendered in favor of plaintiff for $10,953, upon the report of a referee. Comptroller Haws applied for leave to defend the case anew, which was granted, and plaintiff appealed. The following extracts form the opinion of the Court show the grounds on which the Court have affirmed the order:

abstract: We copy a paragraph from the Levant (Greek) Herald containing a piece at advice which the religious and benevolent portion of our people will do well to bear in mind.
lead_paragraph: -- We copy a paragraph from the Levant (Greek) Herald containing a piece at advice which the religious and benevolent portion of our people will do well to bear in mind. It is intended to put them on their guard against a deputation which is about to visit this country to collect funds for the erection of a hospital in Mount Lebanon. The writer characterizes the whole scheme as a down-right swindle -- as an attempt to raise money for private use by false pretences; and he cited the experience of the past as a proof of this statement. It seems that some nine years ago a very large sum of money was collected, in this country, to build schools in Lebanon. Not a single dollar has been thus expended -- the whole amount has been embezzled by the enterprising monk by whom it was collected. If these statements are true, they deserve the serious attention of the religious community.

abstract: ITEMS. A resolution will be presented to the Common Council this evening, to invite the Japanese Embassy to visit this City..... The house of W.H. CLARK, on Gates, near Franklin-avenue, was robbed of silver-ware and other property, valued in all at...
lead_paragraph: ITEMS. -- A resolution will be presented to the Common Council this evening, to invite the Japanese Embassy to visit this City.....The house of W.H. CLARK, on Gates, near Franklin-avenue, was robbed of silver-ware and other property, valued in all at about $100, on Saturday afternoon last.....A boy named SMITH, whose parents reside at No. 80 Prince-street, was run over by a milk wagon, on Myrtle-avenue, on Saturday evening, and seriously injured.....N.F. WARING, counsel for PETE DAWSON, the ex-king of the Fourth Ward, New-York, and now in State Prison serving out a sentence of nine years, for attempting to Kill a man named JOHN J. POTTS, on Saturday, in the Court of Sessions, before Judge GARRISON, moved for a new trial of his client on the ground that additional and essential testimony could now be introduced. The motion was opposed by the District Attorney. It is hardly necessary to add that Mr. POTTS, the principal witness against DAWSON, is dead.......Officer GROGAN, of the Third Precinct Police, arrested a man named GEORGE WISE, at the Hamilton-avenue Ferry, Friday night, on suspicion of having stolen two hundred weight of sugar, which he was about to carry to New-York. The accused acknowledged that he bought the sugar from Mr. THOMPSON, mate of the bark Loch Lomond, lying in the Atlantic Basin, and he was committed to answer. The mate of the bark denies selling WISE any sugar, but there is evidence that the sugar found in his possession came from the vessel's cargo, which is owned by Messrs. SEBASTIAN & BLANCO, merchants, New-York....JAMES EAGAN and PHILIP CLARE, laborers, fell a distance of twenty feet down a hoistway in WARD & Co.'s store, foot of Sedgwick-street, on Saturday, when each had a leg broken, and were otherwise severely injured. They were taken to the Long Island College Hospital....The Mayor of Cincinnati, accompanied by several officers under the City Government, recently visited this city to examine the sewerage system adopted here....A propeller of 200 tons burden was launched on Saturday last, from the yard of ELISHA S. WHITLOCK, at Greenpoint. The boat was built for Messrs. FOUNTAIN, HOMES & SON, of Middlepoint, N.J., and is to form one of a line of boats between that point and New-York City....JOHN WARD, of No. 26 Remsen street, E.D.. died on Saturday, from the effects of a rupture, caused one day last week by running a footrace....A woman described as "30 years old, light complexion, drab silk gown, white silk shawl and straw hat, has been playing the confidence game in South Brooklyn. She represents that she is a member of the Strong-place Baptist Church, and in one instance got $30 from a man to pay a fine which had been imposed upon her husband for fast driving. She is a dangerous impostor....There were 99 deaths in this city last week, of which 31 were adults, (68 children, 59 males and 40 females. There were 11 deaths by consumption.

abstract: The reception of the Japanese Envoys in this City on Saturday last, may or may not be the definite inauguratian of a new and most important era in the relations, social and commercial, of Western Christendom with the heathen East. It is rather premature to infer
lead_paragraph: The reception of the Japanese Envoys in this City on Saturday last, may or may not be the definite inauguratian of a new and most important era in the relations, social and commercial, of Western Christendom with the heathen East. It is rather premature to infer from the presence among us of these inquiring guests that the old Exclusivism of the Mongol monarchies is immediately to give way to a large, liberal and progressive policy of unfettered intercourse between the realms of the Western Pacific and the rest of mankind. Two centuries ago the powerful empire of Anam sent its Ambassadors to the court of LOUIS XIV., and established the most delightful harmony between its gold-coated envoys and the embroidered noblesse of Versailles. But conservatism dies hard the world over, and at least not more easily in the East than in the West. Anam has since persecuted the Christians, abolished treaties, annihilated commerce, and shrunk back into her shell, from which France and Spain are even now urging her with bayonets and bullets once more to emerge. And it is only fair to warn our impulsive countrymen against counting too confidently upon any complete and permanent results from the marvelous experiment which the rulers of Japan are now making, and of which this country has been made the conspicuous theatre.

abstract: The proceedings in the Senate yesterday were interesting and important. Mr. WILSON's amendment to the Navy Appropriation bill, proposing to provide three steamers for the suppression of the African slave trade, was debated. Mr. COLLMER, of Vermont, said that the time had come to have some understanding with ourselves and the British Government in relation to the slave trade. The British Government, finding that emancipation had not worked well in her West Indian Colonies, captures Africans and sends them to Sierra Leone or St. Helena, where they are induced to become voluntary laborers for the West India Islands. The British Government gives $25 a head for them, and the effect was that both British and American coasters have an inducement to ship as many slaves as they can, to get the Rritish prize-money, while we, on our srde of the treaty, have to furnish our ships, hire our men, and pay $100 each for every African captured, and $100 each to send them back. So long as this was the case, so long would the Slave-trade continue. After some remarks by Mr. MASON, Mr. WILSON said he would not defend Great Britain. She might be false and hypocritical in relation to the Slave-trade, but assailing her did not justify us. He knew of nine vessels which had sailed within the last six months from New-York, and one at least from New-Orleans, to engage in that trade. We wanted for its suppression small steamers that could enter the bays and rivers of Africa, and sail swiftly, and not the large 80-gun vessels we have Mr. MALLORY denounced the conduct of Great Britain, in reference to the treaty, as a fraud practiced under the name of philanthropy. She could stop the Slave-trade with Cuba any day if she chose to do it. He said that no prominent man in the South was in favor of the Slave-trade. Mr. SEWARD said that a year ago he had introduced a proposition to increase the naval force and police to prevent the escape of slavers, and Southern Senators, opposed to the Slave-trade, had approved his bill. He was not prepared to abrogate the treaty with Great Britain, which required us to keep a squadron on the African coast, but he preferred that we should not make Great Britain a police for us. England had enough to do to take care of herself. The Slave-trade that we should abolish was our own trade. We should prevent our own merchants from fitting out ships, and our citizens from buying Africans. After further debate a vote was taken on the amendment, and it was lost by a vote of 18 against 25. The Navy Appropriation bill was passed. The business in the House yesterday was not of much importance. The Civil Appropriation bill was amended by the appropriation of $350,000 for the extension of the Treasury Building, $300,000 for the prosecution of the Capitol extension, with $205,000 for labor and materials, and $47,600 for the purchase of marble columns for the Capitol.

abstract: MURDER BY A SLAVE. -- The Atlanta (Georgia) Intelligencer gives the substance of a letter from Hon. W.R. NICHOLL, of Oglethorpe Co., Georgia, detailing a horrible murder perpetrated by a negro in the employ of Mr. WM.P. SMITH. JIM, the negro, was ordered by Mr. SMITH to do a piece of work, which he refused to do, peremptorily. An altercation ensued, and Mr. SMITH told the negro, if he wished to quarrel with him, to go to the house. The two started together, Mr. SMITH walking in front. Just as he entered the gate, the negro asked Mr. SMITH what he intended to do with him. As he made no reply, the negro sprang upon him and stabbed him sixteen times, jumping upon his victim as he fell. Mrs. SMITH, with some negroes who were in the house, witnessed the scene, and managed finally to drag the murderer away. He fled to a straw-house, where was captured the next morning Mr. SMITH died soon afterwards. The People had determined to burn his murderer alive.

abstract: THE BOARD OF ALDERMAN AND THE CROTON BOARD -- NEGLECT OF PUBLIC BUSINESS. -- The Board of Aldermen held last night along and somewhat stormy session, some of the members evidently feeling that they would be much more pleasantly located in waiting upon the Japanese. For this, or possibly some other reason, they have omitted for the past three weeks to open and read a communication from the Croton Department on a topic of great importance, especially to parties owning property in the upper part of the Island. Of course as the communication has not been officially read, it would be impertinent on the part of the reporter to anticipate its contents, but when it is asserted that it calls earnest attention to the necessity of draining and sewering that portion of the Island at present occupied only as country seats, but soon to be apportioned into City lots, the subject may attract the attention of the parties most interested. The communication has been lying on the table of the Aldermen for three weeks, and is certainly of sufficient magnitude to entitle it to early consideration.
lead_paragraph: THE BOARD OF ALDERMAN AND THE CROTON BOARD -- NEGLECT OF PUBLIC BUSINESS. -- The Board of Aldermen held last night along and somewhat stormy session, some of the members evidently feeling that they would be much more pleasantly located in waiting upon the Japanese. For this, or possibly some other reason, they have omitted for the past three weeks to open and read a communication from the Croton Department on a topic of great importance, especially to parties owning property in the upper part of the Island. Of course as the communication has not been officially read, it would be impertinent on the part of the reporter to anticipate its contents, but when it is asserted that it calls earnest attention to the necessity of draining and sewering that portion of the Island at present occupied only as country seats, but soon to be apportioned into City lots, the subject may attract the attention of the parties most interested. The communication has been lying on the table of the Aldermen for three weeks, and is certainly of sufficient magnitude to entitle it to early consideration.

abstract: Senator MASON has just wound up the Harper's Ferry affair by presenting a majority report which reveals nothing, and by getting himself discharged from the manufacture of a bill to protect States from invasion. THADDEUS HYATT has also, at last, been released from his dungeon, and the country has thus been delivered from the horrors of civil war, with which Dr. CHEEVER threatened it.
lead_paragraph: Senator MASON has just wound up the Harper's Ferry affair by presenting a majority report which reveals nothing, and by getting himself discharged from the manufacture of a bill to protect States from invasion. THADDEUS HYATT has also, at last, been released from his dungeon, and the country has thus been delivered from the horrors of civil war, with which Dr. CHEEVER threatened it. No complicity with JOHN BROWN has been brought home to anybody in the Republican Party. No organization for the invasion of Slave States has been discovered in the North, except the contemptible one which the unfortunate BROWN headed. Nothing has been fastened even upon GERRIT SMITH, WENDELL PHILLIPS or DR. HOWE. In so far, in short, as the inquiry was intended to damage the Republican Party, or even the Abolitionists, in the eyes of timid people, it has proved a miserable failure.
headline: {'main': "End of the Harper's Ferry Affair.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "End of the Harper's Ferry Affair.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: This Annual Regatta of the Hoboken Club, which is always an attraction, took place on Friday. There was a more numerous attendance of ladies and other guests than on former occasions. The steamer Chicopee was provided by the Regatta Committee in order that the guests might accompany the Regatta, and a Band of music enabled the ladies to enjoy a merry dance with their nautical friends. The Committee consisted of Messrs. Barker, Byrom, Asten, Cushing and Pope, and the Judges were Messrs. Asten, Shippen and Byrom. The whole trip was one of thorough enjoyment. The distance sailed was from the Club-house to buoy No. 15, below the Narrows, and the prizes for each class were to be selected to the value of $25 each.

abstract: The Baltimore Convention is in full blast. Yesterday was spent mainly in preliminary movements, but some of these were not without significance. The New-York delegation seems to be, as the French say, master of the situation, and it is quite evident that its leading members intend to husband their influence by using it with caution. Nominally they are for DOUGLAS and their votes will probably be cast for him, as decidedly the strongest man whom the party can select for the Northern States. But it is also evident that their devotion to him is by no means of an uncompromising character. Their votes upon questions of order and of form indicate an unmistakable determination not to push their claims or their opinions to any extreme. When they find it impossible to carry DOUGLAS by a two-thirds vote, they will probably present some new name; and it will not be until after every conceivable effort shall have been made to secure the union of the party, that they will consent to the repeal of the two-thirds rule.

abstract: All the world, unless we are to except with the Austrians and the Pope, the Irish brigade of the Knights of St. Patrick, which is now forming to aid the renegade LAMORICIERE, in sweeping back the waves of the sea, is rejoicing with Italy in the triumphs of GARIBALDI. Italians may take a special pride in the thought that a new name has been inscribed on that splendid roll of masters in the art of war which their race has kept so bright from the days of CAESAR to those of NAPOLEON. GARIBALDI has taken his place in history with the MONTECUCULIS, the EUGENES and the MASSENAS. He has wrung the heartiest homage to his abilities as a commander, even from those cynical critics who were cooly debating, a few weeks since, whether he should be set down as a madman or a pirate; and the little steamer to which he confided the fate of Southern Italy with a boldness now recognized in its success as the ripest wisdom, bids fair to be remembered with the frail boat which once carried JULIUS and his fortunes.

abstract: The case of Judge WATROUS is one which must excite in a special manner the honest indignation of Messrs. BUCHANAN and TOUCEY. The Committee appointed to examine the charges against him have actually for some months been engaged in hearing testimony, for the purpose of ascertaining if there are sufficient grounds for impeaching him, and have by the last accounts come to the conclusion that there are, and he is to be impeached accordingly.
