abstract: One of the closest and most spirited matches of the season was played between the above clubs on Saturday last, at Hamilton-square, and after some excellent play on either side, resulted in the victory of the Manhattans by one run. The small totals show that the fielding was superior to the batting, and in no single innings was there sufficient "let up" in the former to permit many runs to be scored. In fielding the champions showed a marked superiority, but two or three miss-plays having occurred, while their batting, on the other hand, was much below its usual degree of excellence -- GOLDIE, E.D. KELLEY and HENRY, being the only ones who did at all well. W. KELLEY made a good home run, as did HUDSON for the Manhattan. The pitching of GOLDIE was effective, but he is not fully at home except on the first base, his proper position. The play of W. KELLEY as catcher, and H. KELLEY on the second base, was fine, more than half the Manhattans falling victims to these two. The play of HENRY on the third base was without a flaw, and E.D. KELLEY in the right field played well. On the side of the Manhattans, the batting of JONES was undoubtedly superior to that of any other on either side, and his play on the third base was also deserving of great praise. The batting and catching of HUDSON were also commendable, though his batting was not up to his standard. Capt. TUOMEY's play on the first and second bases left nothing to be desired, and SPRAGUE and DUNPHY, though unfortunate at the bat, were very efficient in their respective positions. In this contest the Champions felt severely the loss of their pitcher, and one or two others, while the Manhattan was short of their full nine by JACKSON and SANDERS. In consequence of this the Champions were not, with three exceptions, in their proper positions. The Manhattans made several changes during the game. They changed DUNPHY and SPRAGUE, and PAGE and Capt. TUOMEY, and undoubtedly by these changes in position, they won the game.

abstract: The United States Mail steamer Quaker City arrived at the Light-ship yesterday morning with news form Havana to Thursday 14th, 1 1/2 P.M. The Quaker city reports the weather at Havana fine and the general health of the harbor and city good. A grand ball was given on the night of the 13th inst. at the summer Palace of the Quinta, in honor of the birthday of the Countess SERRANO, which was numerously attended, and passed off with eclat Major HELM, American Consul-General, has had form Washington leave of absence, and contemplates sailing on the 30th for New-York. Among the Quaker City's passengers are Count DE GABRIAC. French Minister to Mexico, and family, on their way to France. The De Soto arrived 14th form New-Orleans, and would sail next day for New-York.

abstract: The United States vs. The Schooner Josephine. -- This cause came up on a motion to discharge the vessel from custody. The claimant's affidavits showed that he had claimed the vessel and had given bonds as required by law with sureties, which had been on examination approved. The District-Attorney objected to the discharge of the property, nevertheless, on the ground that he had excepted to the claim filed in the action taking issue on the right of the claimant to appear and file any claim in the action.

abstract: This match terminated in favor of St. George on the second day, by 98 runs, making the third victory for them this season. In this match the fielding of St. George was very fine, and the bowling of BRETT and H. WRIGHT was especially so; whilst the batting of S. WRIGHT, WALKER and BRETT was a fine display of cricket. GIBBS and CUREIE also played well; but SADLRR gave several chances which ought to have sent him back before he entered his teens, but for the bad fielding of Newark. The Messrs. ROBINSON batted very well, and fielded in fine style, and CURRIE was almost as good as LANG at wicket-keeping. The Newarkers made a better display of fielding in the second inning, (though they showed only moderately in the match,) by the fine bowling of HALLIS, WALTERS and WARNER, and the really fine batting of GREACEN and HALLIS.

abstract: Among our foreign extracts this morning will be found an interesting letter from St. Petersburg which we have translated from the Independance Belge, concerning the emancipation of the Russian serfs.
lead_paragraph: Among our foreign extracts this morning will be found an interesting letter from St. Petersburg which we have translated from the Independance Belge, concerning the emancipation of the Russian serfs. In spite of the formidable difficulties by which it is surrounded, the Emperor persists in the prosecution of this great work, and so far as the result aimed at is concerned, he is supported by the nobility and owners of great estates throughout the Empire. The wisdom of the measure, -- its harmony with, the Christian spirit and popular enfranchisement of the age, are universally recognized, -- and there is a general desire in all quarters to promote its success.
headline: {'main': 'Emancipation in Russia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Emancipation in Russia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. An adjourned meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held last evening.
lead_paragraph: BOARD OF SUPERVISORS. -- An adjourned meeting of the Board of Supervisors was held last evening. Considerable routine business was transacted. The Special Committee appointed to select a suitable site for a County Court-house, reported in favor of purchasing the property on Joralemon and Fulton streets, owned by JOHN SCHENCK, and now known as the Military Garden, for a sum not to exceed $70,000. This property has a front of 140 feet, and extends back to Livingston-street, 351 feet The report was received, and made the special order for consideration on Monday next, to which time the Board adjourned.

abstract: The majority report of the Covode Committee, which has just been presented to the House of Representatives, and of which it is proposed to print 50,000 copies for the edification of the country at large, is a document..
lead_paragraph: The majority report of the Covode Committee, which has just been presented to the House of Representatives, and of which it is proposed to print 50,000 copies for the edification of the country at large, is a document which Mr. BUCHANAN will doubtless treasure as a most valuable addition to the annals of his Administration. If by any extraordinary accident all copies of this little work should be destroyed, a hiatus would be left in the history of his time which all future chroniclers would bitterly lament. It is true that previous to the period at which this remarkable narrative commences, he had seen "forty years of public life," on which he frequently looks back with pardonable pride.

abstract: The past few days have been unusually prolific in fresh arrivals from foreign shores. That arid waste at the foot of this island, styled the Battery, was the landing-place, on Monday and Tuesday, of two thousand Germans, and perhaps half as many Irish.
lead_paragraph: The past few days have been unusually prolific in fresh arrivals from foreign shores. That arid waste at the foot of this island, styled the Battery, was the landing-place, on Monday and Tuesday, of two thousand Germans, and perhaps half as many Irish. The interior of Castle Garden presented an aspect much more suggestive of the Tower of Babel than of the historic scenes that transpired when the infant liberties of America were cradled there. The commingling of every dialect that prevails in Europe, from the Land's End to the Bosphorus, poured through throats of every age, from the babbling of infancy to the hoarseness of old age. Nor was the variety of tongues greater or more characteristic than that of garbs and manners. Thoughtful Germans from the banks of the Rhine withdrew to retired corners to study maps and books for information of the region through which their journey led them. Celtic pilgrims to the land of "fraydom," sought similar intelligence from whomever they met, Young "Greek met Greek," and joined in Hibernian "tug of war," for the possession of disputed crusts, while embryo SCHLEGELS and GOETHES sat in pensive silence, apparently in brown studies of "the unities of the drama," or in profound aspirations after "the transcendental." Women, with a profusion of braided hair which a Yankee belle would envy, indulged in a much less than Yankee expansiveness of apparel, and wore shoes much larger in proportion -- while sons of Erin, with a commendable thirst for knowledge, asked when the train would leave for Millwaukee or Kansas.

abstract: The City of Washington puts us in possession of our correspondence and foreign exchanges to the 6th inst. They render still more certain the steady and rapid advance of GARIBALDI to complete success, and render it extremely probable that the revolution will extend to Naples, where the news of his successes created the most intense popular enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: The City of Washington puts us in possession of our correspondence and foreign exchanges to the 6th inst. They render still more certain the steady and rapid advance of GARIBALDI to complete success, and render it extremely probable that the revolution will extend to Naples, where the news of his successes created the most intense popular enthusiasm. The capitulation which was entered into at Palermo has either expired or been broken, and the contest had been renewed. Our private advices state that the Great Eastern will probably sail on the 20th. The passage of the pending amendment to the Reform bill in the British House of Commons was likely to lead to a change of Ministry. The Russian nobles have presented a plan of emancipation which excites a good deal of attention.

abstract: THE NEXT CENSUS. -- The new plan of paying the United States Census Marshals a specified sum per name collected, will, it is said by those who ought to know, insure more complete returns than were given under the last regime. The old plan was to pay the Marshals by the day; the present one makes it an object to them to collect as many names as possible in their respective districts. Some of the best informed Marshals, who have diligently pursued their investigations, express great surprise at the unexpectedly large number of families found in localities with which they supposed they were previously familiar, and in which they believed there were few persons residing. If the census is fairly taken, it will surprise even New-Yorkers with the multitude of people who live in tenant houses and back alleys. It may be a question, however, whether the Marshals will not be tempted to write up fictitious statistics, since it is much easier to write at home than to collect information from house to house; and the more they write the more pay they get.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Historical Society was held last evening. A large number of ladies and gentlemen were present, and considerable interest was manifested in the proceedings. In the absence of the President, FREDERICK DEPEYSTER, Esq., occu
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Historical Society was held last evening. A large number of ladies and gentlemen were present, and considerable interest was manifested in the proceedings. In the absence of the President, FREDERICK DEPEYSTER, Esq., occupied the chair. A lengthy report from the Committee appointed to purchase Dr. ABBOTT's Collection of Egyptian Antiquities, together with several communications relative to the purchase and transfer of this valuable collection, was read, and a Committee appointed to receive and arrange it in the rooms of the Society during the Summer vacation. The Committee consisted of WM.C. PEIME, F. DEPEYSTER and GEO. H. MOORE, Esq[???]s.

abstract: The Brussels Nord publishes a letter which a respectable family at Orleans has received from Palermo, confirming previous accounts of the barbarity with which the inhabitants were treated by the royal troops. The writer states that on May 22 Gen. LETIZIA went round the environs of the city with a troop of infantry and another of cavalry, sacked 26 houses belonging to persons supposed to favor the insurrection, and set fire to a number of others. Three enurenes were also sacked by them. "An English I[???]oy, the wi[???]e of a Sicilian, who is a functionary of the Neapolitan Government, on going to their country house a few days ago, found the gates torn down and the house plundered. Three Neapolitan soldiers were carrying off the last remains; one of them had two Cashmere shawls of here under his arm. The writer gives an amusing an anecdote. After an engagement at Calalascibetta, in which the King's soldiers were completely beaten and lost their cannon, the insurgents found on the field a dispatch of Gen. LETIZIA's to the Government, complaining that the cannon were too heavy, and that the mules could not draw them. The insurgents forwarded the dispatch with a postscript stating that the cannon suited them exactly, and that they meant to make good use of them.

abstract: St. THADDEUS HYATT has met with this match. The "Most Rev. the Catholic Archbishop of New-York" has fairly "capped" the determined martyr of the Senatorial Committee.
lead_paragraph: St. THADDEUS HYATT has met with this match. The "Most Rev. the Catholic Archbishop of New-York" has fairly "capped" the determined martyr of the Senatorial Committee. Indeed, when the circumstances in which the Archbishop has preferred his plea, for the instant infliction upon his venerable person of torture, imprisonment or death, are considered, it must, we think, be conceded that the shepherd of souls has outdone the inventor of patent pavement-lights, and that in respect both to the smallness of his raw material of molehill, and to the bigness of his manufactured mountain, the ambitious ecclesiastic has surpassed his political prototype.

abstract: The twenty-seventh anniversary of the formation of the City Guard was celebrated yesterday by an excursion to Long Branch, and a dinner at the National Hotel. It being the occasion of the opening of the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad, to Long Branch, the City Guard accepted the invitation of the Railroad Company to pass over their road and join in the opening celebration at the same time that they celebrated their own anniversary.
lead_paragraph: The twenty-seventh anniversary of the formation of the City Guard was celebrated yesterday by an excursion to Long Branch, and a dinner at the National Hotel. It being the occasion of the opening of the Raritan and Delaware Bay Railroad, to Long Branch, the City Guard accepted the invitation of the Railroad Company to pass over their road and join in the opening celebration at the same time that they celebrated their own anniversary. The steamer Rip van Winkle, in connection with the Alice Price, which is hereafter to run between here and the terminus of the Railroad, arrived at her dock, foot of Robinson-street, at 10 o'clock, and took on board a large number of invited guests, who were to participate in the opening celebration. In a few moments, the City Guard made its appearance, dressed in the company uniform, with shakos, and headed by Dodworth's band, with 35 pieces. As soon as they had embarked, the boat put out into the stream amid the cheers of the crowd and a parting cannonade salute from the pier. The City Guard mustered 75 muskets, exclusive of the officers, whose names are as follows: Mansfield Lovell, Captain; E.L. Stone, 1st. Lieut.; David Banks, Jr., 2d Lient.; C.E. Prescott, 3d Lieut.; C.H. Cooper, 1st Sergeant; H.E.R. Miller, 2d Sergt.; H.C. Jones, 3d Sergt.; H.B. Burtnett, 4th Sergt.; C.F. Peters, 1st Corporal; B. Gurney, 2d Corp.; H. Ferris, 3d Corp., J.H. Stevens, 4th Corp.

abstract: The welcome rain yesterday morning relieved the Japanese from the overcrowding of the inquisitive, but the customary throng collected in and about the hotel. The Messrs. LELAND and the Naval Commission were besieged with applications to visit the..
lead_paragraph: The welcome rain yesterday morning relieved the Japanese from the overcrowding of the inquisitive, but the customary throng collected in and about the hotel. The Messrs. LELAND and the Naval Commission were besieged with applications to visit the Japanese quarters, to see Tommy, to have a look at the Princes, to examine the new Japanese dining-room, to exhibit specimens of American industry, to procure just one more card written by a Japanese, to get for a very particular friend only a few Japanese curiosities, to secure a Japanese visit to certain stores, and, in short, to do a multitude of other things more easily asked than granted. But firmness and patience prevailed, and the Japanese were allowed to keep comparatively quiet. It was determined on Monday that a number of the officials should be taken yesterday to view the charming scenery and gorgeous mausoleums of Greenwood Cemetery, but the state of the weather at the hour named -- 2 P.M. -- prevented their carrying out that design. Between the drops, however, a number of the under officials succeeded in doing considerable shopping among our Broadway stores. Two of the Secretaries, a physician and two officers were much interested at one of the book-stores, and purchased two dozen copies of a work on the United States coinage. They expressed much pleasure with their examination of illustrated and other books. A large assortment of jewelry and watches was exhibited during the day to the Embassy and members of their suite, and a number of purchases were made. The Japanese seem indeed to have exhibited an unusual taste for these things, although it is said they are, as a nation, rather opposed to ornamenting the person. The subaltern officers of the Embassy were much interested in a description of the process of making and galvanizing chains, and a valuable present of firearms sent in during the morning. A number of the Japanese, during their stay in this country, have adopted the American shoes altogether, finding them much easier than their own loose sandals, which enforce such an ungraceful walk. The slip-shod style, most usual among the Japanese, is somewhat illustrative of the minstrel style of representing a Virginia "darkey's" circular "walks before commencing a breakdown. Yesterday, an additional number of Japanese provided themselves with shoes, and one man secured two dozen pairs.

abstract: There is no likelihood of the adoption of the Japanese costume in this country. However baggy the fashion of trowsers may become, it will still fall far short of the amplitude of a Kami's toiski, and let the rage for a sensation " tile" run
lead_paragraph: -- There is no likelihood of the adoption of the Japanese costume in this country. However baggy the fashion of trowsers may become, it will still fall far short of the amplitude of a Kami's toiski, and let the rage for a sensation " tile" run never so high, any habitue of Broadway will instinctively shrink from mounting the mud-turtle shell of a covering in which the Niphonese delight. Nor is it probable that the peculiar style of hair-dressing in vogue with our visitors will ever become a favorite with our nice young men for full-dress occasions. Straw sandals pale before the glories of patent leather, and the gowns which envelope the forms of the Princes are deformities not to be mentioned in the same breath with a stylish "sack," to say nothing of the full-fledged "swallow-tail coat." The lacquer-ware of the Niphonese may become a passion with our people, but their personal wear will never grow into favor. However extensive may be our importations from Japan, the fashions will be let alone. Paris need fear no rival in Jeddo.

abstract: JOHN BINNS, Esq., an old Editor and publisher, died in Philadelphia on the 16th, in his 88th year. Mr. BINNS was born in Dublin in 1772. He took an active part in the political agitations of the time, and as a consequence became involved in difficulty with the English Government. He was tried for high treason and uttering seditious language, but was acquitted, and came to this country. He entered into the newspaper business, first in Northumberland, Pa., then in Philadelphia. He ranked among the fiercest assailants of Gen. JACKSON. After his paper, the Democratic Press, had lost its hold on popular favor, he relinquished it, and was elected Alderman. In this position he gained a high reputation for honesty and energy.
lead_paragraph: JOHN BINNS, Esq., an old Editor and publisher, died in Philadelphia on the 16th, in his 88th year. Mr. BINNS was born in Dublin in 1772. abstract: GARIBALDI has gratified and almost outstripped public impatience. The preparation, the departure, the landing, the quick succession of decisive battles, and the surrender of the Royal army have followed each other almost as rapidly as telegraphs could tell them.
lead_paragraph: GARIBALDI has gratified and almost outstripped public impatience. The preparation, the departure, the landing, the quick succession of decisive battles, and the surrender of the Royal army have followed each other almost as rapidly as telegraphs could tell them. We sit and see it all pass rapidly on, and clap our hands, growing impatient if the curtain should be let down between the acts. This guerilla chief, although now a great General, and the supreme leader of two millions of people, still makes war like a guerilla chief. That promptitude which success stamps as wisdom and which failure brands as rashness is, in his circumstances, the only chance of victory. With guns and forts, and trained armies, and regular Generals versed in the regular strategy of modern warfare as his enemies, with brave, ardent fellows, destitute of everything but stout hearts and strong limbs as his supporters, GARIBALDI had to do all by dash, or not at all. He has done it. He has forced his way into Palermo, he has beaten the King's army, he has driven them into their forts, and he has obliged them to admit their inferiority by consenting to capitulate. Fast upon the intelligence that the capitulation had been completed, and that the 25,000 soldiers of the King's army were going forth under the pressure of the patriotic bands which had beaten and surrounded them, comes the news that the capitulation had been broken, that the forts and vessels have again opened fire upon the city, that the insurgents have resumed their arms and are swarming round the army, that the city is barricaded, and that amid the devastation which is going on the troops are deserting, and even a Neapolitan General has gone over to the popular cause. The procession of great events is rapid enough, but unhappily we have them as yet only in outline. GARIBALDI is the hero for the present age, when steam and electricity have so spoilt us for enduring the tardiness of old tidings that we should, perhaps, if we got CAESAR's celebrated dispatch, quarrel with the comma which separates the vidi from the vici. But still, when we have quenched our thirst for news, we yearn for a long, quiet enjoyment of the details.

lead_paragraph: The card of Mr. STOUT, published in all the City papers of Saturday, withdrawing from any further opposition to his own removal, and the appointment of Mr. PLATT as his successor, has of course ended the contest. On Saturday, the Comptroller being duly advised of Mr. STOUT's withdrawal, sent a circular letter to all the Heads of Departments requiring all future deposits of City money to be made with Mr. PLATT. abstract: We published yesterday a very interesting debate in the Senate on the proposition of Mr. WILSON to fit out five small steam-vessels for service on the Coast of Africa, in the suppression of the Slave-trade.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday a very interesting debate in the Senate on the proposition of Mr. WILSON to fit out five small steam-vessels for service on the Coast of Africa, in the suppression of the Slave-trade. It is not to be disguised that this question is surrounded with practical difficulties, many of which were very clearly stated by Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont, as well as by two or three Southern Senators, who concurred, nevertheless, in denouncing the traffic and desiring its suppression. There is, indeed, no question in any quarter as to the activity with which the traffic is at this moment carried on, or the impunity with which it is attended. Not one of the hideous facts which were set forth in the letters of our correspondents on the coast of Africa, during the past Winter, in the TIMES, is denied. It is not disputed that nearly all the ships engaged in it are American ships, fitted out in American ports, and sailing under the American flag, or that a large portion of the cargoes are brought to market over our own waters, and under the noses of our cruisers. Nor is there any dispute as to the weight of the obligation which is imposed on us by religion, as well as by honor and sound policy, to do our utmost to suppress it. But in spite of all this, when we come to practical measures for suppressing the traffic, we encounter very formidable difficulties. The prize money offered tempts cruisers to permit the trade, in order that they may capture the traders. Sending the captured slaves to the English colonies supplies them with labor which they greatly need -- while our Government is compelled, at very heavy expense, to do them the very questionable service of returning them to the shores from which they were stolen. It is easy to multiply objections of this kind, and to make them pretexts for neglecting our plain and obvious duty in regard to the traffic.

abstract: A fire happened between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning in a row of frame stables, situated at No 119 Fifth-street, involving the loss of seven horses, two of which were valuable animals. How the fire originated has not yet been ascertained, but the Fire Marshal is of opinion that it was the work of design, and has entered upon an investigation of the matter. The building was two stories high, and the upper part was occupied by FRANCIS ROLZHAUSE[???] as a dwelling. He suffered a loss of $ 50 up[???]n his furniture. and was not insured. Mr. SAMUEL LAUDERBECH had four horses stabled in the lower part of the building, three of which were saved and the other burned to death. STRAUSS & Co. [???]ost one horse valued at $200, and Mr. DANEMAN two fine ones valued at $3,000 H. LAGAMS & Co. lost two worth $200, and Mr. Slaver o[???]e, which he valued at $200. None of these animals, except the four owned by Mr. LAUDERBECH, were insured -- and his policy is from the Pacific Co. Mr. FRANK ROLZHAUSER owned the building, which was uninsured. The loss upon it is estimated at $500. The building No 117, adjoining the stables, owned by Mr. F.S.E GOODMAN, was silently injured.

abstract: Congress has pushed through its business today, and had the House not refused to consider the Loan Bill the adjournment would take place to-morrow. As the Committee on Ways and Means refused to report the Loan Bill the rules had to be suspended by a two-thirds vote to allow it to be considered. The vote was 100 to 65, not two-thirds. It will be again tried to-morrow.

abstract: A NARROW ESCAPE A CHURCH STRUCK BY LIGHTNING SEVERAL PERSONS IRJURED. During a violent thunder storm which passed over Bloomfield, New-Jersey, on Tuesday evening, between 7 and 8 o'clock, the Methodist Church, where a strawberry festival was in progress, was struck by lightning. Happily the rain had made the attendance at the festival thin, so that there were but about one hundred and fifty persons in the building at the time.
lead_paragraph: A NARROW ESCAPE -- A CHURCH STRUCK BY LIGHTNING -- SEVERAL PERSONS IRJURED. -- During a violent thunder storm which passed over Bloomfield, New-Jersey, on Tuesday evening, between 7 and 8 o'clock, the Methodist Church, where a strawberry festival was in progress, was struck by lightning. Happily the rain had made the attendance at the festival thin, so that there were but about one hundred and fifty persons in the building at the time. Five or six of these were assisting in transferring the contents of tables which had been spread out doors during the afternoon, to the interior of the Church. Of this number hardly one escaped without receiving a shock more or less severe. Mr JOSEPH OSBORN was the most seriously injured. The electricity apparently glanced from the tin water-leader, near which he stood, to his arm. He was knocked senseless, and it required the free use of cold water and other restoratives for nearly an hour to revive him. A young man inside the building received so severe a shock as to need medical assistance, and a young lady who was near an open window, had a hole burned in her dress. Others were slightly injured, but the majority were only startled. Many who were not sensible of having received any of the electricity at the time, complained next day of a numbness in their limbs.

abstract: JOHN TYLER, Jr., writes a letter to the Richmond Enquirer, in explanation of the statement that he had advocated a dissolution of toe Union. He said that he thought the success of either the BELL and EVERETT ticket, the HAMLIN and LINCOLN, or one bearing Mr. DOUCLAS' name, "would be fatal to every institution of the South in the Union, whether political, social, moral or religious, through the predominating and all-absorbing influence of the North in possession of the Government, and an absolute control of the Union at once arising." Mr. TYLER concludes as follows: "I, for one, will not consent to be made the echo of Abolitionism by any party whatever. I will uplift the standard of patriotism even against party organization. Live or die, survive or perish, I will stand over the graves of my ancestry, by the hearthstones of my relatives and by the side of my friends -- all, all here in James City, Charles City and New-Kent -- and defend the one and the other against all enemies whatever, whether they appear as compromisers of my rights under the Constitution and in the Union, or as Republican Abolitionists -- whether they consist of Northern oppressors or of Southern traitors. In six months we shall know whether the ominous junction of twenty five millions of nonslaveholders, North and South, has been formed, tearing the Constitution into shreds, in order that they may obliterate with brute force the rights and interests secured by that great charter of liberty and freedom to the two millions of slaveholders in the Southern States. In six months we shall know whether a war will not have to be raised at the South, similar to that of the Revolution, between the Patriots and the Tories. In that brief time we shall know whether it will not be necessary, as it was then, to purge the political atmosphere of the South through a baptism of blood. The 'Constitutional Unionists' of this day may find themselves in the predicament of the 'British Unionists' of that day. My 'funeral' may then come; but if perish I must, let me fall under the folds of the patriot flag. 'If this be treason, make the most of it.'"

abstract: William Fuller, a lad who, until within the past few days, has been engaged as clerk in the office of Edward Cunard, Esq., agent for the Cunard lines of steamers, at No. 4 Bowling-green, was taken into custoday yesterday morning, by Officer Codett, of the First Precinct, on a charge of having stolen a check for $1,072 28, and other property from his employer. The robbery was effected on Monday night, but Mr. Cunard did not suspect anything wrong until Tuesday morning. when the mother of the young man called at the office to inquire the reason he had remained from home the previous night. It had been supposed by his employer that his absence from business on Tuesday morning was attributable to illness, but the statement of Mrs. Fuller awakened suspicion, and an investigation of the accounts showed that the check in question, with several bills payable, had been abstracted from the cash-book. The Police were informed, and yesterday an officer was detailed to watch at the City Bank, upon which the check was drawn, for the young man's appearance. In a short time he came and presented it, and was at once arrested. It then transpired that he had added forgery to the crime of larceny, as the check had been altered so as to make it payable "to bearer" instead of "to order." The prisoner was taken before Justice KELLY, at the Tombs, where he made a full confession of his guilt. He said that for a long period he had been incrusted with the business of purchasing postage stamps for Mr. Cunard, a large quantity of which are used in the office, and that he had systematically engaged in purloining them, finding it an easy matter to dispose of them with the aid of two confederates, named Scully and Henderson, who, however, knew nothing of the robbery of the check. At the time of his arrest about $5 worth of stamps were found upon him, and $6 in cash, which he had collected upon one of the bills payable. He was committed for further examination.

abstract: Yesterday, as the Express train which leaves Chambers-street at 11 A.M. on the Hudson River Railroad, was within a quarter of a mile of the Peekskill depot, it ran over and killed three men, two of whom were fighting upon the track. The following are the particulars of the accident. The three men in question -- GEORGE RAWCLIFFE, HENRY W. HALL and THOMAS GRANGER -- were walking on the track near Peekskill, when HALL and GRANGER got into a quarrel, clinched and fell. This occurred just as the train appeared in sight, but it was impossible for the engineer to observe them at that distance. As the train approached, he gave the usual signal of danger, and continued to blow the whistle up to the time of the accident. The warning was unheeded by the two men who were fighting, but the other, GEORGE RAWCLIFFE, went to them as soon as he saw their danger, and attempted to separate them, when HALL seized him by his arm, and held him on the track. The engineer perceiving that it was almost impossible to prevent running over them, reversed his engine, and applied the patent brakes, but to no purpose, as before the train stopped, it had passed over them, instantly killing two, and fatally injuring the third. RAWCLIFFE, the young man who attempted to separate the others, was struck upon the head by the cowcatcher and thrown over on the other track. He struggled hard to free himself from the grasp of HALL, but the latter held him so closely that his head alone projected over the track upon which the train was. He was instantly killed. THOMAS GRANGER, who was underneath HALL, was mangled in a horrible manner, and instantly killed. His remains were carefully collected, and placed in a box. The other, HENRY W. HALL, was struck upon the head by the cow-catcher, and thrown to the side of the track. He lived nearly half an hour, but was speechless and insensible. On examination, it was found that his skull and ribs were broken. The accident was witnessed by several persons. The men were recognized by Mr. DAVID YATE, who keeps a brickyard Peekskill. They were all Intoxicated at the time. The bodies were taken up and conveyed to the engine-house. Coroner GRIFFIN, of Sing Sing, was notified; and an inquest was probably held last evening. No blame can be attached to the engineer or fireman. HALL was an American, and for several years a member of Engine Company No. 40, of this City. He is about 35 years of age, and lived at Oyster Bay, L.I. GRANGER was an American, 28 years old. RAWCLIFFE was an Englishman. Some three or four days since, he received a letter from his mother, and yesterday morning he bought some writing paper and envelopes, with the intention, doubtless, of answering his mother's letter. Unfortunately he met HALL and GRANGER, and the trio went round to several drinking-places, and got intoxicated. RAWCLIFFE was 22 years of age. They were all unmarried.

abstract: -- Mr. BUCHANAN's special organ at the Capital is at last convinced that Mr. LINCOLN did not have "several pairs of boots charged to his stationery account and paid for out of the public funds," while he was a member of Congress. Perhaps it does not go quite so far as this, but it does say that "the official records afford no evidence of such a transaction." Having thus started on the road of concession, we should not be greatly surprised to find the Constitution in due time expressing its delight at finding that Mr. LINCOLN did not rob his neighbor's hen-roost, or throw assafoetida into the back parlor of some gentleman who differed from him in politics. It is not impossible that this high-toned organ of our "old public functionary" may concede, by and by, that Mr. DOUGLAS is not a common thief. How far below the level of common decency it is necessary for a journalist to descend in order to become a good partisan, we are not aware, -- but we rely, confidently on finding out by watching the course of the Constitution. Whatever Mr. BROWNE's position in the Custom-house may have been, his editorship of the organ is by no means a sinecure.
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. BUCHANAN's special organ at the Capital is at last convinced that Mr. LINCOLN did not have "several pairs of boots charged to his stationery account and paid for out of the public funds," while he was a member of Congress. Perhaps it does not go quite so far as this, but it does say that "the official records afford no evidence of such a transaction." Having thus started on the road of concession, we should not be greatly surprised to find the Constitution in due time expressing its delight at finding that Mr. LINCOLN did not rob his neighbor's hen-roost, or throw assafoetida into the back parlor of some gentleman who differed from him in politics. It is not impossible that this high-toned organ of our "old public functionary" may concede, by and by, that Mr. DOUGLAS is not a common thief. How far below the level of common decency it is necessary for a journalist to descend in order to become a good partisan, we are not aware, -- but we rely, confidently on finding out by watching the course of the Constitution. Whatever Mr. BROWNE's position in the Custom-house may have been, his editorship of the organ is by no means a sinecure.

abstract: By the United Kingdom at Father Point, from Glasgow to Quebec, we receive to-day European advices to the 9th inst. The intelligence is interesting and important. GARIBALDI's success at Palermo has been confirmed, and the wide sweep of its probable consequences very clearly indicated by the official action of the Neapolitan Government, which had petitioned the Great Powers to guarantee the integrity of the King's dominions. To this suit in forme pauperis France and England had replied instantly in the most discouraging terms. The Emperor NAPOLEON had informed the King, that unless he officially recognized Sicilly as an independent State, no foreign Government could interfere, and then only as a "mediator." The London Times ventures to prophecy that by the end of June Sicilly would cease to belong to the House of Bourbon. Lord BROUGHAM, in the House of Lords, had stigmatized the conduct of the royal forces at Palermo in unmeasured terms, and the almost universal feeling of Europe had been declared in the same sense, and in favor of the Sicillian revolution.

abstract: George Deshon vs. Mary C. Packwood and the Merchants' Bank. This was an action upon a check for $2,000, drawn by Samuel Packwood, deceased, husband of the first-named defendant, in favor of the  plaintiff a relative to whom deceased was partial. The deceased, shortly before his death, transferred his bank account to his wife, that she might draw money for household purposes; but subsequently gave the check in suit to plaintiff.

abstract: The Evening Post is inclined to believe that our Common Councilmen intend to swindle the City. It suspects such a design from certain movements on their part. It seems they have passed a resolution asking the Corporation Counsel, in substance, whether they have not a right to violate the Charter whenever they can make something handsome by it. They desire to re-pave Broadway, but not by contract.
lead_paragraph: The Evening Post is inclined to believe that our Common Councilmen intend to swindle the City. It suspects such a design from certain movements on their part. It seems they have passed a resolution asking the Corporation Counsel, in substance, whether they have not a right to violate the Charter whenever they can make something handsome by it. They desire to re-pave Broadway, but not by contract. They want the hiring of the men, the fixing of the prices, the "bossing of the job," themselves. The Post fears they are seeking to establish a bad precedent. We think there is some ground for its apprehensions. If the Common Council goes on much longer in this style, they will be suspected of being no better than they should be. If they don't stop stealing, their integrity will, sooner or later, be seriously questioned. It is utterly impossible that men should go on, month after month, and year after year, plundering the City Treasury in every possible way, -- giving away valuable grants by votes that are bought and paid for, -- stopping all public work of which they do not share the profits, -- discarding the charter, violating the law, and braving public sentiment for the sake of filling their own pockets, -- without ultimately begetting the suspicion, in the minds of sagacious men, that they are less scrupulous than public men in their positions should be. The hints of the Post show clearly that they are already in some danger of incurring this suspicion.

abstract: The two Houses of Congress are about to agree on a new loan to fund the outstanding Treasury bills of the Government, twenty millions in amount, which have heretofore been once renewed or extended under the authority of Congress. The present loan, if finally voted by both Houses, and the act approved by the President, will, in no proper sense, be a new debt, but an obligation in a funded or more permanent form to take the place of a debt of twenty millions already existing in the shape of Treasury Bills or Notes, a good part of which are already due but not presented for payment at the Treasury, the remainder falling due within all the next eight months.

abstract: The Legislative Committee appointed to investigate the affairs of the Central Park met at 10 o'clock yesterday at No. 54 Exchange-place, Ron. J. McLEOD MURPHY presiding. Thus far, the business of the Commission has been mostly preliminary, being occupied with the preparation of details, and arranging the order which the investigation is to take. It was voted that the Clerk be directed to send a copy of the charges already made to the Commissioners of the Central Park, and that the Clerk of the Common Council and the Clerk of the Central Park Commissioners be requested to furnish copies of all resolutions and ordinances relating to the Central Park. They decided to employ an accountant to aid the Clerk in preparing an account of the expenditures of the Central Park, to be arranged under the following heads: Labor, materials, work done under contract, police, clerk hire, salaries of engineers, architects and draftsmen, and what has been paid to the Commissioners, if any thing has been so paid.

abstract: One peril and one pain, at least, our Japanese visitors have scarcely undergone in their visit to America, which would have figured in the front rank of their distresses had they gratified the self-complacency of our British cousins by recognizing England as Queen of the Seas. The peril of being hunted, and the pain of being shown up as social lions, are penalties which all distinguished foreigners in London must pay for their distinction.
lead_paragraph: One peril and one pain, at least, our Japanese visitors have scarcely undergone in their visit to America, which would have figured in the front rank of their distresses had they gratified the self-complacency of our British cousins by recognizing England as Queen of the Seas. The peril of being hunted, and the pain of being shown up as social lions, are penalties which all distinguished foreigners in London must pay for their distinction. The Siamese Envoys who wore gold coats and never washed their faces; the Nepaulese, JUNG BAHADOOR, who shot twelve nobles of Nepaul to secure the Premiership and put himself on good terms with his sovereign; the Persian princes, who thought it hard they could not bring their harems to St. James', were all alike pounced upon by ladies who either led, or wished to lead, some circle of London "society," and turned volentes nolentes into lions. It is not of the least consequence to the true lion-hunter whether his lions enjoy themselves or not. In the case of other human beings, nobody ever thinks of inviting them into companies with which they cannot converse, or to banquets of which they cannot partake. The lion receives no such consideration. He may be deaf and dumb, but that is no reason for hesitating to drag him to a concert. He may be a Catholic anchorite, but his hunter will clap him down on a Friday to a dinner-table a la Soyer as calmly as BOOLE: would ask the Grand Turk to a breakfast of sausages. The lion, indeed, is to "society" what the lamentable persons who parade Broadway in red oil-skin coats, inscribed with large white letters, are to commerce. He announces the existence and enhances the importance of his hunter. There have been instances in London of ambitious ladies who, after sighing uselessly for years at the gates of the heaven of "Society," were admitted to full Peri-dom on the strength of a single well-man[???]uvred and well-hunted "lion." BRUMMELL in his day made several such fortunes.

abstract: The presumptive presence of the princes at the Japanese Matinee left the Embassy comparatively unmolested yesterday by the crowd of the Common Council Committee. The audience at the Academy of Music, if not gratified with the promised sight of Ambassadors and Naval Commissioners, was at least [???]fred by the presence of the treasurer, the young prince, the censor, an interpreter, and a dozen of the [???]enlant officers, who, being judiciously disposed in various parts of the house. served at least as a prefence of carrying out the programme of the hand-bills. The demonstrations of curiosity were much the same as have been exhibited heretofore on like occasions, and were bor[???] with the customary stoicism by the objects thereof, who seemed to be intensely absorbed in the operatic entertainment. TOMMY refused stares with interest, by the use of his opera[???], as did the others who were so fortunate as to possess the requisite optical assistance; The star from the Metropolitan, and the return from the Academy, were alike made amid a bounteous shower.

abstract: COMMON COUNCIL. -- THE JAPANESE -- THE CORRUPTION FUND AGAIN -- THE LAMP AND FIRE DISTRICT EXTENDED -- WORMS -- MESSENGER'S SALARY. -- At a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution was presented by Alderman DAYTON, inviting the Japanese Embassy to visit Brooklyn, and appointing Aldermen KALBFLEISCH, VAN BRUNT and CASHOW a Committee to take charge of the reception. The resolution was lost by a vote of 8 nays to 7 ayes. On motion, the whole of the Ninth Ward was included in the Lamp and Fire District. Alderman DAYTON submitted a lengthy protest to the action of the Common Council last Monday evening, in calling upon the Special Ferry Committee for a detailed account of expenses incurred, claiming that the Board had already passed upon and approved the action of the Committee. The document was laid on the table and ordered printed. A communication was received from the Mayor asking that some action be taken to rid the city of the warm nuisance. Alderman JENKINS proposed that all of the linden tree should be cut down. This was opposed, when the subject was referred to the Health Committee with the Health Officer, for report. By resolution, the messenger's salary was fixed at $500 per annum. The business of this office occupies the incumbent about one day of each week. A new city flag was ordered for the City Hall, when the Board adjourned to Monday next.
lead_paragraph: COMMON COUNCIL. -- THE JAPANESE -- THE CORRUPTION FUND AGAIN -- THE LAMP AND FIRE DISTRICT EXTENDED -- WORMS -- MESSENGER'S SALARY. -- At a special meeting of the Board of Aldermen last evening, a resolution was presented by Alderman DAYTON, inviting the Japanese Embassy to visit Brooklyn, and appointing Aldermen KALBFLEISCH, VAN BRUNT and CASHOW a Committee to take charge of the reception. The resolution was lost by a vote of 8 nays to 7 ayes. On motion, the whole of the Ninth Ward was included in the Lamp and Fire District. Alderman DAYTON submitted a lengthy protest to the action of the Common Council last Monday evening, in calling upon the Special Ferry Committee for a detailed account of expenses incurred, claiming that the Board had already passed upon and approved the action of the Committee. The document was laid on the table and ordered printed. A communication was received from the Mayor asking that some action be taken to rid the city of the warm nuisance. Alderman JENKINS proposed that all of the linden tree should be cut down. This was opposed, when the subject was referred to the Health Committee with the Health Officer, for report. By resolution, the messenger's salary was fixed at $500 per annum. The business of this office occupies the incumbent about one day of each week. A new city flag was ordered for the City Hall, when the Board adjourned to Monday next.

abstract: Yesterday, in the Court of General Sessions Recorder BARNARD delivered his decision in the case of Messrs. William N. McIntyre and John C. Tucker, charged by Alderman Brady with an attempt to bribe him to vote for the appointment of Mr. Gideon J. Tucker to the Presidency of the Croton Aqueduct Board. The charge against these gentlemen, made in January last, in the Board of Aldermen, by Alderman Brady, upon which, through the influence of District-Attorney Waterbury, the Grand Jury found an indictment, caused considerable sensation at the time. The defendants' counsel argued the case before the Recorder, some days since, arguing that the indictments, on the face of them, were illegal, and yesterday his Honor delivered the following decision, ruling them out of Court:

Ward, of Washington-place, offering money prizes to the successful competitors for the pe[???] and other medals at the coming Commencement. The prizes offered are a half eagle to each medal, and an addition of a whole eagle to the success un competitor for two medals, two eagles to the person winning three medals, and so on. The communication was referred to the Committee on the Free Academy.

abstract: The Irish crusaders who are flocking to the standard of St. Peter and the Blessed Virgin, to battle -- as the Irish journalists put it -- beneath the "Sun-Burst of Erin," in green and glorious uniforms, embroidered with the harp that once, through Tara's halls the soul of music poured, are beginning to discover that the priest, who promises, is one person, and the Pope, who performs, another. We are assured from Ireland that the friends and relations of these valiant volunteers look on their departure with a "calm resignation," which is more creditable to the good sense of the bereaved than flattering to the self-respect of the emigrants. Ireland is evidently quite able to bear up under the loss of the flower of "fighting Tipperary," bent on earning the Pope's benediction and St. Peter's pence in the shape of silver Roman pauls. But Italy -- even that small knot of fanatics who compose what still remains of Papal Italy -- does not seem to welcome the exiles of Erin half so warmly as they are dismissed by their friends. We published yesterday morning the doleful story of some Irish recruits at Ancona, who fled flea-bitten and famished from the barracks of his Holiness to beg the protection of the hated "Saxon" Consul, and were very properly sent back to lie in the beds which their priests had made for them.
lead_paragraph: The Irish crusaders who are flocking to the standard of St. Peter and the Blessed Virgin, to battle -- as the Irish journalists put it -- beneath the "Sun-Burst of Erin," in green and glorious uniforms, embroidered with the harp that once, through Tara's halls the soul of music poured, are beginning to discover that the priest, who promises, is one person, and the Pope, who performs, another. abstract: Sicily presents the point of most intense interest. GARIBALDI's progress towards the complete expulsion of the reigning power is watched with eager satisfaction in every part of Europe. We reprint in another part of this morning's TIMES the very full and graphic report of his proceedings, from the hour of his landing on the coast down to the suspension of hostilities after the capture of Palermo, which appears in the columns of the London Times, from its special correspondent. It is the only complete narrative of these important incidents which has been published, and is probably the most authentic that will ever be written.

abstract: The leading feature of the foreign news which the Asia brings us to-day, is the brilliant story of GARIBALDI in Sicily. We transfer to our columns in full, the graphic and glowing Sicilian correspondence of the London Times, in which this story is told with equal breadth of descriptive power and accuracy of detail by the same accomplished pen to which the leading English journal was indebted for its best accounts of the last year's campaign of Italy. The conduct of the Neapolitan commanders and Government throughout this insurrection, now by their own recognition elevated to the rank of a war, would appear to have been unspeakably contemptible. It is established that the Neapolitan General at Palermo availed himself of the armistice to take up positions more threatening to the Liberal forces than those he had previously occupied, and that the cruel and cowardly bombardment of the city was only stayed by a menace of reprisals on royal prisoners from GARIBALDI. The attitude of the English Government confirms the position taken by NAPOLEON, and makes it certain that the conflict between Sicily and Naples must be settled without the intervention of any foreign power. The heir of FERDINAND has indeed been virtually notified that the existence of his dynasty is no longer considered necessary to the "order of Europe." It is rumored that the Queen Dowager, to whose evil counsels the mad policy of FRANCIS II is largely attributed, was on the point of quitting the Kingdom, and that the King, resigning Sicily as hopelessly lost, was about to attempt to save his continental crown by inaugurating a constitutional system. Great dissatisfaction begins to show itself at Rome between the Government and the crusaders under LAMORICIERE, who are ill-paid, worse-lodged and worst-treated. From the North of Italy we learn that a strong "outside pressure" is put upon the piedmontese Government, to force it into a declaration of war against Naples. The official transfer of Savoy and Nice to France was accomplished on June 1. After that date the government of those provinces would be administered in the name of the Emperor NAPOLEON, and the Domnie salvum fac imperatorem would be chanted in the churches. France and Russia, as a proof of their moderation, had promised to aid England and Prussia in helping the Sultan to carry out his proposed inquiry into the state of the Turkish Christians. But no serious results were expected from this inquiry, and the grave difficulties of the Turkish question were regarded as only adjourned for a few months at farthest.

abstract: Advices of June 9, from Denver City, to which credits given, state that Mr. FOWLER, the defaulting New-York Postmaster, whose whereabouts has been so long unknown, and about whom so much cariesity has been felt, is reported to have been identified at Pike's Peak. The main features of the statement are as follows:  The Pike's Peak Express arrived at 6 o'clock this evening, bringing $8,900 in specie and Denver City dates to June 14.

abstract: The police of Newark telegraphed, last evening, that they had arrested John Stewart, the young scoundrel who robbed a poor blind Indian on the Erie Railroad train, a few days since, of about $75 worth of fancy articles which he was bringing to this City for sale.
lead_paragraph: The police of Newark telegraphed, last evening, that they had arrested John Stewart, the young scoundrel who robbed a poor blind Indian on the Erie Railroad train, a few days since, of about $75 worth of fancy articles which he was bringing to this City for sale. Very little of the property was recovered....Silas Herbert, a sailor, was taken into custody by Officer Rode, of the Fourth Precinct, on a charge of having, with two confederates, stolen a patent-lever watch from Nicholas Roach, a New-York pilot, whom they induced to go up an alley-way in James-street, in April last. Herbert has since been to sea, and has just returned... Jeremiah Powers, a deck-hand on board the propeller Niagara, has been enriching himself of rate by stealing portions of the boat's machinery and disposing of it to junk dealers. Officer Holland, of the Harbor Police, captured him with about $25 worth of brass journals in his possession. He had already sold some of the machinery, valued at $56....James Ross, a young Irishman, was found wandering up Roosevelt-street with his cheek-bone split and his face so bruised and cut that pieces of the flesh hung down! He was only able to articulate that a ruffian known as Boston Jack had assailed him, without provocation, upon one of the docks. He was sent to the Hospital.

abstract: The fly game is becoming more and more popular, as is shown by the increasing number of matches that are played in this manner. An interesting fly game took place on the Excelsior ground between the above Clubs, and ended in a decided victory for the Excelsior Club, thus reversing the result of the last game which ended in a victory for the Charter Oak. The fielding of the Excelsior was marked by a general excellence and freedom from missplays that is seldom witnessed. Mr. LEGGETT's catching, PEARSALL's play at first base, REYNOLDs' at short and J. WHITING's at the third, were splendid exhibitions of good judgment and activity. The three fielders and second base performed good service, and the pitching of RUSSELL and CREIGHTON were most excellent. On the Charter Oak side, SHIELDS pitched well, but threw badly to the bases. VANDERHOOF played finely at various points, as did RANDOLPH at the second base. S. PATCHEN, CARROLL and VANDERHOOF batted well for the Charter Oaks; while POLHEMUS and LEGGETT took a decided lead for the Excelsiors.

abstract: ITEMS. -- Last evening a fireman residing at No. 83 Pineapple-street, was struck by engine No. 3 and severely injured .... Several squads of the Japanese visited different places of interest in the city yesterday. Two -- one an M.D. -- visited the Inspector of Police office, took notes of the Rogue's Gallery, and examined the operation of the Police Telegraph very critically .... HENRY PAYSON, one of the earliest settlers of Williamsburgh, and who held several offices of trust when that portion of the city was a small village, died at his residence in Bowronville yesterday morning at an advanced age .... Mr. DUNHAM, of No. 247 South Fourth-street, was severely bitten in the hand, yesterday, by a dog, supposed to be rabid. He received prompt medical attention, and no serious result is anticipated .... St. Paul's (R.C.) Church, on Court-street, was struck by lightning during the storm Wednesday evening last. The damage done was very small .... On Wednesday night, the store of CHRISTIAN HUNKER, corner Flushing-avenue and Broadway, was entered by burglars, who carried away $13, all in pennies. On the same night the house of GEORGE HOWARD, No. 272 South First-street, was entered and property valued at over $100 carried away ... CATHARINE JOHNSON, colored, of Weeksville, died on one of the Fulton ferry boats, yesterday morning, of a disease of the heart .... The Common Council Committee held another session in the Governor's Room, City Hall, last evening, to hear argument for and against the proposed Prospect Parks. The Committee adjourned for one week.

abstract: Coroner GRIFFIN, of Sing Sing, held an inquest at Peekskill, on Wednesday night, at 5 o'clock, upon the bodies of GEORGE RAWCLIFE, THOMAS GEANGER and HENRY W. HALL, the three men who were run over and killed while fighting on the track, near that village. Several witnesses were examined, and from their testimony it was proved that the engineer blew the whistle six or seven times, and that no notice was taken of the signal. The verdict of the Jury was that the men were killed on the track, and the Company were censured for the rate at which the train was running at the time. The bodies were interred yesterday.

abstract: The telegraph brought us the news from Richmond, Va., yesterday morning that EDWIN ROBINSON, President of the Washington and Richmond Railroad, had voluntarily confessed  a fraudulent appropriation of the funds of the company, to a large amount, and awaited an investigation. In these days of speculation and defalcation this is nothing very extraordinary. But the telegraph adds "His conduct in this affair is highly honorable, and he is much respected."
lead_paragraph: The telegraph brought us the news from Richmond, Va., yesterday morning that EDWIN ROBINSON, President of the Washington and Richmond Railroad, had voluntarily confessed a fraudulent appropriation of the funds of the company, to a large amount, and awaited an investigation. abstract: A note from a naval official at Norfolk states that the new steam gun-boat Pawnee, in leaving harbor, was working admirably, as far as the Lights She is to go to the Mediterranean, if her trial trip prove successful. Our Norfolk correspondent, writing on the 19th, informs us that, in compliance with the desire of the Department, the preparations for the departure of the Richmond steam sloop are rapidly approaching completion. She is also to join the Mediterranean fleet, from which the Wabash recently returned. Our naval rank in "the Straits" is at present inferior to that of all other powers, there being only the steam gun-boat Iroquois representing our navy there. The Macedonian corvette is on her way home. The British forces consist of 22 vessels, carrying 532 guns, and manned by 5,800 men; the French of 12 vessels, manned by upwards of 3,000 men. The unsettled state of European affairs has rendered the increase of our squadron in the Mediterranean a matter of expediency.

abstract: BALTIMORE, Thursday Evening.  The Convention has accomplished nothing practical to-day. The reports of the Committee on Cre  dentials are in, and serve to draw a line of demarcation between the respective factions. But there is too much bad blood among the delegates to permit business to be done, and an adjournment until tomorrow was carried mainly because it seemed impossible to do anything else.
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER DISRUPTION IMMINENT.

abstract: SCHOOL RECEPTION AND EXHIBITION. -- In accordance with the annual custom the pupils of Grammar School No. 29, in the First Ward, gave a reception yesterday to the local Board and numerous other guests. The building was handsomely decorated with flowers and evergreens, and the children in holiday attire, with faces radiant with happiness, made the occasion one of real festivity. The exercises conducted by the principals, Mr. L.W. ANNAN and Mrs. C.A. TIER -- consisted of singing; recitations,dialogues and speeches. Among the dialogues were three original ones, evincing greet credit on the part of the composers, Miss M. VREELAND and Miss E. BURKE, pupils of the school. The excellent solo singing of Master AULD and Miss E. BLACKBURN afforded great pleasure, and a recitation by Miss SPRINGER, of "The Auction Extraordinary," fairly "brought down the house." Addresses adapted to the comprehension of the youthful auditors, were made by HENRY RIDDLE. Esq., Assistant Superintendent, JOHN H. WILLIAMS, Esq., one of the Trustees, and others, and the certificates and premiums were awarded by CHARLES McCAY, Esq. The programme was made up with very good taste, and the entire proceedings reflected credit alike upon pupils and teachers.

abstract: The Royal Mail steamship Asia, Capt. LOTT, which sailed from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 9th, and from Queenstown on the evening of the 10th inst., arrived here yesterday morning. abstract: ADOLPH MAEURKIEWIEZ, a boy three years of age, while playing at a fifth story window of the house No. 343 East Tenth-street, missed his balnce, and fell to the sidewalk. He did not survive his injuries...
lead_paragraph: ADOLPH MAEURKIEWIEZ, a boy three years of age, while playing at a fifth story window of the house No. 343 East Tenth-street, missed his balnce, and fell to the sidewalk. He did not survive his injuries long, and yesterday Coroner SOSIRMER held an inquesiupon the body .... Yesterday morning, the body of DENNIS McCARTY was found in the water, at the foot of Morton-street, North River. Deceased was seen alive as late as 4 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon; but the testimony taken by Coroner JACKMAN failed to show under what circumstances he was drowned. He was an Irishman, 46 years of age, and resided at No. 131 Leroy-street .... Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest upon the body of Wm. KIRWIN, who was found drowned at the foot of Forty-fourth-street, East River. Deceased had been missing about a week, and, as he was known to have been on a drunken bout at the time of his disappearance, it is believed that he fell into the water while intoxicated.

abstract: -- The season at the watering places is opening brilliantly, though the cool weather has made it some days later than usual. At Saratoga especial preparations have been made for an extraordinary influx of guests. The hotels have all been overhauled and refitted, and have accommodations for many more than the usual number of guests. Congress Hall has been made particularly comfortable and attractive, and rejoices in the best cuisine and attendance of any of the hotels. But, after all, the great attraction of Saratoga is the Congress Spring, which for seventy years has been yielding an unfailing supply of its delicious and healthful waters. There is probably no medicinal spring in the world which has contributed so largely within the same time to the public health. It is said that Saratoga can now accommodate comfortably 8,000 persons.

abstract: Sir H. BULWER informed the English Mercantile body, at a levee at Constantinople, that he had been requested by the French Ambassador, M. DE LAVALETTE, to inform the English merchants that he never said what had been represented; and that, far from expressing any fears, he had, on the contrary, encouraged the French merchants to continue their operations, provided they were, as he doubted not, of a legitimate mercantile and industrial nature.
lead_paragraph: Sir H. BULWER informed the English Mercantile body, at a levee at Constantinople, that he had been requested by the French Ambassador, M. abstract: Another contempt case has been "settled," by allowing the delinquents to go scot free. We have already stated that in the case of TOWNSEND vs. GRAY, during an examination in supplemental proceedings before the Supreme Court, the plaintiff's counsel threatened to strike the judgment debtor; whereupon the latter informed the lawyer that, if he did so, he would "cut his guts out." To this elegant menace the counsellor replied by drawing a pistol, which it seems he carries in his practice. The matter was then brought before Judge BONNEY as a "contempt of Court," and he ordered affidavits to be prepared in support of the charge. We were in hopes that the summary punishment of both the participants in the outrage would have indicated the desire of the Court to purify, in some degree, the manners of the Bar. On Monday, however, Judge BONNEY was informed that the matter was "settled," and he accordingly dismissed it.
lead_paragraph: Another contempt case has been "settled," by allowing the delinquents to go scot free. abstract: The Austrian Government, with the view of reorganizing the representative system of the provinces, was about to extend the authority of the Central Congregation in Venetia. A deliberative vote will be granted to it on a large number of Administrative questions. The decisions of this Congregation will become law upon being signed by the President. It will, in future, decide on judicial affairs without further appeal. The only reservation made in favor of the Central Administration is the approbation of the proposed expenditure and revision of Provincial Treasury accounts. In order to reestablish the national character of the Municipal system in Venetia, all the franchises and immunities granted by the patent of the 26th of April, 1815, are to be confirmed.

abstract: One of the most pleasing entertainments yet given the Japanese was that afforded them yesterday afternoon -- a visit to the Central Park. The party consisted of all the higher officers of the Embassy, including the three Princes and "TOMMY," the Naval Commission and the special Committee of the Common Council. The party of Japanese numbered thirteen, and their appearance in front of the Metropolitan in the act of entering their carriages created quite a sensation on Broadway. TOMMY was as usual the principal object of attraction, and took his seat after a hop, skip and jump from the house to the vehicle as if he was running a gauntlet for his life.

abstract: The third day's races of the Fashion Course, Spring meeting, took place yesterday, as announced, in the presence of a moderate attendance of persons, not quite equal to the first day. A number of carriages were in the arena, in front of the stands, and as usual, a number of ladies were in the ladies' reserved portion of the grand stand, as well as in some of the carriages. The first race was for the proprietor's purse, $700, three-mile heats, for which C.S. LLOYD entered Mr. F. MORRIS' Throgsneck, a gray gelding, 5 years old, carrying 111 pounds, rode by GARRY THOMAS, and THOS. DOSWELL entered Irona, a gray mare, 5 years old, carrying 111 pounds, rode by WINDHAM WALDEN. The betting was in favor of Throgsneck, at 2 and 3 to 1, his form being considered as greatly to his advantage considering the state of the track, which was very heavy. His compact build enabled him to carry his extra weight over his yesterday's 95 [???]s., with comparative ease, whilst the gray mare labored considerably over the soft ground, and was so badly beaten that she was withdrawn after the first heat.

abstract: We are at last definitely assured, by official authority, that the Emperor of China has declined to comply with the demands of the French and English Governments; and that the long-expected collision of those Powers with the Central Flowery Kingdom has become inevitable. It is probable, indeed, that active operations on the part of the allies must have begun long before this time. About the middle of April the allied land forces in China, in number more than twenty thousand men, were on their way towards the scene of operations in the north, and the French had established themselves in the important post of Chusan, which they were fortifying as a part of their base of operations. It will be noted as a curious feature of the Chinese official reply to the ultimatum of the Allied Governments, that the Peking Cabinet seek to distinguish between the part played by the English and that sustained by the French, in the negotiations which were brought so rudely to a close at the mouth of the Pei-ho. It is evident that the Mandarin Court is kept much more clearly informed of the political and diplomatic movements of Europe than might be expected of so dignified and self-centred a body. The "great Emperor, always full of compassion for strangers," would gladly see France imitate towards her ally in the East the course pursued towards herself by England in the affairs of Italy and of Europe. But any hopes of such a result, if any were ever seriously cherished even at Peking, were simply puerile. The action of Baron GROS, and the conduct of the French force, which, although comparately insignificant in numbers, yet led in the attack on the forts of the Pei-ho, bound France to the quarrel of England in China. However ill-advised the diplomacy of Mr. BRUCE may have been judged by the Cabinet of the Tuileries to have been, NAPOLEON could not in honor, nor perhaps in policy, decline to accept its consequences. France must join England in forcing compliance with the treaties of Tien-tsin, as England understands them, from the Celestial authorities. Perhaps some compensation for this necessary expenditure of French blood and treasure may be found in the restraints which a concert of action with France in the East must impose upon the conduct of England in Europe. It will not be easy for any British Government to throw difficulties in the way of the Napoleonic policy in Italy or Turkey while the armies of VICTORIA are contending side by side with the armies of NAPOLEON in China.

abstract: The younger BULWER -- for he is the author who is generally understood to have adopted the pseudonym of "Owen Meredith" -- has essayed, in this volume, the difficult task of producing a novel in rhyme. Lucile is a new book, reissued in "blue and gold," like TENNYSON's, LONGFELLOW's and LOWELL's poems, and must occupy the same shelf with these latter, whenever it shall find its way to a library; but its coat is better than its body. The author declares that the "novelty of the effort" inspired him with dread; that he submits the work with "diffidence and hesitation;" and that he labors under "discouragement and doubt" when he contemplates the possible verdict of the public. A confession like this, indicating the dubiety of an author, almost disarms criticism; yet it behoves us to say that the book contains a great deal that is bad, much that is passable, and a little that is good. It is bad in one respect, at the outset. The straining after jingling rhymes is so repulsive in the first twenty pages that one is tempted to throw the book away. Blank verse would have been better than a set of forced rhymes that have no rhythm, and serious prose would be better than either. The story is one of disappointed love, jealousy, intrigue, war, self-sacrifice, passion and remorse. Lucile, discarded by a fickle lover, bids us farewell, after a series of sharp personal experiences in the character of a FLORENCE NIGHTINGALE, whose office it is "through suffering to soothe and through sickness to nurse." She leads a heroic life, and some of the finest passages in the narrative are those which portray her struggles. Witness the following -- the healthiest and most natural picture in the volume:

abstract: Concerning his rumored fight with the "Staleybridge Infant," Heenan says a letter to Wilkes' Spirit: "I have not made up my mind yet, but I shall accommodate him, though it would be pretty tough for me to remain five months longer away from home, with, perhaps, no chance to get a fight at the end of the time, and no chance of bringing it to a conclusion even if we succeeded in getting the thing on. I should very much like to accommodate Master Staleybridge on the west side of the Atlantic, pay his expenses over, and give him handsome odds; but I suppose it would be no use in making such an offer, as he understands his little game too well to quit here to look after me. I do not wish to underrate him, but it is my candid opinion that Tom Sayers could get himself into condition in six weeks from now, and whip a dozen such men as this Staley-bridge chap, at intervals of a week apart."

abstract: EXPLOSION. -- At about 6 1/2 o'clock last evening, the pyrotechnic establishment of Messrs. BOCK & CO., corner of Dupont and Liberty streets, exploded, destroying the building and severely injuring one of the workmen named DORICK. The loss is estimated at $500. The explosion was from accidental causes. This is the third time this company has met with loss by explosion in their works.
lead_paragraph: EXPLOSION. -- At about 6 1/2 o'clock last evening, the pyrotechnic establishment of Messrs. abstract: Our Democratic friends are making haste very slowly at Baltimore. They have made progress, certainly, and to-day will undoubtedly witness the end of their labors. But they ought to have reached this point at least two days sooner; -- and in that case they would have saved two days of discreditable wrangling and of very unprofitable and undignified controversy. The only question which has given them any real trouble, has been the admission of delegates from the Southern States, -- and this has been decided more by the personal preferences of the respective claimants than by any intrinsic justice in their claims.
lead_paragraph: Our Democratic friends are making haste very slowly at Baltimore. They have made progress, certainly, and to-day will undoubtedly witness the end of their labors. But they ought to have reached this point at least two days sooner; -- and in that case they would have saved two days of discreditable wrangling and of very unprofitable and undignified controversy. The only question which has given them any real trouble, has been the admission of delegates from the Southern States, -- and this has been decided more by the personal preferences of the respective claimants than by any intrinsic justice in their claims.

abstract: The fourth and last race of the Spring meeting, on the Fashion Course, was run yesterday. There were three races. To Mr. HENRY COLTON are we New-Yorkers indebted for this racy carnival; but which we are sorry to say, has not been patronized to an extent which will remunerate him for the great outlay he has incurred. The purses and stakes offered have all been run for, and promptly paid over at the conclusion of each race. About 2,500 persons were at the course, and a larger number of ladies occupied the grand stand yesterday than on the previous days.

abstract: SIR : I regret to be unable to accept the invitation to the public meeting of the inhabitants of Rocadale; but feeling that my constituents have a right to know my sentiments upon the recent proceedings of the House of Lords, which are, I understand, to be brought under their consideration, I beg leave to trouble you with this communication.
