abstract: In the House of Commons on the 8th inst., Mr. CAVE rose to ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether his attention had been directed to the Message of the President of the United States to Congress, on the 19th day of May, respecting the slave trade, and whether her Majesty's government had received any recent communications from the government of the United States, or intended making any fresh proposals to that government on this subject? The honorable gentleman had no doubt at all that the government of the United States was sincerely desirous to assist us in the suppression of the slave trade, but unfortunately there was a large portion of American capital invested in that trade, although the citizens of the United States generally were opposed to it. The employment of steam gunboats on the coast of Cuba had fallen like a thunderbolt upon the people engaged in the slave traffic, and they therefore determined to procure the recall of those gunboats if possible. The American people became excited on the subject of the right of search, and the American government became uneasy, and at length the service was so arduous to the officers employed in consquence of the difficulties thrown in their way, that we were compelled to do one of two things either to recall the vessels or to prevent their interfering at all with any ship hoisting the American flag. He thought from a passage in the President's message to Congress, that there were signs of an intention on the part of the American government to act more cordially with her Majesty's government in suppressing the slave trade on the coast of Cuba. It seemed monstrous that, year after year, in defiance of the most solemn treaty obligations and directly in the teeth of America and England, that Spain should persist in carrying on this iniquitous traffic. There were at present in Cuba 400,000 slaves, who died at the rate of ten per cent annually. Forty thousand were annually imported, and it there was any further deficiency it was supplied by introductions from China and Yucatan. The Americans were bound by the Ashburton treaty to employ eighty guns in the suppression of the Cuban slave trade, but he thought their efforts would be much more efficacious if they employed a smaller and lighter class of vessels. If America would fairly unite with her Majesty's government in suppressing the trade, the squadrons of the two countries might cruise together, and what a slaver attempted to escape by hoisting the American colors, an American vessel could be immediately signalled to overhaul her. [Hear, hear.]

abstract: The regular meeting of the New-York Academy of Medicine was held on the evening of June 20, in the small chapel of the University -- Dr. WATSON, the President, in the Chair. After the reading of the minutes of the previous meeting, and also of the meeting called in Brooklyn to attend the funeral services of Dr. ISAACS, Dr. LA ROCHE, of Philadelphia was invited to sit on the platform, and was introduced to the Fellows as the only native Honorary Member of the Academy. Dr. LA ROCHE, Jr., was also introduced by Dr. R.S. KISSAM. Dr. BUCK proceeded to read a paper describing the operation for the removal of a cancerous disease involving the whole under lip, and the subsequent restoration by the formation of a new lip by an autoplastic operation. The patient was exhibited, and, although his appearance might have led to a question how much he was personally improved, the operation was evidently a mechanical success.
lead_paragraph: The regular meeting of the New-York Academy of Medicine was held on the evening of June 20, in the small chapel of the University -- Dr. WATSON, the President, in the Chair. After the reading of the minutes of the previous meeting, and also of the meeting called in Brooklyn to attend the funeral services of Dr. ISAACS, Dr. LA ROCHE, of Philadelphia was invited to sit on the platform, and was introduced to the Fellows as the only native Honorary Member of the Academy. Dr. LA ROCHE, Jr., was also introduced by Dr. R.S. KISSAM. Dr. BUCK proceeded to read a paper describing the operation for the removal of a cancerous disease involving the whole under lip, and the subsequent restoration by the formation of a new lip by an autoplastic operation. The patient was exhibited, and, although his appearance might have led to a question how much he was personally improved, the operation was evidently a mechanical success.

abstract: Recorder BARNARD yesterday sentenced Chas. P. Thompson, convicted of perjury for giving false bail for his father, who was charged with forgery and false pretences, to the State Prison for three years. The Jury, on account of his youth, and the fact that his father was the party in whose behalf he committed the perjury, recommended him to mercy, otherwise his sentence would have been more severe.

abstract: The political doings of the Democratic "statesmen" assembled in Convention at Baltimore of course receive due attention from the public; but we think their martial exploits, also, should not be lost sight of. We therefore beg to present a short summary of the encounters of the past week in chronological order.
lead_paragraph: The political doings of the Democratic "statesmen" assembled in Convention at Baltimore of course receive due attention from the public; but we think their martial exploits, also, should not be lost sight of. We therefore beg to present a short summary of the encounters of the past week in chronological order. The Convention met on Monday, and on Tuesday, before the Committee on Credentials, Mr. HOOPER called Mr. HINDMAN "that man," and designated his statements as "unqualifiedly false." HINDMAN thereupon got home heavily on HOOPER's knowledge-box, and drew a pistol. HOOPER, having no pistol, withdrew from the ring. On Wednesday, Mr. WHITELEY, of Delaware, waited upon Mr. TOWNSEND, of the same State, at his hotel, and delivered him a vigorous right-hander on the frontispiece, which led to Mr. TOWNSEND's seizing him by the shirt-front and cravat, and shaking him. After a bold rally both men went to grass, WHITELEY underneath, searching for his pistol. The police interfered before the commencement of the second round.

abstract: Half the allotted time of the Japanese stay in the Metropolis has elapsed, and still their appetite for the curiosities of the Jeddo of America is unseted. Neither the perils of processions, the fatigue of extended rides, the stare of inquisitive crowds, the pressure of official invitations, nor the persistent wrong spelling of their names in the newspapers, appears to have affected their tempers. The Japanese historian might search in vain for the name of SIMME-BUJZEN NO-KAMI, among the jumbled types designed to represent the name of that august dignitary. He himself (SIMME) would in vain endeavor to recognize his own portrait in the multitude of descriptions of his dress and personal appearance; while he would need the property of omnipresence to have shown his intelligent face in an iota of the places said to have been favored by his visits. The seclusion of the Prince Ambassador is, however, more than atoned for by the inquiring turn of mind evinced by the rest of his suite. The most confirmed female shopper in this nation of bargain-hunters could not more indefatigably pursue her object than have the numerous Japanese exploring expeditions in our principal streets during the past week. Guided by faithful Metropolitans, they still pursue what appears to be the ignis fatuus of completing their purchases. Their baggage already increases to such huge proportions that even the capacious Niagara bids fair to be well filled, and still they shop -- not to the credit of our Aldermen and Councilmen be it said, in the shops of friends of the Committee who have them in charge, but at their own volition, in Broadway or Bowery, as pleases them best, despite the experiences of our variable climate that they have been called upon to endure. Roasting or shivering, dripping or parching, they pursue the even tenor of their way, to the great delight of the shopkeepers whom they favor with their calls.
lead_paragraph: Half the allotted time of the Japanese stay in the Metropolis has elapsed, and still their appetite for the curiosities of the Jeddo of America is unseted. abstract: -- The reply of the Chinese Government to the ultimatum of the British and French, which we published in the TIMES of yesterday morning, renders it certain that the war will be renewed. The Chinese have made preparations for the most obstinate resistance, and rely with confidence on their ability to repel the invaders. It is evident from the tone of their reply, that they cherish feelings of special aversion to the English, and that they will refuse to them commercial and political privileges which they would cheerfully grant to the Americans, and even the French. John Bull is clearly under the necessity of compelling their friendship by hard blows, if he ever enjoys it at all. Business correspondents write from China that the prospcet of a new war has a very depressing effect upon commerce, and that merchants forbear entering upon new speculations of any kind. There is danger, too, that, with the renewal of the war, the rebel excitement may be renewed. A rebel force of nearly 20,000 is in the neighborhood of Soochow, and the Imperialist troops of Shanghai are exercised with great assiduity for the purpose of meeting them. The Spring opens with a very gloomy prospect upon the Celestial Empire.

abstract: Lord BROUGHAM, on whose zeal and activity in all good causes advancing age seems to make no impression, and who has apparently as clear a head at more than four score as he had at forty, is now seeking to add one more to the long list of valuable reforms for which English law is indebted to his exertions.
lead_paragraph: Lord BROUGHAM, on whose zeal and activity in all good causes advancing age seems to make no impression, and who has apparently as clear a head at more than four score as he had at forty, is now seeking to add one more to the long list of valuable reforms for which English law is indebted to his exertions. He has just introduced a bill into the House of Lords for the admission of a wife's evidence in favor of her husband, and of a husband's in favor of his wife, and of the prisoner's in his own favor in criminal cases. It is simply an application to criminal procedure of a principle already in force in civil procedure, both in many States of the Union and in England.

abstract: The contest between the Independent and Evangelist, the organs of the Congregationalists and New School Presbyterians respectively, relative to the Home Missionary Society, loses none of its vigor. The Evangelist surrenders nearly the whole of its editorial space to this topic.
lead_paragraph: The contest between the Independent and Evangelist, the organs of the Congregationalists and New School Presbyterians respectively, relative to the Home Missionary Society, loses none of its vigor. The Evangelist surrenders nearly the whole of its editorial space to this topic. First, it grapples with the Congregationalist of Boston and the Congregational Journal of Concord, N.H. It does not wonder that the proposition for a conference should meet with dislike on the part of these journals, for "it might chance that some judicious and fair-minded friends of peace would get upon the Committee. The idea that the Association would not appoint representatives as thoroughly acquainted with the subject matter of the issues involved, as is the Committee which would act for the Assembly, is ridiculed. Neither is the objection that the New-York Associations are not invited to the Conference of any weight, for it is not designed that its results shall be authoritative upon the denominations as such, or upon the Home Missionary Society. The only end proposed is mutual counsel. The Evangelist abjures the idea that it is solicitous for the Conference. The acceptance or rejection of the proposition rests with those to whom it has been made. The Assembly surrenders none of its rights by making it, and shall be estopped from no ulterior measure which, in such a juncture, duty may seem to require. A strong point is made of the action recently taken by the State Association of Illinois, which indorses the course taken by the Home Missionary Society heretofore, and yet, at the same time, through its Missionary Association, keeps in commission in the Stare nineteen missionaries, besides its general missionary. Why, it is asked, does not the Home Missionary Society pursue the same course toward this Association which it does toward the other Presbytery, in refusing to extend it, and because it supports missionaries of its own? In another place the Evangelist, looking forward to a cessation of cooperation between these two denominations, so far as this Society is concerned, discusses the disposition which shall be made of the funds. It calls attention to the fact that large legacies have been left to the Society by Presbyterians. The late ANSON G. PHELPS bequeathed it $100,000. For Congregationalists to claim these legacies the Evangelist thinks would look like stealing from dead men's graves, and it is authorized to say that the Executive Committee of the Society recognizes "the obvious rule of equity in the case, that what came from Presbyterians should go to Presbyterians."

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a supplementary resolution, providing that the Secretary of the Interior shall contract for the erection or purchase of a Government Printing Bureau, was reported, and caused some debate. The bill authorizing a loan of $20,000,000 was received from the House and passed. The Legislative Appropriation bill was also passed. The Post Route bill was then taken up, and an amendment offered, allowing the Postmaster-General to provide for the overland transportation of the Californian mails. This gave rise to considerable debate, the majority of the speakers, however, still favoring the amendment, although the opposition in favor of the steamship lines was very strong. The bill provides for three overland routes; a Northern weekly route, at a cost of $200,000; a tri-weekly middle route, via Salt Lake, at a cost of $600,000, or daily at $800,000; and a tri-weekly from New-Orleans, via San Antonio, to connect with the Butterfield route at El Paso, for $200,000. In the evening session, after several hours' debate, it was informally laid aside, and the Post-office Deficiency bill taken up. In the House, the unfinished business was transferred to the next session. The Committee of Conference on the Post-office Deficiency bill being unable to agree, were discharged from further service, and the House insisted on its amendment restoring the inland service discontinued in 1859. The Loan and Treasury bill was passed, as were also a number of private bills. A motion to adjourn to-day was discussed, but not acted upon. An important bill has been reported from the Committee on Foreign Affairs, providing for the carrying out of treaty stipulations with China, Japan, Siam, Turkey, Tripoli, Tunis, Morocco and Muscat, by conferring judicial functions on our Consuls there. Hitherto, in Japan and Siam, these treaties have been null and void, while in China and Turkey there is not sufficient authority to enforce justice. The bill also contains a proviso which gives validity to the rite of marriage, when performed by American Consuls in foreign countries. The Attorney-General has decided that Consuls abroad cannot lawfully celebrate marriage between foreigners or even Americans. The bill in question makes all such marriages valid to all intents and purposes, as if the said marriage had been solemnized within the United States.

abstract: On the 19th of February last the warehouse No. 69 Gold-street, occupied by Mr. HENRY ARTHUR, was visited by a burglar, who carried away patent leather and other articles, valued, in the aggregate, at $168. Subsequently, nearly all the property was found at the shoemaker's shop of SAMUEL ROSNER, No. 163 Greenwich-street. ROSNER was arrested, and, after an examination before Justice QUACKENBUSH, of the Second District Police Court, fully committed on a complaint for burglary. He was indicted for burglary in the third degree, and on Monday, the 11th inst., his case was tried before Judge RUSSELL, in the Court of General Sessions. The trial resulted in a verdict of guilty of an attempt to commit the offence charged, and Judge RUSSELL sentenced him for one year to the Penitentiary. During the progress of the trial the Court was thronged with friends of the accused, who manifested much interest in the case, and after the sentence, when the prisoner was removed from Court, gathered around him, earnestly protesting their belief in his innocence.

abstract: Summer toilet is no longer a matter of prophecy. The bright and genial weather with which we have lately been favored has enabled the fashionables of Paris to display their taste to the best advantage, in adopting the light and elegant materials prepared for the present season. At present, for out-of-doors dress, silks of a light shade have been mostly worn, and these generally made with flounces. Dresses of stripes alternately white and colored, trimmed with a broad flounce of the color predominating in the material, are also seen.

Dresses of stripes alternately white and colored, trimmed with a broad flounce of the color predominating in the material, are also seen.

abstract: A telegraphic dispatch, received late on Thursday, from Cape Island, New Jersey, announced the loss of the United States Coast Survey Steamer Walker by collision with an unknown schooner off Absecom, early on Monday morning of that day, and stated that twenty of her crew were supposed to be lost, while the survivors, some forty in number, had been saved in the boats. By the arrival, yesterday, of the steamer Kennebec, Capt. JOHNSON, from Cape May, with forty of the crew of the unfortunate steamer, we have been enabled to gather full particulars of the disaster, and a complete list of the saved and lost. The Walker, Lieut. J.J. GUTHRIE commanding, which has been absent for several months, engaged in the work of the coast survey, at the South, was returning to New-York for repairs. She left Norfolk on Tuesday, the 19th inst., and, at the time of the collision, had passed Cape May, and was within about ten hours sail of New-York. The wind had been blowing fresh from Northeast, and there was a heavy head-sea, which considerably retarded the progress of the steamer. She was, however, making about seven knots an hour under steam. At about 2 1/4 o'clock A.M., the man on the look-out saw a schooner approaching under full sail, and steering head on. He notified the man at the wheel, and gave the usual order to port the helm. The order was obeyed, the helm being put hard a-port; but at the same time the schooner was observed to put her helm a-starboard thus rendering a collision inevitable. As both vessels were under full headway, there was no time for either to alter his course, and the shock was instantaneous and terrible. The schooner struck the steamer on the port-bow, near the forward chains, her head-rail taking under the steamer's plankshear, staving in the iron plates, and opening her down to the water-line. The vessels then swung clear of each other, and the schooner was obsdrved to round to and remain with her sails shaking for four or five minutes. She then filled away and kept on her course. An effort was made to hail her from the steamer, but it failed. The shock of the collision immediately brought all that were below on deck and word was passed that the steamer was sinking. Captain GUTHRIE ordered the vessel headed in shore, and sent men below to stop the leak if possible. Hammocks and mattresses were stuffed into the opening, but the hole was so large and the force of the water so great that it was found impossible to stop it. In fifteen minutes the water had risen to the furnaces and extinguished the fires, causing the engines to stop. Orders were now given to clear away the two boats, (one having been destroyed by the collision,) and to drop them astern, that they might be ready for use. There was no time to be lost, however, as she was fast sinking. The mainmast was ordered to be cut away, and the booms and spare spars cut loose to afford the crew the means of sustaining themselves in the water. The boats were now hauled up, and one of the crew who was sick, and the only lady passenger on board, first put into one of them. Implicitly obeying the commands of Capt. GUTHRIE and his officers the boats were then filled with as many as they could safely sustain, and, at the word of command, pulled away from the sinking ship. The next moment she went down, carrying with her all who were on her decks. The crew were now seen clutching at the floating spars and loose materials of the wreck, or clambering up the rigging to save themselves by clinging to the topmost head. The boats were very deeply loaded, there was a heavy sea running, and their crowded condition left little or no room to pull at the oars. They were some ten miles from the land, and, even if they were able to reach it, the heavy surf which broke upon the beach would render it impossible to land without swamping the boats, and probably losing many lives. In this extremity a vessel was seen bearing down for them. She was hailed, and immediately answered by rounding to and giving them a line. All the crew were put on board, excepting men enough to man each boat, both of which then returned to search for those who were still clinging to the wreck or floating spars. All who could be found were picked up. At this time another schooner was seen, apparently engaged in the same work, but she soon kept away, and how many she may have picked up, if any at all, is not known. It is hoped that, of the twenty persons missing, some at least are on board of this unknown vessel, which has probably carried them to some Southern port.

abstract: The Legislative Committee of Investigation into the management of the Central Park, met at the Astor House yesterday morning Mr. J. MCLEOD MURPHY in the Chair, and entered upon the investigation of the charges of Mr. JAMES HOGG, formerly one of the Central Park Commissioners. ROBERTS, WARBURTON and BLUNDELL were sworn as official reporters of the Committee. Mr. HOGG was called to the stand, and interrogated at length upon the written charges made by him against the Park Commissioners, each of which, with the specifications attached, was read over to him, and he was called upon to substantiate them. This, for the most part, he was unable to do of his own personal knowledge, but he reiterated the truth of each charge, and avowed his ability to substantiate them all at the proper time. He was not aware that he was to be called to the stand yesterday or he would have had his witnesses with him. The charges relate principally to the manner in which the work on the Park has been done, to the competency of the Commissioners and of the men in their employ, including the Chief Engineer and his subordinates, to the departure from the original plan adopted by the Commissioners, and the increased and unnecessary cost entailed thereby, and finally to the whole management of the Park under its present administration. Some of the specifications are extremely frivolous, as for instance he mentions that at a certain place in the Park is a pile of flag-stones which cost a great deal of money, and were originally intended for Summer-houses, but which are now "lying entirely useless" -- a charge which was readily disposed of by Mr. GREEN, one of the Commissioners, who said that the stones were not only "originally" intended for Summer-houses, but were still so intended, and in due time would be used for that purpose. Mr. HOGG complained that the Commissioners had already expended a million and a quarter of dollars, and that the Park was not yet one quarter finished; that by departing from the original plan they had deceived the public as well as those who were invited to compete for plans, and who were required to confine their plans within certain cost limits; that certain employes of the Commissioners had been allowed to occupy themselves in other employments while drawing pay from the Park Fund; that the book-keeper of the Commissioners kept a porter-house at the corner of Seventy-eighth-street and Third-avenue, which was the resort of bad characters; that the accounts of the Engineers were not kept so as to enable them to tell the cost of any particular work; and, finally, that the Park would ultimately cost four times the amount originally contemplated. In addition to these general charges, Mr. HOGG accused some Commissioners of collusion between themselves, as against others of their colleagues, by which great injustice was done, but declined giving any names, or bringing forward any proof until the next session, when he said he would have the documents with him to substantiate the charge. He also stated in the course of his examination, that Mr. BLATCHFORD, the President of the Central Park Commissioners, attempted to bribe him not to go to Albany last Winter to oppose the Central Park bill before the Legislature, offering him $500 in money, and promising to discount his note "for any reasonable amount." In answer to a question as to what reply he made to this offer, he said he told Mr. BLATCHFORD that "he couldn't be bought for any such price."

abstract: The Court of General Sessions presents a contrast to the Civil Courts of the City, often not particularly favorable to itself either in the character of parties interested in trials, or the judges and counsel who conduct them. In one respect, however, it must be confessed that it suffers nothing by comparison with even the highest civil tribunal in the City: -- Recorder BARNARD seems disposed to exact at least an outward respect for the Court over which he presides. We mentioned with commendation last week his prompt commitment for contempt of a gross offender, and we are happy to be confirmed in the belief that this was not the result of a sudden spasm of judicial dignity, by the equal promptness with which on Tuesday last he punished a similar offender.

abstract: We were again startled at the report that the Mohawk had made another capture, but it has turned out to have arisen from the fact that Capt. CRAVEN was seen with a vessel in tow on the south side of Cuba. The vessel had gotten ashore, and the Mohawk was assisting her out of danger.

abstract: We are apparently dealing with our Japanese friends on the faith of the old Scotch catch of "Whistle and I'll come to you, my lad!" We are certainly determined to woo the coy Niphon by all sorts of enticements into exchanging her kobangs, her tea and her lacquer ware for our cottons, calicos and steam engines. This is reasonable enough, we suppose; and if we will agree not to be unhappy about the cost of our whistle after we have used it, there will be no great harm done. But in order to this consummation we had better make up our minds at once that the said whistle is to be a pretty expensive one. We shall pipe to the Japanese to-night, for instance, and no doubt they will do their best, polite and amiable creatures that they are, to dance to our piping; but are we ready to pay the piper afterwards without a wry face or an angry word? His bill, we may be sure, will be a long one, much longer than those who have not thought of the matter -- as journalists must -- in detail, have probably so much as begun to suspect. We may depend upon it that New-York will have no such Japanese account to contemplate as Baltimore. The Baltimoreans have not even yet recovered from their amazement at finding that their authorities had failed to expend more than two-thirds of the sum voted to defray the expenses of the Japanese Reception. The Councilmen of New-York will inflict no such perilous surprise, we may be sure, upon their constituents.

abstract: Adam Wright and Frederick Simms, German laborers were apprehended on Saturday night for stealing a case of shoes from a store in Grand-street. In their possession the officer found a quantity of knives and forks, a silver cup, spoons, table linen, and other articles having the names of the proprietors of the Metropolitan and St. Nicholas Hotels stamped upon them.
lead_paragraph: Adam Wright and Frederick Simms, German laborers were apprehended on Saturday night for stealing a case of shoes from a store in Grand-street. In their possession the officer found a quantity of knives and forks, a silver cup, spoons, table linen, and other articles having the names of the proprietors of the Metropolitan and St. Nicholas Hotels stamped upon them. The men were sent to prison.....Officer Quackenbush, of the First Precinct, found one Mathew Small lying upon the sidewalk in Broadway early yesterday morning, helpless from the effects of wounds in his left side. He was removed to the City Hospital, where he revived sufficiently to state that he had been stabbed by one Daniel Hays, in Partition-street. Brooklyn....Christopher Cox, a man who is under indictment for a felonious assault, committed last April, upon John Saarka, keeper of a drinking saloon, corner of Thirty-first-street and Tenth-avenue but who did not appear when his case was called up for trial, and thus forfeited his bail, was rearrested on Saturday on a bench warrant....Justice KELLY committed Thomas Fitzpatrick, a youth, for trial on a charge of an attempt to pick the pocket of Mr. Henry Lichstentater, residing at No. 107 Columbia street, of a watch. The prisoner acted in a very disorderly way while in Court, by making frantic attempts to assault the complainant....Thomas Miller and John Murray, both young men, were apprehended on Saturday night for passing counterfeit $1 bills on the Central Bank of Cherry Valley, at various places in this City. A quantity of good money and several of the counterfeits were found upon them. They were held for trial by Justice KELLY....Peter McCarron, keeper of a liquor saloon at No. 186 Avenue A, was required by Justice CONNOLLY to furnish bail in $300 to answer a charge of having defrauded one of the Gas Companies by detaching the metre from the pipe in his place and burning the gas, so the amount consumed could not be measured.

abstract: The Circuit Court of this county came in session yesterday, and among the first business was brought up the decision on the motion of the defendant for a charge of venue in the celebrated Burch divorce case.
lead_paragraph: The Circuit Court of this county came in session yesterday, and among the first business was brought up the decision on the motion of the defendant for a charge of venue in the celebrated Burch divorce case. In her application the defendant asks that the hearing may be removed from a community strongly prejudiced against her, and the plaintiff acceding to this, it only remained to settle to which county the case should be taken. By the decision agreed upon yesterday, it goes to Naperville, Du-Page county, before Judge NORTON, the trial to take place early in November next. It will prove in all respects one of the most remarkable trials in the annals of our Courts, not only from the wealth and standing of the parties, but the determination with which the case will be fought.

abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest, on Saturday at No. 196 West Thirtieth-street, upon the body of HENRY W. SMITH, a lad sixteen years of age, who was drowned, on the 14th inst., while returning to this City from Dudley's Grove, on the Hudson, where he had been attending a Sabbath School picnic.
lead_paragraph: Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest, on Saturday at No. 196 West Thirtieth-street, upon the body of HENRY W. SMITH, a lad sixteen years of age, who was drowned, on the 14th inst., while returning to this City from Dudley's Grove, on the Hudson, where he had been attending a Sabbath School picnic. The barge which the youth was on board had reached a point opposite Fort Lee, when he requested a companion to draw up a small boat which was towing astern that he might enter it. This was done, and after he had reached the boat, the lad holding the rope let it go, and the boat brought up with such a violent jerk that SMITH was thrown overboard. Efforts were made to rescue him, but they were unsuccessful, and his body was not recovered until Saturday morning, when it was found in the river near Eightieth-street.

abstract: Wilson Eyre and Louisa Lincoln Eyre, his wife, vs. Edward Y. Higbee and Fanny L. Higbee, his wife This was an action brought to recover a large number of letters and other documents, written by Gen. Geo. Washington to Col. Lear.
lead_paragraph: Wilson Eyre and Louisa Lincoln Eyre, his wife, vs. Edward Y. Higbee and Fanny L. Higbee, his wife This was an action brought to recover a large number of letters and other documents, written by Gen. Geo. Washington to Col. Lear. The plaintiffs are the representatives of Col. Lear, to whom the letters were written and sent by Gen. Washington. The letters having in some way come into the possession of the defendant, Mrs. Higbee, the plaintiffs brought this action in the Supreme Court to recover them. The defence was that they had no title to the letters, or right to the custody of them.

abstract: The Brooklyn Yacht Club has just erected a new Club house at the foot of Court-street, Brooklyn. It is two stones high, and adjoins the Excelsior Base Ball ground. The first floor is intended for the members and is fitted with rooms and lockers. The upper story, for the use of ladies and friends of the members, has a veranda, from which can be obtained a splendid view of the yachts in the harbor, and down the bay as far as the Narrows. The Club possesses at the present time over thirty yachts, measuring more than 300 tons in all, over a hundred members, with constant accessions at every meeting. Great vigilance is exercised with regard to the respectability of applicants for admission. The Commodore introduced into the squadron, last year, series of sailing manoeuvres which were attended with much success. A code of pocket signals has also been invented which will be used hereafter by the Commodore for the evolutions of the yachts.

abstract: The steamer Melita, from Liverpool 14th inst., or Quebec, which passed Father Point yesterday, brings us four days later news from Europe.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Melita, from Liverpool 14th inst., or Quebec, which passed Father Point yesterday, brings us four days later news from Europe. The Sicilian Revolution was steadily making progress. The capitulation of the Neapolitans at Palermo took place on the 6th. The royal troops retiring with the honors of war from the city committed the most disgraceful and characteristic excesses on their retreat. Great efforts were making by the Neapolitan Government to secure Naples from the contagion of revolt by promises of a liberal Constitution; and it was rumored that the Emperor NAPOLEON had accepted a mediation on the basis of Neapolitan reforms and of a separate Government for Sicily under a Bourbon Prince; the latter clause "subject to the will of the Sicilian people." The experience of Central Italy after Villafranca would seem to make this clause, with the condition annexed, rather a mockery of the "Bourbon prince" aforesaid, and his royal family MAZZINI had sailed, it was said, for Sicily; and GARIBALDI, after establishing a Provisional Government, had ordered a levy en masse of the people, and was negotiating loans. The King's army had been concentrated in the two points of Messina and Syracuse. In the British Parliament Lord JOHN RUSSELL's Reform bill had died of inanition. His lordship had announced that the Government would postpone the measure till the next session, and the announcement had been received with general apparent gratification. Moderate and unpretending as the proposed bill undoubtedly was, the recent agitation of the whole ground, and working of representative institutions in England, has seriously weakened the faith of most intelligent Englishmen in the existence of any necessity for further progress in the extension of the suffrage at this time; and there can be little doubt that all parties were delighted to be rid of the question. Even Mr. BRIGHT acquiesced in the action of the Ministry on this subject, and took occasion in doing so to say a strong word in behalf of the Commercial Treaty with France. A remarkable speech was delivered on the 12th in the House of Commons by Lord PALMERSTON in which he openly denounced the conduct of the Neapolitan Government in Sicily, and declared that Governments like those of "Rome and Naples were themselves the authors and instigators of revolution." He also announced that Austria had peremptorily refused to interfere between Naples and Sicily. The Great Eastern had returned from a trial trip, in which she seems to have excited the admiration of her New-York pilot, although she did not succeed in equaling her own speed of last year. She was finally advertised to leave Southampton for New-York on the 16th, and to make the passage in about ten days. In this case we may expect to see the monster in our harbor in the course of the next forty-eight hours. A meeting was to take place at Baden on the 15th, between the Emperor NAPOLEON and the Prince-Regent of Prussia, from which grave political results were to be expected. It is to be hoped that the interview may have the good effect of calming the excited German mind, and banishing for the present the fear that France is upon the point of devouring her Teutonic neighbors along the Rhine. The commercial news by this arrival is not of special importance.

abstract: TOMPKINS MARKET FINISHED. The long looked for completion of the new Tompkins Market building is announced at last.
lead_paragraph: TOMPKINS MARKET FINISHED. -- The long looked for completion of the new Tompkins Market building is announced at last. The basement is to be used for restaurants and the like, the first floor for marketing, the next floor for offices, and the top floor for a drillroom and armory for the Seventh Regiment. The City Inspector visited the building on Friday, and on inspecting it he discovered a few faults, which he will require to be made satisfactory to him before he will be willing to assume possession. He particularly objects to the lightness of the iron grating used on the stoops, and will request the Street Commissioner to replace it with much stronger grating. He also complains that no side apertures, or [???]escapers," are made through the walls, for the outlet of floor washings. These and other imperfections probably will be immediately remedied by the street Commissioner, and the building be taken up by butchers, fish dealers and hucksters in the course of a week.

abstract: The Baltimore Convention has closed its labors. It met to nominate a Presidential candidate, and to adopt a platform; it has ended by giving the party two of each. Its ostensible object was to harmonize the party, to compromise points of difference, to reconcile sectional jealousies and distrusts, and to nominate a candidate who should unite the sentiment and support of the party, and thus secure a victory in the coming canvass.
lead_paragraph: The Baltimore Convention has closed its labors. It met to nominate a Presidential candidate, and to adopt a platform; it has ended by giving the party two of each. Its ostensible object was to harmonize the party, to compromise points of difference, to reconcile sectional jealousies and distrusts, and to nominate a candidate who should unite the sentiment and support of the party, and thus secure a victory in the coming canvass. It has accomplished exactly the opposite of all these things. It has divided and demoralized the party, -- sharpened and made more prominent its differences of principle, -- aggravated its sectional and personal hatreds, and nominated two candidates, each of whom will aim, specially and primarily, to defeat the other. The Convention was not in fact a deliberative assembly at all. It was not a conference of delegates having common interests, common hopes and common aims. It was, from the outset, a duel of hostile sections. The South came into the Convention hoping to rule it, and determined, failing in that, to break it up. The Administration shared alike its ambition and its hatred, and lent it what little aid its enfeebled condition would permit. The North came, goaded by long years of suffering servitude, superior in force and resolute in its purpose to use it. There were some among them who hoped a chance would arise for compromise, -- but the great body of the Northern delegates were determined upon the nomination of DOUGLAS at every hazard and at whatever cost. Finding that this could not be prevented, the South and the Administration resolved as the next step to defeat him at the polls; and it is for this specific object that their ticket has been put in nomination.
headline: {'main': 'The Baltimore Convention The Democratic Candidates.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Baltimore Convention The Democratic Candidates.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Boston Traveller, of the 20th June, gives full particulars of the murder perpetrated in Lowell, on the 19th, by BRYANT MOORE, a shoemaker. About a year ago MOORE married Mrs. SISSON, widow of a well-known druggist in Lowell, and a lady highly respected in the community. Soon his jealous disposition began to manifest itself by unfounded suspicions of one or two of the boarders, who had rooms in the house, and more particularly of a milkman who supplied the family with milk. This jealousy went so far that in the early part of last May, MOORE, as is supposed, wounded himself with a knife, and then entered a complaint against one PERLEY E. WATSON for stabbing him. This matter was adjusted between the parties without its coming to trial. Mrs. Moore determined to endure these annoyances no longer, and a separation occurred. A fortnight since her husband came to her, begged her forgiveness, and entreated a reconciliation. She finally consented, and he returned to live with her. Soon his jealous conduct was renewed. One night Mrs. MOORE was awakened by her husband's choking her. When he found that she was awake, he remarked that her sleep was broken more easily than he thought it would be. Another time Mrs. MOORE found a dull hatchet behind her husband's trunk. She asked him whether he intended to kill her and her daughter with it. He replied No, that he would use something sharper than that. This conduct determined Mrs. MOORE to again leave her husband. On Tuesday, after dinner, when there was no one in the house but himself and wife, with her little granddaughter and his idiot son, a young man 20 years of age, he came down from the attic to the kitchen, where his wife was busy at work, and asked her to go up stairs and help him pack his things, preparatory to going to Somerville. She complied, and went up with him. After they had been gone some minutes, the little girl heard two sharp reports of a pistol, and in a few moments Mr. MOORE came rushing down, with his head covered with blood, crying that he was murdered. He rushed out on the street, and on going up stairs she found her grandmother lying dead. City Marshall LOVEJOY, who was in the street, was attracted by MOORE's cries and went back with him to the house, when he found Mrs. MOORE in the attic lying dead in a pool of blood. On or near her left hand was a five barrelled revolver, all the barrels of which had been discharged. The pistol was very bloody but there was no blood on Mrs. M's hand. MOORE, who was below, several times stated that his wife had shot him and then killed herself, MOORE himself had three bullet wounds in his head, and persisted in asserting first that another man had shot him and then that his wife had done so. In the attic bloody marks were every where found. An account book was also discovered which contained a number of memorandums which proved that MOORE had long meditated the murder.

abstract: The time has come when the public expect some general outline of the programme likely to be observed in the reception of the Prince; and without being oracular, we may be able to give our readers a general idea of what will be done.
lead_paragraph: The time has come when the public expect some general outline of the programme likely to be observed in the reception of the Prince; and without being oracular, we may be able to give our readers a general idea of what will be done. The public have been laboring under the impression that a great portion of the arrangement would be sketched out in England. This, we have reason to believe, is not the case. Nearly everything is left to the authorities here, who, it is understood, have now been for the first time notified officially that the departure from England will take place on the 10th proximo. The Royal convoy will make St. John, Newfoundland, their first landing point; proceeding thence to Halifax -- from which place the Prince will go to New-Brunswick and Prince Edward Island. In the Lower Provinces his stay will necessarily be very limited, and the arrival of the royal fleet in the Lower St. Lawrence is confidently expected to take place not later than the 6th or 8th of August. At this point, therefore, the Canadian arrangements will necessarily commence; and these arrangements will be conducted almost exclusively under the dierction of the Commissioner of Public Works, who will charge himself with what may be called the governmental portion of the duties appertaining to the reception.

abstract: We referred, a few days ago, to the circumstances which gave rise to, and subsequently attended, the issue of twenty millions United States Treasury Bills, now authorized by Congress to be funded.
lead_paragraph: We referred, a few days ago, to the circumstances which gave rise to, and subsequently attended, the issue of twenty millions United States Treasury Bills, now authorized by Congress to be funded. This sum, and a similar one in five per cent. stock, have been added to the public debt of the United States since the close of the year 1857, raising the present total to $65,000,000. To our people this may appear a large sum, and by home comparison it is so; because our Government, in its brief history of seventy-one years, has been at least once wholly freed from debt, and at two other periods nearly so. But when we come to institute a foreign comparison, it will be found that neither our debt nor expenditure is anything in amount to be ashamed of, or anything in its nature to indicate an alarming or formidable degree of national extravagance. If we cannot, with strict truth, add that there is nothing of corruption in their administration, we can, at least, claim that there is little difficulty encountered in its exposure, as there ought to be none in its summary correction.

It is thought they will have a more difficult matter to settle at home than they had at Charleston or Baltimore.

abstract: CHURCHES DEDICATED. The new building recently erected by the Warren-street Methodist Episcopal Church, was formally dedicated for divine worship yesterday. It is located on Warren-street, between smith sad Court-streets. The building is constructed of brick, with brown-stone trimmings;  size 22 feet front, extending back from the street 87 feet. When completed and furnished it will cost about $22,000 $12,000 of which sum has been proviced for. The interior is divided two rooms.
lead_paragraph: CHURCHES DEDICATED. The new building recently erected by the Warren-street Methodist Episcopal Church, was formally dedicated for divine worship yesterday. It is located on Warren-street, between smith sad Court-streets. The building is constructed of brick, with brown-stone trimmings; size 22 feet front, extending back from the street 87 feet. When completed and furnished it will cost about $22,000 $12,000 of which sum has been proviced for. The interior is divided two rooms. The basement, which is 13 feet in the clear and on a level with the street, is for Sabbath School purposes, and will accommodate about 700 children. The main auditorium is on the floor above. It is 36 feet in the clear, and will have sittings for about 1,200 persons. This portion of the building is not yet ready for use. This Society was organized eight years ago as a Hedding Mission and was located in Butler-street. Subsequently the Society hired the old church, corner of Court and Butler streets, where it remained for some time, until the building was sold, when a hall at the corner of Court and Sackett streets was secured. Here the Society remained, under the immediate care of the Ladies' Missionary Society, until four years ago, when the ladies abandoned it, and the managers secured a private room on Warren, near Hoyt-street. Through the agency of several active members a sufficient subscription was obtained to warrant the commencement of the present edifice last Spring. At that time the Society had only 20 members and about 25 Sabbath school scholars. There are now 75 members of the Church, and a congregation of about 400 persons; and there are 175 children in the Sabbath school, under the charge of Mr. HUNT, as Superintendent. The Church is in a locality where a Protestant society is much needed, and in a position to do much good. Yesterday, Rev. JOSEPH LAW, pastor, Rev. Mr. Foss, of the Fleet-street Church, and Rev. Dr. DUNBAR took part in the dedication services..... The Washington-avenue Baptist Church, located at the corner of Greene and Washington avenues, was dedicated yesterday, Rev. C.W. ANABLE, pastor, Rev. JAMES L. HODGE, and Rev. Dr. LATHROP taking part in the exercises. The Church is a neat Gothic building, constructed of brick, at a cost of about $30,000, about two-thirds of which has been provided for. The interior is neatly arranged, and has about 1,200 sittings. One peculiar feature of this Church is that the choir and organ are located in a nave on a level with the main floor and at the left of the pulpit.

abstract: The Japanese furore in the Metropolis culminates in the grand Municipal Ball and Promenade at the Metropolitan this evening.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese furore in the Metropolis culminates in the grand Municipal Ball and Promenade at the Metropolitan this evening. The unanswerable question is now, Where are all the tickets? Who are the lucky six thousand that have monopolized the Committee's favors? A few hundreds may be accounted for as having been distributed to members of the City Government; but, at the rate of distribution generally admitted, it is difficult to account for a tithe of the whole number known to be printed -- and yet they are publicly advertised for sale in one of the daily papers, and command prices varying from $25 down. Only fifty tickets were given to the Naval Committee in charge of the Embassy, and these with the request that Capt. DUPONT would "Supply the Naval officers on the Station." All the Naval officers who apply to the Committee are referred to Capt. DUPONT, and the result is, the Captain is considerably perplexed. He is now engaged in solving the mathematical problem of how to supply one hundred applicants with half that number of tickets. The Common Council Committee is in the same fix, or pretends to be, so that since six hundred thousand are anxious to go, and only six thousand cards are issued, five hundred and ninety-four thousand must be disappointed. Meanwhile the question, "Who sells the tickets?" remains to be answered by the members of the Common Council who had the control of them, and through whom alone they must have been procured. The idea of supplying the heaviest tax-payers, who really have to "pay the piper," seems never to have suggested itself to the City Solons, and some of the largest property-owners have in vain endeavored to procure admissions. Yet the Ward politicians have a plentiful supply, and to spare.

abstract: No further intelligence has been received to relieve the anxiety which is felt concerning the fate of the twenty missing persons of this ill-fated steamer. There are, however, strong hopes that some of them have been saved, and may yet be heard from at Norfolk, or some other Southern port. A strong northeaster was blowing at the time of the accident, which would render it inconvenient for a sailing vessel bound south to stop in the Delaware. It is now stated that the schooner which sunk the Walker was named the Johnson, and that she came to anchor the same morning inside of Cape May, with her bowsprit and cutwater carried away.

abstract: The spectacle which we are again, about to witness of the reshipment to Africa of the negroes captured in slave ships, at an enormous cost to the Government, is one of the strangest of the many strange incidents by ...
lead_paragraph: The spectacle which we are again, about to witness of the reshipment to Africa of the negroes captured in slave ships, at an enormous cost to the Government, is one of the strangest of the many strange incidents by which this question of Slavery is marked. The fate to which these people are consigned by being sent back to their native shores is only one degree better than that from which we rescued them in the first instance. We know that the population along the African Coast, for some, hundreds of miles into the interior, have been so demoralized by the Slave-trade, that the native chiefs look on their subjects simply as so many head of cattle, and are always ready to supply as many as can be caught to the first trader that comes in the way. We know, consequently, that to send a cargo of slaves back to the place from whence they came, even if we could restore each one of them to his home, would be simply to expose them to a repetition of the horrors from which they have once been rescued. But, with the best intentions in the world, their return to their former places of abode, and to their families, is impossible. They are collected from various places, at various distances from the coast, and the same raid which consignes them to the slaver, in many instances consigns their villages to destructions. If we leave them on the coast they of course starve, unless some friendly kidnapper chances to light upon them before they cease to be worth the trouble of shipment.

abstract: Dr. RIDGEWAY, of Olney, Ill., has been startled from medical meditation by finding a man's head, minus the body thereunto belonging, near the door of his shop. He is anxious that any ...
lead_paragraph: Dr. RIDGEWAY, of Olney, Ill., has been startled from medical meditation by finding a man's head, minus the body thereunto belonging, near the door of his shop. He is anxious that any one having lost a head should call, prove property, and take it away. Though not much of a head, he thinks it must be a great loss to its owner. The phenomenon may easily be accounted for. It is undoubtedly one of the many "dead-heads" that attended the Chicago Convention.

abstract: Mrs. Dr. LYDIA SAYRE HASBROUCK, has been compelled to vacate the editorial chair of the Sibyl temporarily. Hear her reason: We are the fortunate owners of a clover field, and we just returned from walking through and inhaling its sweet
lead_paragraph: Mrs. Dr. LYDIA SAYRE HASBROUCK, has been compelled to vacate the editorial chair of the Sibyl temporarily. Hear her reason: We are the fortunate owners of a clover field, and we just returned from walking through and inhaling its sweet -- sweets such as no cosmetic can imitate. But above all the fruits, plants and flowers, we have another little nursing plant to tend and nestle to our hearts in the form of a little boy of ten days old, who lays quietly sleeping near us as we write this. A blue-eyed, fair-skinned, golden-haired and tender plant, he seems to meet the roughness of this world in striking contrast to our dark-eyed little Daisy, whose place here seems if possible more vacant now, that the little brother she so often asked us to get her has come among us."

abstract: The memory of the night of June 25, 1860,  will long shine like a rose-pink lantern, or an apothecary`s window, in the civic annals of NewYork. The ball given by the Councilmen, at the ...
lead_paragraph: The memory of the night of June 25, 1860, will long shine like a rose-pink lantern, or an apothecary`s window, in the civic annals of NewYork. The ball given by the Councilmen, at the expense of the City, to the Japanese guests of the nation, is an event of which, in the language of college [???]ators, it may be justly said that it marks an era in the history of our race. Possibly this sublime view of the grand festival which all night long thundered with carriages and lightened with gas lamps, in the heart of New-York, and which is, no doubt, at this moment still echoing, though more softly; through the unquiet slumbers of thousands of lovely beings, who will not be "up and doing" till long after "business hours" to-day, may strike some of our readers as extravagant. No Councilman, we are sure will think so; but we are speaking to the multitudinous public mind, and so we must take nothing for granted. We repeat, then, that the bal which began last night, and will end, we suppose some hours after we shall have gone to sleep this morning, was one of the events of the age.

abstract: Messrs. GRINNELL, MINTURN  Co. had received no information yesterday, previous to the arrival of the New-York, of the day of sailing of the Great Eastern. Our special correspondent writes, however, that she was positively announced for the 16th, though so little confidence is felt in anything pertaining to her management that no great reliance was placed on the advertisement. Mr. MURPHY, the New-York pilot, who ...
lead_paragraph: Messrs. GRINNELL, MINTURN Co. had received no information yesterday, previous to the arrival of the New-York, of the day of sailing of the Great Eastern. Our special correspondent writes, however, that she was positively announced for the 16th, though so little confidence is felt in anything pertaining to her management that no great reliance was placed on the advertisement. Mr. MURPHY, the New-York pilot, who went out to bring her into port, writes that she will positively sail on the day named. If she did, she is now ten days out, and may be expected today or to-morrow, though we should not be greatly surprised if she were to be eleven or twelve days in making the voyage.

abstract: The Legislative Committee on the Central Park investigation held another Session on Saturday, and resumed the inquiry upon the charges preferred by Mr. HOGG. The Chairman of the Committee, Mr. ...
lead_paragraph: The Legislative Committee on the Central Park investigation held another Session on Saturday, and resumed the inquiry upon the charges preferred by Mr. HOGG. The Chairman of the Committee, Mr. MURPHY, was absent, and Mr. ROTCH presided in his place. Mr. ANDREW A. GREEN, one of the Central Park Commissioners, was examined at length relative to the management of the Park from its inception, the text for the interrogatories being the charges and specifications of Mr, HOGG. He said he was appointed one of the Commissioners in April, 1857, and had successively held the offices of treasurer and comptroller of the Board. The work upon the Park, had been well conducted from the beginning. The chief engineer and architect, Mr. OLMSTED, was eminently qualified for the post, and had invariably enjoyed the entire confidence of the Board. The head men in his employ had also, as a general thing, performed their duties to the entire satisfaction of the Board. There had been no peculations or other abuses worthy of note; in fact the strict surveillance exercised in the management prevented the possibility of peculation. The only case he had ever heard of was a young man being charged with selling some powder, but he was never proved guilty of the charge, and as he had resigned his position witness preferred not to mention his name. The number of acres in the Park at present was 773 45-100, which would eventually be increased 60 acres.

abstract: Further news from Pike's Peak is received this evening.  A band of Arapahoe Indians have just returned from the South Fork, where they had a battle with the whites, in which the latter was defeated with some considerable loss. The Arapahoes lost several warriors, among whom is little RAVEN, one of their Chiefs. They also took some of the whites prisoners.

abstract: BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL.?A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening President KALBFLEISCH in the Chair. The principal portion of the session was occupied in the consideration of subjects possessing no general interest.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. -- A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening President KALBFLEISCH in the Chair. The principal portion of the session was occupied in the consideration of subjects possessing no general interest. Alderman MANGER, of the Fifteenth Ward, offered a resolution appointing a special Committee of five to as�certain whether the late city of Williamsburgh and the town of Bushwick did not get cheated under the consolidation act by the valuation placed upon Washington Park and City Hall Park. The former, he said, was valued at $300,000 and the latter at $120,000 -- a sum much larger, he contended, than the property would bring to-day if placed in the market, Aldermen DAYTON and JENKINS exposed the fallacy of this statement, and, after an amendment offered by Mr, DAYTON to direct the Committee to inquire also whether the Eleventh Ward had not been taxed too much for the Washington Park, had been incorpo�rated into the resolution, the whole subject was laid on the table. The Farmers' and Citizens' Bank, by resolution, was made a bank of deposit for the city funds, and after the transaction of some routine busi�ness, the Board adjourned for one week.

abstract: The Central Park investigation is, so far a it has gone, so very ridiculous, that we are sorry that gentlemen who can be better employed, should be engaged in it. It appears to ...
lead_paragraph: The Central Park investigation is, so far a it has gone, so very ridiculous, that we are sorry that gentlemen who can be better employed, should be engaged in it. It appears to be promoted by a person who passed the most flattering encomium on the manage�ment, in the expectation that the Commission�ers would employ him at a salary of $2,500 a year, and who now opposes it, because this nefarious arrangement was not carried out. His principal witness is a Mr. DANIELS, who sent in a plan, which was rejected, and he is actually being gravely examined as to the merits of the plan which got the prize, and as to the competrcy of Mr. OLMSTED his sucessful u[???] If the inquirty progress is it has begun, it will be too farcical to receive any further notice outside the Astor House.

abstract: The Senate was entirely orderly in its manner of adjournment to-day, but the House presented such a scene of wild disorder that Mr. VANCE called for the leading of the riot act. The last two hours of the session were consumed in calling the ayes and nays, to prevent legislation on private bills or the introduction of resolutions. The galleries of both Houses were crowded, to witness the closing scenes.

abstract: Yesterday witnessed the close of the First Session of the Thirty-sixth Congress; and few, probably, who hsve been cognizant of its proceedings from first to last, will regret that the country is at length at liberty to breathe with a little more freedom, in view of the fact that one element of discord and strife is for the present quieted. On ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday witnessed the close of the First Session of the Thirty-sixth Congress; and few, probably, who hsve been cognizant of its proceedings from first to last, will regret that the country is at length at liberty to breathe with a little more freedom, in view of the fact that one element of discord and strife is for the present quieted. On the assembling of the Senate, Mr. SUMNER presented a petition of citizens of Massachusetts, praying for the repeal of the Fugitive Slave law, the a[???]olition of Slavery in the District of Columbia, and the prohibition of the inter-State Slave-trade. At his request it was laid on the table. The p[???]route bill was then taken up, and after considerable debate and the adoption of various ame[???]nts, it was passed and sent to the House. The House bill to amend the Consular act was reported from the Committee on Commerce, but laid over. Various other measures were proposed, but they were laid over. A message was received from the House notifying the Senate that they receded from their amendments to the Post-office Deficiency bill -- therefore it stands passed. The customary Committee was appointed to act in conjunction with one from the House, to notify the President that Congress was ready to adjourn, and after a vote of thanks to the presiding officer, and a short Executive session, the Senate was declared adjourned. In the House, another protest was received from the President against the proceedings of the Covode Investigating Committee, in which he characterized the action of the House as violative of the lights of a coordinate branch of the Government, and asserts that, should the proceedings of the Committee be sanctioned, the Constitution will have been violated. The message was referred, to a select Committee, and its consideration was postponed until the next session. The House refused to agree to the Senate's amendments to the Post Route bill, and it was consequently lost. After some other unimportant business, and the usual preliminary ceremonies, the House adjourned sine die.

abstract: This match will commence to-day (Wednesday,) at the new Cricket Ground, Hoboken. It is expected to be the great match of the season, as the opposing forces on each side are comprised of first-class cricketers, and there is no little rivalry among the friends of tooth Clubs. The Kings County Club feel sanguine in their expectation of defeating the hitherto victorious Knights of St, George, notwithstanding the array of names, such as Gibbets, Walker, Waller, Lang, Tinson, Earnshaw, Brett, S. and H. Wright, and a score more to pick from -- Kings County, bringing into the field the two great English cricketers, Sadler -- who made fifty against Philadelphia -- and Sams, backed by the Sussex player Hagges, Bray, and a dozen other good ones.

abstract: The Coroners were yesterday notified to take the ante-mortem deposition of a laborer named THOMAS RAFFERTY, who was stabbed with a cheese-knife on the evening of the 18th inst., during an altercation between himself and one O'NEIL. The affray took place in the grocery-store No. 23 Laurens-street, kept by WILLIAM MILLER, and both the disputants were intoxicated at the time.  RAFFERTY now lies at the City Hospital in a dying condition. His assailant has not been arrested.

abstract: We published a note-from Mr. H.D. TOWNSEND, yesterday, touching the "contempt of Court," in this case, which sheds no new light on the matter, and proves that he has entirely misunderstood the position we took in regard to it. We are willing to give him the benefit of his denial that he carries concealed weapons "as part of his practice," but it certainly is very odd that when a lawyer is threatened with personal violence in a Court-room, in which a Judge is sitting, he should forthwith draw a pistol. The presumption which such an incident raises as to the learned gentleman's habits is an unpleasant one, but he must admit it is natural. That it should have occurred, shows the spirit which is beginning to predominate at the New-York bar. If the members placed serious value on the self-control which is the essence of gentle-manliness, they would no more think of drawing a weapon in a Judge's presence than of producing one at a church-meeting. The thing was a shocking and inexcusable breach of decorum, and it is not in the least palliated by the judgment debtor's insolence and violence. If lawyers undertake to protect themselves against the foul language and brutal threats of all the coarse and ruffianly persons with whom their duties in Court bring them in contact, suits might as well be decided by a "rough and tumble fight" in a bar-room. It is the Judge's duty to protect the bar in the discharge of its duty. When Mr. TOWNSEND was assailed, as he says he was, by " rude insult," he would, if he were thoroughly alive to forensic proprieties, instead of " replying quickly" and then drawing his revolver, have done at first what he did finally -- apply to Judge BONNEY for an attachment.

If lawyers undertake to protect themselves against the foul language and brutal threats of all the coarse and ruffianly persons with whom their duties in Court bring them in contact, suits might as well be decided by a "rough and tumble fight" in a bar-room. abstract: SHOOTING AFFRAY BETWEEN EDITORS. -- The Lvnchburg, Va., correspondent of the Baltimore Sun describes a desperate affray which occurred in that town, on the 23d, between G.W. and W.H. HARD. WICKE. of the Republican, and C.W, JOSEPH, ROBERT and GEORGE BUTTON, of the Virginian. The difficulty grew out of an article which appeared in the editorial columns of the Virginian,charging Mr. GLASS, political Editor of the Republican, and postmaster of Lynchburg, with dereliction of duty in attending the Democratic Convention. The next morning a paragraph appeared in the Republican denouncing C.W. BUTTON, proprietor of the Virgiman, as a coward,&c. This Brought out a card from JOSEPH BUTTON, local Editor of the Virginan, charging G.W.HARDWICKE with cowardice, reflecting on him as being the son of a vagrant, whose father, now dead, was sold in the streets of Lynchburgh for fifty cents. The following morning, another card appeared in the Virginian in witch JOSEPH BUTTON expressed regret for having invaded the sanctuary of the dead, but affirmed that he had no retraction to make in relation to what he had said about G.w. HARDWICKE. The parties met on the afternoon of the same day in the streets of Lynchburgh, when they at once drew their revolvers and began firing at each other. Fifteen or twenty shots were exchanged. The HARDWICKES escaped uninjured. JOSEPH BUTTON was shot in the abdomen -- the ball passing entirely through his body. He died soon after. ROBERT BUTTON was shot in the side -- the ball lodging in the spin alregion. The HARDWICKES have been committed and the offices of both papers are at present closed,

abstract: James Dunn, an employe in a tool factory, in Rochester, fell into the race in front of the old cotton factory ruins, while endeavoring to pull out a piece of scantling which had been left in an opening there. The force of the current swept him through the ruins of the building to the tail race, and then hurled him down a precipice fifty or sixty feet high, upon the rocks below. He was carried along by the stream from the point where he fell, until he lodged anions some drift wood. Strangely enough no bones wen broken, and he was able to crawl up on the bank where he was soon found and carried home.

abstract: LECTURE BEFORE THE YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN UNION.--A lecture was delivered before the Young Men;s Christian Union at their meeting on Monday evening, by C.W. TOLLES, Esq., of Newark. His subject was Orthodoxy.
lead_paragraph: LECTURE BEFORE THE YOUNG MEN'S CHRISTIAN UNION.--A lecture was delivered before the Young Men;s Christian Union at their meeting on Monday evening, by C.W. TOLLES, Esq., of Newark. His subject was Orthodoxy. The theological tenets usually termed " orthodox " he claimed, had no obligatory force upon men, ner could they command their consciences and judgments to recognize the bible as the only source of religious truth. Man had bestowed upon him the power and ability to investigate and arrive at religious truth in the same manner as at scientific or other truth. The original intuitions of men were the primary revelations implanted by God, and were tie true criterion for determining the nature and value of all other revelations. Hence it was argued that the system of religious truth was not completed by the instructions of Christ and his Apostles but is always progressively developing, and is capable of being rendered more perfect in this age, than ever before. The arbitrary adoption of creeds of abstract dogmas, and the imposition of them on men as tests of religious or moral rectitude, were reprobated, and declared to be inconsonant with the will of God, with the freedom of man, and with the progress of truth. Entire independence of thought should be allowed every man, since God regarded action, and not opinion, and had placed in the heart of man laws for determining what is right and wrong. The thanks of the Association were tendered to Mr. TOLLES for his instructive lecture.

abstract: The regulars and volunteers under Col. HAYES and Capt. STEWART were attacked on the afternoon of the 2d inst. near Pyramid Lake. The Indians were defeated, with a loss of 70 killed and several wounded. Two volunteers were killed and three wounded. Capt. STORER was mortally wounded. Three regulars were killed and one wounded.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times: As a member of the New-York Bar I may be permitted to volunteer in defence of the Court, when undeservedly censured through your columns. I am fully aware that the dignity of the Bench must be upheld by the Judges themselves in punishing severely the slightest contempt on the part of counsel, suitor or witness; and of your duty, as Editor of one of the most influential and widely-circulated papers in the State, to expose any failure on their part to do so; but, unless the power of the Press be wielded, I will not say with caution, but with justice, in these cases it will not only cease to be of any avail in counteracting the evil complained of, but must necessarily be productive of great evil, because it will lead the public to believe that there is a much greater want of decorum, dignity and respect prevailing in our Courts than is really the case, and consequently must neces. sarily bring the administration of justice into contemnt.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: As a member of the New-York Bar I may be permitted to volunteer in defence of the Court, when undeservedly censured through your columns. abstract: The Tribune yesterday announced that the City Inspector, Mr. DELAVAN, has appointed JOHN E. ENRIGHT to be one of the Health Wardens of the City. As we have seen no contradiction of the statement, we are constrained --discreditable as it is to a City officer whom we have found frequent occasion to commend--to believe it to be true. Who and what this man ENRIGHT IS, the community in general need not be informed.

abstract: If not "first in peace," GARIBALDI has assuredly made himself first in war and first in the hearts of his countrymen, of all Italy, by his heroic invasion and brilliant conquest of Sicily. And the motives which have ruled the whole life of this great patriot are not left to the conjectures either of his friends or his foes.
lead_paragraph: If not "first in peace," GARIBALDI has assuredly made himself first in war and first in the hearts of his countrymen, of all Italy, by his heroic invasion and brilliant conquest of Sicily. And the motives which have ruled the whole life of this great patriot are not left to the conjectures either of his friends or his foes. They have been proved in the conflicts of a core of years, tried by temptations the most [???]arious, the most subtle, the most poignant, and justified in the sight of all men. GARIBALDI has given his sword, his strength, his [???]opes and his life to the regeneration of Italy, with as absolute and earnest a devotion as hat which bound our own WASHINGTON to the [???]ause of the American colonies. Nor is this all. As much might be said for other men 'horn it would be an outrage upon common tense to rank with the great founder of our republic. MAZZINI too, for instance, has lived not for Italy. But MAZZINI has lived not for Italy lone. He has worshipped himself, after sublime Brahminical fashion, in worshipping is own ideas of policy, his own philosophy of [???]tecraft.

abstract: A man known as Abram parish was committed, by Justice WELSH, for examination on a charge of forgery, the complaint having been lodged by Mr. William Campbell of Sing Sing, Westchester County, who alleged that in January last the accused obtained from him a quantity of cigars, valued at $756 49, giving as payment therefor a note of hand, purporting to have been made by H. Van Allen & Co., merchants at Logansport, Indiana, whose agent he professed to be. The document proves to have been forged, William Wright, an alleged confederate of Parish in the transaction, is said to have fled to Europe.
lead_paragraph: A man known as Abram parish was committed, by Justice WELSH, for examination on a charge of forgery, the complaint having been lodged by Mr. William Campbell of Sing Sing, Westchester County, who alleged that in January last the accused obtained from him a quantity of cigars, valued at $756 49, giving as payment therefor a note of hand, purporting to have been made by H. abstract: STABBING AFFRAY. -- On Sunday afternoon an affray occurred between a party of semi-intoxicated men near South Bergen, which resulted in the stabbing of one of them named DANIEL CRAIG, by one CORNELIUS H. GOETOHIENS, of Jersey City. The wounds were inflicted with a knife, and consist principally of two severe cuts in the face and head, with other minor injuries. GOETCHIENS was arrested, on Monday morning, and brought before Justice RYERSON, of Hudson City, when the examination was postponed until Tuesday at 3 o'clock P.M, in order to allow the prisoner time to procure counsel.

abstract: The grand " Japanese Reception " of Monday night was not only a curiosity in its way, but a very instructive one. That it was morally a failure, every one admits; and when we consider the elements of success which it possessed, this result is really somewhat surprising. It is not every day in the year that the wealthiest City in the New World lays out forty thousand dollars upon flowers, lights, music, banners, frescoes and champagne, for the entertainment of an embassy from remote and hitherto inaccessible empires. The occasion of the fete of Monday night, its guests and its cost were alike exceptional. How, then, did it happen that, in spite of all these incentives to effort and all these opportunities for success, New-York contrived to give the Japanese a ball from which everyone who attended it was delighted to get away, and which nobody can now speak of without a sardonic smile or an angry shrugof the shoulder?
lead_paragraph: The grand " Japanese Reception " of Monday night was not only a curiosity in its way, but a very instructive one.
