abstract: This annual festival took place on Monday, although there was not sufficient wind to finish the race, which is to be sailed over again. The new two-story Club-house was overflowing with a large concourse of ladies and gentlemen, and the steamboat John L, Lockwood carried about two hundred more, who enjoyed themselves in dancing, a fine band of music being on board. Commodore Haight, Secretary Lee, the Hegatta Committee, Messrs. Doty, Sawyer and Courtland, and the Reception Committee, Messrs. Hillyer,Wilson and Adams, were most attentive to the numerous company.

abstract: A NEW FORGERY.--Some shrewd rascal has lately got up a lithographic fac-simile of the Brooklyn Ferry Co.'s tickets, so exact in every particular that the best judges cannot distinguish the difference without the closest scrutiny and comparison. abstract: Congress has adjourned, without attracting special attention from any quarter. abstract: Under the caption "I Smell Wool," the Matagorda (Texas) Gazette of the 13th, says: "It is rumored that a Baltimore clipper, commanded by Spaniards or Mexicans, and having a very suspicious appearance, was seen off Passo Cavallo last week. She appeared to be trying to get a pilot, and at the same time avoid a group of vessels lying at anchor, just outside the bar, among which she seemed to suspect the existence of a revenue cutter. She is described as being a very trim and neat-looking vessel, and decidedly the fastest sailer that has been in these waters for a long time. After some time spent in peeping into our pass, and satisfying herself that there was nothing dangerous about our quiet bay, she sailed in the direction of Pass Aransas. We would not be surprised to hear that something "drapped" about the time she got to Aransas. This is probably a vessel that intended to land negroes on the Island of Cuba, but was chased off by a cruiser, and is now seeking a market on our coast. Cruisers have become so numerous on the Cuban coast that many of the cargoes of Africans intended for that place may be expected on this coast.

She is described as being a very trim and neat-looking vessel, and decidedly the fastest sailer that has been in these waters for a long time. After some time spent in peeping into our pass, and satisfying herself that there was nothing dangerous about our quiet bay, she sailed in the direction of Pass Aransas. We would not be surprised to hear that something "drapped" about the time she got to Aransas. This is probably a vessel that intended to land negroes on the Island of Cuba, but was chased off by a cruiser, and is now seeking a market on our coast. Cruisers have become so numerous on the Cuban coast that many of the cargoes of Africans intended for that place may be expected on this coast.

abstract: The People Vs. Christian Hansen.--The trial of this case, which is a prosecution for arson in the first degree, was commenced, yesterday in the Oyer and Terminer, before Justice GOULD. The facts of the case, as stated by the Assistant District Attorney, Mr. Sedgwick, in his opening address to the jury, are these: The defendant kept a lager bier saloon at the corner of Centre-street and Park: and had girls boarding in the establishment.
lead_paragraph: The People Vs. Christian Hansen. -- The trial of this case, which is a prosecution for arson in the first degree, was commenced, yesterday in the Oyer and Terminer, before Justice GOULD. The facts of the case, as stated by the Assistant District Attorney, Mr. Sedgwick, in his opening address to the jury, are these: The defendant kept a lager bier saloon at the corner of Centre-street and Park: and had girls boarding in the establishment. These stairs were narrow and circuitous, and did not permit a person to go up and down quickly. At the time of the fire there was only one person in the house besides the prisoner, and that was a female named Jane Ennis. Shortly before the fire occurred, two other girls bad been sent away by the prisoner, who said he was going to give up business and go to California. He was insured for $800 in an Insurance Company, and it was claimed that there was but a few dollars in value in the house at the time of the fire. The day before the fire, Jane Eanis was told to sleep up stairs, as the defendant wanted to do some carpente[???]ing. About 1 A. M., Jane Ennis was told to go to bed, and a little while after she heard the prisoner going up and down stairs. About mat time there was a smell of campbene in the room, which became so strong that she hid her bead under the bed clothes. About 5 A. M. she was woke up by the prisoner, who was fully dressed, and who told her to get up, there was fire. He then made his escape by preparations already mane, and went [???]hrough the scuttle on to the roof of another house. When the police broke in, they found the traces of camphene all over the house. There was nothing in the house at all except the girl's clothes. Testimony on the part of the people in support of these facts was commenced. The testimony the case was not sufficient to convict the accused, and he was accordingly acquitted.

abstract: Morpheus was extensively courted yesterday among the Japanese visitors at the Metropolitan. The zest with which the entire Embassy, from the prince down to the cooks, enjoyed the festivities of the grand ball, necessitated a day of rest. The chief Ambassador, however, found time in the morning to visit the Brooklyn Glass Works in company with two or three of his suite, under the guidance...
lead_paragraph: Morpheus was extensively courted yesterday among the Japanese visitors at the Metropolitan. The zest with which the entire Embassy, from the prince down to the cooks, enjoyed the festivities of the grand ball, necessitated a day of rest. The chief Ambassador, however, found time in the morning to visit the Brooklyn Glass Works in company with two or three of his suite, under the guidance WM, LELAND. The prince viewed with great interest the various operations of glass melting, plowing and moulding, and gratefully accepted presents of various articles manufactured in his presence. Another party, including TOMMY, visited the Brooklyn Navy-yard to view the arrangements on the Niagara. The baggage is now nearly all stored, and all will be ready promptly on Saturday for the Embassy to embark on their homeward voyage. The subordinate officers continue their shopping excursions, and throughout yesterday, as during every day of their stay in the City, their presence in some of the principal stores could be noted by the crowds peering in at the doors and windows. Two or three of the Niphonese experienced a new sensation by riding in an omnibus, which they were, after some difficulty, persuaded to enter. During their stay they seemed suspicious of the whole arrangement, as if fearful of a design to play some trick upon them.

abstract: George A. Simmons Vs. George Law. -- This is an action against George Law, the Celebrated Shipper, as a common carrier, and it is now on trial before Justice BOSWORTH, in the Superior Court. The Plaintiff alleges that in March, 1851, he shipped on board the Antelope, one of defendant's line of steamers, at San Francisco, a quantity of gold dust, to be conveyed to this City, and which, when arrived here would have been of the value of $3,561 50. During the voyage the dust was stolen by thieves, or taken from the agent of the defendant by robbers, and the plaintiff sues Law an a common carrier, seeking to make him responsible for the loss. The plaintiff claims this his bill of lading for the dust provides for the safe delivery of the treasure without conditions.

abstract: The Great Eastern sailed from Liverpool on the 16th inst., and is now, therefore, fully due at this port. It is quite probable that she will arrive to-day. We understand that it is not high tide until 1  P.M., and that she will not cross the bar, at whatever hour she may reach it, until that time.
lead_paragraph: The Great Eastern sailed from Liverpool on the 16th inst., and is now, therefore, fully due at this port. It is quite probable that she will arrive to-day. We understand that it is not high tide until 1 P.M., and that she will not cross the bar, at whatever hour she may reach it, until that time. This renders it extremely probable that our citizens may have from the Battery and the shores of the North River an excellent opprtunity to observe her huge bulk as she passes to her dock at the foot of Hammond-street. We shall publish upon her arrival a full and reliable account of her voyage from the pen of our special engineering correspondent, " Tubal Cain," who went to England expressly to make this voyage home in the gigantic steamer.

abstract: Hon. WILLIAM PENNINGTON, Speaker of the House of Representatives, left Washington yesterday morning and arrived at his home, in Newark, at 9 o'clock last evening. A large concourse of people, comprising men of all parties, had collected at the depot awaiting his arrival, and the enthusiastic cheers which greeted his return testified to the universal popularity which he enjoys among all classes of his fellow-townsmen.
lead_paragraph: Hon. WILLIAM PENNINGTON, Speaker of the House of Representatives, left Washington yesterday morning and arrived at his home, in Newark, at 9 o'clock last evening. A large concourse of people, comprising men of all parties, had collected at the depot awaiting his arrival, and the enthusiastic cheers which greeted his return testified to the universal popularity which he enjoys among all classes of his fellow-townsmen. The "Wide Awake" battalion of Newark, numbering upwams of 200 men, turned out in a body with torchlights and a band of music, to escort him from The depot to his residence, on the arrival of ears from Philadelphia, at 5 minutes past 9 o' clock, cannon were fired opposite the deopt, bonfires blazed, ockets were shot up, and amid the cheers of several thousand people, Mr. PENNINGTON stepped out of the ear and was escorted through the line of the "Wide Awakes" to the head of the proceassion. After some deay the order was given to move, and the procession started on its way to the residence of Mr, PENNINGTON, on High-Street, about one and a half miles from the depot. It passed up Market-Street to Broad, down Broad to Court and up Cout to Hoyt, and was greeted all along the route with the cheers of the crowd, displays of rockets. Roman candles and other manifastations of joy. At about 10 o'clock the procession arrived at the residence of Mr. PENNINGTON -- an old-fashioned wodden manion, embowered in a forest of trees and with pacious grounds attached.

abstract: The Pike's Peak Express arrived here this evening with $11,353 in gold dust and dates to June 21. The reported death of LITTLE RAVEN, chief of the Arapahoes, in the recent battle with the Utes, proves to be false. His brother was severely wounded. The Arapahoes lost five killed and 32 wounded. They captured four Utes' children and 63 ponies. The loss of the Utes is not known.

abstract: THE SENTIMENT OF VENETIA. -- Venice though dumb still speaketh. On the 5th of June Marshal VAILLANT, the commander of the French forces still in Italy, visited the ancient and heroic city of the Doges. No sooner was his arrival known than the word went round in all the circles of Venetian society. On Monday night the Marshal reached the Albergodi Europa; and on Tuesday morning visitors of the highest rank began to call at his hotel and leave their cards. This silent demonstration continued throughout the two days of his stay, and by Wednesday evening two thousand cards had been received. On the same evening a magnificent bouquet, in which the red, white and blue of France predominated, was left at the Marshal's hotel in the name of the ladies of Venice. Whenever the Marshal left his hotel, the middle and lower classes in their turn, took up this strange and silent testimony against the Austrian. Wherever he went every hat was raised, every head uncovered; till the gallant soldier who had faced the foes of Italy so fearlessly on the field of battle, found himself at last unable to endure the mute appeal of a noble Italian people, upon whom the sun of independence has not yet been suffered to rise. He cut short his visit to Venice on the 8th.
lead_paragraph: THE SENTIMENT OF VENETIA. -- Venice though dumb still speaketh. abstract: The body of an aged woman was found yesterday in the water at the foot of Twenty-third-street, North River. Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, but no evidence could be obtained with reference to her identity, or the circumstances attending her death.... The same Coroner held an inquest upon the remains of a sailor named BENNET, who was employed on board the schooner Mayflower, lying at Pier No. 21 North River. He was drowned last Friday night, in attempting to go on board the vessel....Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest upon the remains of an unknown woman, apparently 40 years of age, who was found drowned, at the foot of Duane-street. The Fifth Precinct Police recognized deceased as a person of intemperate habits, who resided in Thomas-street, but whose name they did not know....The same Coroner investigated the circumstances connected with the death of an unknown man, who was found in the water at Pier No. 44 East River. The body was too much decomposed to admit of recognition....SELINA BOWMAN, a German woman, died at Bellevue Hospital, in consequence of injuries received four weeks ago by the falling of an embankment at the corner of Sixty-fourth-street and Fourth-avenue....TIMOTHY DESMOND, an aged printer, died at the First Ward Station-house from the effects of intemperance. He was well-known to the police as an habitual drunkard, who obtained his liquor by tapping barrels upon the docks....DAVID D. BAILEY a man 50 years of age, residing at No. 112 West Thirty-third-street, also died in consequence of his drunken habits. In each case inquests were held.

abstract: The propeller Kenosha, of the Collingwood and Chicago line, exploded her boiler off Sheboygan, yesterday morning, instantly killing CURTIS BURTON, of Cleveland, clerk, and MICHAEL CAREY, of Buffalo, first engineer. Three deck hands and the chambermaid were dangerously injured. The Kenosha was towed into Milwaukee this morning, by the steamer Huron.

abstract: Commencing at four o'clock yesterday afternoon, there was an alarm of fire for every hour until 11 o'clock at night. The bell during that time rang almost incessantly, and the Firemen were on a constant run. Fortunately, however, at neither of the seven fires was there a great demand for their services. The first happened at No. 300 Henry-street in the saw-mill of Mr. BOANELL. Very slight damage was suffered.

abstract: During the reception of the Japanese by Mayor WOOD at the City Hall, his Honor took occasion to invite the Embassy to his residence at Bloomingdale, leaving to them the determination of the day for the visit. abstract: The objection raised in the Board of Supervisors to compliance with the demand of the Central Park Commissioners for $97,000, to meet the year's expenses of the management and maintenance of the Park, is based on two grounds the great expense of the work, and
lead_paragraph: The objection raised in the Board of Supervisors to compliance with the demand of the Central Park Commissioners for $97,000, to meet the year's expenses of the management and maintenance of the Park, is based on two grounds the great expense of the work, and the fact that the City Government has no control over its execution. The question of cost is entirely a relative one. Such a park as the Central Park promises to be is certainly not dear at the price it will cost. The money is acknowledged to have been judiciously expended, and what still remains, in doubt, is, whether New-York can afford to acquire such a luxury, and enjoy it. To discuss this question fairly, it must be remembered that the New-York for which the Park is being made is not alone the New-York either of 1857 or of 1860, but the New-York of the next hundred or two hundred years; and this is just the thing which the enemies of the work obstinately shut their eyes upon.
headline: {'main': 'The Completion of the Central Park The Future of New-York.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Completion of the Central Park The Future of New-York.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. RANNEY, whose note we published yesterday, [is entirely mistaken in supposing that we have mis-stated the facts of his case, or done him any injustice.
lead_paragraph: Mr. RANNEY, whose note we published yesterday, [is entirely mistaken in supposing that we have mis-stated the facts of his case, or done him any injustice. He was tried and convicted in the Court of Sessions; he appealed to the Supreme Court for a new trial, -- and when that was refused he was duly sentenced to confinement in the State Prison. His application for a new trial is to be carried to the Court of Appeals, by way of appeal from the Supreme Court: and until this is decided we presume the execution of the sentence will be suspended. There is nothing in all this at all inconsistent with what we have said on the subject. If a new trial is granted, Mr. RANNEY will have another chance to disprove the charges against him. If not, he must serve out his sentence. We are not aware that we have expressed any opinions as to his guilt. The charge is, that he required deposits of money from persons whom he promised to employ as agents,-- and that he afterwards refused to employ them, or to refund the money they had deposited as security, -- the inference being that the promise of employment was merely a pretext in order to obtain their money. If the offence was clearly proved it deserved severe punishment. If there was any doubt about the fact, Mr. RANNEY is entitled to the benefit of it. Meantime, we wish our authorities would show half the rigor and decision in regard to the ticket-swindling, mock, auction, and other villainies openly practiced with complete impunity, which they have brought to bear upon this case.

abstract: NORFOLK, June 25. -- The ship Jane Henderson, previously reported ashore south of Cape Henry, remains pretty much in the condition first stated, but the wind and surf were too high to render her any assistance. Some eight of the crew had managed to get ashore, and it is only to be hoped that the ship would hold together: until those on board could be saved. The ship and cargo, it was thought, would be a total loss. -- (By letter to Ellwood Walter, Esq., Secretary Board of Underwriters.)
lead_paragraph: NORFOLK, June 25. -- The ship Jane Henderson, previously reported ashore south of Cape Henry, remains pretty much in the condition first stated, but the wind and surf were too high to render her any assistance. Some eight of the crew had managed to get ashore, and it is only to be hoped that the ship would hold together: until those on board could be saved. The ship and cargo, it was thought, would be a total loss. -- (By letter to Ellwood Walter, Esq., Secretary Board of Underwriters.)

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Police Commissioners yesterday, a number of filthy tenements were reported by the Sanitary Squad. Sergeant Lord also represented that a steam boiler, belonging to H.W. Shipman, in the rear of No. 59 Ann-street, was in an unsafe and dangerous condition. Immediate action will be taken on the matter. A resolution was adopted, to the effect that any person belonging to the Department who should be known to lend money at usurious rates of interest should be dismissed. It was decided that the triangular block between Canal and Walker streets, within the limits of the Fourteenth Ward, should be incorporated into the Sixth Police Precinct.

abstract: From recent advices of an authentic character, it appears that the Liberal army under Gen. URAGA attacked the city of Guadalajara, occupied by the Church forces under WOLL, on the 24th ult.
lead_paragraph: From recent advices of an authentic character, it appears that the Liberal army under Gen. URAGA attacked the city of Guadalajara, occupied by the Church forces under WOLL, on the 24th ult. According to all accounts, the attack was carried on most brilliantly and successfully, until, at an unfortunate moment, a shell burst near Gen. URAGA and amidst his staff, tearing off the General's leg and killing several of his officers. The battle is described as being one of the most severe ever known in Mexican warfare. The Liberals are said to have lost five hundred men. The loss of the enemy is not stated, but Gen. WOLL, was wounded, perhaps mortally.

abstract: The action recently taken by the French Government on the subject of the French codfisheries significantly illustrates the determination with which NAPOLEON III. is following up his purpose of raising the French navy to the highest possible point of efficiency.
lead_paragraph: The action recently taken by the French Government on the subject of the French codfisheries significantly illustrates the determination with which NAPOLEON III. is following up his purpose of raising the French navy to the highest possible point of efficiency. Ten years ago, July 22, 1851, a law was passed offering certain premiums for the equipment of fishing vessels in the northern seas of Europe and America. This law was to be in force for ten years, and the Corps Legislatif is now invited to extend the term indefinitely. Its provisions offer various premiums ranging from 15 to 50 francs per seaman, for the employment of sailors in fishing vessels on the Dogger-Bank, the seas of Iceland, the Grand Banks, and the Coasts of St. Pierre, Miquclon, and Newfoundland in America. The peculiarity of these premiums is that they are applied to the numbers of the crews engaged, and are, therefore, plainly intended to encourage the increase of sailors for the service of the navy rather than to foster the fishing-trade itself. The commercial problem of this trade is, of course, to secure the greatest results with the smallest crews. But France needs sailors for the State as well as codfish for the people, and the Government accordingly makes it an object to every fishing-captain to take as many men with him as possible, all of these men being immediately put on the books of that formidable Inscription Maritime, by means of which France already keeps well in hand a larger body of trained seamen ready to man her national vessels than any other Power can assemble at short notice.

abstract: It was harmless and wise pastime, undoubtedly, for the good grandfather to teach his grandson chess, until, more to the old gentleman's mortification than he would have cared to acknowledge, the youngster learned to check-mate him, and fairly drove his knights,
lead_paragraph: It was harmless and wise pastime, undoubtedly, for the good grandfather to teach his grandson chess, until, more to the old gentleman's mortification than he would have cared to acknowledge, the youngster learned to check-mate him, and fairly drove his knights, castles, kings and queens off the board; but it was not harmless, nor was it wise in that officer of CHARLES the First's Cavalier army, to whom PEPYS makes allusion in his Diary, to reveal to the Roundhead captain the secret cipher of his dispatches, and thus strip himself of his armor in the very place where he should be best defended. Similia a similibus. The Cavalier officer of the seventeenth century may give us of the nineteenth a lesson and a warning.

abstract: Mr. BUCHANAN has at last plucked up courage to remove GEORGE SANDERS. Why he has not done it months ago remains a profound mystery. While the President has been breathing out threatenings and slaughter, against every man.
lead_paragraph: Mr. BUCHANAN has at last plucked up courage to remove GEORGE SANDERS. Why he has not done it months ago remains a profound mystery. While the President has been breathing out threatenings and slaughter, against every man who would not bow down to the new idol of Democracy which he had set up, GEORGE has for the last two years lost no opportunity of blaspheming it and its author, in the most explicit and unmistakable language. He has been a most open, active, zealous and effective advocate of DOUGLAS for the succession, from the date of the Lecompton stampede. Men of inferior influence have been ejected from office by the irate and inflexible J.B. upon the mere suspicion of being in favor of DOUGLAS; while SANDERS, with, ostentatious frankness and a zeal outstripping that of PETER the Hermit, has preached the Douglas faith, in season and out of season, in every City and State of the Union, and nowhere more openly than in the parlors and purlieus of the White House itself. He has done more than any other Northern man to organize whatever there was of the Douglas Party in the Southern States, attended all the Conventions, and done everything in his power to give shape and vigor to the movement for his nomination. Threats of removal have hung over his head, like the sword of Damocles, for years; but they might as well have played around the shaggiest peak of the Rocky Mountains.

abstract: A NEW SERIAL OF ART. -- Mr. GEORGE WARD NICHOLS, already favorably known to the artists and amateurs of New-York, has just issued the first number of a new artistic serial, in which our painters are to speak for themselves in the most literal sense. By means of auto-lithographic drawings the best works of our best men are to be put in this serial within the reach of all. The idea is an excellent one, and the first number realizes it admirably. This number, contains four prints -- a characteristic figure "Marguerite," by EASTMAN JOHNSON; a view of the Bay of Naples, by GEORGE L. BROWN; a clever composition, the " Ford." by BELLOWS; and an together charming reproduction by RONDEL of Mr. GEORGE INNESS' noble picture of "Twilight." This picture, of which we spoke several months since in terms of the sincerest praise, reappeared in the Academy exhibition, where it shone by contrast, and although stupidly ill hung, commanded the universal verdict of competent connoisseurs as the finest landscape in the collection. Mr. NICHOLS has done good service to art in transferring the quiet: power and vital glow of this extraordinary painting through Mr. RONDEL's skill to the chi???r???uro of the ???thograph.

abstract: Col. W.G. Overton, of the Louisville Courier, and Wm.E. Hughes, of the Democrat, have had a disagreement. The Courier charged the Democrat with, copying an article from another journal which it knew to be a lie. This statement elicited a reply, of which Mr. Overton demanded a disavowal. Mr. Hughes claimed that the first offence was given by the Courier, and refused to retract. Then a direct challenge was given, and Mr Hughes replied bluntly that the note which he had written on the previous day was all Mr. Overton would get, and that he might make the most of it. The matter dropped, with the affirmation of Mr. Overton through the columns of the Courier that Mr. Hughes has added the reputation of a coward to that of a liar.

abstract: One of the largest political meetings ever held in Kings Country was held by the Republicans last evening, in City Hall Park, to ratify the nominations made by the Republican National Convention at Chicago.
lead_paragraph: One of the largest political meetings ever held in Kings Country was held by the Republicans last evening, in City Hall Park, to ratify the nominations made by the Republican National Convention at Chicago. A few rockets, a calcium light and a band of music, aside from the speaking, were all the attractions offered to induce a large attendance. At the stand in the Park the meeting was organized by electing GEORGE FIELD, Esq., of the Thirteenth Ward, Chairman, and the usual number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries.

abstract: The People, and Taylor and Brennan vs. The Mayor,  This is the commencement of the argument of the motion of the Comptroller to set aside the judgment in this case, on the ground of fraud and collusion in obtaining it.
lead_paragraph: The People, and Taylor and Brennan vs. The Mayor, This is the commencement of the argument of the motion of the Comptroller to set aside the judgment in this case, on the ground of fraud and collusion in obtaining it. The motion now came on in its regular order, pursuant to adjournment, before Justice PECKHAM, sitting at Chambers of the Supreme Court. Judge Bronson stated as a reason for a further postponement, that he should attack the Land Office in his argument, and as that department was controlled in part by the Attorney General, and as His Honor had been associated with Mr. Tremain, he (Judge Bronson) presumed Justice Peckham would not care to hear this motion. It would be painful to Judge Bronson censure the course of Mr. Tremain, but he felt it his duty, and for that reason was compelled to do it.

abstract: The Cattaraugus Republican tells of a narrow escape of a child from being buried alive. It died on Sunday, and on the afternoon of the day following the funeral services were held. The coffin had been lowered into the grave, and the dirt had begun to fall on it, when a stifled cry was heard. Immediately on removing the lid from the coffin the child called its mother. It was at once properly cared for, and is now in a fair way to recover.

abstract: THE COOPER UNION COMMENCEMENT. The Annual Commencement Exhibition of the "Class of Vacal Muaic" of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, was given last evening, in the lower hall of the Cooper Institute.
lead_paragraph: THE COOPER UNION COMMENCEMENT. The Annual Commencement Exhibition of the "Class of Vacal Muaic" of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, was given last evening, in the lower hall of the Cooper Institute. The seats were all filled with an audience composed mostly of ladies, before the exercises had been commenced and soon afterwards all the standing room was occupied, and there were hundreds who left the building because they could not obtain even a sight of the platform. The Class, as represented, numbered about one hundred. The ladies -- between thirty and forty in number --were all dressed in white, and were seated near the front of the platform; and the gentlemen, in black, occupied seats immediately behind them; while Dr. CHAS. A. GUILMETTE, the instructor of the Class, occupied a central position. After prayer by Rev. Dr. MATTHEWS, the Class-sang as the opening chorus, "Let There be Light" in a manner that elicited vigorous and prolonged applause. Then .followed a carefully prepared and very interesting address from Dr. GUILMETTE, on "The Abuse of Music." The remainder of the programme consisted of solos, duets, glees, and a chorus; and all of them were received with well-merited applause. While the audience was retiring, the remark was general that the Class was an honor to the instructor. The other Classes of the Union will give an exhibition this evening, when the diplomas will be presented.

abstract: Mr. James M. Pushee, of Massachusetts, came to this City on the 19th inst., for the purpose of procuring second-class cabin passages by the California steamer for his sister, Mrs. Elmira F. Choate, and her little boy.
lead_paragraph: Mr. James M. Pushee, of Massachusetts, came to this City on the 19th inst., for the purpose of procuring second-class cabin passages by the California steamer for his sister, Mrs. Elmira F. Choate, and her little boy. He did not take proper measures to inform, himself as to the locality of the genuine ticket-office, and having met James Enright, (the notorious brother of the more notorious Deputy Health Warden John Enright,) was beguiled by that individual into the swindling-office No. 109 West-street. There he was introduced to Stephen Gordon, whose name is quite familiar to the readers of the police reports, to whom he paid, after his apprehensions with regard to the fairness of the transaction had been set at rest, the sum of $208 for what he was told were two second cabin tickets, but which he subsequently learned only entitled his relatives to the privileges of the steerage, and the regular price of which was $45 50 less than the amount which had been given. Yesterday he lodged complaints against both Gordon and Enright for false pretences and violation of the law relating to the sale of passenger tickets. The accused having bean arrested by Capt. Hartt, of the 26th precinct, were taken before Justice WELSH, who held them to answer -- fixing their bail at $1,000 each. Enright furnished his bail, but Gordon could not obtain a surety and consequently was sent to prison. In view of the fact that these parties have invariably been bought off by the defendants when they found the case proven against them, it has been deemed advisable to commit the complainants to the House of Detention. It is a hard case, but is the only sure way to reach these rascals. Capt. Hartt and Mr. Dickinson have been unremitting in their endeavors to bring them to punishment. The papers will go before the Grand Jury to-morrow morning and under the new law these ticket cases take the precedence over all others. Mr. Dickinson, the Calfornia Commissioner for the protection of emigrants, will exert himself to assist the prosecution.

abstract: These Clubs played a fine match on Wednesday at the Red House Ground, in which some very good play was shown on both sides, the batting beat the fielding, the short comings of which must be attributed to the warm weather. The catcher of the Socials was very good, as were EVERISS, UMPLEBY, WITHERS and DERBY at the bat. The Baltics were well represented by the extra play of LEWES as pitcher. DURELL as catcher, and COOPER as Short stop. The batting of DURELL and ANDARIESE was also very superior. A large number of ladies were preeent at the match.

abstract: THE LEE-AVENUE SUNDAY SCHOOL JUBILEE.  One of the most delightful of the Strawberry and Floral Festivals of the season was enjoyed yesterday in Mr. BREVOORT'S grove, in Bedford, Long Island.
lead_paragraph: THE LEE-AVENUE SUNDAY SCHOOL JUBILEE. -- One of the most delightful of the Strawberry and Floral Festivals of the season was enjoyed yesterday in Mr. BREVOORT'S grove, in Bedford, Long Island. It was the "Seventh Grand Jubilee" of the Lee-avenue Sunday School, and, as a jubilee, certainly exceeded all the former jubilees of that large and useful organization. The grove, which is well fited for such occasions, was divided into play-grounds, strolling places, places for the tents, in which were the refreshments, and for the performances of the children. The platform was plentifully decorated with flags and wreaths of flowers, and in front of it seats were placed for 2,000 persons. The ceremony of crowning the queen took place at midday, and was very prettily done. The performance of a piece called "Our Benevolent Society" was also a very interesting feature of the occasion. With the exception of the time when the performances were going on on the platform, the strawberry ladies, the ice-cream men and the soda water pop, lemonade, sandwich and pickled-oyster men were exercised without the slightest consideration of the heat of the day, and everybody seemed to enjoy everything provided for them. Although many were on the ground as early as 7 o'clock, and several thousand were there at 9, the gathering was as numerous and happy at 5 P.M. as at any time during the day. Certainly the Seventh Grand Jubilee of the Lee-avenue Sunday School will be green and pleasant in the memory of the children and those who saw them there for many a day to come.

abstract: There was not a quorum present yesterday at the meeting of the Commissioners of Emigration. The next meeting occurs on the 11th of July. There are 693 inmates in the institutions; received for commutation of passengers, $7,536 13. Disbursements to June 20, $108,205 45, balance in Bank, $34,434 08.

abstract: Packing up was the order of the day among our Japanese guests at the Metropolitan yesterday, though a large number of the inveterate shoppers found time to take strolls in various portions of the City, affording opportunities to the rara aves who have failed to "see the Japanese" to gratify their curiosity.
lead_paragraph: Packing up was the order of the day among our Japanese guests at the Metropolitan yesterday, though a large number of the inveterate shoppers found time to take strolls in various portions of the City, affording opportunities to the rara aves who have failed to "see the Japanese" to gratify their curiosity. The authoritative announcement that the Great Eastern had arrived, seemed to do away with the last particle of interest in our thirteen days' wonder, and they were comparatively unmoleted. A few of our country cousins, however, were at the hotel on a tour of inspection.

abstract: A letter in the Times, under date of June 5, says: Anybody who wishes to be well received at the Court of St. Petersburg must not speak ill of the Emperor NAPOLEON. I cannot describe the joy felt among all classes when it was known the French Government was in accord with the Emperor ALEXANDER on the Eastern question. The Emperor Nicholas, pierced for 130 guns, and the giant of the Russian navy, was launched the other day. She is to carry steel rifled cannon.

abstract: Mrs. Rachel T. Medkerk, a teacher in a District School in Cincinnati, has been presented by the citizens with a gold hunting watch and chain, valued at $125, and the freedom of twenty railroad lines, as a reward for her bravery in preventing the children under her care from rushing into the street during the terrible tornado which swept over the city some weeks ago.

abstract: Wm.E. Gaw, who, it will be remembered, was arrested a few days ago, on a charge of throwing vitriol in the face of Maria E. Gaw, his wife, injuring her very much. When arraigned, this morning, the prisoner pleaded guilty, and stated, that his wife had deserted him, and refused to live with him any longer. He did not know what was in the bottle, as he bought it from a peddlar, to cure his corns. In a moment of excitement, he threw the stuff in his wife's face. Mrs. Gaw appeared before the Court, and stated that she left her husband because he filtreated her, and because she subsequently ascertained that he was already married at the time of their marriage.

abstract: If the Old Public Functionary who has presided during the past forty months over the distribution of our Federal patronage, has not become satisfied by this time that his Administration has been a failure, and the most utter failure on record, we can only account for it by regarding him either as self-conceited beyond the arrow-flight of rebuke, or as ...
lead_paragraph: If the Old Public Functionary who has presided during the past forty months over the distribution of our Federal patronage, has not become satisfied by this time that his Administration has been a failure, and the most utter failure on record, we can only account for it by regarding him either as self-conceited beyond the arrow-flight of rebuke, or as possessing a density and apathy of the moral nerves, utterly paralyzing those organs through which ordinary men are made aware of shame. Let us cite a few of the most recent " hints" which have been given to Mr. BUCHANAN of the estimate placed on his services by a grateful country.

abstract: Archbishop Blanc died in New-Orleans a few-days ago. He was a native of France and came to this country in 1817. His knowledge of the English language secured him a curacy in Natchez, Miss., where he remained until 1822. Then he was transferred to Baton Rouge. During part of his nine years residence there he presided over an educational institution. In 1831 he was called to New-Orleans, and in 1833 succeeded Bishop Dubourg. He was appointed Archbishop in 1854.

abstract: Rarely has the Cooper Institute been the scene of so interesting an exhibition as that of last evening, on the occasion of the Commencement -- the first of this noble institution. abstract: Congress has adjourned and dispersed, and yet both Houses of the National Legislature are congregated at the Federal Capitol. The President has summoned the Senate into extra session for the consideration of Executive business, and Mr. BRADY, the eminent photographer of New-York and Washington, has caught the House of Representatives by the power of his wonderful art, and holds them still in continuous, and what is more surprising, in respectable and harmonious session.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Monday, June 25.

abstract: The arrival of the Great Eastern, and the demonstrations of welcome which signalized the event, will make yesterday a day long to be remembered in the annals of New-York. The telegraph announced her arrival off the bar at about 7 o'clock, and as the intelligence became generally known in the City, there uses a spontaneous movement of all classes towards the Battery and other prominent points, in anticipation of her coming. It soon became
lead_paragraph: The arrival of the Great Eastern, and the demonstrations of welcome which signalized the event, will make yesterday a day long to be remembered in the annals of New-York. The telegraph announced her arrival off the bar at about 7 o'clock, and as the intelligence became generally known in the City, there uses a spontaneous movement of all classes towards the Battery and other prominent points, in anticipation of her coming. It soon became known, however, that she would he detained outside until high water, which would not be until 2 o'clock P.M., thus giving abundant time to go to Staten Island, to Fort Hamilton, Bay Ridge, and other eligible places in the harbor, to view the great steamer as she passed up the bay.

abstract: It has never been difficult to foresee that the completion of the Central Park must inevitably produce a very marked effect upon the character and habits of our people, especially on Sundays. The fashionable classes, professional men, and people whose engagements give them some leisure every day, will visit the Park and use it for recreation on week days.
lead_paragraph: It has never been difficult to foresee that the completion of the Central Park must inevitably produce a very marked effect upon the character and habits of our people, especially on Sundays. The fashionable classes, professional men, and people whose engagements give them some leisure every day, will visit the Park and use it for recreation on week days. But the great mass of our laboring classes are absolutely debarred from using it at all, unless they do so on Sunday. Hitherto they have had no place of attractive resort, and have from compulsion, and to the sacrifice of health and comfort, remained at home. But the Park creates a new state of things, -- and it will inevitably be filled every pleasant Sunday by thousands and tens of thousands of our citizens, laborers and others, who embrace that as the only occasion afforded during the week for fresh air, recreation, and a pleasant walk or ride for themselves and their families. This result is already apparent. Every Sunday the Park is even now filled with people of this class, -- respectable in appearance, perfectly orderly in their conduct, and enjoying the beautiful region thus opened to them all the more keenly, because of the rarity of the experience which it affords them.
headline: {'main': 'Sunday in the Central Park.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Sunday in the Central Park.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamer Great Eastern arrived in the Lower Bay yesterday morning at about 7 o'clock, and came up to the City as soon as the tide would permit her crossing the bar, at a little after 2, and reached her dock, at the foot of Hammond-street, at about 6 in the evening. We surrender a large part of our space this morning to a very full account of her voyage, which will long be memorable in the history of steam navigation. So many novelties are involved in her structure and mode of working, that the most ample professional details will be found valuable to those who desire to form a reliable judgment as to her capabilites. The letter of our Correspondent, we are confident, will leave nothing to be desired on this score. We are compelled from lack of space to omit much matter of interest connected with the great ship; but we shall publish this in the TIMES of to-morrow morning, together with a very full description of the vessel, illustrated by diagrams and engravings. The voyage of the Great Eastern, as will be seen by our report, has been a substantial success. The theory of her size is simply this: she can carry twice as much cargo as the Adriatic or the Persia, with the same horse-power and cost, simply on account of her size, the engines being the same. Her first trip has demonstrated the mechanical correctness of this theory, by proving that the ship not only equals, but exceeds smaller vessels in seaworthiness and manageability. More than this -- it demonstrates the equally important fact that the comfort and safety of passengers are increased in proportion to the size of the vessel. The moderate speed attained by the Great Eastern on this trip is fully accounted for by her purposely but not necessarily low steam pressure, by a considerable deviation from the shortest course to avoid ice, by a foul bottom, and by other abnormal circumstances. The positive facts developed are the perfection of the hull and the excellence and reliability of the machinery. The engines were not stopped for adjustment during the entire passage, Mr. SCOTT RUSSELL's wave-line, more beautifully developed on this vessel than ever before, is such that, at her highest speed, the vessel does not raise a perceptible wave, except by the action of her propellers. The commercial question -- Can large ships be filled? -- has not yet been reached. The interval between the announcement of the Great Eastern's arrival off the Hook, and her passage of the Bar was long enough to rouse all our sea-going, yachting and pleasure-loving population to give a welcome to the monster. Tugs of all sorts and sizes, steamers and sail-boats, crowded down the Bay towards 3 o'clock, and rarely has so animated a scene been presented as unrolled itself before the eyes of the passengers on board the great ship, when she fairly opened the harbor of New-York from the Narrows. The skill with which her New-York pilot, Mr. MURPHY, carried her over the bar, navigated her through the crowded bay, and brought her to her moorings at the foot of Hammond-street, was the theme of general comment and admiration. Salutes, public and private, attended her approach -- the Harriet Lane and the Cunard steamers at Jersey City particularly distinguishing themselves in this contest of politeness. The yacht squadron was handsomely represented, and nothing could have been more cordial and festive than the reception which was extended on all sides to the one long-looked for visitor. The wharves of the North River from the Battery to Canal-street, were packed closely with an eager and enthusiastic crowd, which cheered the ship heartily as she slowly and majestically moved along. No accident occurred to mar the satisfactions of the day, although the great ship, on running alongside the dock carried away some ten feet of planking at her first touch of the wharf.

The skill with which her New-York pilot, Mr. MURPHY, carried her over the bar, navigated her through the crowded bay, and brought her to her moorings at the foot of Hammond-street, was the theme of general comment and admiration. Salutes, public and private, attended her approach -- the Harriet Lane and the Cunard steamers at Jersey City particularly distinguishing themselves in this contest of politeness. The yacht squadron was handsomely represented, and nothing could have been more cordial and festive than the reception which was extended on all sides to the one long-looked for visitor. The wharves of the North River from the Battery to Canal-street, were packed closely with an eager and enthusiastic crowd, which cheered the ship heartily as she slowly and majestically moved along. No accident occurred to mar the satisfactions of the day, although the great ship, on running alongside the dock carried away some ten feet of planking at her first touch of the wharf.

abstract: A suit was recently brought against Mr. A. Page by the Boston Journal to recover a bill for advertising. The defendant was a traveling physician, and as the bill was incurred six years prior to the commencement of the suit, he set up the statute of limitations in defence. The verdict was given against the plaintiff on the first trial. Exceptions which he took were sustained by the Supreme Court, and a new trial was ordered in the Superior Court. The Superior Court instructed the jury that if after the cause of action accrued the defendant was temporarily absent from and temporarily resident out of the Commonwealth with the intention of returning, and not having lost here or gained elsewhere a domicil, then the time of each temporary absence should be reckoned as part of the six years running time of the statute.

abstract: COMMENCEMENT OF RUTGERS INSTITUTE. -- The twenty-first annual commencement of the Rutgers Female Institute was held yesterday afternoon, in the Rutgers-street Church. A very large audience was in attendance. The exercises opened with an anthem, sung by the pupils of the school under the direction of Prof. J.C. WOODMAN. The President of the Institute -- Rev. Dr. KREBS -- then offered a prayer, which was followed by the reading of the reports of the Committees on the various branches of study pursued in the seminary. Testimonials of merit and scholarship were then distributed to a large number of pupils. After singing the "Parting Hymn of the Graduates," the President presented diplomas to the following ladies, members of the graduating class: Mary C. Woodford, Anna O. Snowden, Clementina Correja, Mary B. Sutt, Kate White, Antoinette Daly, Ella Hanfield, Martha Rhodes, Mary E. Myers, Fanny E.T. Parker, Anna Hodgkinson, Anna Van Glahn, Kate C. Wood, Martha Colyer, Margaret M. Wood. The exercises were concluded by the singing of a hymn to the tune of Old Hundred, followed by benediction by the President. The Rutgers Female Institute numbers at present 175 pupils, and is in highly prosperous condition.

abstract: Mrs. JULIA DEAN HAYNE, whose original engagement of six nights only has been prolonged from week to week by the "pressure of public opinion," will receive to-night a grand "testimonial" in compliment to her graces and her talents, at the Winter Garden. On this occasion, a new actor Mr. CHAS. BARRAS, will make his debut in New-York in a play of his own, the 'Hypochondriac.' Mr. JORDAN, Mr. C. BARTON HILL, and other actors of mark and merit have volunteered their services in behalf of a lady whose high qualities adorn her profession with so rare and honorable a light. Mr. HAYNE is shortly about to leave this country for a professional visit to Europe, where, we doubt not, new triumphs await her.

abstract: The Great Eastern has ceased to be an empty name to the people of New-York. After months of excited expectation, continually dashed by ever-recurring blunders, follies and failures on the part of the management to whose hands the great ship had been committed, the commercial metropolis of the New world was yesterday roused to a moment of general and sincere enthusiasm, by the tidings ...
lead_paragraph: The Great Eastern has ceased to be an empty name to the people of New-York. After months of excited expectation, continually dashed by ever-recurring blunders, follies and failures on the part of the management to whose hands the great ship had been committed, the commercial metropolis of the New world was yesterday roused to a moment of general and sincere enthusiasm, by the tidings that this leviathan of the deep was actually passing the bar, and gliding to her moorings at our docks as easily and gracefully as if she were but an ordinary member of the great family of steamships which have made this port so long their Western home.

abstract: The mass of matter published about the great ship, in newspapers and guide books, has been mostly a rehash of the original reports of her engineers as to her dimensions and capacity, and of partial descriptions printed in the London journals during her construction. While these materials furnish much that is of engineering and commercial importance,...
lead_paragraph: The mass of matter published about the great ship, in newspapers and guide books, has been mostly a rehash of the original reports of her engineers as to her dimensions and capacity, and of partial descriptions printed in the London journals during her construction. While these materials furnish much that is of engineering and commercial importance, there remains to be told a vast amount of descriptive, comparative and critical facts, without which the general reader would have a very imperfect idea of the vastness and peculiarities of the Leviathan of ships. Particularly with reference to the engines, I here-with furnish some new, correct and much more comprehensive facts than have yet appeared in print.

abstract: Henry O. French, a blacksmith, married a Miss Rowan, of Hebron, N.Y., some time since, but they did not live happily together, and Mrs. French found herself obliged to leave her husband. Since the sep-...
lead_paragraph: Henry O. French, a blacksmith, married a Miss Rowan, of Hebron, N.Y., some time since, but they did not live happily together, and Mrs. French found herself obliged to leave her husband. Since the separation, she has resisted repeated importunities for a reconciliation, and on the 21st, French left Poultney, Vt., and went to his father-in-law's, at Jackson, N. Y., where his wife was staying. After some conversation, she again refused to live with him, when French drew a pistol and discharged it at her, fortunately without doing any harm. Mrs. French immediately ran to a neighbor's and gave the alarm. When she returned to the house, in company with a Mr. Collins, she found her husband lying by the side of his wagon, dead. Having failed to take the life of his wife, he had shot himself.

abstract: Our Japanese visitors' take their departure for home to-day. It may seem discourteous, but we cannot help saying we are glad they have gone. Their visit has not been without a certain interest to us, but we have had enough of it. They may be, and doubtless are,...
lead_paragraph: Our Japanese visitors' take their departure for home to-day. It may seem discourteous, but we cannot help saying we are glad they have gone. Their visit has not been without a certain interest to us, but we have had enough of it. They may be, and doubtless are, very respectable persons at home, -- but their social intercourse with us has not been especially fascinating. When persons can neither speak nor understand a syllable of each other's language, and are compelled to converse through the medium of a double interpretation, their intercourse must lack something of the ease and grace essential to cordial and protracted delight in each other's society. The pantomime of the Japanese is expressive enough, but pantomime at the best is a very unsatisfactory style of conversation. One tires of it after a while, even on the stage. In the affairs of daily life, a very little of it will suffice for a long time.

abstract: At 9 o'clock last evening information was sent to Police Head-quarters from the Seventeenth Precinct, that an attempt was to be made to circulate counterfeit $5's on the Valley Bank, of Danvers, Mass. The fact was at once made known by telegraph to every Ward of the City, and soon afterwards the officers of the Second Precinct apprehended two young men, giving the names of Charles Nelson and Smith Clark, who are said to have passed a $2 counterfeit on the Mystic Bank of Connecticut, at the store of George S. Robinson, No. 87 South-street, in payment for a glass of soda water. Upon searching the prisoners, $332 of worthless bills, $90 of which was in $10s on the American Exchange Bank of this city, and the remainder in $5s on the Village Bank of Denvers, $3s and $5s on the Union Bank, New London, Conn., and $2s on the Mystic Bank, Coun., were taken from Nelson, while Clark had the good money, which was identified by Robinson as that he had given in change for the counterfeit which was passed. Four of the bills found upon Nelson were secreted in the lining of his hat. All the counterfeits, excepting that on the Village Bank, are poor affairs, and may be easily detected by their unartistic appearance. The prisoners will be taken before a magistrate this morning.

abstract: The National Democratic Committee, representing that old great party, under which the flag of the Constitution, the Union, and the equality of States has so often been borne on to victory over sectionalism...
lead_paragraph: The National Democratic Committee, representing that old great party, under which the flag of the Constitution, the Union, and the equality of States has so often been borne on to victory over sectionalism and over the many-hued varieties of opposition to Democratic principles and measures, made a call yesterday on the President of the United States. Having finished their business of organization, and appointed their executive committees, &c., &c., they proceeded in a body from wilfard's Hotel to the Executive Mansion. Arriving during the usual reception hour, when Mr. BUCHANAN is accustomed to receive his friends, quite a number of ladies and gentlemen were present; and the Committee were welcomed in a most hearty manner. Each of the members having been introduced to the President, who had a warm grasp of the hand and a kind word for every one. Mr. WRIGHT addressed him on behalf of the Committee, expressing the pleasure they felt in having this opportunity of mantesting their respect for his personal character and public services.

abstract: ACCIDENT.--Yesterday morning, the 9 o'clock Newton Express train, consisting of five or six cars loaded with passengers, narrowly escaped being precipitated into the Passaic River, by running off the Newark Bridge. The draw was opened to allow the passage...
lead_paragraph: ACCIDENT. -- Yesterday morning, the 9 o'clock Newton Express train, consisting of five or six cars loaded with passengers, narrowly escaped being precipitated into the Passaic River, by running off the Newark Bridge. The draw was opened to allow the passage of a vessel, and the proper signal shown, but the Engineer, who has recently been placed on the road, failed to discover it. The Conductor of the train saw the signal, and pulled the Engineer's bell to stop. The order was promptly obeyed, but not an instant too soon, for the locomotive was within six feet of the draw, and in a moment more the whole train would have been precipitated into the river. It was a miraculous escape, and the circumstances attending it will undergo the most rigid examination.

abstract: The Metropolitan Record for the present week discusses at much length the merits of the controversy between Archbishop HUGHES and City Inspector DELAVAN regarding the registry of marriages.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Record for the present week discusses at much length the merits of the controversy between Archbishop HUGHES and City Inspector DELAVAN regarding the registry of marriages. Its Statements must be accorded a certain weight, from the fact that it is the official organ of the Archbishop. First of all the Record states in emphatic terms that Mr. DELAVAN has suppressed a portion of the correspondence. This he can publish for his satisfaction as soon as he desires. In giving to the newspapers the correspondence the Record claims that he has violated the sanctities of private correspondence, and of this the Archbishop complains. But although "he may have spoken incautiously or imprudently in the confidence that he was answering a private communication from a gentleman, albeit, the City Inspector of New-York, still as regards the substance of that answer he has nothing to retract. He is prepared to do his duty, and to refuse doing what his conscience will not approve." After this explicit statement of the position which the Archbishop at present occupies, the Record says that the comments made by the public Press on this lacerated but official statement have inflicted such an injury as he never before experienced. It hints further that, if brought to trial, he might seek for a change of venue, as the case has been prejudged here, but urges Mr. DELAVAN to do his duty, nevertheless. Archbishop HUGHES can save his conscience by refusing to obey the law and paying the fines, and at such passive resistance the people of New-York need not be surprised. The Record then discusses the merits of the law itself, citing instances in which it would be improper and injudicious to register the names of parties married, and quotes letters which Archbishop HUGHES has received on the subject from Protestant clergyrmen. One of them describes the enactment as "foolish and useless," another writer says that "he would have his arm cut off before revealing secrets which have come to his knowledge in the relation of matrimony," and another still thanks the Archbishop for the stand which he has taken. The Record acknowledges, in conclusion, that a Catholic member procured the passage of the act, but charges that it was concocted not far from the City Inspector's office, and that it had in view the creation of a new clerkship or the increase of the emoluments of the City Inspector's office, without the expense of a penny to the State. The other religious journals look at the subject from a different standpoint. The Observer, for instance, dismisses it in a brief paragraph. It says that Archbishop HUGHES "has been making himself ridiculous again." His reasons for refusing to obey the law "are puerile in the extreme, and measures are already in progress to compel him to do his duty." The Observer says further, "his conscience must be exceedingly tender, but we greatly doubt his readiness for the scaffold. It is not the habit of martyrs to volunteer until there is a call for them." Communications in some of the other papers state that there is no penalty attached to a neglect to send the register of marriage to the City Inspector, and that an attempt to enforce the law will reveal this weakness.

abstract: When Mr. HALE made a reckless attack upon the Court of Claims in the Senate, the other day,--reflecting upon the memory of the very able and pains-taking Judges of that tribunal, now deceased, and upon the judicial character of one of the living members, Judge SCAR-...
lead_paragraph: When Mr. HALE made a reckless attack upon the Court of Claims in the Senate, the other day,--reflecting upon the memory of the very able and pains-taking Judges of that tribunal, now deceased, and upon the judicial character of one of the living members, Judge SCARBURG, -- we thought a motive might be detected in his speech beyond what met the eye. After denouncing some bill that had passed the Senate at its last sesaion, he said that it had "by some means or other, got through the Court of Claims." A more severe impeachment of the integrity or ability of a Judicial' tribunal can hardly be Imagined. There is no way in which any case can pass this Court, except upon such testimony and upon the application of such legal principles as would establish it in any other Court in the land, that might be clothed with the same jurisdiction. Mr. HALE, therefore, could only have intended to insinuate that the Judges were bribed, or captured by the button-hole and lobbied with, or befooled, and the interests of the United States sacrificed, in spite of the able solicitors who have them in especial charge. This was a grave charge against the Court and against the solicitors. It was followed up by remarks in the same vein, touching the facility with which the Treasury was plundered -- conveying the idea that while the Court of Claims and other Senators might unite in the robbery of the Treasury, yet the Senator from New Hampshire formed a splondid exception in this era of venality, and was ready to denounce all public robbers, whether they appeared as Senators or Judges.

lead_paragraph: Sionada, (adieu,) was the watch-word among the Japanese at the Metropolitan Hotel, yesterday morning. Long are the mid-day season for their rice and fish, they had donned their newest rober, and prepared for the final leave-taking. The Messrs. LELAND, their attentive hosts, came in for a plentiful share of presents in acknowledgement of the many disinterested attentions paid to their comfort. To CRARLES LSLAND was given a sword and suit of clothes: to WARREN, various articles of apparel, and a number of trinkets, together with some Japanese caps; to SIMEON, a sword and a Japanese robe, and to WILLIAM, the identical surt in which TOMMY was presented to the President. Accompanying the present was a note in the Japanese language, of which the following is a translation:

abstract: We publish in the SUPPLEMENT to this morning's TIMES, a very full and complete description of the Great Eastern, her engines, hull and general equipment, as she lies at her dock at the foot of Hammond-street. It is from the pen...
lead_paragraph: We publish in the SUPPLEMENT to this morning's TIMES, a very full and complete description of the Great Eastern, her engines, hull and general equipment, as she lies at her dock at the foot of Hammond-street. It is from the pen of Mr. A.L. HOLLEY, an educated and practical Civil Engineer, whose articles upon this great ship in the columns of the TIMES have combined technical accuracy and professional knowledge, with marked-literary and descriptive ability, to a greater degree than any similar reports of the day on either side of the Atlantic. His report of the voyage of the Great Eastern, which we published yesterday, we consider the fullest and best description of any voyage ever written. The description published to-day, contains many particulars concerning the Great Eastern, and especially in regard to her engines, which have never before been published.

abstract: On Wednesday morning, a young man named WILLIAM HOPKINS, residing near Glen Cove, committed suicide under the following singular circumstances. He procured a razor and pail, and went into a shed adjoining the kitchen, where he deliberately knelt down, leaned his head over the pail, and drew the razor across his neck, inflicting a gash about three inches in length. When discovered, he was quite dead, and the pail half full of blood.

abstract: A fire happened at 10 o'clock, last evening in the back room on the fourth floor of the building No. 208 Broadway, occupied by C. DAVERSEN, as the champion show-card office. The flames were quickly extinguished, and an examination showed that the fire was probably kindled by an incendiary, there being a strong smell of camphene, and a broken can, containing a quantity of the fluid, lying on the floor. The Fire Marshal will investigate the matter. The loss was not very great, and it is met by an insurance for $1,200 in the Hamilton Company.

abstract: --Foreign scientists do not rush into print so precipitately as those on this side the water. We are too apt to record a phenomenon and then forget it, or allow our attention to be distracted by the advent of some new wonder. Thus, just as we are abandoning fur-...
lead_paragraph: -- Foreign scientists do not rush into print so precipitately as those on this side the water. We are too apt to record a phenomenon and then forget it, or allow our attention to be distracted by the advent of some new wonder. Thus, just as we are abandoning further research into the circumstances attending the great aurora of August and September, 1859, to look for the source of meteoric stones or the cause of tornadoes, maturer observations are coming to us from quarters where we hardly knew that there had been an aurora. The Comptes Rendues furnish those who may be investigatigating the causes of these brilliant displays with many important data. A fact which Prof. OLMSTEAD, of Yale College, was in the habit of urging as establishing the cosmical origin of the aurora, was repeated last August. France, England, Norway, Australia and the United States were favored with this celestial illumination on the same evenings, so that it must have originated where more than one side of the earth could be illuminated at once. At Paris, a few cirrus clouds were noticed during the exhibition, but they were all black, without any reflection from the light of the aurora, so that it must have emanated from a region much above them. Its effects upon telegraphic wires have been noted in general in this country, but in France the observations were more scientific in their character. On lines running north and south, the effects wore much more evident than on those running east and west, and the longer the lines the more perceptible was the electric action. M. HIPP calculated the power of the current at Berne, by means of a magnetic needle. The regular current employed in telegraphing should have sufficient power to deflect the needle 30"°;;", but when the aurora was the brightest, it reached 58"°", and in one instance 64"°".

abstract: When I enumerated, in a former letter, the causes that, in my judgment, have combined to ruin Jamaica, and attributed them, as I think they ought to be attributed, to faults and errors com-...
lead_paragraph: When I enumerated, in a former letter, the causes that, in my judgment, have combined to ruin Jamaica, and attributed them, as I think they ought to be attributed, to faults and errors committed by the planters themselves, it was with no feelings of hostility to an interest I believe to be of paramount importance, and no desire to see its lawful energies cramped or its success obstructed. When the planters were compelled to receive an inadequate compensation for their slaves, they did so with the understanding that their staple should be protected in the British market. The wrong, if wrong it was, lay with the Government that held out such a promise � not with the Government that, by the bill of 1846, abolished the heavy tax paid by the English people for the support of a West Indian aristocracy. The planters could not be expected to take an abstract view of a measure that consummated their, own ruin. They complained bitterly of injustice, and though their complaints carried, with them no argument for the restoration of protection, they should have silenced all factious opposition to wholesome plans devised for the restoration of Jamaica's prosperity.

abstract: George Ayrault, et al. vs. William Elliott. ï¿½ This was an action tried before Justice MONCRIEF, in the Superior Court. The plaintiffs sued to recover an amount claimed to be due them from the defendant upon a sale of fifteen cattle. It was alleged that the sale was made in October, 1857, at which time it was agreed that the purchase money should be paid within 30 days. The plaintiffs now claim that they have received only fifty cents, in all, of the entire amount to be given for the fifteen head of cattle.

abstract: A numerous meeting of the Alumni of this institution was held in the chapel room last evening. The occasion was one of special interest in view of the recent demise of its able Principal, Prof. GRAY. At the Commencement, on the previous evening, diplomas were awarded to fifteen graduates. Rev, Dr. STORRS, the President of the Board, has given instruction and officiated as Principal since the death of Prof. GRAY. His parting address to the graduates was one of unusual beauty and interest, reviewing in the most touching manner Prof. GRAY's nine year's laborious assiduity. Prof. CHAS. E. WEST, for twelve years the head of Rutgers Institute, now assumes the office of Principal. He will continue in it. His inaugural address on the comparison of female education here, with that in Continental Europe and England, and the rise and growth of the Press of America and its mighty influence on education, was full of most sensible points. Prof. WEST enters upon his duties on the opening of the next term in September.

abstract: Sensations and excitements are now multiplying so fast in New-York that it is sincerely to be hoped they will result in infusing a little of the nil admirari spirit into the population. We should be sorry to see a cold in difference...
lead_paragraph: Sensations and excitements are now multiplying so fast in New-York that it is sincerely to be hoped they will result in infusing a little of the nil admirari spirit into the population. We should be sorry to see a cold in difference take the place of the exaltation by which the City is now characterized, but there is a happy medium between brutal cynicism and frantic exuberance of sentiment, on which we have so far never managed to hit. There is something decidedly provincial in the convulsions into which we fall over every great man that passes our way and great event that befalls us, and it is high time they ceased. When the City went stark mad over Kossuth and Jenny Lind, it was ten or twelve years younger than it is now, and this may be considered a valid excuse, as ten years is an age in New York.

lead_paragraph: Charles McDermot, for the defence, in this case, testified that he was present on the night of the occurrence; saw the boxing match, and the melee which followed; Dunnigan requested the men to desist, which they did; subsequently a quarrel ensued, and the prisoner wanted the quarrellers to leave; they refused; he went to put them out, and he was knocked down; a regular scuffle then took place, and Donnigan was knocked against the bar; the party fought again, and Donnigan was knocked down again, while one of the men cried out,"Give it to the son of a b -- h, give it to him;" Donnigan was afraid of being murdered. witness then saw a man stagger against the counter and say he was stabbed.

abstract: CAMILIO DE CANAS, a passenger from Havana by the steamer Granada, which arrived on Thursday night, was taken suddenly ill, yesterday morning, at the "Hotel de I'Amerique del Sud," No. 36 Houston-street, where he had put up, and soon died. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest, and it having been shown by a post-mortem examination that death had been caused by heart disease, a verdict to that effect was rendered. Deceased was 34 years of age, and a native of Cadiz, Spain. In his pockets were found $400 in gold, and a lot of lottery tickets for the Havana lottery, to be drawn on the 12th of July. The remains were interred in Calvary Cemetery.

abstract: France and Germany have met on that thrice famous frontier of the Rhine, to look each other in the face, and judge, if they can, what the future has in store for them and it. If we are to believe the angry and sarcastic leader of the English Press, the 16th of June, 1860, will be marked in the annals of Teutonism as a day of shame and humiliation for all true German hearts. The London Times. which for months past has been extoiling Prussia as the natural head of Germany, and as, of all the Great Powers of Europe, the most near and dear to England, on hearing that the Prince-Regent has gone to shake hands, at Baden-Baden, with NAPOLKON III, flies into a sudden fury of contempt for the blindness, greed, and incapacity of Germans in general, and German Princes in particular. Prussia is politely compared to a stupid trout, without wit enough to know deadly bait from wholesome food, and to a blundering crow, which sees its father nailed upon a barn-door, and yet flies directly into the fowler's toils.
lead_paragraph: France and Germany have met on that thrice famous frontier of the Rhine, to look each other in the face, and judge, if they can, what the future has in store for them and it. abstract: Since the true value of hypnotism as an an[???]sthetic agent has been definitely determined by numerous experiments, the excitement regarding the revival of this species of magnetism has measurably decreased. It is settled that this kind of an[???]sthesia can be developed but rarely, and in persons whose nervous disposition predisposes them to it, and further that its development may give rise to epileptic attacks. These conclusions demolish the absurdly illogical deduction of M. BROOA, that hypnotism must be harmlers as an an[???]sthetic agent, because it introduces no substance into the system. These investigations have also established the fact that hypnotism was known under the name of irradia[???]ism or acttnoblism more than two centuries ago. P. KIRCHER discussed this identiral phenomenon under these names in his ATS Magna. Lucis et Umbr[???].

lead_paragraph: By closely and patiently examining the votes in the Board of Aldermen on all questions affecting money, or money's worth, we have discovered a secret little less auriferous than that of the fabled "philosopher's stone." We have found that there exists in the Board of Aldermen a combination of eleven members who always vote together on money questions, irrespective of party lines; who are always appointed on committees where perquisites can be enjoyed; and who are frequently referred to in mysterious whispers round the City Hall as the "Aldermen in the pool."

abstract: Lord Macaulay complained that Englishmen cared more about the victories of the Spaniards over the savages of South America that about the history of the foundation of our great Indian empire. This reproach is amply justified...
lead_paragraph: Lord Macaulay complained that Englishmen cared more about the victories of the Spaniards over the savages of South America that about the history of the foundation of our great Indian empire. This reproach is amply justified by the manner in which the records of the old Company are now being disposed of. There are 20,000 volumes of them, all indexed and arranged, partly, perhaps, by the hands of Charles Lamb; and these are daily sent off in waggon-loads to the papermakers, to be pounded up into pulp. One hundred tons of Records, which must have cost the country more than as many thousand pounds, have thus already been carted away. Well, it is, perhaps, good for the future historian of India. The existence of such a body of authentic documents would have ob[???]iged him to dive deep into the sea of original research, instead of drawing from the shallow wells of his own imagination.

abstract: A very close and exciting game was played by the above Clubs on the Putnam ground, on Friday afternoon, and after a brilliant display of fielding on both sides victory once more sided with the Atlantics. Very few misses were made on either side, and a little more steadiness in throwing and a little lower batting would have left nothing more to be desired. A few incorrect decisions of the umpire turned the game in favor of the Atlantics, the objectionable decisions the other way happening to have no effect on the number of runs. So many changes were made on the Atlantic side that it was very hard to keep track of the fielders, M. O'BRIEN filling no less than four different positions at various periods of the game, and all being subject to some change. All of the Atlantics fielded very finely, but two catches by SMITH and M. O'BRIEN and the guarding the bases by PRICE are especially worthy of notice.

abstract: THE GREAT EASTERN.--If the experience yesterday may be taken as a criterion of the future the excitement which attended the movements of this great vessel in England will be reproduced in a...
lead_paragraph: THE GREAT EASTERN. -- If the experience yesterday may be taken as a criterion of the future the excitement which attended the movements of this great vessel in England will be reproduced in a great degree among the sight-seeing, wonder-loving people of this country. Beginning at an early hour in the morning, and continuing throughout the day people of all classes thronged to the pier at the foot of Hammond-street, to obtain a view of the mammoth ship, and the number who thus visited the neighborhood throughout the day was estimated at many thousands. Nobody was admitted on board, by the rigid orders of Capt. HALL, who has put her Under a cleansing and painting process, to prepare her for the reception of visitors, who it is understood will not be admitted until about the middle of next week. The class of small speculators and keepers of lager beer, fruit and eating stands, with "a single eye" to the public convenience, have monopolized all the vacant places in the vicinity for the purpose of plying their respective tradeS. Considerable sums, in the shape of temporary licences, have been paid by these persons, who evidently expect to reap a handsome harvest while the excitement lasts. The approach to the dock is being covered with coarse gravel, to lay the dust, and workmen are removing the material and rubbish which has accumulated on the piers. The excitement attendant upon the arrival of this ocean monster has already communicated itself to our neighbors in other States, We notice that excursion parties to visit her, are forming in Boston, Philadelphia and Baltimore. The sight lovers of the latter city intend to make a Fourth of July trip of it.

abstract: FROM PORT-AU-PLATTE. � We have advices from Port-au.Platte to the 9th inst, by the brig John Botler, Capt. Miner, at this port. Business was very dull The Government has taken off half a dollar per ton on American vessels, making the port charge now the same as for other foreign vessels. No American vessels in port.
